Just walking in hearkens to a supper club experience from the 30's and 40's - you enter from an alley tucked away in the Jackson Square historic district, once inside the rich interior makes you feel like Bogie will be sitting at a corner table all tux-ed out and running the show. The bartenders know classic cocktails and serve them - along with copious knowledge and a few jokes - while donned in classic white bartender jackets from behind a huge (read 'real') bar. For a treat try a Boxcar - a scotch-based drink made with honey and smoked ice...

The bar is also one of the best bars/counters in town at which to have dinner, for which I always start with the Deviled Eggs with Truffle. Tough to beat shaved truffle on anything but on these deviled eggs it is especially a treat. I have friends who swear by their pork chop, but I am a bigger fan of their duck - served with duck sausage, greens, relish, and a wine reduction. The lobster spaghetti is amazing as well; you really can't go wrong with anything on their menu.

Bix is also a prime "A" date / night-out place, if that's your plan be sure to ask for a booth upstairs when you make your reservation. And try to make it on a night when jazz legend Mary Stallings is performing there, which she does now often - hearing her at all is a thrill, at Bix it is magic...

Don't let the fact that this place has been around so long - and has been so well received - dampen your 'cool meter.' Bix is a unique SF experience that hearkens back to another time on many levels: environment, ambiance, food, and service. Bix is "all that"...
author: Arthur S.

description: This place had some pretty good food. It's well out of my budget but I went here on a company dinner. Anyway, the food is good but the portions are small. I didn't expect anything different. They had some live music (piano and a singer). The whole place had an awesome feel to it.  My favorite part though was the rad painting of a clown making out with a ballerina.. HOT!
author: Mark W.

description:
BIX was just okay, the tables are way too close together so this is not a private place. A waiter knocked into my purse that was hanging off my chair, he apologized and encouraged me to "go check it in". My purse? With my wallet, cash, credit cards, etc? WTF? No thank you. 
About half way through my glass of wine, I felt a sharp edge, there was a huge crack in the glass rim. I told the waitress and she dumped my remaining wine in a new glass, that was it. The support staff took my girlfriends plate while I was still eating, numerous employees were eyeballing our plates at all times, are you done yet, are you done yet, are you done yet, are you done now?
I would go back to BIX for a drink at the bar, but that would be it. The food was good, the bathrooms were very clean and the live music was delightful.
author: Jillian C.

description: Had date night with the bf at Bix, it was perfect. The entrance is tucked away  down a nondescript alleyway but it's quite huge inside. Lower lighting throughout makes for a very intimate dinner, and the comfy seating was rather enjoyable. The hostess and waiter were very nice and professional. The food was great and not too little proportioned like most fancy restaurants are. Had a great experience with my bf and would definitely visit again.
author: Erica G.

description: My son and I ate here while visiting San Francisco at the suggestion of a local. Arrived 15 minutes prior to reservation. Seated on the button. The decor took you back in time. The jazz music was an added bonus. Now for the food. Potato pillows and deviled eggs marvelous. The lobster and blood orange salad was perfect. New York strip steak cooked as asked and very good. Even the evening ending coconut sorbet was refreshing. A French wine was perfect. I will make it back to San Francisco and back to Bix. The only suggestion I would make is have a roving drink server in the bar when it is packed as only those sitting at the bar were getting drinks.  I would have liked one while waiting.
author: jeffrey o.

description: Great ambience and delicious food.  Service was excellent. I loved the ny strip and arugala salad. If your ever in the financial district I recommend you stop here for lunch or dinner
author: Siobhan W.

description: Really nice ambiance and great food. Loved the General Tsao Chicken appetizer. Great service. My only complaint is the NY Steak, while it looked beautiful, it lacked flavor and had too much fat around the steak. The Trio Jazz Band and the pianist was really cool to listen during dinner.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
The food was great and the ambiance was on point. The one star was for the TERRIBLE service we received tonight. Our waiter from the beginning was super dismissive, rude and crass. We could definitely tell that the service with us was different from the other tables. I guess he was thinking that he could "suck up" to the other diners who may order more, though we definitely didn't skim-- bottle of wine, entrees and dessert! 

I've dined here previously for my birthday and experienced great service, but this time, it leaves me wondering if I should come back. 

We even talked to the manager, but he seemed uninterested..

Overall, pretty darn disappointed
author: Phoebe T.

description: A  wonderful place tucked away on Gold Alley. Located on two levels the restaurant is professional all the way. The food is basic high quality and nicely prepared. A special treat is the steak tartare, prepared right table side by your waiter. Well trained staff and service even when busy is outstanding. Expect there to be a large crowd, so I think reservations are in order.
author: Hugh B.

description:
BF and I came here for our anniversary, and we had a PHENOMENAL meal.  The highlights of the meal were the foie gras, which was absolutely heavenly, and the lamb, which was so tender you didn't need a knife to cut it off the bone.  I also really enjoyed the steak tartare -- the flavor was pretty subtle, but so tasty. 

I would pass on the bone marrow next time -- it was a bit too oily for my taste. 

The busboys were awesome -- so polite, constantly refilling our water and clearing plates.  Our waiter (though polite) could have been more attentive -- service was by no means bad though.

Bonus touches were the warm bread they bring you and the fact that they kept telling us Happy Anniversary!  They even gave us a card!  Also, there was complimentary coat check, and we were seated nearly a half hour early for our reservation.  

I would come back to Bix in a heartbeat!
author: Ashlee C.

description:
Came here for my birthday dinner a few weeks ago! Old fashioned but classy, swanky, gatsby-esque place in the middle of a tiiiny street in FiDi. 

SETTING
-Upon entering we gave them the name for our reservation and they took our coats. Fancy. I should have probably dressed up a little more for this place, oh well :)
-Dark ambiance, romantic vibe, paintings and old fashioned decos everywhere, live music.
-Service was fabulous. Our waiter gave us recommendations for his favorites of the menu as well as his preference for wine pairings. 

FOOD
-Appetizer: We tried the Steak Tartare - with shallots, capers, parsley, and mustard. Fancy points because it felt like being in Iron Chef as they prepared it tableside. Raw meat yo. It was good!
-Duck Breast with Stuffed Morel Mushrooms, Fava Beans, and Citrus Confit. One of the favorites here! The duck was tender and very flavorful. 
-Black Truffle Cheese Burger served open face on Rye with Truffle Fries. Also delicious but the fries were a little too salty. 

All that paired with a glass of wine recommended by our waiter, was just the right amount of food. They offered us the dessert menu afterwards but we politely declined. 

I walked out of BIX feeling full from a high classy birthday dinner. The alleyway was beautiful at night, it felt like I wasn't in SF but in a little nook in Europe or something. It was cute. I'll come back here for some other fancy/special occasion maybe.
author: Grace J.

description:
Hadn't been to BIX in a long time.  Arrived with my date on Friday night without reservations and entered the queue.  While waiting spent $40 on 2 'stock' drinks.  Eventually got a table after 45 minutes (which is why they received 2 stars).  

The waiter acted like we did not belong in the restaurant.  He was blunt in a confrontational manner from the start.  As soon as we sat down he was condescending. Ordered a few appetizers which were above average.

When we were ready for dinner I ended up ordering the steak.  I jokingly ordered it 'as rare as possible' and the waiter smugly replied 'in this restaurant you mean bleu'.  Understandable reply because that is how I do enjoy my steak but his tone was off putting. Long story short, my steak arrived pink, alerted my waiter, and to my best guess, he thought I was too intoxicated (1 drink at the bar) and told me that the steak was bleu.  No, it was bright pink. In the end, drinks ended up costing more than the entire meal.

Anyways, props to seating us on a Friday without reservations.  Cant get past 2 stars for the overpriced drinks, snobby service and lying about the status of the food.
author: Patrick T.

description:
To begin great appetizers; especially  the deviled eggs, (simple: always creamy) and the crab rolls (tasty and with a light crust providing texture).  Entrees of chicken hash and halibut with fried egg plant, both very good.  Relaxing atmosphere (No TVs) with piano music (starts at 6). 
A destination to be savored.
author: Andy A.

description:
Martinis and steaks.
It's hip not to be trendy.
Hot jazz keeps the beat.
author: Nish N.

description:
I came here for the very first time a couple months ago.
This place has a very nice ambiance, perfect for a romantic date.
Theres a cute piano downstairs where they offer lovely live music all week 7 days. 
A staircase leading up to the second floor over looking the bar downstairs. 
It's beautifully decorated, it made me feel as though i was on a cruise ship.

The food was overall OKAY.
I ordered the pork chop and a side of french fries.
It was slightly disappointing. It was the pork chop was a little too dry, but i finished it anyways.

The price definitely didn't match up with the quality but I guess you're paying for the ambiance right?

I would probably go back for bar bites and drinks on a jazz night.

Friday and Saturday Jazz at 8:30PM
Tuesday to Thursday live music starting from 7:30PM

Its a great place if you want to feel as though you're no longer in San Francisco.
author: Alui L.

description:
Was drawn to Bix by reviews so we gave it a shot. Arrived 20 min early for our reservation as our party was arriving by foot and car. We were all there early but still had to wait 15 minutes to be seated and we were seated in mix and match tables and chairs. The Hostess was on the verge of being belligerent, just not very nice at all,we found.
On to the food. We tried several apps and were unimpressed with all. The steak Tartar was some of the blandest I've tried. The Bone marrow was plain and flavorless.for an Entree I tried the Lobster Spaghetti....meh.. I've had better. 
Overall, group of 10 of us, treated like we were bothering them by being there. With drinks, we left $1000.00 there. Was not worth it. This place is not as good as it thinks it is.
author: Karl S.

description:
Tucked away in an unassuming alley, BIX is an impressive restaurant in a beautiful space with high ceilings, live piano music, and a classy old school vibe. Don't eat too much of the delicious warm bread and order the amazing foie gras and truffled deviled eggs as appetizers.

The salmon entree is also must-try, cooked perfectly melt-in-your mouth medium-rare while nice and crispy on the outside--pairs well with the Duckhorn sauvignon blanc.

I would avoid the rather bland lobster spaghetti entirely--there are definitely better entrees, like the burger and the sea bass special. 

Try the raspberry parfait for dessert!
author: Jia H.

description: Great place to bring clients to. They have live jazz music after 8:30. This is an upscale restaurant with great food and cool old Art Deco decor.
author: Allen M.

description:
I came here for my farewell dinner and was pleasantly surprised by the exceedingly classy ambiance. There is actual live jazz music playing on the first floor. The crowd is mostly middle-aged and reasonably dressed up for a San Franciscan crowd.

The waiter suggested a BIX Sidecar, which I wasn't a fan of because I only like drinks where I can't taste any alcohol. It consisted of brandy, dry curacao, and lime juice. For an appetizer we had the sampler plate, which came with Dungeness Crab Rolls, Pork Belly Banh Mi, Deviled Eggs, and House Mozzarella Skewers. To be honest only the Banh Mi stood out, it had an enormous amount of flavor packed in the meat, which left me wishing it were a tad larger than a bite. Everything else was definitely good, but not extremely unique or memorable.

My entree was the Pacific Swordfish with summer squash, basil crema, and Sicilian cherry tomato vinaigrette. The fish was a little fishier than I prefer, but the portion was fair. I also tried bites of the American Wagyu Beef and the Lobster Spaghetti - both of which I enjoyed very much. I'd recommend ordering the spaghetti most of all. The overall experience was worthy of four stars, but on food alone it'd probably be closer to a three star since it is rather expensive and didn't quite blow me away.
author: Charlotte Z.

description: In the words of previous reviewers, the lobster spaghetti is divine. Others in our party ordered the potato pillows, gazpacho, truffle burger, food gras, and the lamb. Everyone agreed that everything was superb. Top that off with Alonzo, the perfect waiter, and we had the perfect evening.
author: Kathy L.

description: What a disappointment. Our bad for going to a sentimental but definitely * passé * favorite. They courteously did all they could to rush us through in one hour, pushing the drinks. Croquettes were lukewarm, lamb was tough, bass (their alleged special) was tasteless. They gave us a sub main course in a hurry for the lamb but no comps of any sort, still rushing us. We had a birthday at the table- not even a candle in the desert and folks were informed.
author: jj c.

description: Very classy and elegant restaurant. Your bill can easily go up to ~$180 for a party of two, so it's not a thing for every day. But definitely a nice place to treat yourself and a friend/spouse. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed this place. The food was delicious and all the staff was friendly. One of the bussers even came to talk to us and told us about the history of the restaurant. I recommend getting the scallops and the lamb dish. A+!
author: Ness J.

description:
The service was great and we had an enjoyable meal.  I had the black truffle cheeseburger - but they did not put the cheese on it!  I realized this later when I looked at their menu again online.  Cheese would have made it a lot better.  Also, the little salad on the plate was WAY over salted.  The chef might have had some memory issues that day - learn to taste and season appropriately!!

Also, and I say this about so many restaurants in the US, stop with the lame truffle oil!  Truffle oil is not made from truffles.  Its an artificially flavored oil.  INSTEAD focus on simple great potatoes cooked in good clean oil at the right temperature; possibly blanching them.  The biggest problem with fried potatoes in the US is our dependence on our crappy russets.  I challenge any chef to go to Europe, and even Cuba, or Ukraine and learn what kind of potatoes they use for fries.  They are a 1000x better!
author: Richard R.

description: My final night in SF couldn't have been spent better unless i could have shared this experience with family or friends. The food here is over the top as well as the decor. I feel like I stepped back in time to New Orleans in the 1950's, live jazz band 7 days a week. Words can't describe the overall appeal of this place! Just Try It!
author: David S.

description:
Bone marrow was the best here. I had the lobster spaghetti and shared the broiled halibut. The sole was exactly how it should be cooked, flakey and moist while the lobster spaghetti was full and flavor with nice chunks of lobster. Their hot bread and butter is perfect too. 
This place would get 5 stars from me but the long wait time to be seated was a drawback. We had reservations for 930 and it still took us a good 20 minutes to be seated.
The food was perfect so I will be going back.
author: Jaleel H.

description:
I don't do this often, but the nuance of this place bumps a 3 star to a 4.  Apologize in advance, I can't quite seem to find the right words to do this place justice.

Summary: It's a lovely throwback into the past... the ambiance is amazing, the experience very different, the music (live) impeccable and overall a very enjoyable evening.  It's just so elegant, and there doesn't seem to be anything quite like it.  Armed w/ the right info, It's def worth experiencing once.   

Recommend: dressing up (it's fun once -n- awhile)..... get carried away in the mood of it all, get a cocktail or two, graze on a few appetizers or share a "proven" main course & move on.  With this in mind, I'd come back.

Food: B-
1. Oysters (raw): A
As long as they're fresh, can't really go wrong with these puppies.  The Yuzu mignonette was one of the best I've had. 
2. Smoked Trout Mousse: A
3. Truffle fries: A-
Great flavor, a little soggy.  Will rectify by requesting crispy
Started to go a little down hill from there...
4. Veal Chop: C
Unfortunately, I over looked the "pounded".  It was def pounded....  maybe floured (yuck) and the sauce reminded me of salisbury steak.   It was not bad by any means, but it wasn't very good (Especially at $42).... Not what I was expecting & not sure why something like that would even be on a menu of a place like this.  Weird.  I guess at least it was hearty...
5. Duck Breast: B
Well cooked, tender.  The stuffed morel mushrooms were my favorite bite of the evening.  The portion overall was small.  

I have no issue with spending $$ on a meal, but the meal really needs to be better than just "ok". It's seems to be really hit or miss.  Being a pricey place, I'm not a fan of those odds (our bill was almost $400 for 4 people).   

Drinks: B
The bartenders make the drink & your server brings it upstairs & shakes.  Unusual, but I liked it!  haha it adds positively to the vibe.
1.  Vodka up w/ a twist: B  not bad.
2. Rye Manhattan: C-  It was watery & the proportions were off.  Too sweet/bitter, where was the Rye??  

Seating:
For conversation, sit upstairs.  For music, sit on the 1st floor but request a little further back.  They take resos.  Bonus!

p.s. The colouring in the pics are a 'lil funny.  It's a very dark place & didn't want to use flash.  =P
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description:
Meh.

Deviled Eggs were great.
Lobster Pasta was really delicious.

Steak tartare not good.
Crab Rolls flavorless.

Pours were short and pricey.

I'll probably never come here again, but not horrible just been there done that.
author: James G.

description:
Walked in with my husband and our besties.  A dark haired male with black round glasses was 
behind the bar.  We ordered a kettle/soda and a beer.  Then we wanted to see the drink menu.  This dude came up to us after a few minutes saying I need all your drinks at once.  I get interrupted and that's how it is.  Really...  we walked out with our money.  This guy was RUDE and there are A LOT of pricey places to go and drink.  Called and spoke to the manager, he didn't care either.   We stayed at the OMNI and we made sure to pass along our crappy time at this place...
author: Jen P.

description:
First time there and overall it was a good choice.  I do wish the live music would have started earlier, but.....  Our server was attentive and made sure all of our questions were answered.  I had the Sole and it was amazing and bananas foster for dessert - yummy!

Would recommend going later, like 9pm, if you wanted to hear the Jazz part of Bix.
author: Kelly P.

description:
I'll admit I was skeptical at first, I thought the bartenders too cool for school "you can only order a drink of our mixologist menu" attitude was going to set the tone for the night.  Happily I was mistaken.  The beverage did turn out to be quite tasty (Ruby Red Collins) and our server more than made up for the snootiness downstairs.  Speaking of stairs-if you go request an upstairs table! It was awesome to take in the old wooden bar, interesting paintings and jazz band playing downstairs, while we ate.
On to the food-deviled eggs and lobster spaghetti-do it. Both were amazing.  Sadly there was no room for dessert but that just means I will have to go back!
author: Vickey A.

description:
Food is prepared with perfection.  The deviled eggs and ceviche appetizers were delicious. 

Drinks were simple request of wine but the wait staff seemed to have nothing to add when we were trying to select our wines.

We had 6pm reservations and were running behind.  We let the hostess know and asked if this was okay.  She said it's fine as long as table is returned by 8 because it's reserved for 8:30. Sure but still made us sit at the bar first though there were many tables open.  The moment we order our drinks she asked us to close our tab and carry our drinks to follow her.  Takes us upstairs to realize she meant downstairs.  Back down we go with full drinks.  

We had to ask the waiter if we can please place our order after 25min of being seated.  Our avocado salad never came out, instead they sent another salad but we couldn't correct this because no one checked in on us.  We also couldn't return the table at 8 as we didn't receive our entrees until 8:10, but again no one checked in on us throughout our meal.  

I would return if I am in the area because of the food only.
author: Ange M.

description: One of the best restaurants in a city of great restaurants, Bix has been a favorite of mine for about 25 years. Beautiful room, great food, excellent service, live jazz and Bradley the bartender, who I think has been there since the opening.
author: Steve H.

description:
We had a relaxing post SFMOMA dinner
The Perfect Manhattan and squash blossoms with lobster and cream cheese we're a perfect start.
The service was excellent
author: Gene B.

description:
Is it just me or does being inside BIX feel like being on a ship? I absolutely love it. When I go here, I feel like it's an experience and it's best to really go all in. Don your finest attire (think Old Hollywood, perhaps even a touch of Roaring 20s) and get started at the bar. 

After a cocktail, order cocktail #2 and head to your table. By now, you should definitely feel like you're on a ship - not in a crazy/dizzying way (I mean you only had 1 cocktail), but in a way where you've let go, remembered these words and have decided to just go with it. The lighting, the decor, the laughter and energy - it all sets the tone for the perfect evening - oh and the food is alright too. ;P 

Definitely one of my favorite spots in this small town. Love.
author: Jaime L.

description:
While the food at Bix is top notch and the ambiance is classy and intimate, my overall experience here was disappointing.  Even with the live piano music, the candle lit booths, and the exquisite wine list I was left with a sour taste in my mouth by evenings end.  After being seated on the second floor promptly at our reservation time, our night went from a high note to a low note due to the rudeness of our waiter.  He seemed to be dismissive of us in particular and after a slight miscommunication he basically gave up on being polite.   Not only is this unprofessional, but it is also plain ill-mannered.  We ended up letting the manager know what happened and I hope this issue can be rectified.  

In the end Bix has excellent food and a trendy and classy atmosphere.  However, after experiencing the rude service we got I can only give out two stars.
author: Ben M.

description:
A mysterious location, a (not so) hidden dinner and jazz bar and an extensive wine menu, that somehow left me feeling uninspired.

Turn down a brick alley hardly big enough for the taxi we pulled up in and drive to the neon sign; you're there! You step into a dimly lit room and find yourself stepping in sync with the bass line on your way to the table; unless you forgot to make reservations a few days in advance, then you'll be tapping your foot outside for a few hours.

It's quite loud in here. I could hear the table next to us go on and on about their sexual conquests (no joke) of their young up-and-coming real estate careers; something I didn't coordinate for our romantic anniversary dinner. The musicians also take quite frequent breaks though I believe there are two groups, one upstairs and one downstairs as there is never a moment without some sort of accompaniment.

We started off with the crab cakes, per our servers recommendation. They're a spoonful of typical crab meat/mayo mixture served over these super light, puffy sweet breads and are each about the size of a sushi roll. I figured, judging by price and description, there would be around six to eight (I was thinking sushi) but when it came to our table, either our server ate half of them on the way over, (quite possible, they were delicious!) or the actual serving size was four. The portion was even more disappointing when we learned just how good these were. So simple, but done so perfectly.

Next was out entrees. I ordered these very homestyle chicken patties breaded in Pako crumbs with a mixture of peas and carrots inside. It came to the table as two patties stacked on top of each other. Presentation was laughable. I know I'm old enough where I shouldn't be playing with my food, but it looked so boring that the thought never crossed my mind once. My girlfriend ordered this New York steak and it was cooked to absolute perfection. You know when someone tells you a piece of meat is "melt in your mouth" and you just smile and nod at them like they're crazy because it's meat and it doesn't melt in your mouth? Well, this did. I've literally never had a steak cooked this perfectly before.

We got the banana's foster desert and that was delicious as well. It comes as a scoop of ice cream in a bowl and when you look at your server with your eyebrow raised like, "I could have gone to Baskin Robbins for this" she pours this heavenly mixture of hot chocolate, bananas and caramel and you dive right in, hardly looking up as you shovel it into your mouth. You might not, but I sure did and I definitely recommend it.

All-in-all I really can't give this place five-stars but I wouldn't say I experienced any atrocities that would deem them less than four-star worthy. It's great food but you also pay a great price for it. I'd love to try it again when the real estate fraternity convention isn't in town.
author: Michael S.

description: We went there for our anniversary celebration and i had called earlier to request a booth near the stairs instead we got seated on a table near the service door. When we told them that we had requested a booth they said nothing was available and that the next availability would be an hour later. So making a special request is useless. The wait staff was rude and uptight and it definitely put a damper on the celebration ... the food was very average and nothing special. People on other tables around us also seemed to be upset with the service. I have to say that the live jazz and old world ambience is nice and the reason we chose to go here...it puts you in a different time...however i will never return
author: Dwiti V.

description: Came for drinks after dinner and loved the ambiance and jazz. Would definitely want to come back to try their food!
author: Felicia F.

description:
My brother took us here for Friday night dinner (6/6) as a post celebration of my son's graduation.  

If one is unfamiliar with SF one would get lost in trying to locate this hidden gem.  Located off Gold St (alley), you are away from the busy Financial District streets. Once inside the restaurant, I was in awe with the interior.   I was put back in time with it's early 1940's decor.  

It is recommended to make reservation as you are seated within less than 5 minutes of your arrival.  For a party of six, we ordered an array of food.  For starters, we ordered our cocktails.  I decided to order a peach bellini.  Our table decided to order appetizers - family style - bix chilli glazed fried chicken, pork belly "banh mih" and house mozzarella skewers.  For our main course, three of us ordered the chicken hash a la bix, which was delicious and filling.  My son ordered black truffle cheeseburger and my brother-in-law ordered american wagyu bavette.  For side dishes, we all ordered and shared grilled zuckerman's asparagus and creamed spinach. The spinach was a disappointment as it was slightly salty.  Of course, dinner wouldn't be complete without a bottle of Chardonnay and two bottles of prosecco.  

We all decided to order two types of dessert, even though we were all stuffed.  Banana foster dark rum/vanilla ice cream and strawberry rhubarb  tart was ordered.  Both desserts hit the spot.  

Our waiter and the staff were very attentive. Glasses never empty, warm rolls at it's abundance and the restaurant manager greeted each table.  

Towards the end of our meal, you can hear a live band playing just below us.  A great ending to a nice dinner.
author: Lyn N.

description:
Located on Gold St, 19th Century SF The Golden Era, 
dark woodgrain, theatrical ceiling, refined glamour, 
all that jazz, got me feelin' like Frank Sinatra, 
golden potato pillows, crème fraîche and American Caviar, 
this that crispy on the outside, soft on the inside refined tater, 
tone sweet and somber, delicate with the punch Charlie Parker, 
foie gras torchon, strawberry rhubarb preserves, 
flavors smooth like Coltrane, these are a few of my favorite things, 
lobster spaghetti, jalapeños, basil with cherry tomatoes, 
live pianist at the bar, Dave Brubeck with them notes, 
open faced black truffle cheese burger, you already know, 
subterranean ascomycete fungus, vibe hard Charles Mingus, 
finished the night off with warm chocolate cookies and whiskey cream, 
got me feelin' like Count Bassie, singing the blues, 
that Duke Ellington, catch me in a sentimental mood
author: Roy C.

description:
2.5 stars.

I came to this place for my birthday in Feb 2012, and it was one of my favorite dining experiences I've had. Maybe between then and now I had built it up too much in my mind, but this experience certainly did not live up to the last one. 

There was some confusion about our reservation, which was very likely 100% my fault. Originally we were 3 people at 8:00pm, then I used opentable to switch it to 4 people at 8:30. I don't think my yelp/opentable and legit opentable are connected, because apparently the change didn't go through. I felt really bad when we showed up with 4 people at 8:30 and the only record they had was my 8:00 for 3. The hostess glazed right over the problem and reset the table, and sat us even though we were 30 minutes past the reservation. 5 stars for the hostess and her awesome flexibility, it was awesome and a great start to our meal.

... And then it went downhill. We had done a happy hour with snacks prior to coming here for dinner so we weren't here for a big meal. Ordered a bottle of wine and two appetizers to start. Wine was Syrah and it was standard. I remember the potato pillows being delicious, so I ordered them again for the group. It was like a cube tater tot with some creme fraiche on it, very very unmemorable and we each got a small bite for an overpriced cost for the simplicity of the dish. We also got the ceviche - not remarkable, but good.

Then when we ordered what we would be having for dinner, 3 of us got appetizers and 1 got a burger - we weren't hungry enough to order main entrees. The first person ordered a caesar, and the waiter said "nothing else? no entree?" and he said no. The second person (me) ordered the steak tartare, and he said the same exact thing. Third person ordered the caesar salad, and he asked the same exact thing. It felt like he was guilting us for not being extravagant. Last person ordered burger and he walked off, never to return to our table again. Our wine/food was brought out by a runner, and we were never asked how it was.

Tartare was not as magical as I remember it - I will not longer spout this place as having best tartare in San Francisco. Others' were nothing special either. Would be 2 stars if not for our outstanding experience walking in.
author: Sarah B.

description: Great spot! We stopped here shortly after we landed in SF on our vacation. Josh the bartender took great care of us! We enjoyed a couple of glasses of wine and a salad and deviled eggs before we had to head out but we would love to go back for dinner in the near future!
author: Katie N.

description:
How do I love thee, Bix? Let me count the ways.
I love thee for the secret alleyway 
I love thee for the service beyond compare
I love thee for the cooking. Ah, the cooking.
I love thee....okay, enough of that.

Ever have a love affair with a restaurant? Pour moi, it all started with Mark Stock's  painting - The Butler in Love - that hangs over the piano next to the bar. And it continues every time I set foot in Bix and order a vodka martini...
author: Hendrix B.

description: Crazy good. OMG Fabulous dinner. Great service. Yeah AJ. Terrific ambiance. We are planning our next trip back.
author: Cecilia B.

description:
Down a little alleyway you will find Bix, a true gem in the restaurants of San Francisco.  A little bit speakeasy and a lot of good food and drink, Bix charmed me from the moment we walked in the door.

The place was packed with no seats to be found at the bar so we sidled up close to the live band and watched the people go by.   The ambiance is pure 1930's and 40's making you feel as if you walked back in time. And the artwork is lovely. . . All in all a sight for the senses!

If you like old school jazz- then waiting for your table will go by in no time as the musicians are pumping out tunes that are sure to make you smile.

We were seated right on time for our reservation and I was thrilled to see we were being led to one of the best tables in the house- upstairs overlooking the melee  and also within eye contact of that fabulous band!

 Our server was terrific, bringing warm bread and making sure our drinks were never empty!

 We started with some raw oysters and then quickly moved on to some steak tartar prepared table side.  Delicious!

For my entree I had the pork which was amazing along with some Brussel sprouts that made me re think eating brussel sprouts they were that good!  And if that wasn't enough decadence- try the bananas foster for dessert.  Certainly calorie worthy!!

All in all a fabulous restaurant that I can't wait to return to the next time I'm in town!
author: Carol K.

description:
BIX is everything you want for a perfect dinner experience: beautiful architecture, swift service, artfully cooked cuisine, and live music to top it all off. 

The lighting and quaint interior are conducive for a very romantic first date, proposal, or otherwise special night to share with someone. 

Despite all of these romantic elements described, I came with my rowdy friends after a day at the office and had to take pictures of all the food for the greater good of Yelp as well as ask questions about all of the dishes. (What!? There are so many great choices and the waiters very eloquently describe the process of how each is cooked!) 

With this being said, BIX is really a great venue for any couple, crowd, or individual in need of a classy, laid-back night of delicious eats.
author: Stephen D.

description:
This resto is a must see when in San Fran!  With a live jazz piano player, and a great ambiance, very calm and relax. Bix has an upscale  business feel to it and the staff is very friendly and attentive. 

The waiter Aj gave some good recommendations of places to see while in town. The food was great, I love the variety of different veggie options, pillow potatoes & truffle fries, butternut and carrot soup. 
The main course was a bit disappointing, the overall meal a bit too salty for my taste. ( that is why I am not giving 5 stars) but I will definitely come again and I would stick with just the salad, as a healthier veggie options.
author: Aella M.

description:
UNEQUIVOCALLY MY FAVORITE RESTAURANT IN SF!

As a Yelp-a-holic, I'm always on a lookout for new restaurants to go to just so I can write a review. So it's very rare that I would go to a restaurant twice. 

When my friend asked for restaurant recommendations for her birthday dinner, BIX immediately came to mind because the food was such a memorable experience. It's been over a year since I been to BIX but last night just reconfirmed WHY it's my favorite restaurant in the city. The food is deliciously tantalizing, the staff is like a well-oiled machine and the ambiance is stunningly beautiful! 

F O O D
*POTATO PILLOWS w/ Creme Fraiche and Sturgeon Cavier ($15) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=M4W2q82ltDQ_Cr5SSwskKQ
My friend hit the nail on the head when she said it reminded her of tater tots but it was oh so refined. The potato pillows were fried to a golden brown and were deliciously crisp on the outside and pillowy soft and airy on the inside. The crème fraiche added a nice layer of creaminess and the sturgeon cavier a pop of subtle saltiness. Each bite was so orgasmic that I tried to savor each one very slowly.

*BONE MARROW w/ Parsley, Shallot, and Caper Salad w/ Grilled Durum Batard ($14) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=rKYL3S17CKsENppCUq2q2w
The bone marrow was just as good as the first time I've had it at BIX, decadently rich filled with bold condensed beefy flavors but there wasn't enough to spread on the crunchy durum bread. I love the parsley, shallot and caper salad which really help cut through the richness while adding a pop of freshness to each bite. 

*LLANO SECO PORK DUO w/ New Potatoes, Sweet Red Onions and Stone Fruit Chutney ($29.50) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=vKMmWG6TA6r7oLMo3caZGA
NOPA and Spruce got nothing on this pork dish! The pork duo consisted of a grilled pork chop topped with fruit chutney and a pork sausage crepenette atop new potatoes and sweet red onions. 

The pork chop was grilled to perfection. It so well-marbled and incredibly succulent that I could have mistaken it for a steak if I wasn't told that it was in fact pork. The fruit chutney added a sweet tang which balanced out the flavors nicely. The pork sausage crepenette was rich, savory and packed with porky flavor and spices with a hint of smokiness. The potatoes were tender yet soft and the red onions added a nice sweetness which complemented the sausage. Although there were 2 different elements, the dish was cohesive and impeccably flawless; it was SO good I could have easily licked the dish clean!

*BANANAS FOSTER w/ Dark Rum and Vanilla Ice Cream ($8.75) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=vKMmWG6TA6r7oLMo3caZGA
I'm not a fan of Bananas Foster but BIX has totally converted me! As the warm banana foster and dark rum was poured tableside atop the vanilla ice cream, I literally watched all the flavors and textures meld together. The banana slices were cooked to a soft tenderness that literally melted in my mouth. The deliciously sweet rum sauce married with the uber creamy vanilla ice cream creating a hot/cold concoction that was indescribably mouth-watering. *eyes roll back to the head*

S E R V I C E
Our waitress was professional, friendly, and attentive but not intrusive. The bus boy always made sure our water glasses were filled and empty plates were taken away promptly. My only gripe is our entrees took a little longer than expected to arrive (~30 minutes after we finished our appetizers). Nonetheless, BIX's service is everything you would expect from a restaurant of this caliber.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Stunningly beautiful and romantic but it's a lot darker than I remember it to be. This time we sat downstairs which was very loud and it was especially hard to hold a conversation since the pianist was nearby. Definitely request to sit upstairs for more lighting, easier conversation and to have a view overlooking the entire restaurant. If you're looking for a place to "woo" her, look no further because BIX is it!

P A R K I NG
BIX is tucked away in the Gold alleyway which is one block up from Bubble Lounge towards Broadway (between Jackson and Pacific Streets). Street parking can be difficult. Valet parking is $10. 

If you read my reviews, you'll know that it takes A LOT to impress me. BIX not only "WOWED" me once but it "WOWED" me twice and I'm sure it will continue to WOW me in the future...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
A hidden gem in SF. The atmosphere is incredible, the food is excellent, service impeccable and personable. Excellent cocktails... Their Manhattan is worth making a trip alone. 

Having been here a number of times, the pork chops, marrow bones, and oysters have stood out. Lots of excellent options including deviled eggs, and bananas foster.
author: James T.

description:
BIX never ceases to impress.  Impeccable service and delicious food.

Appetizers:  As usual, the steak tartare was delicious.  The salmon tartare was also very tasty.  Interestingly, the dill and creme fraiche tasted like the tarter sauce of McDonald's fish filets!  No joke.  The foie gras pate was also delicious, but the jam on the side overwhelmed the taste of the foie gras.

Entrees:  The main lobster spaghetti is amazing.  Sadly, I ordered the wagyu beef and short ribs with potatoes and creamed spinach, which might have been wonderful if I wasn't constantly thinking about the deliciousness of my friend's pasta!

All in all, another delightful meal at BIX!
author: Christina L.

description:
Bix is really a bastion of San Francisco style. Yes it has been open quite sometime and what impresses is the consistency that they provide their clients with.

Service and ambiance are just incredible. The food is very good.

I started with their Plum ginger aid which was incredible. My partner had the same. 

We split the deviled eggs with truffle oil....only four and not cheap ....but the flavor and texture was really amazing, lush, and divine.

I had their wonderful cobb salad which is really good using really quality ingredients. My accountant ( sort of like taking your dentist out for lunch...perhaps less painful?...perhaps)  had the burger with swiss cheese and avocado. Their burgers are phenomenal works of art: Beautiful ground beef, hand crafted bun , and wonderful accoutrements. Dam him for not ordering the fries and getting a salad instead....I was hoping to steal a few!

The place was pretty busy for Friday lunch and I know why....they give you what cha want!

Def check out for lunch or dinner
author: David G.

description:
When you want to capture the essence of San Francisco, few places come to mind and even fewer places deliver like this. Even before you step foot in the place, the mere location is a prelude of what you would expect at a place like this. Located in the hidden, romantic alley way of the Financial District, the bright lights of the sign signal a secret, underground speakeasy restaurant/lounge/bar is just a few steps away. 

Upon entering, you are greeted with a dimly lit, venue that is oozing in detail and classic decor - it's like taking a step back in time. Bix, having been around now for 26 years now, captures the old school Rat Pack vibe with live jazz trio, mahogany panels, intimate booth seating, bartenders in white blazers, and classic art pieces on the walls - it is captures such a distinct, nostalgic ambiance that the old soul in me loves and craves. Every time I step into this place I take a look around expecting to see 1920's flapper / dapper clothing draped on the ladies and gents in attendance.

It's upscale and sophisticated without being pretentious. Come in, grab a seat at the bar, order and Old-Fashioned and sit back and enjoy the live music and ambiance in one of San Francisco's classic offerings. 

The only complaint I have is they don't always use the big square ice cubes for drinks (need to specify them if you order an Old Fashioned for example) and the drinks are good, not great.
author: E E.

description: Great place. Amazing service. They took great care of us. I was so hungry though I couldn't bare to send my food back...only problem was it was over-salted. I tried a few other things that were also salty, unfortunately. I would come back and asked if the chef could ease up on the salt.
author: Chammy C.

description:
With new and hip restaurants materializing out of nowhere all the time in this city, Bix has managed to survive the test of time. Despite having been in business since the 80s I was surprised that it didn't feel stale and/or dated and patrons still flock keeping the place very much alive. 

Some might initially be put off by the entrance being located in an alley way and might even double check the street signs second guessing if this is really the restaurant's rear exit. But once you spot that neon blue Bix sign rest assured, you have arrived at the correct entrance. 

Once we got inside I immediately thought "classy", "upscale" with a bit of a vintage vibe and a hint of Art Deco. High ceilings, a very large mural and large pillars are a few notables throughout the space. Unfortunately for us, there were no live entertainment during dinner the time we happened to come by. 

I would have liked to sit upstairs in the mezzanine level however we ended up sitting at the oddly positioned section right below it. A couple next to us kept complaining they had awful seats and declared it the THE worst in the house to their server. I silently had to agree as they were seated at one of the two tables that flanked regular seated tables. Rather than face their dining companion their seats are arranged so that they are sitting next to them and facing the side of the couples who are seated at the regular tables in between. Awkward and uncomfortable. 

We enjoyed our orders and they had a vegetarian friendly option for the non-meat eaters that night. It was not printed on their menu but it was mentioned by our (friendly and likable) server before I even had a chance to ask. Perfect. Food was of American fare and although of quality it wasn't anything fancy. Actually quite perfect for Bix.

I'm all for coming back. Sooner than later.
author: Esther A.

description:
Just a quick word to the wise: Bix does not have air conditioning.  Usually this wouldn't be an issue in San Francisco because it's usually not 90+ degrees, but wow was it stuffy in there last night!  

The three star review is, however, not because of the heat, but because of the service.  To be fair, the service was likely impacted by the heat in two ways: 1. the staff looked, understandably, just as miserable as many of the patrons and 2. a bottle of champagne literally exploded behind our table because of the heat and the staff seemed to be occupied apologizing to the table it belonged to.  Regardless, the service was bad.  

Things started off fine, if a little rushed.  After placing our order, however our server checked in maybe once, never asked if we wanted another drink and, after we had both cleared our plates, we waited 10-15 minutes just to see our server again, let alone get a dessert menu or another drink.  We had been interested in both dessert and another cocktail, but by that point we were ready to get out of there.  Getting the bill took another 10-15 minutes even after asking for it as our server continually walked by our table, seemingly ignoring our attempts to get her attention.

As for the food, we had the mozzarella skewers (good, but seemed to be melting because of the heat), the halibut (fine), and the steak (good but overpriced).  

All in all, I think that we would come back to give Bix another try, chalking up most of the issues to the heat, but it wasn't a great first impression.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Fun location off the main road and in an alley.

The atmosphere was nice. It was quiet with music playing in the background. All at a good conversational level.

I had read about some of the top items here so I made sure to check them out. I'd have to say the potato pillows are overrated. Creme Fraiche and caviar sound great, but when it's on top of a tater tot, you can hardly taste them. They were good, but what tots aren't? The Deviled Eggs were a different matter. They were so good! Maybe it's the truffle talking, but they were familiar yet unique enough to make me want to order more.

For entrées, my wife ordered the Lobster spaghetti and I got the truffle burger (more truffle is always better). Both were very good choices.
author: Ian F.

description:
Gorgeous place, sultry lighting and romantic booths. Beautiful cocktails. The food, however, was a joke. 

I started with the mozzarella skewers. They tasted and felt like cheap string cheese. I usually never have a problem with cheese but I actually couldn't get myself to eat them. 

Then I had the truffle burger. The flavor was right but the burger was so dry I thought someone was playing a trick on me. I got it medium and it felt like ash in my mouth. This is what a $30 burger tastes like?

Huge disappointment.
author: Amelia V.

description:
Very cool ambiance- nice big bar for post-work drinks and seating upstairs/downstairs. Food comes with a hefty price tag but it's what you'd expect walking into a place like BIX. 
The cream of corn soup tasted so fresh! Our waiter allowed us to change out some of the sides for our meal due to dietary restrictions without making any fusses, which was nice. I'd come here again!
author: G G.

description:
Great vibe on a Wednesday night. 
Good food, good cocktails , good wine. 
Front of house staff are on point here.
Great find in the hidden alley way.
author: Chris C.

description:
Bix reminds you of a time travel experience in that you feel like you're in an old (but new) spot. It mimics a jazz/20's era with a grand piano and very classy bar. It has an adorable upstairs, as well. 

It's a pricier spot and is great for dates or special occasion dining. The menu changes, although there are staples on the menu. The cocktails are tasty and high-end although I had a glass of the red Lambrusco and it was great (not too sweet).

I went with a few gfs for lunch on a Friday and we enjoyed a little lavishness on a few items. We decided to go family style so we could share and try a few things. The deviled eggs were amazing!!! They were made with truffle oil and so delicious. Came with 4 halves and probably my favorite as I'm a deviled egg fan so we were all pleased. The ahi dish was good but pretty small (believe it was a small plate) and didn't come with anything to eat the ahi with so didn't make it so shareable, although tasty! The crispy chicken was so tasty but super small too. I think portions aren't huge. We wished we ordered more. The Cobb salad was tasty not the best but for a Cobb I enjoyed it!

This is probably a better dinner place when you're looking to get fancy! It's in the cutest (hidden gem) part of Fi-Di too.
author: Priya S.

description:
This cute little restaurant is another one of SF's gems. Its nice because its hidden away down Gold Street and the ambiance is very inviting. 

When you first walk in, there is a bar on the right side, so it always seems busy..but when you get a little farther in it isn't too bad! It isn't one of those restaurants where you feel crammed in. Be sure to make a reservation though!

There was live music when I went and it was the venue for intimate dates, girlfriends catching up, and even a birthday party. I loved the charm of the decor...except for the random framed plate in the left corner that is apparently a Picasso! (yeah, i didn't know that until the manager msg'd me and pointed it out.. oops, thank you, Blake T!)

The bread came out warm with slightly warmed butter, so that was really nomsy. I'm alllll about the bread.. :)

I ate:
1. Pork belly banh mi - four little sandwiich serving were really great for sharing. Each little bite was packed with the tender pork belly and the sweet a kick of the pickled radishes/carrots. noms.

2. Lobster Spaghetti - This was really flavorful with large chunks of lobster. I thought it was a bit on the salty side, but the noodles were perfectly chewy and tasty!

Can't really say anything about the dessert menu though..since I wasn't all that impressed by it. It was interesting that it came with an entire list of whiskey and scotch selections. i didn't order anything, but the table next to us seemed to be having a jolly good time with their servings of scotch! :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
WOW - what an awesome place.  Not only does it have character, but the service, the drinks and the food are rock solid.  

The perfect Manhatten they claim to have - believe it - we didn't stop at 1!
  
We ordered just about all of the appetizers.  My fav's were Trout Tar Tar, the Potato Pillows, Pork Belly and the Bone Marrow (very cool presentation on this one).   The deviled eggs were too vinegary for me.

The seasonal heirloom salad was devine. 

I opted for the Lobster Spaghetti.  I had lobster in every bite and the sauce was not too heavy which allowed me to eat the entire thing - by myself.  Seriously was so good, I couldn't stop.  

This needs to be a must when you visit San Francisco.  It seemed like it was a local favorite hangout for having a cocktail or grabbing a bite.  Can't wait to visit again!
author: Brenda D.

description:
Walked out. 
The hostess was incredibly rude,  and after waiting for 20 minutes after our reservation time (which we were 10 minutes early for) it became clear the band was not going to be able to be heard over the roar of noise in the restaurant.  That coupled with straight ahead piped in music,  made it clear that our hope for some classic jazz in an intimate setting was not going to happen.  The owner infers a connection with Bix Beiderbecke, but my guess is the spelling differences (BIEderbeck) should have been the first clue this isn't what you may expect.  Food was vastly overpriced and nothing appealed to us.  Happy we left before blowing 45 a plate.
author: Brian P.

description:
Our meal was disappointing. To start we shared the Gougeres, the General Tso's chicken and the Dungeness crab rolls. The Gougeres were cold and filled with a strange cheese spread--nothing tasty about it. The chicken was very yummy and the crab rolls just so-so.

On to main courses: my husband had the hanger steak and said it was fine. The lobster spaghetti was flavorful, but very short on lobster--unforgivable given the steep price ($37.00). The truffle cheeseburger was only okay. The patty was decent, but the cheese was not good, and there wasn't enough truffle. It was on a boring piece of bread. 

Overall, this is just not what we expected, and given how pricey the meal was, it should have been great. Finally, I'm being generous with the three stars, and would have given 2.5 stars had that been an option.
author: Julie K.

description: I have gone to Bix a lot in the past and enjoyed it.  However, it has now turned into a mill where the major goal is to get you out as fast as possible and to TURN THOSE TABLES.  I went there tonight with a friend I haven't seen in years.  We felt so rushed to order and the server and the manager kept going to every table to keep people moving.  The second my cocktail was deposited, she asked if we had decided on dinner.  I said we'd like about 10 minutes to chat and the manager then came back TWICE in 15 minutes to take our order.  I asked if we could have bread and he said that would only be given after we had placed our order.  We left saying it would be more relaxing at McDonalds.  When you're paying $40 per entry, $15 for cocktails and $20 for a glass of Zinfandel, being rushed to this extent is not acceptable.  So, yes, you did get us out in under 90 minutes but I will no longer be making reservations at BIX.
author: Scott S.

description:
I really want to love this place, but it was just okay!  3.5, but I gotta round down because I didn't taste enough of the menu...

Drink: I tried to order my fave, Captain Diet with a lime; however they didn't have Captain (sad!).  They suggested another rum, so i just went with it.  A friend paid, so I don't know how much it was, but BOY was it strong!  I had to ask the bartender for more Diet, to which he made a little scene and for some reason had to announce to the whole bar that I was asking for more soda.  Kinda douche-y if you ask me (total opposite from the bartenders at Johnny Foley's, love them).

Hostess: Yes, she gets her own shoutout.  I made a reservation for 10:00p, but we showed up just after 9:00p because we were so hungry.  We grabbed a drink at the bar, and she was able to seat us by 9:30p.  So friendly, just wanted to point that out.  Wish I grabbed her name, but she is Filipino.

Service: Our food runners/busboy were good, but our server was kinda ehh.  Not sure if she was having a bad day or just shouldn't be in the restaurant/hospitality industry, but she definitely took away from the meal for me.

The food: Okay, hands down the Dungeness Crab Rolls.  WOW.  So amazing, we all agreed we could just eat a bunch of those as a meal.  Kinda pricey at $18 for 4 bite-size pieces, but definitely worth it.  I went with the infamous Lobster Spaghetti for my main, and I have to say, I was a little disappointed.  I can't deny the freshness of ingredients; however, it lacked major depth and flavor for me.  Sorry, BIX!

If someone suggested to come here, I would; otherwise, I wouldn't go too out of my way.
author: Carla C.

description: My fiancé and I started off with their asparagus and bacon soup. It was refreshing and just the right amount. We had an amazing lobster spaghettini dinner with a side of truffle fries! Our server Alex was prompt and didn't pester which was nice
author: Desiree a.

description: This is the best restaurant I have ever been too!Me and my husband went here for our 3 year anniversary and they took amazing care of us.Just the little card saying happy anniversary at the table meant a lot.The romantic ambiance with the candles at each table really set the tone.Our server (Abe)was great, knowledgable, professional , yet very down to earth.He checked in on us often but not too much to interrupt our date.The deviled eggs and meatball appetizer were fabulous(what's in that sauce?!)For my main course I had the chicken hash a la bix which was the best dish I've ever had(again...what's in the sauce?!)I have been craving it ever since.So glad I found this gem can't wait to be back.Wish we could have stayed longer for the music we thought it started at 6 but didn't want to be a table hog.
author: Deidre G.

description:
3rd year anniversary!!!
I accidentally reserved a table to celebrate my 3rd year anniversary with my husband. 
1. Making a reservation was convenient and prompt.
2. Parking was not bad the location is in an alleyway. You should either use an uber, taxi or in a parking lot that only cost $10 after 5pm.
3. The place is beautiful on the inside! It's a jazz club type feel.
4. A little loud but it does not matter because of the music, friendly staff and people having a good time!
5. The food was exquisite I had the lobster spaghetti. There was lobster in every bite. My husband enjoyed his open faced burger. The deviled eggs were to die for to say the least. To top it off the dessert was delicious!!!!
6. The chocolate pudding with whip cream melts in your mouth....
7. Of you are looking for a romantic, lively, and delicious place to celebrate definitely pick this one! For the 2 of us it cost $100 not including tip! We came out fully satisfied!
author: Mary Lou W.

description: Cool little place for cocktails. Located on a tiny street in Jackson Square, Bix has that old 1930s feel with some great art on the walls. We tried the truffled deviled eggs and the potato pillows, both of which went over well, as well as a couple of cocktails made tableside. Would return.
author: MichLee A.

description:
The Great: We were seated immediately upon arrival at a very nice corner table, our server was exceptional, and the rest of the staff was very attentive.
The Good: Crab and shrimp appetizers were really, really tasty. Also like the lobster pasta signature dish and bananas foster dessert.
The Okay: The halibut was somewhat disappointing - more of an overcooked slab than a real fish. Lobster portion is pretty skimpy.
The Bad: Somewhat overpriced like most "name" restaurants in SF; $30 corkage is a bit excessive (particularly when we ordered cocktails); and the "SF mandates" nonsense needs to disappear (no other non-food businesses add this to your bill).
Overall, one of the better places to dine in SF, nice vibe, great service, but be prepared to pay...
author: Boris G.

description:
I really like this place. 

First the semi-bad. The food quality does not equate with the price. The food is good, but it's not that good. The food quality is something you would get out of BJ's or Cheesecake factory. Not bad, but not exquisite. 

You're paying for the vibe. Which is great. Live music and a really awesome enviornment. It really has a classy feel of the 1940's. Also, the cocktails are really great here. The bartenders know their stuff. 

You're not going to get the food quality of many other fine dining places in SF, but you will get a spectacle you won't easily find in the Bay Area. 

I'll probably go again.
author: Benny H.

description: This place is perfect for live music, romantic or after business ambiance,  and food. It's tucked away in a side street in San Francisco so keep your eyes out, but you'll have a great time.
author: Akram A.

description: Been here a few times and this was the first time I got mediocre service. Went for a date with my lady, and right off the bat, the glass the waiter was pouring water on broke, spilling all over my lady's dress. Got moved to a different table, and from there on, I noticed the waiter wasn't as attentive as he was to the other tables. Our waters were only filled once and that was when the glass was empty already and had to make eye contact with him on multiple occasion. I think the busser was more attentive. On the good end, the crab cakes were good, and so was the meatballs. Do not order their Cesar salad. I keep forgetting this.
author: Paulo R.

description: I absolutely love Bix. I have been here too many times. Everytime i have friends visiting from other states, i bring them here, Their food is amazing, they have live music, a great ambiance, and valet parking.  And my absolute favorite (chocolate bread pudding). LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.
author: Shanzay H.

description:
Some of us went out to this tony SF bar after work on a random Wednesday evening.  

I made a reservation for 6 on Open Table.  

Once we were seated, I ordered a "Sidecar."  I ordered it because I saw it on "Check Please! Bay Area"  .... I can be easily cajoled into going anywhere on that show and, moreover, ordering anything they recommend.  A Sidecar is a STRONG drink.  Of course, I had to switch, because I started getting that scary drunk feeling where I stopped listening to everyone around me and started inwardly obsessing about whether there was any way I could get sober immediately.  Needless to say, I switched drinks.  

There is live jazz music (piano bar and singer) at BIX, and some really weird art, which is pretty cool.  We all noticed the picture of the clown kissing the ballerina.  I like this kind of weird art.  

The best part of this place is the food,  The reason for that is because they put truffle oil on EVERYTHING,  Grilled cheese?  Truffle oil.  French fries? Truffle oil.  Brussel sprouts?  Truffle oil.  We only ordered appetizers.  We had deviled eggs, (great!); meatball skewers (meh); lamb sliders (love me a lamb slider); and cashew cauliflower.  It was all good.  I would have to say the grilled cheese and the lamb sliders were my favorite.  

For dessert, we had a chocolate bread pudding, which seemed to impress everyone at our table, but I would have been more satisfied with a choco taco, no offense.  We also ordered a coconut cream pie.  It was average.  The crust wasn't crisp enough and there was definitely something missing flavor-wise.   

All in all, very good and fun for after work happy hour.
author: Sunny S.

description:
No doubt about it, Bix has it down pat in the ambiance department. Loved the dark, intimate interior, live jazz, elegant decor. The restaurant is smaller than I expected, so noise seemed to be bouncing off all the walls, but overall I enjoyed the vibe. We had a "2nd story" table which provided a great view of the downstairs bar / jazz trio. 

I had really high expectations before going to Bix. Lobster spaghetti? Truffle burger? Sign me up! I opted for the lobster pasta, everyone seems to rave about it. For a nearly $40 dish, I was expecting more lobster. There were more tomato halves than lobster chunks, super disappointing. Also, the flavor didn't wow me. I understand the need for a light flavor panel as to not deter from the lobster, but there was hardly any lobster to begin! Sigh.

My mom's Chicken Hash a la Bix was delightful though - super rich, so not sure I could have ordered/handled an entire entree myself.

Overall I hand it to Bix for atmosphere, service, presentation, and execution. If I return, I'll grab a spot at the bar and get the burger.
author: Brianna M.

description:
From the moment you enter you can sense the great ambience inside. You hear the tunes of a piano and the energy of the guests. The dim lights set the mood for a very nice romantic date. My girlfriend and I came and immediately loved it. 
The food was good. I had the lobster spaghetti. She had the sea bass. Portions were good. They have a variety of drinks, wines, and non alcoholic beverages. USE VALET PARKING FOR at 10$ IS A STEAL COMPARED TO EVERYWHERE ELSE.  
Make room for dessert! I would come back to San Francisco just to come here! Thanks did the great service and awesome experience BIX.
author: Aron C.

description:
A unique location, but well known among the drivers. 
The setting is wonderfully old school and we were there on a piano player night. He was just the right amount of Piano Man in the background and very skilled. 
The presentations are excellent. The liquor pours are very tight. Not much generosity there. Part of the reason for the 4 not 5 star review. 
The other was lack of description on the meals. No one really likes the song and verse of where the cattle was raised and overly flowery descriptions of your impending meal, but a little would help. 
The potato pillows were actually fried little hash brown squares. While they were delicious, there was no way we were prepared for the fried part since the pillows implied softness. 
That's the only indifferent part. All the rest was excellent. The burger was well infused with truffles, the lobster spaghetti was terrific and the dessert was a great balance of wonderful cake and fruit. 
Our service was casual and friendly and this will be a must stop in the years to come. I just hope they adjust the bar pours. Let people enjoy.
author: David B.

description:
Was there last night for a business dinner for a party of 13. Hard to find but great that they have valet parking. Nice bar, beautiful yet dark interior. We sat on the ground floor. It was about 90 degrees in SF and pretty stuffy in the restaurant. Not too squished at our long table but everyone was breaking out their phones to read the menu - a bit too dark. Our waiter (and I'm sorry I didn't get his name) was terrific - patient, gave terrific suggestions for wine, and very attentive with a great sense of humor.

We ordered several apps for both ends of the table. The deviled eggs are amazing and the asparagus is terrific. The chicken bites are ok - tasty but nothing to write home about. We also ordered a side of the truffle fries as an appetizer - so glad we did - YUMMY!

The special was a lovely halibut with a "raviolo" served in a nice broth. About 75% of the table ordered it. I found it a bit too salty for my taste but others liked it. The fish was cooked perfectly - a bit crispy on the outside, moist on the inside. Two people ordered the truffled cheese burger. Looked very good, cooked as requested, good helping of crispy truffle fries with it. Two others ordered a steak, said it was good but also a bit salty. One ordered the lobster spaghetti and had trouble finding much lobster - lots of tomatoes. (I had read this on other reviews). 

One of our party was celebrating a birthday and I had brought a homemade cake. Waiter brought it out with candles - perfect. They sliced and plated (for 4$ pp) and added a small scoop of ice cream to each plate - nice touch. A couple of other desserts were ordered - crème brulee and bread pudding. They seemed to like them - I tried the bread pudding (which is a favorite) and wasn't too impressed. Nice presentation however.

Water and wine was refilled without asking. Nice as that doesn't happen much these days. Conversation was difficult as it was very loud, especially after the trio started playing. May have been better had we been sitting upstairs. Found I was a bit hoarse at the end of the evening. 

All in all a nice company event.
author: Ronda F.

description:
It's like stepping into the roaring 20's --- right out of the Great Gatsby. 

The restaurant is dimly lit with a few neon signs directing you to the exits and lounges (restrooms).  There is a live pianist and jazz singer with the purest tone. Her beautiful scat singing almost made me forget I was in San Francisco. 

The bar is well stocked, with a plethora of whiskeys.  

I feel like we ordered the whole menu, or darn close to it. 

Truffles make me weak in the knees --- and the truffle deviled eggs and the truffle fries were AMAZING.

I really don't like roe, but it brought a brightness and salinity to the potato pillows. 

Probably the most shocking (in a good way) was the General Tso's chicken.  Now, seems an unlikely menu item for a jazzy restaurant, right?  But good lord,  the caramelized glaze and the tenderness of the chicken was unforgettable. 

To be truly honest, the appetizers outshine the entrees in my opinion.

I had the fish of the day but was unimpressed.  Pan seared fish on a bed of greens topped with olives. 

However, one of my friends ordered the pork chop and was very pleased with the polenta. 

In any case,  I'll be back.  More likely for appetizers, fries, and drinks.
author: Risa G.

description:
Elegant ambiance. Classy old school style in terms of decor and service staff. Ask about the paintings by Mark Stock.
Nice bar with range of cocktails, wine, draft and bottled beers. (If you like beer try Death and Taxes.)
Steak tartare prepared at the table, to perfection.
Asparagus salad and Brussel sprouts side: well prepared, well presented. Brussel sprouts nicely complimented with olive oil and lemon.
Catch of the day was char: priced competitively with other seafood offerings: flavorful, not over cooked, moist, with tasty sides of cucumber salad and scalloped potatoes.
Jazz trio (fabulous drummer) playing standards in keeping with old school decor. Talented and capable, alternating energetic with mellow. Not so loud that we couldn't hold a conversation. Plays until midnight!
We chose bread pudding for dessert. Light topping and chocolate-y bread pudding.
Service, thanks to Christopher, was classy, unobtrusive and well informed. 
Romantic celebration or just a nice treat.
author: Liana T.

description: I don't know why some people complain so much,  I think people expect way too much,  and standards are way too high....... when it needs to be down to earth.  This place is a 5 star,  base on the service alone.  The food is amazing, the wife and I loved it so much,  its our new place to dine.  The live band is awesome,  the vibe is definitely hip, classy folks who enjoy good food and drinks. The pork chop is to die for,  absolutely the best chops I've ever eaten.
author: Tony Y.

description:
I definitely agree with the "SF old school dining" experience that other reviewers are writing about. The cocktails and appetizers, however, were quite a let down. At $10-$12 for drinks and appetizers I was expecting more. The oysters, deviled eggs, fried chicken and meatballs all tasted run-of-the-mill. The cocktails tasted very watered down.

The entree itself, however, was quite a delight (although the salad that was a part of it was terribly over-salted). The semifreddo dessert was amazing; it tasted like half-creme brulee, half-ice cream.
author: Thomas C.

description: While in the city I was looking for an experience. Boy did I get one at Bix!! Very elegant older crooner type vibe. People were dressed up, the Jazz trio, the waiters in their white coats, the design of the place... My boyfriend and I only had appetizers with our cocktails and they were delicious. We had the potato pillows , the deviled eggs and the sliced halibut crudo.  My experience is an unforgettable one.. Just what I was looking for, a romantic place and a classy atmosphere.  Will definitely be back next time we're in town!
author: Diane R.

description: Porkchop was very well seasoned and I went with this over the steak. We got the $28 openfaced burger which was very heavy with really delicious onion ontop of it. Might not have been "the best burger ever" but it was very good and one of the best in SF. A bit on the buttery side so it really depends what kind of burger you are going after. I love the minetta tavern burger in NYC but that was one even heavier. The brussel sprouts here are probably the best (I have found) in SF and the portion is very generous. They are very lemony but very crispy. We also got the bone marrow spread with parsley which was very good and pretty refreshing with the parsley (more places should do this!).
author: Lily P.

description:
Where do I start??  You enter this dramatically lit 1920's Art Deco designed restaurant and instantly feel the posh surroundings.

A guy sits behind a baby grand piano playing jazz, rags and music from that decade as well as live singing either by the pianist himself or a solo jazz singer.  No detail in interior design is spared here.  There is a beautiful Art Deco mural spanning the length of the bar and two chandeliers hanging above from ornate medallions on the ceiling over the bar.  The upstairs booths are one of the most comfortable booths I've ever sat in.  They are lit with colorful sconces appropriate for the Art Deco theme.  

The service here is impeccable.  The servers and runners are pleasant, and all dressed in white shirts looking refined.  

Every dish was absolutely palatable and served with exquisite presentation.  We decided on a culinary adventure with hors d'oeuvres and salads rather than just main courses.  It made dinner more exciting and interesting to taste a new medley of flavors with each new dish.

We dined on bone marrow, mini lamb burgers, Dungeness crab rolls, mozarella wrapped in prosciutto, smoked trout with endives, shaved asparagus, and pickled red onions, and truffle fries.

Unfortunately, we didn't save room for dessert.  Fortunately, there will be a next time!  -can't wait to come back here again!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Our server was my hero! He cured my hiccups by telling me to exhale completely before gulping down a glass of water as fast as I could until I felt like I was "drowning". Thanks to him, I went from feeling irate and miserable to actually being in the mood to enjoy the swanky ambiance, down my Hibiscus Swizzle and inhale a subpar dinner. 

While the steak tartare was decent, the ceviche was borderline bland with the thinnest, most measly slices of fish.  Lame. We also tried the Black Truffle Cheese Burger, which they were nice enough to split on two plates without us asking (BIX knows what's up!). Unfortunately, the patty was under-seasoned and devoid of any truffle essence. The accompanying truffle fries were also too lightly flavored. Maybe Umami Burger has raised my standards to unrealistic levels, but BIX's version definitely needs some work if it wants to join the gourmet club.

Skip the Bananas Foster dessert. I had hoped it would be ignited tableside but was disappointed when all that was brought out was some cooked banana slices in a cloyingly sweet rum syrup over ice cream.
author: Suany W.

description:
Good points: food was acceptable for the price, interesting chocolate mousse, knowledgeable waitstaff and bar staff.

Bad points: lighting so dim you can't really see your food other than in black and white. Live jazz that bordered on the aggressive - felt like they were trying to speed up the pace of the whole operation. Speaking of which ...

Extremely bad points: so our party arrived late, and prior to being seated we were warned that we might lose the table. Fair enough. The manager reminding us at every possible occasion from that point onwards that we'd arrived late and could we please get a move on ... AFTER we'd been seated ... completely unnecessary, rude and unprofessional. Once you've made the choice to seat a table, you treat them like guests, not inconveniences. Needless to say, we will be one-time Bixers!
author: Ed O.

description: It always feels like a special occasion when we go here.  Fun to get dressed up with high heels (can only wear if there is valet parking which Bix has), drink champagne at the bar, sit in big comfy booth and eat lovely meal to live music.  Lovely San Francisco institution!
author: S. C.

description: Normally love this place. Celebrated our engagement here two years ago. My parents are currently visiting from the U.K. ,  the first time in 10 years, so I wanted to bring them to 'the' quintessential SF restaurant. My wife ordered the Liberty Duck, which I thought was a signature BIX dish. The duck was not cooked properly - rubbery skin, un-rendered fat, poorly executed generally. Sadly trying not to cause a stir and upset my parents, she ate half her plate, but finally gave up and sent it back. BIX was cool - asked if we wanted to replace the dish and comped our dessert. Server was great. However, now we are at home and (1hour later) my wife is really sick - hold the hair back sick. Again, normally love this place but we really expect so much more. Clearly nobody did QC on this food before it went out. My wife is a heroic dummy for eating part of it, but at this level of restaurant, the food should never have made it out of the kitchen.
author: Stuart C.

description: Service is horrible. Food is not that great either.  There's really nothing to say about this place other than the fact that the service is atrocious.
author: Amir B.

description: Went here for an anniversary, and the staff did a great job at congratulating us on it.
