The smallest things from a personalized card, to little complimentary desserts, even just the staff mentioning  "happy anniversary" made it that much more special for us.  Thanks a bunch to the staff.  The place is stunning, food was amazing and the atmosphere even better.  Live music was a huge plus. The cute little alley was super cool. Couldn't be happier with my visit.
author: Gary D.

description:
I wanted to go on a date to a classy, romantic place and boy, did we score when we picked this place or what?!

I love the location of this place. It reminds me of my favorite place to eat on Post Alley in Seattle. The ambiance is very dim, romantic and sensual here. The live music just sets the mood too. 

Food- 6/5 
Service- 6/5
Experience- 6/5

We had such a great server who was so informative about the menu, gave us suggestions, pairings and gave us satisfactory service for making our double date one to remember. 

Thank you, BIX! We shall see you again soon.
author: Chelsey S.

description: What a beautiful place to celebrate a birthday. Made a reservation for my boyfriend's big bday and they welcomed us with a paper on the table. Waiters are there for you, food is amazing, so are drinks (both wine and cocktails). They brought ice cream at the end for free without singing a song (my bf hates it!) Can't wait to go back!
author: Serena P.

description:
Came with Martin L. the vegetarian and he loved his food! 

Apps
House Mozzarella Skewers can be served without the prosciutto, and still yummy. 

Entrees
Specialty Vegetarian Pasta - he finished the whole plate
Black Truffle Cheese Burger which came with a side of arugula salad (too salty) and fries (delicious, and enough to share). I asked for it cooked medium - it was cooked medium. +1 for that

Dessert
Sorbet - Strawberry Rhubarb, Honey Mascarpone (Martin L. loved the honey mascarpone)
Creme Brulee - delicious and would order again

Drinks
Perfect Manhattan - as promised, it was perfect
Paloma - tequila taste was almost overwhelming
Roman Spring - a bit bitter, if you're into that

Service
Perfect, our waiter made his rounds made quick eye contact in case we needed anything

Ambiance
Live Piano and a singer!
author: Jane N.

description:
Hubby and I were part of the first round of Bix' cool vibe back in the day - was it late '90's or early 00's when they first opened? Can't recall exactly, but we liked it then - and we still do.

We arrived a bit early and waited in the bar.  We stood near the jazz group setting up, and there was plenty of room for the 5 of us to wait.  We probably were seated about 9:15 for our 9pm reservation....but when we had arrived the hostess had let us know they were just waiting for the party at our table to pay their check. You know how that goes. So no big deal.

Here's the one negative of the evening: hubby ordered a bottle of wine and failed to tell me I was going to take the sample sip (he was across and at the other end of the table from me). So when the waiter arrived with the bottle, I was apparently very involved in my conversation with my friend, and to get my attention, he touched the bottle of wine to my bare arm.  It was kinda weird. A light touch to the shoulder with your hand seems more appropriate to me. Especially in such a classy joint.

Took a friend from the east coast there who is a firm meat eater.  Then there's me, seafood only, and son, vegetarian.  Hubby and daughter will eat most things. And their menu items were able to make all of us happy. Started with the potato pillows and deviled eggs, which were both delicious. Also got the truffled fries which I didn't get to try but they were gone so must have been good. The roasted cauliflower was yummy.  I got the market fish (trout that night) and the piece of fish was perfectly fine, but the deliciousness credit goes to the bed of kale and mushrooms it was on.  That could have been my whole meal. Dessert was bread pudding and bananas foster.  Don't think I'd particularly recommend the bread pudding...and the bananas foster was good, but so rich I couldn't eat more than 1/4 of it. Me. Can't. Finish. My. Dessert. That just doesn't happen so you know it's hecka rich.

Sat in the booth right next to the jazz band and I have to say that, while it was a little loud, it was perfectly fine and we kinda loved it.  Just be aware, if you don't want jazz music right in your ear, don't sit in that 5-6 person booth.

And yes, it's expensive. There ya go. Don't say no one told you that.  We'll be back.
author: Laurie H.

description:
I have been to BIX a couple times and finally ready to talk about how satisfied I am with my experience(s).

Service: just as what you would expect from a traditional/new American restaurant. Server is attentive and explains drinks, the menu, and daily specials. Also the "scrapping the table clean with the knife-life metal thing between courses" part. lol. Now does that have a proper name? If anyone who's reading this knows please enlighten me :P

Food: My friends and I got our eyes on too many appetizers so we just ordered a few appetizers and kinda had them tapas style.
1. the truffle DEVILED EGGS!! I love deviled eggs in general but his place has one of  the best deviled eggs I've had (in my opinion, it beats Wayfare Tavern and Park Tavern). 
2. bone marrow; I have always wanted to see what the hype is about for this seemingly luxurious delicacy so we gave it a shot. To be honest I wasn't quite sure if I could taste the bone marrow distinctively so... this one you can pass
4. "The BIX Tomato Cart":tomatoes and burrata cheese +basil +olive oil (and our server offered vinaigrette on the side b/c we couldn't make up our minds whether we want it or not. how nice) 
5. steak tartare: was added after we were on our second appetizer. Very unique and well seasoned. Kinda different from the steak tartares I've had elsewhere but good in its own way
And we still got 2 entrees after all those food haha
7. the lobster spaghetti, it's just ok. I can pass on that
8. the TRUFFLE BURGER!! yes, I know now it just seems like I am biased towards truffles. But I gotta give it to BIX on how they 100% deliver what they promise as far as listing truffle on their menu.(What I mean by that is, if you see on the menu a dish has truffle, you WILL taste the truffle unlike many other places.) Ok, back to this dish. even the truffle fries that came with the burger are divine!! I am not a big fan of fries but they were just so good. On to the burger, the brilliant combination of beef and the copious amount of truffle is just so delicious!!!

Lastly, we were so stuffed but still managed to share a creme brulee :9
Good, nothing too special. But then again I am no creme brulee expert. However my friend is a creme brulee fanatic said it beats many others she's had so I guess it's that good.
author: Deb S.

description: I am absolutely in love with this gorgeous supper club, tucked away on Gold Street in Jackson Square. The food is generous, fresh, perfectly prepared and aesthetically pleasing. I highly recommend the foie gras mousse as an appetizer. The people are calm, kind, and welcoming. The infamous mural behind the bar as well as the art that decorates the dining room are lovely. Aj, the man behind Bix's superb wine list, made a greater impression on me than most. A great balance between old world and new world wines as well as permanent selections from producers who are described as life long friends. When my soul asks for an evening of fine food and wine, among friends, I will make my way to Bix time and time again.
author: Martha V.

description:
Let me start off by saying that the pork chop was excellent, as was the salad. 
The kitchen staff, including the waitress, were extremely attentive and made our dining experience quite pleasurable. 

The hostess seating us, however, came across as rude. We got in and requested a look at the two table options(downstairs and upstairs) before choosing which one to sit in. This is after waiting by the door for a good five minutes before being attended to. 

When we requested her to show us both options, she made it seem like a lot of effort for her to go through, and did so grudgingly once she saw us pleasantly persist. We found a lovely table upstairs, but our first impression entering wasn't the best. 

And first impressions do last....
author: Michele Y.

description: I was quite embarrassed picking out this place for a celebration. First of all, it's in a alley and don't bother going alone... The bartender was not bad but was not quite impressed with cocktail list. The appetizers were... Nothing to rave about. Just do not order those fried potatoes. Devils eggs were decent but not flavorful. Now to the main course... The lobster spaghetti was over cooked & not enough noodles.  Lobster did not taste fresh. Our server didn't bother checking up on us after our plates arrived. There were no free desserts for occasions. Was so disappointed by the dessert we ordered too. Bread pudding was way too sweet.
author: Ann L.

description: Fantastic appetizers and stellar service to match. Our server paid close attention to our needs and was genuine and helpful with menu recommendations. Food was amazing. We tried the sweet and sour chicken appetizer (10/10), a halibut fish special (8/10) and a Gouda infused open face burger on rye (9/10). I will definitely go back! Great ambiance as well.
author: micah v.

description:
Food's really neatly presented (sometimes it feels like they try too hard to be trendy & fancy w/ the presentation) and overall 3.5-4 stars, but the steep prices brings that enjoyment down a notch! We only got appetizers because all the entrees seemed to be at least $20-$30 and we still paid a good amount for dinner.

Gotta say love the live music though.

Only must-have: deviled eggs!!

We tried:

Roasted Beet and Chévre Skewers with Basil & Balsamico  8.50 - The cheese had a nice tangy flavor, balanced well by the beet & sauces.

Deviled Eggs with Summer Truffles, Romano Beans and Chives  11.50 - Delicious!! Love the strong garlic flavor. Awesome.

House Made Mozzarella wrapped in La Quercia Prosciutto 
with Fiordolio Olive Oil   9.75 - The mozzarella had an amazingly unique texture, almost like a marshmallow. I couldn't really taste the olive oil (and this dish was the whole reason I came here - it was reviewed on my favorite blog TastingTable). We got the prosciutto separate for my vegetarian friend so I'm not sure if that took away a little from the dish.

Creamed Organic Bloomsdale Spinach 9.00 - A little too creamed & homogenized - the spinach was cooked so thoroughly that it lost all of its texture and was almost soupy. Maybe for some people, but not so much for me.
 
Truffled French Fries 9.50 - Great crisp. Intense flavor. Could taste the garlic more than the truffles, but I like garlic.

Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding 8.95 - Comes w/ a giant dollop of whipped cream. The bread pudding was really rich yet fluffy and light. I would've preferred a more solid and heavy texture, but that's just me. My friends really liked this one.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I arrived here without reservations with a party of 5 on a Saturday night hoping to have a nice meal for a friend's birthday before a night of clubbing and was told there would be a minimum of a 45 minute wait. Not knowing if my party wanted to wait that long since we were on a time crunch, I crossed my fingers asking if they wanted to order a drink at the bar. Shortly after 10 minutes, I was informed we would be able to be seated! Although it was a corner table upstairs right next to the kitchen, my whole party was extremely happy we were able to be seated. Our waiter was very attentive and helpful in helping us choose what to order. The ambiance was great, dimmed lighting, live jazz music and a very lively packed bar downstairs.

I thought that the bite sized pork belly BANH MI was going to be a miss, but they were actually pretty delightful.
Most of the dishes everyone ordered were enjoyable and the BONE MARROW was gone with quickness.
OYSTERS were fresh and came with a type of yuzu sauce.
The STEAK TARTARE was prepared tableside and was very delectable.
Cocktails and refills came fast and had a nice kick, just the way I like em.
We ordered a variety of desserts from the BANANAS FOSTER to the warm CHOCOLATE BRIOCHE BREAD PUDDING and all of them were equally as delicious.

Valet parking is available up front, I love how this restaurant is located in a cute secluded alleyway! Will definitely be back.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Blown away by impeccable service, transcending ambiance and delicious specials and cocktails. Very memorable evening! All the stars in the world are yours!
author: Ally M.

description:
If you're in the US, you need to get to this bar, bottom line!  Try to drop in after 9pm for the live jazz.

The food is innovative, delicious and not cheap!  It's in a beautiful room, it is a full service restaurant of the highest caliber.  Worth following on Facebook too since they announce the latest additions to the menuo.

Famous for excellent martini's too and my favorite hide-away in the Financial District.

Have fun1
author: Vincent M.

description:
Bix ambiance and service was good but did not deliver for me in terms of food.  
Everything  looked very good on the menu it did not match the taste.  We ordered 6 different types of aps 
And they did not impress me.  The taste just did not match the description.  I read similar reviews but I was willing to try.

Apps: Duck ham, Poke, Pillow/caviar, Meatball, chesse/truffle, deviled eggs. 
With the exception of Poke, I could not really taste the main ingredient.  The meatball was not very good.  Costco bought taste better.
On the pillow, the potatoe completely overpower the caviar.  

Main course: New yortkSteak, lobster spaghetti, quail, salmon, truffle burger, brioche crusted halibut
The steak was very good.  The rest was mediocre.  

Dessert: Bread pudding and Dark Chocolate hazelnut
This was ok but not something I would order again.

Overall, I did not get what the hype is all about.  Specially for the price they charge.  In my opinion, this is a 2 star restaurant 
who charge $$$$.

I would not come back here or recommend it to my friend.
author: Rodel A.

description:
Duck and P. chop done perfectly. Ignore their thinking kale done like rotkohl is new. It IS new. It's crunchy. 

And order pink wine.
author: Kenny C.

description: In my humble opinion, the best bar in SF.  The bartenders Peter and Brad are true professionals.  Best dirty martini I have ever had.  I mentioned to my parents we (my wife and I) found a great bar in SF.  When my parents were visiting, we took them there, and my dad decided to test them.  (really?  Thanks dad)  He ordered a Horse's Neck. ( I have never heard of that drink)  Peter did not hesitate 1 second.  He grabbed the appropriate glass and made the drink.  My dad said is is the best one he has ever had. The whole restaurant has great ambiance as well.  Fantastic food is also available. My wife and I usually just sit at the bar and share some apps and a few drinks and have a wonderful time.
author: Lars L.

description:
Food: 
Deviled eggs- we ordered it because of the hype over it on other reviews but it just tasted like regular deviled eggs that I could've made at home, nothing mind-blowing. I'd pass on it next time

Steak tartare- pretty good but not amazing

Duck breast- it was nice and juicy and the sauce was salty but good. The pears were a nice complement but the pieces of duck sausage that came with it made me wonder why they were there..

Pork chop- once again, pretty good but not amazing; I think I've had better for a lesser price

Ginger gimlet- good; tastes like a gimlet. Maybe could've made it a bit more gingery but personal preference 

Service: meh ok the usual, nice but forgetting your water etc.

Ambience:
The bar downstairs is nice and I loved the live music! It can get a bit noisy and if you really want to be picky they probably could've done a bit better with the decor but I'd still say it's not bad 

Basically, decent ambience and service, okay food but probably not worth the price. I might come back just for the bar and live music though!
author: Esther J.

description: We come to the city from Scottsdale a few times a year and just landed on this gem last night.   The Caesar salad was one of the best ever, deviled eggs  and sea bass ceviche awesome and the Bix chicken appetizer was tasty.   Service was excellent.  Will and Nicole were welcoming, accommodating and fun.   Great experience.  We will be back!!!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
If you could go to one restaurant in SF - then this is it.
(travelers note)
any day, any time, any thing on the menu or at the bar.
the secret looking location with the 1930's art deco decor, great service and food is not to missed.
Want to impress a date? or client for that matter - This is the spot.
author: Misa A.

description:
Bix Burger- #27 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

4 stars for Bix, 3 stars for the Bix Burger w/Pommes Frites ($18, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bix-san-francisco?select=8dCywpdDXGiMT_ptZhjqjw#8dCywpdDXGiMT_ptZhjqjw). Bix only serves their burger during lunch, and they only open for lunch on Fridays. I made reservations for lunch one week, which was easy to do on OpenTable. The restaurant was only about half full at noon, and it wasn't too loud in the restaurant, which was really nice. We were greeted and sat right away, and opted to sit at the bar that day. The bartender was really friendly and attentive, and we ordered and received our food pretty quickly. Unfortunately, I thought the burger was overrated, and think there are a lot of better options in the city. However, I still love the vibe/ambiance at Bix, and would come back for dinner since I really enjoyed the last meal I had here. The food is definitely on the pricier side for dinner, but the it's worth it for the taste and quality.

Parking in this area can be tough, even during a Friday afternoon. There are a lot of metered spots, so at least you have a chance to grab a spot with some circling. Bix is located in a tiny alleyway, so make sure you keep your eye out for Gold Street when you're walking.
author: Amy D.

description:
on a recommendation we decided to have some late night drinks and appetizers.  When we walked in the Hostess was too busy talking with friends to say hi and help us with a seat.  For a classy restaurant you would have this as an expectation.

Then two seats at the bar opened and we had to ask a bar back and then a bartender (who didn't seem happy) to clean up the mess the last person left.  Again disappointing for a nice place.

Nevertheless they made an awesome martini but then never came by to see if we wanted another or anything else.  

Poor experience since my boyfriend and I made a special trip to try Bix.
author: Lanae S.

description: This was my first time back to this restaurant in about 15 years. It hasn't changed much. Still has a great jazz band and the ambience is very cool. My husband I came here from LA for a special anniversary dinner and we did mention it on the online reservation.  The food was really good and the lobster pasta did not disappoint and they really know how to make a proper Caesar salad. My only disappointment was they didn't acknowledge our anniversary the entire night.
author: Gia R.

description:
As you walk down an empty alley, all you see is a neon Bix sign and a valet. Once you step through the door you are greeted by tall ceilings, jazz band and bar that stretches the length of the entire wall. 

My friends and I were lucky enough to get one of the balcony seats over looking the entire restaurant. The lobster spaghetti was delicious as well as the bone marrow. We got an assortment of appetizers that was to die for.
author: Claire W.

description: This bar / Resturant invokes a speakeasy with an alley entrance and generous ceiling heigh to floor area ration . A grown ass man back bar and solid selection of champagnes ( wine list is good but not great) so why five f- ing stars ? Service is killer ! Phil says check it out !
author: Phillip T.

description:
The food was good, not great..the four of us ordered separate plates with appetizers and drinks and nothing really we had screamed amazing.  A couple of drinks we ordered weren't prepared properly and their drinks aren't cheap. 

The kale salad was just way too overwhelming and was quickly put aside barely touched. The fresh oysters were served with a not so tasteful sauce...not sure what that was? The ambiance within the restaurant is nice, but we all agreed that the price for the quality of food you are prepared is too expensive and if you want to bring your own bottle of wine in, be prepared for a $35 cork fee added to our bill.  The waitress also errored charging us for an extra drink.

In summary, the four of us were left in awe as the bill was over $500 and we didn't feel the food was that great (we brought in our own bottle of wine so the $35 corking fee contributed to that).  Not worth going back with so many great restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Ron M.

description: This place was even better than advertised. Every detail of the food preparation was perfect. Don't miss out on the lobster spaghetti, it is such a light take on the dish and it is amazing.
author: Josh B.

description: The service was excellent. We had the quail and it was amazing. The other food choices were okay. Since the place was on the smaller side it can get quite loud in there.
author: Tony L.

description:
We went on two dinner dates in 2 weeks here, on a Wednesday and Sunday night respectively.  Our first visit was amazing - sat upstairs, had perfect service, delicious food, in a beautiful and lively yet romantic venue.  We happened to be dressed up (suit + nice dress) from work.  5 star visit, highly recommend. 

Our second visit was on a Sunday night.  I had requested an upstairs table in the reservation after loving it the week before, and when I looked at the restaurant seating system upon arrival we had indeed been placed upstairs.  We were casually dressed - jeans, sunday-afternoon type of button down shirt, a bit downscale for Bix honestly, but still presentable.  The hostess walked over, looked at us, clicked on my reservation, and moved us to a downstairs table in the system as I stood there watching.  Kind of an awkward move by her, but not worth complaining about so we didn't.  Unfortunately, it was compounded by consistently cruddy table service from a male waiter - reading other recent reviews (Ben, Phoebe) it seems like the same guy might have bugged other customers as well.  Combined with a few food duds (meh-for-the-price lobster spaghetti, prix fixe menu that is a decent bargain but underachieves compared to the awesomeness of the regular menu), probably a 2-3 star experience. 

In all, this is a great restaurant and I'm planning to go back many times.  I just know now that I'll need to conform to the staff's image of a service-worthy customer if I want to enjoy myself, which bums me out enough to knock this from 4-5 to 3 stars.
author: Jim C.

description:
Good tasty food. Nice warm atmosphere. Passable service. Bad management.

The atmosphere is warm, cozy, lively, with hints of a NYC establishment from the 40's or 50's. Our first waiter was polite, but lacked any enthusiasm or personality.  Luckily, another one approached us a few minutes later to take our order and he was great.  He took our order, and carefully explained to us the order in which the plates, drinks, and wine would come.

The Steak Tartare was excellent, the speed at which it came made us wonder whether it was freshly made or previously refrigerated. Regardless, it tasted great.  Our second appetizer was Oven Roasted Bone Marrow.  They were hum.. okay, a bit bland tasting.  Bone marrow tastes so much better if it has been slow cooked in a broth, then oven roasted.  Another way is to mix the marrow with spices and put them back on the bone, kind of like you do with escargots sometimes.

For the main courses, we ordered Roasted Duck and a Blanquette.  The duck was good, cooked with caramelized onions, pears, and I believe some apples as well.  The dish was very tasty, but the duck could have been cooked better, or sliced thinly. Unfortunately, the consistency felt like processed meat.  The Blanquette was very tasty, grilled to perfection with a delicious side of chimichurri sauce and potato puree.

Desert was a chocolate brioche pudding which was decadently delicious.

The Malbec wine we ordered was an ideal accompaniment to the meats.  Velvety with great body.

While the meal was good, it was not up to par, especially considering the high price range ($30-40 per entree).  

However, the real issue and reason behind the 3 star rating is the poor service and management which started well, and precipitously declined as our meal was progressing:

- The first waiter. It was either a bad day, or he wanted to be somewhere else. He brought us the check before we asked for it, and without asking if we wanted coffee or if we were done.

- The "Terminator" - hold on to your plates, spoons, or glasses. The Terminator will snatch them away the second after you are done, or think you are done.  If you so much look like you're done with your plate or apetizer, boom! the plate's gone, nevermind or not if your friends are still eating. Same for your drinks, and because the place is dark, the Terminator won't see that last piece in your plate or drop in your glass.

- The Manager (the guy in the over-sized grey suit) - wow, this one's a winner. At first we thought he was just a little too jolly and folksy.  Then we wondered if he hadn't sampled too many glasses of wine beforehand.  Happiness was unfortunately not what transpired.  After trying to take away my plate before my friend had finished, at the end of our meal, he made sure we knew (repeatedly) we should vacate the table after the check landed.

On that subject, and once we were done with desert, our first waiter simply slapped the check on the table, boom!  No asking if we were still going to order coffee, if we were done, not even saying 'thank you.'  Fortunately, we were in a good mood so we simply laughed.  What else to do when a waiter is an ambulant catastrophe?

My friend and I were still chilling, having a good conversation, and slowly finishing our drinks.  That didn't seem to sit well with the manager who kept sending us every staff member to tell us "thank you for coming" (roughly translated to get the f*$# out).  At one point, he even came himself to "thank us" for coming, while we were still sitting and enjoying our conversation.  That was the last straw.

While the setting is very warm and definitely has lots of mid-century charm, the food did not match the price levels, and neither did service which was simply appalling and downright rude at the end.  Unless the latter drastically improves, I would absolutely not recommended Bix to friends or colleagues.  I have hope it will if owners are reading and care.
author: Stefan R.

description:
My bf brought me here for an early V-Day dinner. We sat upstairs. I really liked the atmosphere, it's a really good date place. It was a Saturday night and a lot of people were dressed up. 

We got the veal special and the pork. I liked the veal a lot better. The flavor of the food was really good. I came back a second time with a large group of coworkers and we sat downstairs. It was really loud but we had a great time. I ordered the truffle burger and it was very filling. I would definitely come again and try the lobster spaghetti.
author: V N.

description:
Had a reservation at 9 on a Friday night,  arrived a bit early.  The hostess was remarkably friendly and fantastic at the door.  

The place was quite busy,  but it was easy to grab a couple drinks as we waited outside at a quaint table.

Our waiter, Jonathan,  was on point in every way.  He was polite and friendly while he discussed the menu. We ordered bone marrow as an appetizer,  which I thought was a fear factor type meal,  but I was wrong. It tasted amazing.  Jonathan heard my date mention how she liked the crab cakes here and surprised us with a couple compliments of the kitchen.     

Being very averse to seafood,  and having never eaten a crab cake,  I felt obliged.  Continuing on,  I believe the standards are now unrealistically high for me. They were amazing.  I feel if I ever order them again,  however pallet able they may be,  that at any other establishment I will be let down.  

My entree was the duck,  which was appreciable but to be honest I've had better.  My date thought her lobster spaghetti was great, and loved my duck. 

All in all,  I tried two new foods and was impressed,  the staff was fantastic and quick to action.  

Will be back.
author: Mike B.

description:
I had no expectations coming into Bix, and almost had no visibility walking to the table (man the place is dim - talk about mood lighting).  Luckily, my eyes dark-adapted, and as we listened to the bluesy singer at the grand piano, my friends and I enjoyed a nice bottle of A. Rafenelli Zinfandel, several appetizers, and a few entrees family style.  We had the duck, wagyu beef, bone marrow, steak tar tar, veggie pasta...I could go on and on, but you get the idea (we practically ordered half the menu).  There didn't seem to be a dish that went awry that night.  Then for dessert the most memorable was the bananas foster.  Our waiter even treated us to a complimentary dessert.  

Good food + good service = happy camper.
author: Pam S.

description:
After seeing the reviews for BIX's I made a reservation a month ahead of time. Arrived promptly on time for the reservation yet they sat us next to the bathroom although the rest of the restaurant was fairly empty. 

Never the less, I am still going to give Bix's a four star review. Missing one star because of the seating and our not so attentive waitress.


Potato Pillows -$18
Size is much smaller than you would imagine. About the size of a checker piece.
The crispy flaky outside was deliciously complimented with the rich filling within.
Very delicious but may have to order another appetizer as well with this dish.

Lobster Spaghetti -$34
Was a bit let down by this dish. I had it without the jalapeños so maybe that was a factor. The noodles were definitely over cooked and there was simply just nothing special about this dish. 

Crème Brûlée - $9 
Absolutely heaven. The custard within was the perfect texture and just the right amount of sweetness. The sugar glaze on top did not overpower the custard but went well perfectly. Could not get enough of this one and the price was so reasonable!

All the food came quickly. The complimentary bread, crispy on the outside and warm on the inside. The secluded alley location. Bix's is an ideal location to enjoy a delicious meal while enjoying an elegant atmosphere.
author: Shaylene L.

description:
Restaurant was great
5 stars
Ate at the bar without reservation
Cocktails excellent
Food as well
Had 
Cerviche-highly recoend as well as deviled eggs
Scallops fabolous oerfectly cooked followed by 
Chocolate brioches pudding excellent
Cheese platter Alsoexcellent
Bar service attentive friendly not rushed
Spent two hours eating talking
Listening to good jazz
author: Andrew B.

description:
Very nice place to grab a few drinks.

I said 'drinks' because I was a tad disappointed by the food they had to offer. 

Got a reservation for my husband's birthday on a Friday. While waiting, tried their signature cocktails at the bar: Manhattan and (forgot the name but) the one with bourbon, honey and smoked ice mixed drink, which I REALLY loved, had to order 2 more :)
Then we got seated at the best table (the middle of the 2nd floor, overlooking EVERYTHING of the restaurant, quite nice). They placed a little note 'Happy Birthday' for my husband, which again I thought was a nice surprise.

BUT! That was it. us big eaters ordered about 3 appetizers and 2 entrees, the waiter maybe couldn't believe what he just heard because the entrees never came out even when we finished the appetizers. By that time, though, we thought it was actually better because the food wasn't really impressive. They had to put sliced/baked/any some sort of bread on the side of EVERY dish, except the salad, which I thought it looked kind of cheap. We would be fine with having just the food if it's good enough. So the presentation was off. 

And the waiter was VERY slow, asked for a whiskey menu which he never brought out, and I could see in his face that he wasn't really focused on what we were saying, apparently his mind was occupied with some other table he had to serve. 

So, as a conclusion, food and service was just a okay at the best. The drink was good. I would go there again after work, since it's just about five blocks away from my office, but I won't eat any food there.
author: Ginger K.

description:
Came here for my birthday, being a bit fancy in SF, looking forward to delicious food. BIX is located within a little alleyway, away from the hustle and bustle of downtown SF life. The restaurant is quite large, with an upper deck with additional seating, a large bar, and a mini grand piano on the main floor.

BIX became a mixed bag of hits and misses, ultimately leading to an underwhelming [birthday/dining] experience.

Odd: BIX is the only restaurant I know where a waiter comes to your table and plops a little bread role onto your bread plate. No plate of bread to pick apart and share. Just a 1 bread/person policy...

Amusing: BIX is also the only restaurant where the waitress comes to you with [some] already made cocktails... and some which she brings in a shaker, shakes it for you, and then pours it into your glass.

Clumsy: I ordered my first drink, and the waitress came to serve my drink. She vigorously shook it, and when moving in to serve, almost dropped the entire shaker (luckily she only dropped the cap).

Weak & not worth it: Throughout the dinner, I ordered two drinks. A BIX 'Perfect' Manhattan and an Old Fashion. Both cocktails were horribly underwhelming and weak. You get a watered down texture to it, and it doesn't come close to being spirit forward. For them to call it the 'Perfect Manhattan'...shame on them! I also tried my girlfriend's Huckleberry fizz, and it was horribly syrupy. Her Blossom Dearie was also not the best drink on the list...

Tasty: The Lobster Spaghetti was a nice saving grace to our dinner - a silver lining that was well appreciated. Good amounts of lobster, and the pasta was not overcooked. Cherry tomatoes provided some tart/sweet notes to the dish. My girlfriend's duck breast was also quite tasty - nice and tender - some pretty well prepared duck.

Nice: The mini grand piano was a refreshing bit to the restaurant. As the dinner crowd came in, a pianist provided some lovely music to set the tone of the lively restaurant.

Sigh: Surprise, it was my birthday, and my girlfriend surprised me with one of their desserts: the bananas foster. I sigh at this 'surprise' because of the fact that they charge you for the dessert. Even though it's your birthday... you are basically ordering dessert. The only difference is that they give you a candle. For the amount we paid for all our food... they could loosen up and provide a free birthday dessert. Also, this scoop of vanilla ice cream with bananas and rum cost $10. Not worth it... for this bowl of diabetes.

My dinner was quite disappointing, and now that I've visited once, I doubt I'll return. If you come across BIX on Yelp, you've been warned. There is an average of 4 stars, but don't be surprised if your dinner takes a turn for the worst...
author: Kevin J.

description: I loved it, location, ambiance, and people actually get dressed up for dinner! Only downfall they need better desserts-) but steak tartare makes up for it. I have gone back, and plan on going back often.
author: Mari H.

description:
I can't get enough.

As we all know, my favorite feature of BIX is the live music and intimate atmosphere. Fridays and Saturday nights draw a crowd with their magnificent jazz trio, and Sunday nights are quaint with a pianist. Friday afternoons (the only time they're open for lunch) and Sunday evenings are my favorite times to sit back and relax. No crowd, just me, Peter, and a cocktail.

Granted, the entrees aren't the best (nor is the variety of dessert offerings), but the hor d'oeuvres are to die for (I often opt for a tapas-style meal here). Order yourself potato pillows, tartare, Dungeness crab rolls, deviled eggs, mozzarella with procuitto, and onion and truffle cheese croquettes will have your bill running up a mountain without even realizing it. Oh, and you can't forget the truffle fries!

I stopped by a week ago, singing Simon and Garfunkel blues in attempt to remedy my lost soul. Within a half hour, Peter had me soused with (I think) five drinks. The mix of bellinis, blood orange margaritas, bowl of spicy Goldfish, salmon tartare, $42 spaghetti, along with a little philosophical conversation definitely made a great turn for the evening. The next thing I remembered was taking the Dublin/Pleasanton train and waking up to a homeless man at Pittsburg/Bay Point yelling, "Hi Honey!"
author: Elaine N.

description:
Had my birthday dinner here with my family- the service was incredible. All the servers kept wishing me happy birthday, they even gave me a card. I thought it was so sweet! 

First time here, loved the classy ambiance. It's very comfortable, and with the bar it also has a casual feeling to it. Live piano music was wonderful, and we had a great table upstairs.

I have no complaints about the food. I was so happy to have foie gras for the first time in years, along with an array of appetizers and perfectly cooked duck breast for my entree. I was also delighted to see they had Bordeaux wines. 

There is no doubt that I will be returning. I've added the Bix as one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Sora M.

description: Bix has a sultry atmosphere with nice live jazz and excellent service. The menu isn't very inspiring. Though the food was prepared perfectly, it was boring and lacked inspiration. Overall, I'm giving 4 stars for solid execution across the board but being somewhat spoiled by all the culinary innovation in this town, I prefer to find places doing things that are more inspired in the food realm.
author: Eater S.

description:
To start off, this is a fancy place, dessy attire and pricey meals. I went for a friend's bachelorettre party dinner. They had a congrats card waiting for her at the table which I thought was nice. 

I ordered the Chicken a la Bix and split that as well as the lobster spaghetti with a friend. Loved the Chicken a la Bix, it was like a chicken crab cake, hearty and great flavor, and loved the vodka sauce. The lobster spaghetti had handmade noodles and a good amount of lobster. My favorite was the Chicken a la Bix though. 

I also ordered a vodka gimlet that was just the right amount of tart.

They brought out a special dessert for the bride to be with a candle, nice touch. The service was top notch the entire night, our server was great and it was definitely a fine dining experience. They have a coat check, live piano player and also called us cabs when we were ready to leave. 

Great for a special occasion, But be prepared to pay for it!
author: Rachel F.

description:
Cloud 29

Just got home from dinner at Bix for our first date (since son was born 17months ago), and to celebrate our two-year anniversary. The decor and atmosphere was everything I expected and better. Maybe it was the positive vibes we had going on walking in to the place but this place is now going to be our spot. 

Hostess was professional, quick and cute! Atmosphere was ideal and extra smooth thanks to the live band. Server was attentive, knowledgeable and had proper timing throughout the meal, as did our busser. Clean place with sweet decor and a certain quality to its plates. (in comparison to all of our similar favorite joints we have come to know in SF over the last 6 years or so; inc Nopa, Jardiniere, Rich Table, etc)

What we dug into: (look at menu for specs pls)
cesar salad
bone marrow
potato pillows
lobster spaghetti
duck breast
bananas foster
creme brulee

drinks:
kentucky mule
red italian wine

Just get it all and eat it. We both can't wait for the next time we get to come here, with baby or not. Perfect. Thank you.
author: Kristine K.

description: Back in the day (early 90's), long before the term foodie was in household use & celeb chef restaurants were in every nabe, there was Bix.  Love at first sight.  To have an authentic Bix experience, you don't even need to eat.  Everything about Bix is a winner.  From the clandestine location in Gold Alley, to the staircase, to the famous mural above the bar, to the even more famous clown/ballerina painting...you get the gist.  Grand & majestic.  Beautifully refined.  It's like you've walked into a Thin Man film, & Nick & Nora will be walking in any minute to their table.  Known for power martinis & mover & shaker meetings, merely having a drink here is an experience.  But, have dinner too?  BOOM!  Dine downstairs for premiere people watching.  Have dinner upstairs for a bit more privacy.  Having been patronizing Bix for over 20 years now, I can tell you that I've never had anything other than a great meal here.  Ever.  Meat or fish?  You won't be disappointed.  I'm partial to duck, pork, & all things trufflesque (yeah, I just made that word up), so they tend to be my go to dishes.  Truffle burger w truffle fries, I'm in.  Piano music in the background, great drink, delish food...you're guaranteed an unforgettable & romantic time.  Even in this day of Chiarello, Florence, & Patterson restos being all the buz, Bix is a must.  A must.  Do it.
author: Veronica M.

description:
This place is NOT FOR ASIANS!! WHITE PEOPLE ONLY!! 

William the manager called me a "chinaman" and proceeded to kick my friends and I out because we "looked intoxicated" AFTER WE ORDERED AND PAID FOR OUR DRINKS. I've never been so upset. 

I'm a young professional and so are my friends. We aren't troublemakers nor do I take joy in writing bad reviews. 

Please don't support this establishment!!
author: Ivan C.

description: My wife and I spent a long weekend in San Francisco and ate at Bix Saturday night. The food was great, the service was great and the ambiance was very nice. We highly recommend Bix.
author: Andrew G.

description:
Finally got a chance to check this place out.  Restaurant is located  close to the Bubble Lounge.  Perk: they have valet parking.

Two story building with an airy ambiance, 40's style with jazz music playing in the background.  Elegant and classic.  There was a hiccup with my reservations which kind of upset me knowing that I specifically came here to celebrate a special occasion.  I requested their best table and ended up sitting next to the kitchen entrance. 

Right away, our server knew I was disturbed and immediately remedied the situation by offering us a free appetizer and dessert of our choice.  That made me feel better.

In a nutshell, the food was exquisite. Come here if you want quality of food versus quantity.  It's about tasting each and every bite and by the time your finished with your plate, you are more than full. 

We ordered the following:

Appetizers - 
Potato Pillows: 4 mini bite size tater tots with a bit of cavier on top.  Light, crispy, and undenialby delicious.

Chilled Foi Gras with strawberries - yes, I know it's inhumane to  force feed a duck and before it's banned, I decided to try it! OMG!!! IT'S SINFUL!!!  The best duck pate hands down! The texture was soo creamy and it tasted like butter.  It was incredible!

Main dishes -
Fresh Fish of the day - Salmon. Moist and tender, seasoned, and topped with finely chopped onions and relish (I think) which gave it a bit of a tart taste. It complimented the fish very nicely.

Grilled duck - tasted like steak and SUPER TENDER.  

Side order-
French fries with truffle oil - dangerous. I couldn't get enough of it.

Dessert: 
Bananas Foster with Dark Rum and vanilla ice cream.  This was probably my least favorite only because I was sooo stuffed, I couldn't bare to take more than one bite.  

Drinks are made right - with perfection.  Our server was impeccable!  It was the best quality dinner experience I've had in a very long time. =)
author: Diana M.

description:
A truly hidden gem in an unexpected alleyway.  Cherylynn N. made an 8pm reservation here for our party of three for Friday, March 26, 2010. 

AMBIANCE:  As we walked in, this place looked fantastic!  The restaurant is bigger than what it appears from the outside.  You're greeted by the hostess area and a little beyond that is a full and large bar.  The restaurant gives off a 1940s retro theme and even has a live band.  We got lucky and had a table upstairs where we were able to overlook the restaurant as well as the bar area.  This is not a quiet conversation restaurant, do not expect to speak quietly.

FOOD:
-Steak Tartare ($13.95) - I NEVER eat anything raw, but it looked good and for once, I tried something new and liked it!  The steak tartare is freshly prepared at your table and comes in with small pieces of crispy toasts. (photo)

-Dungeness Crab Rolls ($15.75) - I will admit that I thought it was going to look differently and I was quite surprised when it came out looking like a cut up sandwich, but once I bit into the roll, it was delicious!  It did taste similar to a crab salad sandwich, but the crab and the bread it came on perfectly complimented each other.  (photo)

-Marrow Bones ($11.75) - YUM!  Four marrow bones were presented on a plate along with a parsley, shallot and caper salad, crispy toasts, and an upside down shot glass which contained salt.  I've never seen bone marrow on a menu and I recommend this as a starter! (photo)

-Fresh Maine Lobster Spaghetti with Lobster Cream ($39.95) - If you're a pasta lover like myself, I HIGHLY recommend trying this dish.  Generous portions of perfectly cooked lobster is mixed in with the noodles with a light cream sauce.

SERVICE:  A little higher than decent.  As two of us sat down and waited for our other friend to arrive, it took our waiter a couple minutes to acknowledge us.  It seemed as if there were only two waiters upstairs, split among 10 tables or so.

PARKING:  Free metered street parking after 6:00pm but often quite difficult to score, valet parking at BIX is available through the Gold Street alley, and there are many paid lots around the Broadway Street area.

Cash and credit cards accepted.
author: Nicole S.

description:
We had date night at BIX.  We had reservation at 9 and got mezzanine seats facing the bar and live music.  The crowd was so loud that we couldn't hear the live music until about 930pm when the crowd dispersed.  

Ordered wine and started with Salmon tartare.  The rye bread was of perfect crunch and the salmon just dissolved in the mouth.  It is a must try!
For entree, ordered lobster spaghetti (small) and black truffle cheese burger with truffle fries.  The spaghetti had too much of cherry tomatoes and didn't feel the hint of basil and jalapenos.  Got the burger medium well done.  Very tasty and had perfect smoked flavor.  

Finished the night with Banana Foster with dark rum and vanilla ice cream.  They served the ice cream and then poured the syrup.  Couldn't stop digging in to the tasty delight =)

We found plenty of parking on Washington St and Pacific ave.  From Jan 2013 street parking will have meters running.. boo :(

Might want to go there just for drinks and salmon tartare!
author: Hema K.

description:
Bix is an amazing dining experience from start to end. I'ma gonna break it down for you why.  So, ready for this story? I get news I need to be in SF for work during my bf's 30th birthday, he elects to come along for the ride all the way from New Jersey. I fret for a week before going - what are we going to do for his special day? I don't know SF and I really want to do something special for him. What's a girl to do? Thank the mighty lord everyone in my office in NYC is from SF so they all give me their tips and insight, I have been scouring Yelp for hours at this point.  Finally, I look to a cool chica in my office, I like her styz, I think she understands my concept (memorable, dude dinner, not too fancy but EPIC). She replied confidently BIX. I went for it.  I told the reservationist that it was my man's 30th bday so make it epic.

That is what they did. We got a great table right near the piano and live vocalist (love me some jazz while I dine) on the first floor. There was a little card to my man wishing him well on his birthday. (Handwritten might I add). The decor is like 1930s NYC speakeasy/prohibition dining hall.  With some fantastic art on the walls, and a dark wooded bar perfect for a Manhatten or Sazerac.  The restaurant itself is 2 floors; the top floor overlooking the diners on the first floor. Our waiter, whose name I forgotten was amazing. Truly. He was a true professional, friendly and just all around swell guy.

We started off with drinks off their cocktail menu, and moved on to the ceviche and the foie gras to start. The ceviche was so fresh and they plated everything separately as we were sharing so, there was enough sauce and fish for both of us.  The roll they provide was hot and fresh, seemingly right out of the oven. The foie gras was more of a pate that came with some delicious baguette. I enjoyed both thoroughly and would order again.

We moved onto the main plates. We were full at this point but we elected to go with the flounder with crab meat and the famous BIX truffle burger with truffled cheese and truffle fries. Holy truffle right? Both were amazing. I did like the fish better with its rich and buttery meat with the added flavor of the crab but, the burger was one of the best burgers I have ever had (for $30 it better be).  But, for reals, the truffle cheese and the truffle in the burger combo was amazing. I sometimes feel like when one orders something truffly one never truly taste the truffle; this was not the case with this burger. Every bite had this crazy intense flavor, which I am chalking up to yes, you guessed it, the truffle.

Tipsy from copious amount of wine and drinks, our server provides us the dessert menu in which we ordered. I completely forgot what we ate, wow the wine definitely got me but, there was a candle and it was awesome. I believe it was a chocolate mouse type desert. And though I don't remember it, I do remember being in love with it at that particular moment.

Overall, this place might not be the fanciest restaurant in SF but, it may be one of the most memorable. My bf and I felt special, we were happy and super duper in love and the food was amazing. Isn't that what life is supposed to be about?
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
We had a bet to decide whether Branzino was a luchador or an old timey magician. 
We were both wrong. It's Italian sea bass. 

It had a smokey taste which I really liked and truffle potatoes that came as a side. 

The Lobster Spaghetti was fabulous. 
You absolutely must have the truffle deviled eggs, but also try the meatball appetizer and the prosciutto wrapped mozzarella (amazing!)

I ordered a St. Germaine cocktail to accompany an already highly-indulgent dinner, and was pleasantly surprised with its flexibility as a cocktail. 

We waited half an hour after our reservation time but received appetizers and dessert as a very overdone apology. 
I have never been treated so well in SF as I was here.

10/10, would go again.
author: Candice T.

description:
yea this place is good! 
I loved the lobster spaghetti! not what i expected but very tasty! the "potato pillows" were just hash browns with caviar on top. nothing extravagent 
The pork belly sandwiches were tasty little starters. The wagyu was amazing! I wanted to eat two of those plates! So good!
Now onto the dessert. The chocolate bread pudding was just OK. I kept hearing about how amazing this is and it will be one of the best bread puddings Ill have. But I differ. It was waaay too chocolatey and the carb part was a little on the bland side. 
I would definitely recommend Bix to anyone who wants a more intimate dinner, with a live piano artist playing, and wants a great experience!
author: Natasha I.

description:
Have always enjoyed dining here, however last night was a bit of a let down. Overall, the food was not up standard or to our liking and after sending our entree back and getting another dish we still weren't impressed and didn't finish our food. 

Additionally, the service wasn't up to par and we felt like more of an inconvenience rather than guests for the evening. There's so many wonderful restaurants in SF and this experience left us feeling like it's time to branch out. I wish Bix all the best!
author: Derwood A.

description:
Great food and great service all to the tune of Jazz music.

Martini's are mixed well. 
I recommend the Crab in the brich
author: Bradley M.

description:
Horrible service. Our waiter was irritable, aggressive, and rude.

He asked us if we wanted to order drinks, and we told him our drinks were being brought up from the bar. He grunted, as if to show us he was annoyed, and walked away. 

Our party was pretty talkative for the first 20 minutes or so and hadn't even glanced at the menu yet. So our waiter took it upon himself to adjust my boyfriend's menu super passive aggressively without saying a word. What?!

Later, when clearing our appetizer plates, he was being so forceful that he knocked over a full wine glass. Thank goodness my dad was holding onto it (in anticipation of this loose-cannon waiter). The wine spilled mostly on the ground and on the waiter's pants. Instead of apologizing, he mumbled "you're welcome" and stormed off seemingly to cool down. When he came back, my dad asked him to take it easy and told him that his aggressiveness was a bit overwhelming. The waiter fired back with sarcasm in his tone, saying "thank you sir, I am very calm."

As for the food. Meh. If you do happen to go, DON'T get the lobster spaghetti. Bland and with almost no lobster pieces.

Definitely not going back.
author: Morgan C.

description: Bix was awesome. Love the speak easy feel of having to walk/drive down an alley to get there. The service was excellent. The entire staff was friendly, very attentive and quick. The live jazz band gave the restaurant life and was very pleasing on the ears. The food was great. We had the meatballs and general tao style chicken for apps and they were good. For main courses, I had the lobster spaghetti and she had the hanger steak. Both were perfectly cooked and had great favor. Lastly for dessert had the bananas foster and wow, it was amazing. Overall, Bix is a great place to come for dinner. Recommend coming in business casual attire so you don't feel out of place though.
author: Tre M.

description:
Loved this place and can't wait to come back! Came with my husband and had a wonderful dinner. There was live music playing with a band, the lighting was dim and the service was great.

I had the lobster spaghetti as a main course which was delicious. We had firecracker shrimp and crab rolls for apps and chocolate brioche pudding for dinner. 

I'm so glad we went- I called a few days in advance and they were able to squeeze us in for reservations. Definitely worth the drive to SF!
author: Zainab B.

description:
Torn between 3 and 4 stars... ultimately I think it's not quite a good enough value for a full 4 star rating. When work pays (as they did for me), however, it probably gets to 4.

4 of us went for a late dinner. We had a reservation but were ~20 minutes late, and they couldn't seat us right away, which was fine. We had a drink at the bar while they prepared the table. Was somewhat annoying that we had to close out at the bar vs transferring the drink over to our table, but not a huge deal. I got the elixir 3 and it was very good - not too sweet and nicely balanced. One of my colleagues really enjoyed his old fashioned as well.

Pretty soon after we were seated, the waiter came over to describe the menu. Really nice guy and did a great job walking through the menu and offering recommendations, as well as describing the fish of the day. 

We ended up going with 5 starters: fried chicken, "ceviche", crab rolls, arancini, and deviled eggs. All were very good - the best in my eyes were the crab rolls and deviled eggs, though my colleagues liked the chicken and arancini more.

For mains, I ordered the lobster spaghetti, and others ordered the swordfish and wagyu. The lobster spaghetti was good though a little bland - think there were too many tomatoes, though the sauce itself was really nice, and the pasta was cooked perfectly. There was a good amount of lobster meat... though obviously I'd always want more! My colleague finished his swordfish very quickly so I think it was well received. The wagyu was apparently a bit fatty (both my colleagues complained about that), though I think still pretty good.

For desert, we shared the brioche bread pudding, cheesecake brulee, and chocolate cookies. They were all good though nothing was outstanding. The cookies were probably the best, but again, more in the "good" range than great.

Overall service was great and the ambiance was really nice as well with the live music. It's just hard to get past the $35+ for entrees and nearly $20 for some of the appetizers, especially if I were paying for this myself.
author: Rohan N.

description: I wish I knew about this tavern years ago because this is MY type of bar/resto. This is the very place I can really destress after work. Deviled eggs, potato pillows, cocktail meatballs with Keenan Cab Sauv is my formula for chillin'. Cap this with bananas foster and you will sleep with a smile on your face. Thank you Peter for being a sweet, efficient and friendly bartender. I heart BIX!
author: Reena C.

description:
Hmmm...I went to Bix a second time, and I don't know, I wasn't wow'ed like I was the first time.  First, it was steadily raining outside so the host asked if I would like him to hang my jacket.  He was sort of blase, didn't seem to care that he was going to put my wet umbrella on top of my jacket knowing that it would probably leave my jacket soaking...eh, I kept my umbrella separate with the heap of other umbrellas near the entrance.  

I had a glass of Malbec at the bar while I waited for my friend.  I thought I saw that it was $9 on the menu.  I must've read it wrong because I was charged $14.  Eh...

My friend came, and I told her about Bix' signature dish, chicken hash, and I was hoping they would have the spiced apple pie I had last time.  Turns out the apple pie is seasonal, more of a Fall dessert....ok....

We got some small dishes, plus some oysters.  The oysters were a-ok, kind of small, was probably because of the type of oysters.  We got the dungeness crab rolls (good), potato pillows (kind of like hashbrowns with creme fraiche and caviar on top - it was a-ok), and we split the short ribs with bone marrow, vegetables and toast (the short ribs were tender and tasty, the bone marrow was a thicker consistency than my friend was expecting, my first time eating it so I wasn't sure what to expect).  

The dessert was REALLY good though - banana foster with dark rum and vanilla ice cream.  Mmm!  This was memorable and was the highlight!  

All in all, it was an a-ok meal.  I definitely enjoyed the chicken hash I had last time, and they do know their desserts.  Service was good, and the live piano playing and singing downstairs was a nice touch.
author: Maile N.

description:
Every time someone tells me this place is good it's either:
1: because of the drinks/bar or 
2: Bc of the music. Other than that, I haven't heard anything good nor have I experienced it.

Came here last Friday for a fun night out with the fiancé at one of his 'favorite places'.

Bar: my martini was not good but I downed it anyways. I ask for extra dry/ that means no vermouth right?? His old fashion was great though. 

Service: sat promptly with a reservation upstairs. Service was excellent. 

Food: ordered bone marrow -weak- and steak tartar. I liked how they mixed it in front of us. Not my favorite. 

Fiancé ordered a rib eye, and they removed the bone??? They served it split in half? A $47 rib eye should be bone in. NEVER split in half? We complained about the presentation and they brought us a free dessert which almost made up for it. 

I ordered thier specialty friend chicken patties with goat cheese... I won't bore you, it was just plain horrible. 

Wine menu was over priced at well. I'd rather eat at the house of prime rib for half the price then go to bix again. 

My recommendation: stop by for a drink... Or dessert. Save your money and eat down the street.
author: Heather H.

description:
I took my girlfriend here on a surprise date and when the cab stopped at Gold st. she got a very big grin on her face.

You really might want to try the amazing Potato Pillows. They are quite simply the best tatter tots you will ever eat. As soon as you place them on your tongue they melt away. 

The Mai Tai is marvelous, we had two each. Absolutely delectable drinks with the perfect amount of Rum to Pineapple. 

Foi Gras was fabulous and the preserve the perfect touch.

The Short Rib and Duck were delicious. She really needs to comment on the duck as she would only share one small nibble. The Short Rib I cut with the side of my fork as my butter knife was too sharp. I'm having it again next time.

Men, please have a little respect for your lady and wear a jacket.

Total after including a well earned tip for top quality service:

$226.42
author: Justin S.

description: Excellent atmosphere, Live jazz is a treat (sometimes it is a little hard to hear) good food for the most part and definitely worth going to. The portions can be a little skimpy especially when you consider the price, but still a landmark in San Francisco and definitely amongst the premiere uniquely San Francisco eating establishments we have.
author: andrew c.

description:
Thanks you to everyone at Bix for making our wedding amazing.

Blake Tippet did a great job consulting with us on what we wanted. He was laid back in the planning but worked incredibly hard to make sure everything went smoothly. Every mark was hit.

Gene and the rest of the team also went above and beyond to make sure we and our guests were happy at all times.

Then there was the food. So good! The passed hors d'oeuvres were delicious. The three course dinner was also great. Our guests could not stop raving.

Our vendors coordinated directly with Blake which took pressure off of us.

We'd be happy to be a reference for anyone considering Bix for their wedding.

Thank you Bix!!
author: Alissa D.

description:
I walked out of this joint 10 pounds heavier. I'm serious, I looked like I was 5 months pregnant.

The place has an old hollywood feel. Pianist, jazz singer, high ceilings, dark wood paneling, dark burgundy color palette.

We were seated upstairs which I loved. Great veiw of the whole place without feeling like I was cramped. The ceiling was still way above my head even on the second floor. It felt more like a balcony seating rather than a 2nd floor, since it was open to see the 1st floor.

The place was bustling for a wednesday night at 8pm. They had a bar that sat about 12-15 people and few tables on the bottom floor. The open stairs led to a 2nd floor balcony style that had about 20 tables/booths as well. 

I even thought that this venue would be a great place to have a private party! Piano included! 

Now to the food. Potato Pillows.... OMG orgasmic, it was a fancy tater tot. Who doesn't love tater tots? it was perfectly fried, crispy on the outside and I didn't even taste or feel the oil that is was fried in. You know how sometimes when you eat something fried, you can feel the oil seep out of the morsel of food into your mouth and you're disgusted cause you swear you want to believe that you're eating something semi healthy. BUT when you feel that oil in your mouth you know you're going to see the extra cottage cheese on your thighs the next day? well none of that with these potato pillows. AND the Creme Friache was the the perfect balance. I was a bit sad that they didn't put more caviar on it but I'll take what they give me. This is a must try dish!

Foie Gras was refrigerated and served with a grilled bread. Not a crostini but just bread. It was lightly oiled and it went well with the foie gras. It wasn't the best foie gras dish I've had but it was still good. This was the moment when i wished I had ordered the bone marrow. 

My bf and i shared the NY Steak. Medium. Came with fries... it was perfect. If i knew it was going to come with fries I would've asked for it to have been the truffle fries. We were contemplating on the truffle fries and the Brussels Sprouts. We went for the non fried veggie.  Major regret again. The brussels sprouts came out charred, not good. The steak also came with an arugula salad! (my favorite leaf).

The steak was tender, perfectly pink and no A1 needed lol.

We also had the bread pudding. it was good, not the greatest or maybe it was but i was too full to enjoy it. 

They serve illy espresso there as well! 

This place is an amazing date place.... the food is reasonably priced and tasty. 

The ambiance is great and music is JAZZ! 

If i'm ever in the area again, I wanna try the bone marrow, steak tartare, lobster spaghetti and their truffle burger!
author: Violet T.

description:
My First review on Yelp, I had to start with one of my favorites! 
I have been coming here on and off for years, and I feel like I'm going back in time to a golden age of fine dining with a solo pianist belting out soothing tunes. 
There is nothing else in SF like Bix, an Supper Club of the fist order.
The waiters are the best in the city, and I bet the best paid as this is at the upper end of everything.
author: Leonard H.

description: Great experience worth trying. I must say the Potato Pillows were highly overrated. Four tater tots with a small line of sour cream and even less caviar was tasty but not worth $18.  The rest of the meal, however, was very good. I had the duck breast and my friend has steak. Both were cooked perfectly and both veggies were flavorful and good sized portions. For a special occasion this was fun. Just don't plan on intimate conversation. Fun and loud.
author: Jill A.

description:
Came for the Friday Lunch with a colleague.  BIX is located a few blocks from the Transamerica on an alley way.  Once you walk in, you are immediately transported back to another era - opulent furniture and smartly dressed servers.
Food was decent.  I ordered the burger medium rare and twice it was served rare.  I sent it back and had to wait for a good 15+ minutes for another.  The replacement was also very 'red'.  I wanted to send it back but had to head back to the office.
I ate it with gusto but left the center raw pieces of the burger behind on the platter.
My colleague ordered a salad and asked for grilled chicken.  At first they said that they can honor the request but I pointed out that another salad has grilled chicken.  The server was surprised of such comment and said that we would ask the chef.  He came back and told us that the chef can honor it.  Uh.....why would it be an issue? 
Made no sense but whatever.
Overall, food is basic American and service is a tad stiff.
I will definitely come back for dinner with there is live jazz music.
author: Veritas V.

description: Expensive but delicious. I had a multiple course dinner here on New Year's Eve a few years ago and it is still one of the top restaurants at which I've ever eaten. The portions were small but the food melts in your mouth. So good!
author: Kayla C.

description:
Bix is FABULOUS! Everything from how it's located in an alleyway to the authentic "speak-easy" era decor! I took my grandpa to Bix to celebrate his 85th birthday!!! The wait staff were really amazing to my grandpa. They gave us the best table in the house and even presented my grandpa with a birthday card! The food was pretty good except they were kind of heavy handed with the sauces. Unfortunately, I can't remember what we both had but I do know we had different fish dishes that both had a tad too much sauce. However, the truffle French fries were divine. 

This place has amazing ambiance. Around 8:30 (at least on Friday nights) a jazz trio performs. It was wonderful! Go to. Bix to get dressed up and experience a great evening out in San Francisco!
author: Amba A.

description: Great spot for drinks and a good dinner spot to take out of town guests.  Loved the bone marrow, trout was awesome, and tasty oysters!
author: James S.

description: I went here on Saturday. When I got there the ambience had a jazzy feel and very dimly lighted. I had reservations for 10 people and when we got there the table wasn't ready...even though we told Bix Restaurant ahead of time that its a surprise dinner for a friend. So it took an extra 20mins to get the table set up. The dinner menu is limited as well as the drink menu. I ordered the ceviche dish as an appetizer. I wasn't satisfied with the way it tasted. For the amount that the ceviche was...it wasn't worth ordering again. For my main course I ordered the chicken hash. As I took my first bite of the chicken hash the food had a piece of hair in it. The downfall of that part is I couldn't see what I was eating because it was very dimly lit. :/ My date ordered the truffle cheeseburger. That dish was amazing. Everything was perfect on that dish plus great sauces!
author: Marjorie F.

description: Love this place, tucked down an alley in a historic building. Great atmosphere and the food is fantastic.  On my list permanently for business dinners.
author: Matt R.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the country! Every thing I've ever eaten here has been great. The cocktails are stiff and the ambiance is perfect. Great for business dinner, date, or eating with the in-laws. The entrance is in an alley which is so San Francisco. Highly recommend trying this place.
author: Oscar P.

description:
Oh Bix, why did I wait so long to give you a try?  I figured you were more of a tourist spot, where the food and service take a back seat to the atmosphere.  Boy, was I wrong.  

We celebrated a birthday there, and the attentive, polished staff went above and beyond to make it special, from giving us the best table in the house, to the hand-written birthday card, to the warm birthday wishes from every staff member we encountered.  

The food was equally impressive.  Everything was well-prepared, expertly seasoned, and delicious.  There was nothing that we didn't like or were even neutral on.  My favorite tastes of the evening were the Pisco Sour, with a single, huge bitters-infused ice cube, Smoked Trout Salad, Sea Bass, Potatoes in Duck Fat (!!!) and Bananas Foster.  The freshly-baked French baguette-style dinner rolls were also fantastic.
author: Linda S.

description:
Decided to have a dressy night out with a couple of friends and one recommended Bix.  Loved the food and drink.  The Satsuma Driver was refreshing and the Blood Orange Margarita was tasty.  We started with the Potato Pillows with Crème Fraîche and American Sturgeon Caviar, Deviled Eggs with Truffles, Radish and Chives, Dungeness Crab Rolls in Brioche with Meyer Lemon Aioli, Chilled Foie Gras with Spiced Kumquats and a caesar salad.   A lot of food for three but what the hell!  It might be sacrilege to say this but the potato pillows reminded me of fancy, gourmet tater tots.  Truly delicious. The spiced kumquat sauce was so yummy, I asked for extra hot rolls so we could continue to enjoy it.

For our entree, two of us ordered the Bix Chicken Hash with Mascarpone & Cherry Tomato Sauce and one ordered the Grilled Duck Paillard with Spring Onions, Fingerling Potatoes and Foie Gras Sauce.  Two orders of the Creamed Organic Bloomsdale Spinach were shared by the table.  All of it was delicious.

For dessert, we shared the macerated strawberries with meringue pieces that was the special dessert that night and the Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding.  Both came with a huge dollop of cream.  Devoured by the table.

The jazz started in the middle of the meal and was lovely.  Before the set started, the noise could get a bit loud.

I would have given this experience 4 stars but had to take away a star because our party was seated at the only freestanding table up on the 2nd level (all the others on this level were booths) and it was next to the service door.  There was a draft each time the door was used.  This was especially felt by the person at our table wearing a turtleneck!  We asked to be moved but the manager said the restaurant was booked solid and his response instead was to raise the temperature.  

It didn't help.  

For the rest of the meal, I also watched a guest at a nearby booth drape her jacket over her shoulder.  Another thing that didn't help was Bix was only half full when we made the request.  We could easily have been moved to a booth at that time especially since later they would seat parties of two into ones that could have easily fit our party.
author: J. P.

description: Loved loved loved Bix. Delicious food, great service and all to the sound of jazz. The location and ambiance of Bix was perfect for a nice dinner with the Mr, we enjoyed it all from start to finish. We'll definitely be coming back.
author: Debbie N.

description:
Update:

I first went to Bix on my second date with my boyfriend and, as my original review shows, I was impressed. On our second visit, I'm even more impressed. 

I'm updating my review to make two points:

1) Service is even better than I remembered. We arrived an hour early for a reservation and the hostess not only seated us, she gave us one of the best tables in the house--a corner booth where we had a nice view of the piano player and our fellow diners. 

2) This seems to be a big date place for old people. Seriously, with our expansive view of the lower dining room, we watched two semi-awkward dates between silver-haired couples. But don't let this discourage you. I still maintain that this is a great place for a guy to impress a girl. And not just an elderly girl. At least the younger guy won't have to worry about his date checking out the other diners, right?
author: Susan S.

description:
The AWESOME.......
Truffled deviled eggs- this is a must have if you go! totally worth it (4 pieces)

Oysters - Tastes extremely fresh

Dungeoness crab roll -  dugeoness crab on tops of cubes of tasty croissant-like bread. nothing too fancy, but done well and very clean and simple taste to it (4 pieces)

Swordfish entree - the blood oranges and vinaigrette is incredible with the fish. portion is decent.

The OKAY....
Caesar Salad - my date really liked it but to me is was just ok. whole romaine lettuce leaves with big chunky crutons and dressing....meh

Lobster Bisque - Lackluster...not enough flavor and not as I'd hoped. Not terrible but not one I'd recommend. Would have rather had more oysters lol 

Boxcar cocktail - I was hoping it would be more smoky. Again, not bad, not great.
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Bix has an intimate and classy feel to it.
We came on a Saturday evening and enjoyed the jazz trio as we sipped on single malt scotches waiting for our dinners. 
The atmosphere is reticent of the 1920's without the kitschy parts. It is an intimate understated classy Art Deco atmosphere. 

We had the Sea Bass and the Lobster Spaghetti. The Sea Bass stole the show but both meals were delicious. The service was excellent as well. Perfect for a date night.
author: Gayla H.

description: My new favorite spot! Came here with my boyfriend for his birthday. Delicious food, excellent ambience and service. Our server was a very attentive and friendly male. There was live music which created a fresh and classy vibe. The dessert was out of this world!!! -the banana foster was not only delicious but beautifully displayed. This place is definitely one of a kind I would definitely return on an occasion- a bit pricey but worth every penny.
author: Glenda G.

description: Celebrated my best friends birthday here and the food was excellent!!! Perfect ambiance!! Will be going back.
author: Wendy D.

description: Live music, cool and calm atmosphere, great service and amazing food.... Doesn't get much better than Bix:)
author: Billy B.

description: Can't say much about this spot, but I can say I dug it. Stopped in late one night and enjoyed an old-fashioned while a couple guys serenaded the crowd with smooth jazz sounds. I'm sure it's great for a meal, but those looking to grab a quick drink and soak in some hot atmosphere would do well to stop in for a spell.
author: Anthony A.

description:
Stopped in for after-work drinks and stayed for dinner. Incredibly pleased with the location, atmosphere, and the ability to hold a group conversation despite the blaring piano downstairs (ask to dine upstairs).

DRINKS:
+The Perfect Manhattan: which, yes, it is pretty perfect. Go for it if you're a fan of rye.
+Russian River 2008 Syrah Maranet: great table wine that paired fairly well with the wagyu.

EATS:
+Mixed plate appetizer with one-bite wonders of:
-Smoked Salmon on toasted rye with a green tomato marmalade: strong smoked-salmon flavor; perfect if that's your thing.
-Pork belly "bánh mì" burger with cucumber a slice jalapeno: a perfect kick with a delicious pork belly bite.
-Deviled eggs with truffles a sliver of radish: clearly, the table favorite. We could've ordered four dozen and would've been OK with it.
-House mozzarella skewers wrapped in prosciutto: like a savory lollipop and surprisingly delicious.
+American wagyu bavette with grilled and pickled ramps over a potato puree: requested medium rare, but it was more medium to medium well. That's OK as it was delicious anyway.
+Lobster spaghetti with cherry tomatoes, jalapeños and basil: had a bite of this and everything about it was fresh and pleasing. Heard no complaints from the folks inhaling it (and I don't blame them).
+Duck breast with stuffed morel mushrooms, fava beans, served over a citrus confit: I tried a bite and still can't get over my anti-poultry tastebuds, but my dining companion had zero complaints.

DESSERT:
+Bananas Foster: dark rum with vanilla ice cream. Turned into liquid gold within a few minutes and was cloyingly sweet. Fortunately, that wasn't a problem for the person who'd ordered it. 
+Warm chocolate brioche bread pudding: I asked for a scoop of ice cream in place of the whipped cream. It was basically chocolate soup in a bowl. Warm and incredibly sweet, but quickly tiresome after a few bites.
+Chocolate mouse served with a raspberry coulis: far less sweet than the bread pudding with a good amount of tartness from the coulis. Winner winner!

The food all came out in a flash; so much so that we were all stunned. It may have been the slow night, but it pleased us all regardless. A perfect spot for client dinner/drinks or a cozy dinner date. 

Or both... if you're into that.
author: Adena B.
