The bartender poured a grenacha for my entree, and it was the best pairing I have ever experienced, complementing the smokey duck and woodsy morels. 

I was stuffed, but powered through a lovely strawberry rhubarb tart with salted caramel & almond sorbet. I also had a small taste of the pineapple sorbet, and it was perfectly light and semi-sweet. 

Absolutely wonderful evening.
author: Jenn C.

description: Don't let this hidden gem fool you, this place is amazing. My fiancé and I had made reservations and were seated immediately as we arrived. Our waiter wasn't the friendliest but was very prompt and attentive. Yes the food is quite pricey but well worth it. The atmosphere and ambiance goes well with the live jazz music playing throughout the evening. I had an overall great experience and would highly recommend.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Finding Bix can be a bit of a challenge, it's on a small discrete alley (Gold Street) between Pacific and Jackson Streets. Once you do you will be mesmerized by the old school decor, jazz band playing on the first floor and great renditions of classic American fare.  Their dining room could easily be the backdrop for a Hollywood gangster movie set in the '30's and '40s.  

One of their signature appetizers are the Potato Pillows, rectangular tator tots with a dollop of caviar on top, a great way to start off the meal.  The steak tartare was one of the best I've tasted, perfectly seasoned.  Their chilled Foie Gras appetizer was delicious and I usually only like the seared version.  Of all the entrees that I tasted at our table the standout was definitely the American Kobe Bavette Steak, cooked to a perfect medium rare.  

On a Friday night Bix was packed, including all the seats in the bar area. So do make reservations, unless you don't mind standing around a while for a table to open up.
author: Wei K.

description: Nice and laid back place to dine. Kind of an old school vibe. Felt relaxed here. They have live music but not too loud where you can't talk. It's a perfect date place. Food was good and service was quick and friendly. They had a good wine collection. I would love to come here more if I was in the area.
author: Kenny G.

description:
A hidden Gem! Nice ambiance with a large dining area and live jazz music, decent service, and great, flavorful, tasty food.
The fried tomato appetizer was very tasty, followed by a Wagyu steak and Veal chop that were just perfect, and to top it all off, the panna cotta was heavenly! I can still taste it in my mouth :D
Will definitely go back ..
author: Shirin E.

description:
I recently went to BIX with 2 other girl friends and we had pretty high hopes with the amazing reviews we saw on Yelp and fancy decor as soon as we stepped in. I think the food itself leaves more to be desired. We ordered sidecars to start since we'd seen that drink was highly recommended on 7x7. It was your typical martini; nothing special. 

For food, we had their salmon tartare to start and then shared the lobster spaghetti and duck breast with some brussel sprouts and truffle fries on the side. The tartare is really small, but decent. No spectacular flavors though. Entrees were decently sized though the seasoning was a bit too salty for me. I drank a lot of water that night. You can't go wrong with brussel sprouts and truffle fries, so those were pretty standard.

What was nice about the restaurant was the live music that they started playing about half way through the night. The service was really good and there was no pressure to order immediately. Location is a bit odd with it being down a dark alley, but I suppose that helps with the jazz club vibe.

Overall, I think it was a bit too pricey for my taste, but worth a shot if you like a jazzy ambience with fancy menu options, but pretty chill vibe. I was wearing workout attire and no one batted an eye!
author: RJ C.

description:
A year later, and I'm still impressed with this place.  I love that it's this random restaurant in an alley.  The live piano music and the lighting makes this place really romantic for a date :-)

The last time I came here, I was in love with the steak tartare.  I seriously still remembered it a year later.  So obviously, when I came back, I ordered it again and it did not disappoint.  For my entree, I ordered the duck breast. The tenderness was great, and the flavor was nice.  Not the best duck breast I've had in the city  but I would say it's up there.  The bf ordered the lobster spaghetti - it's a lobster based spaghetti (i.e., no cream or no tomato sauce).  I thought it was a great dish.  Very light but flavorful.

No room for dessert this time - that just leaves us a reason to come back again :)
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I have been to Bix a few times, went with a visiting colleague from across the pond.  

Anyway, the food at bix is usually pretty good.  This time was no exception, I got the duck and he got the salmon.  The salmon was definitely the better of the two dishes, the duck was just ok.  the cocktails were excellent, so were the fries.

The service is just ok, we waited forever for our server to take our drink order and then forever for the check.  I will likely be back to Bix, as you can get in with short notice and its a good meal.
author: Michael S.

description:
Fantastic atmosphere and delicious Casear salad! The pork chop was good, but it was a little too lean for my taste.

PRO TIP: If you're dining with 4 or less, request the middle table on the second floor. Hands down the best seat in the house.
author: Alfonzo J.

description:
I've been meaning to come here for some time. Overall enjoyable evening at Bix for our team holiday dinner. It's rare to find a true American restaurant in the city these days where people can dress up and maintains the old school "roaring 20s in SF" vibe. Some items were good, but nothing that stood out as superb.

Food: It's truffle season in Italy, and they have truffles at Bix! We did family style for apps so we could sample more of them. Pro-tip: you don't have to get multiple orders if you want more than 1 order, but 2 orders is too many if you are ordering many apps (most things are prepared with 4 items, but they can make it 5, 6, 7, etc.). We enjoyed the potato pillows, oysters on the half, braised meatballs, deviled eggs, and the fresh sourdough bread. Lobster spaghetti was good, but the ribeye seemed better.

Things we enjoyed: Ambiance was lively with a live singer & jazz band, sizable wine selection with some of California's finest, and most of the meal was pleasant (timing, taste, presentation). Traditional offerings without all the fusion & unnecessary accoutrements. Prices were also surprisingly reasonable. 

Areas for improvement: the table-side service across staff was really lacking attention to detail. The water was never refreshed throughout our two hour meal, servers were shoving platters in our face at untimely moments, (it was busy, but there was clearly a more non-invasive manner of dropping off the plates) and the music was a bit loud.

i'd definitely give this place another chance w/ a group looking for a casual yet upscale restaurant and classic menu items.
author: Tammy H.

description:
WOW. Fine dining like no other.

Smooth, nice atmosphere where you feel relaxed with the dim lights and some conversation noise from the bar while the guy is playing a piano during dinner.

Ordered:
1. truffle fries - these are the best truffle fries i've ever had. Some fries i can compare are the truffle fries from Umami burger, but these are by far better with the nice creamy sauce you get to dip them with. 

2. potato pillows - delicious bite size potato with that smooth caviar 

3. brandt steak - WOW, do not get fooled by the portion size because it's actually perfect portions. The potato side was so good. The steak is cooked medium and perfect for consumption. Some of the best steak i've had, almost as good as kobe NY steak

4. full entree of lobster spaghetti - nice pepper taste and a bit of an asian fusion style to it. Fresh and easily chowed up

5. strawberry sorbet - this was the ICING ON THE CAKE! by far THE BEST SORBET EVER HAD IN MY LIFE. it was a very small sample size to try and I AM SO HAPPY i got to taste it. the strawberry puree part was so good. damn i am craving some RIGHT NOW as i type this

Everything went down great with a nice Anchor Steam while I was at it!

Service: I cant seem to remember the waitress' name off the top of my head but it was by far the best service I have ever had and that is no exaggeration. Regardless of restaurant or service from Louis Vuitton, this service tops it all. She definitely deserved a good tip! Big ups to Blake for providing a great dinner service too. 


I cant wait to find another chance to come eat here again. I would be satisfied if i was just here with a beer and that strawberry sorbet ALL NIGHT!
author: Kenny L.

description:
I have always wanted to go here, but never got around to it until recently. I decided to take The Boyfriend here for his 22nd birthday and hoped for the best.

I read all the negative reviews and I have to say, based on the service I received I find it hard to believe that they may have experienced such horrible service. 

We arrived at 7:10 (our reservations were at 7:30) and used the valet service. I loved driving up that crazy alley and seeing the Bix sign. I also loved seeing the Valet guy totally rock out to his music on his ipod. Upon seeing us though, he was totally professional and drove my Bimmer off to safety. 

When we walked into the restaurant, the hostess was super nice when I told her we have reservations a bit later and didn't anticipate coming this early. She told us it wasn't a problem and led us to our table. The Boyfriend smiled; at our table with a birthday card from Bix! The hostess asked to take my coat and wished The Boyfriend a happy birthday and left.

A few minutes later, a smiling waiter appeared, wished The Boyfriend a happy birthday and had polite chit-chat with him and asked if he wanted a celebration drink. He declined at first but ended up ordering a Meyer Lemon Collins. 

We started our meal with the Lamb Burgers which had a faint Mediterranean flair to them which I loved, since I grew up with a mother obsessed with Greek food. For our main dish, I ordered the Bix Burger and the boyfriend had the Kobe Steak which was a hit with both of us. It was very tender and spiced just right. My burger was fantastic and cooked medium rare (which apparently is hard to do, since many establishments never get it right). 

We ended the night with the chocolate bread pudding which came with two candles. 

Our service was fantastic. We weren't bothered and we could actually hold a conversation with each other without being worried that our waiter would come and interrupt. Often times, he came just to fill up my water glass (I had sparkling water) and left. The service was just right for this level of restaurant. If you want FAST service, go to IHOP.

This sort of place is is for people who want to enjoy their date and meal. 

When we left, the hostess wished The Boyfriend 'Happy Birthday' once more and even the manager came out and asked how our meal was and if everything was perfect for the birthday boy. 

The Boyfriend and I were the youngest people in there that night by at least 5-8 years but our service wasn't lacking because of it.

To top the night off, I saw the Valet guy once again rocking out to his music and actually seemed very gracious when I gave him a tip. 

This is certainly a place I would love to eat at again!
author: Genny H.

description:
I have always enjoyed BIX in the past and have sent many people there over the last 10-15 years, but I will not be back. The appetizers were all very good and the swordfish was exellent - tender and extremely moist.  One of my guests asked to have his blackened which the kitchen did without hesitation.  For a high-volume restaurant, I have always been surprised by the excellent quality of the food.  As good as the fish and apps were, the caesar salad is less than what I would expect at Applebee's.  If you are going to serve one, it should be more than a few leaves of romaine with some dressing drizzled over the top.  Perhaps tableside with an option for anchoive, although Julia Child would disagree.  

This is a fun place to have a good martini and a gregar with friends.  My problem was that I was having a business dinner with a party of 12.  We arrived on time but were told that we could not be seated until all 12 of us were there, even though 9 of us had been waiting/drinking in the bar.  The hostess was so rude about it, that I would have left on the spot if I wasn't with clients.  The bar is always a bit crowded (and fun) but this group wanted to sit and start ordering apps etc.  Finally I was handed off to another host and he begrudingly sat us - after I insisted that all 12 of us would be there.  Bottom line: there are so many great restaurants in town that I go where I am treated like a customer - not a dollar sign.  When I'm prepared to drop $1500-$2000 for dinner, I don't need attitude from a hostess.
author: Oscar M.

description:
The best restaurant in San Francisco - need I say more? 

Eat here. Trust me.

Thank me later. ;-)
author: Farnaz K.

description:
1.5 stars

I came to this place with lots of excitement it had been booked marked for more than a year, it's too bad it could live up to my expectations.

I'm usually not one to really complain about bad service but when the bad service messes with the food...

So the waiter comes to take me and my cousin's order he looks me in the eye and I wait for him to bring out his pen and paper. Instead of bringing out paper to take the order down he puts his hands behind his back and says go ahead condescendingly. 

Before I elaborate about what happens next can somebody please help me understand what the deal is with waiters not taking down your order with a pen and paper? Do they think that people are impressed that they don't take the order down because I've never thought to myself "wow that guy is the man because he can remember my order in his head" so just get the effing pen and paper man!

So I think everybody knows what happens next we order and before he even leaves he already mentions something about the salmon tartare which we didn't order, so already we have to correct him. Strike 1.

To start off the potato pillows with caviar comes out along with the house made mozzarella, the pillows are pretty good but no where can you taste any caviar as for the mozzarella it was pretty good but they give you four lollipop sized pieces that's it. 

As for the entree I ordered the bix burger(med rare) with the truffle fries and my cousin ordered the black truffle burger(med). Of course mine was med with hardly any red on the inside of the meat pattie and my cousin's a perfect med rare. Strike 2.

And the final topper was I ordered the truffle fries but just got the reg fries. Strike 3.

I don't know maybe the food could be good if your waiter doesn't get in the way of it, who knows but I won't be going back in my lifetime. Actually they don't get 1.5 stars they deserve just the single star, I'm getting mad writing this review!
author: Greg T.

description: Great spot! Went here with my girlfriend for my bday. really liked the jazz music and the food was awesome
author: Alec H.

description:
Harkening the speakeasy vibe of the 30's, this (literally) hidden gem of a venue is in the hard-to-find heart of Jackson Square. My cabbie didn't even know how to find the little alleyway entrance on Gold. 

Upon arrival, I was greeted by a friendly hostess and beelined straight to the bar, where the focus is clearly classics (Manhattan) and stiff drinks (Gimlet, straight up). The bar snacks are adequate (pretzel/chex mix), but the dinner is where the food is the focus. Or, tries to be the focus.

The brussels sprouts - one of my recent favorites - were soggy and overly acidic. The Truffle burger was a great concept (served open face), but felt more like a 'salted truffle burger.' Way, way, way too much salt. Their fries are solid - served with house ketchup and ranch, good move there. . .and the steak frites was serviceable.

In fact, the food is a bit subpar but it's outweighed by the intrinsic coolness of the locale. I had an enjoyable time because I was with great company, and I highly advise you patronize, if only for a couple drinks before moving on to somewhere with better food.
author: Evan L.

description: Best restaurant we visited in San Francisco! The food was phenomenal and was only further accented by the sexy atmosphere and jazz music.  A must on your list for dinner in San Fran.  Be sure to make a reservation, especially on the weekend.  The Truffle Burger & Chicken Hash knocked our socks off!
author: Erin R.

description:
This is my "go-to" spot in the city when I am sick of tourists, want to remember why I live in San Francisco, craving a great cocktail and want great food.  I have been here a lot and it never disappoints.  But I do Bix a little differently and I think that's why I love it.  Below are my rules which I promise will make you put BIX at the top of your list.

Rules:

1.  ALWAYS sit at the bar.  The bartenders have been there a long time, they know what they are talking about and will tell you what to order...listen to them.  The tables are too formal and full of corporate-types...avoid if possible for a better time at the bar. 

2.  The wine list is great and their selection of bourbons and ryes are top-notch..keep it simple and enjoy the libations

3.  Try the roasted bones....so freakin' hot that you need oven mits to transfer them to your plate but always a greasy and fatty crowd-pleaser.

4.  Stay for live music - recently saw the guy who did all the old "school house rock" songs....but the jazz is always fun


Not much more to say about this place....I do think that people do Bix the wrong way and try to compare to other more formal restaurants...this is a place where you drink and eat at the bar and listen to the music....no waiters, table-cloths or high-brow service needed.

CR
author: Chim R.

description: BIX has a long history and reputation, but this is a restaurant whose ship has sailed. I had business dinner last evening. Had I not been so engaged in the conversation, I would have sent the food back. I had Arctic Char that was over cooked, dry and tepid at serving. The side vegetables on the plate were cold, along with the sauce. The presentation was inelegant to say the least. My wife had swordfish which she says was well-prepared, but which I did not sample in the setting of the dinner. The Bananas Foster was good, but did not compensate for a meal that overall across the 6 guests was mediocre. We had a table on the upper level in the back corner which reduced the noise level, but it was pretty loud nonetheless. I will not go back.
author: Kenneth B.

description:
Finally another place checked off my list! :)

Bix is a cute restaurant buried in Gold Alley! Nice ambiance and they had somewhat of a band playing when we went

Truffle Burger- my favorite of course! I was surprised when there was no top of the bun, it was topped with onions. I believe the hype def one of the better burgers I've had, very tasty and juicy and it was ginormous

Salmon- very fresh and flavorful also, it did not have that fishy taste that other salmon has sometimes

Sweet Onion Croques- also something i highly recommend. Its basically a grill cheese sandwich but one of the best you will have too

Potato pillows- basically tater tots with caviar, it really needed some ketchup

Gin Martini- one of the most disgusting things I've had, but the bellini was delish
author: Annie L.

description:
We started out with the steak tartare which was very good and prepared at the table. The duck breast was moist with just enough fat and packed full of flavor. The lobster spaghetti was an interesting combination of ingredients with a nice kick from the jalapeño. It also contained a healthy portion of lobster.

The service was great all evening. The servers are attentive without being intrusive. Our server made a spot on recommendation for a bottle of wine. The martinis and shaken at the table side, which is a classy touch to go along with the old fashioned theme of the restaurant.

On this Saturday evening there was a three piece jazz band playing. Even though we were sitting 30 feet from the band the volume was not overpowering to a point of drowning out conversation. It added a great element to the ambiance. Another staple of the decor is the painting of The Butler's in Love by Mark Stock. It is a great piece to admire throughout dinner.
author: Michael S.

description:
Bix is like a rock in the stream.  An anchor in a life.  Something that you can turn to when everything else is out of control; something you know will be just as you left it the last time.

I've not been here in years and last night, true to form, it was as if only a day had passed. 

Anymore I stay in the bar and enjoy the haunting feeling that any moment a little boy riding a big wheel will round the corner.  Carpet, bare floor, carpet, bare floor.  I'm guessing not everybody has this experience.  I do.  I like it.

I'm over the Bombay martinis because they made me crazy.  I'm a new Bond now.  And last night with a wet Goose and a mobius strip of citrus I enjoyed the memories.

This note, btw, is dedicated to Janice.

Five stars.
author: Markus N.

description:
We were seated 30 minutes after our scheduled reservation after making a fuss that we didn't want to wait any longer.

You can only get steak well done or med rare?? Shouldn't I get exactly what I want? Arrogance is bliss. Basically the steaks are prepped and cooked before hand, when you order, it is reheated to what the chef wants, not you.
Hamburger was way undercooked, the waitress noticed this and without my asking, credited the Hamburger. I ate 1/4 of it and was very ill the rest of the evening. 
Salmon was good
Lobster pasta was good.

Ambiance is nice but there are so many better restaurants with so much better food that would seat you at or very near the time of your reservation.
author: Patricia And Don P.

description: Came here for another holiday dinner w/another group of girl friends and had a good time. At this dinner I had several small dishes as I wanted to try a few different things. Had the bone marrow, duck liver and the steak tartar, everything was good but not GREAT... Wish the bone marrow was cut in half down the center rather in rounds but it was actually the best thing out of all that I tried. The duck liver was actually like a moose and was good, steak tartare was good as well and was prepared table side which was cool. Nice place and good food, but not a place I have to go to again.
author: Candice B.

description:
Dark alley, cobble stones, it's hard to find the restaurant thru the mist of fog...but when you do and the grand door opens "ahhhhhhhhhh lovely"...

Such a sexy setting: the bar, the piano, endless paintings and the stairs to the upper level (Breathe in the romance!!)

Food:
Soft creamy butter...
Chilled Foie Gras - Perfection
Marrow Bone - better then Morimotos (have a moment? read that review)
Kobe Steak - Wasn't as rare as I preferred but it's juicy

All and all, a great indulging experience
author: Vee V.

description:
This place was so good my clothes came off!  Seriously.  I agree with the other reviewer, this place does something to people.  

Four friends and I went to a pinup model workshop and photoshoot over the weekend and capped it off with dinner at BIX.  We all had our glamour on, and the elegant retro vibe here only helped to elevate that feeling.  

After cocktails, wine and a fantastic meal of (around the table) heirloom tomatoes and housemade mozzarella, oysters on the half shell, tomato soup, ricotta and grilled squash napoleon,  Little Gem salad, steak tartare, chicken hash and more (all delicious)...   we were discussing the fact that our workshop hostess walked around in a vintage slip and high heels almost constantly... and how cool that was.    

I was inspired... so I changed into a gorgeous silk chiffon shortie nightie that could almost pass as a camisole top.... with my black dress pants and 1940s vintage jacket....     at the table.     Under cover of the tablecloth and giggling girlfriends.   (Don't worry... it was late, we were in a corner and hardly anyone was there)

Then we proceeded to go out to the alleyway, where it is decorated with cafe tables and candles....  and since it was late and there was no one around for miles.... I stripped off my pants (my coat comes to my calves so I could cover up when needed)....   sat down on the cafe chair in high heels and that gorgeous slip.... and threw open my coat so my freind could take photos.

LOL!!!

I don't know what came over us!   But it was great.  

WE LOVE YOU BIX!!!


PS:  Teeny tiny cocktails.  For shame.   Service was good.  Atmosphere was awesome.
author: Shanna K.

description:
I have been here several times with friends and colleagues. The service every time is superb.

The entrance located on Gold Street reminds me of the Prohibition Era just a bit. The bar makes many good mixed drinks. There is live jazz (piano player and/or trios) in the evenings, and you can eat on either the main floor or upstairs. My recommendation is to get a table upstairs. It's a little more intimate and you have a view of the whole restaurant. 

I am a little disappointed that they no longer have the kobe beef bavette and mashed potatoes on the menu. That has long been my favorite. However, on my most recent visit I had the seared albacore tuna, which was good. For appetizers, my friends and I split oysters, and the heirloom tomato salad. For dessert, I had bananas foster and vanilla ice cream covered in rum. It was delicious.

Will I be back? Of course - I love this place!
author: Stephanie S.

description: I was about to update the review to 4 stars because the food and service was so good but then the manager came along asking who wrote the 1 star review. He thought he approached us in a joking manner but all of us took it as aggressive. We were arguing back and forth until my brother calmed the situation down. I'm not sure where his customer service skills went but you never argue with your customer and you never refer to a group of people as "you guys" especially not in a high end restaurant. He tried to make things better with complimentary dessert which I appreciate but I'm still surprised with what happened especially after waiting 25 minutes AFTER our reservation time to be seated.
author: Dalia K.

description: What a nice evening! The cocktails were marvelous, the food was good (the duck was tough), the chocolate bread pudding was to die for and the jazz trio was so amazing we couldn't leave after dinner...had to have a few drinks in the bar before going home.
author: Nancy G.

description: My friend took me to dinner here while I was in town and the food was incredible. The vibe was very Art Deco with a live piano player and singer. Usually I shy away from live music when dining, as it's hard to converse with company, but this was a mellow, good vibe. Don't get me wrong, you should dress up, I wore pants and a blazer and flats and felt dressed down. Specifically, I'd recommend the steak tartar. Not only my favorite dish in general, but exceptionally good here. Very impressed. The best part of dinner had to be the server assistant, Pedro. He was so amazing, attentive, and sweet! He completed my experience at this restaurant that I might have otherwise rendered as average. I hope that you may experience his presence if you decide to visit.
author: Sara M.

description:
The atmosphere here is amazing. As soon as you walk in through the door a lovely medley of jazz tunes is flowing into your ears. The high ceilings & decor add to the inviting warmth of this place. (2 stars)

Sadly.. Food is meh. Added salt & tabasco to everything because it was soooo bland. (Ordered steak tartare, lobster noodles, scallops )  Service isnt what you'd expect from a fancy shmancy restaurant. And worst part, location. Located in a hidden alleyway and smells like a sewer. 

Not sure if it was worth the money or the drive / hassle of looking for parking in that area. :(
author: jennifer f.

description: It is a pretty classy place but the high noise level in the bar area makes it sound like a sports bar, even sitting upstairs in a back corner. We came expecting a quiet & romantic dinner for our anniversary but it was actually sometimes even hard to hear our waitress. The staff run very quickly trying to keep up with all the tables and I asked one of the waiters to take our photo in between running back and forth, but unfortunately the photo was off angle and blurry. Oh well ... Food was good but not sure we would go back. Oh the 'jazz music' is a piano downstairs in the bar area, but very hard to hear due to all the noise. Why can't they put up some sound proof to absorb rather than reflect the noise or separate the noisy bar area ... The restaurant has been around for a very long time in an off the beaten path and apparently has a loyal following. They were nice giving us a free mini-scoop of sherbet ice cream at the end of our meal.
author: bruce f.

description:
Things started off so nicely. We had a couple of expectedly and understandably expensive drinks at the beautiful old bar by a classic barman clad in white jacket. The place presented so much historic elegance and architecture that we were discussing our return before we even moved on to our dinner table for food. Upon being seated, we were in a great mood as it appeared everything about the place suited our tastes. It even reminded us of a small scale version of one of our favorite restaurants called The Wolseley in London.

The waiter seemed very professional and polite, food was selected, and drinks ordered. Our wine arrived, and we told the waiter "We already expect to be returning soon. This is our kind of place." My Caesar salad was not bad, though I was surprised that in a "fine restaurant" the traditional shaving of anchovy was not present. No matter, I've seen it both ways. We also had an order of deviled eggs with truffle. These were very nice. So far so good. 

My entree showed up, which was Sea Bass. I had previously asked the waiter "how is it prepared?" He simply said "it's a boneless fillet, oven cooked." He forgot to mention that it was first mercilessly saturated and preserved in salty brine to the point of rivaling an Egyptian mummy, and that it would  rest upon the tooth less like a leathery fish and more like a fishy shoe. 

I really didn't want to complain or ruin our evening. Washing wine over my abused and unrecognizable sea bass and diluting it with the side vegetables as I went, my desire to be agreeable quashed my judgement and I ate half of the pickled fish slab before telling my wife that it was making me sick and I finally pushed it aside with nausea and regret. My stomach was quickly upset to the point of it becoming clear that I would have to skip my usual coffee and dessert. But for the jazz musicians fingering away, all adjacent diners would have surely heard my stomach protesting what had been done to it.

I decided not to say anything, for my wife's sake, and just leave without mentioning the amazingly bad food to staff. That's when Blake, the manager, happened by. "How was everything?" he inquired. Well, as he asked... I recounted everything that I had loved up until the food arrived, but added "There was so much salt in my food it tasted like shelf stable bait pulled from a vacuum pack bag." And that I was already becoming sick from what I had just eaten. 

Blake struck me as an honest and genuinely nice guy when he responded "I'm not going to B.S. you, you aren't the first person to say that." Wow, really? He went on to say "They brine the fish to remove impurities, but sometimes it gets left in way too long." Firstly, why would anyone brine sea bass? It's clean, light, and wonderful. Second, If the fish was brined for some reason, that certainly should have been  part of the waiter's answer when I asked how the fish was prepared. Also, if the pleasant manager had heard the fish was inedibly salty from others...why did they serve it to me?

He went directly to the kitchen, ostensibly to chat with the cook (make no mistake, there is no chef in this establishment). What he didn't do was offer to comp the offending slab of pickled bait, or even to comp my wife's dessert and coffee. 

To be fair he did say "If you ever come back, I'll buy you a drink." It's something, but I think that offer missed its mark. I felt quite sick and uncomfortable for all of that night and all of the next day. It's now two days later and my stomach is not yet settled. 

Bix had us from the moment we walked in the door. They then set out by the sheer force of will from their kitchen to serve us one of the worst meals I have ever eaten anywhere in quite a long time. I am not exaggerating when I say that this food would have been considered sub par and offensive had it been served to me in a Styrofoam clam shell through the window of my car at a drive-through. 

Two cocktails, one bottle of wine, appetizers, entrees, and a single dessert/coffee for the wife was just about three hundred dollars with tip. As I sit uncomfortably listening to my stomach revolt and attempt to heal two days on, I promise it has cost me much more than that . 

Only if I one day hear they have actually hired a chef, will I possibly consider giving them another chance but it is amazing to me how badly they failed their first chance. 

Stop by and have a drink and enjoy the atmosphere of a fine old building, but stay away from the "food".
author: T A.

description:
This review is only for the cocktails.  Six of us dropped in around 10 p.m. for both the jazz and the bar drinks.  We were seated in a nice crescent moon shaped table that straddled the bar and the dining area.

Great trio jazz in a great setting in an alley off the Financial district & Jackson Square.

Bar drinks - the martinis were served in glasses like you'd get when eating ahi tartare or maybe a shrimp cocktail.  Not your typical martini sized glass.

Lemon drop martini $10 and classic martini $11 each.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I try to stop by whenever I will be spending a few days in SF.  Truly one of my favorite restaurants anywhere, and one of those places that I get really excited to go to. And last night was no different than any other evening I've spent here....great food, fun and classy ambiance, entertaining live jazz music, good service, and just an all around wonderful experience.  Still so many places to try out in the Bay Area, but sometimes I'd just rather come here instead.

Appetizer:
 halibut ceviche - amazingly good. Served with avocado and sea salt and reminded me more of a crudo (presentation-wise). Small serving; comes with 4 small pieces. Almost placed another order of it after finishing the dish, but knew we had a big dinner ahead. 
Then came the "tomato cart," which consisted of 3 different kinds of tomatoes, and mozzarella cheese.  This was amazing as well.
Entrees: 
Duck- tasty and perfectly prepared
Chicken hash- served fried; great flavor.

Hope to be back soon.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Came here for an anniversary. Quite and nice and fancy place. I was instantly giddy. 

There is seating, a bar, and live jazz piano player downstairs. Upstairs is more seating. We got a nice seat in the upstairs in the middle facing the bar. 

We ordered the steak tartare to start- Angus beef, shallots, parsley, mustard, and capers. Prepared tableside, served with crackers and absolutely divine. PLEASE order this if you go to BIX. 

For entrees, I ordered the pork chop and BF ordered the lobster spaghetti . Soft, juicy, tender=SUCCULENT. The apple chutney added a smoky sweetness to the pork chop and the potatoes were quite good too.

BF said he liked the spaghetti. I thought it was... okay. Cherry tomatoes, spaghetti, lobster... it was.. light and refreshing? I think there could have been more lobster pieces though. 

Overall, a nice, romantic place to take someone on a date. DO get the steak tartare and the pork chop.
author: Chau T.

description:
A very belated review.

Met up with hubby here for drinks and apps.  Realized we were on the under dressed side upon entering but the host/maitre d' was very welcoming and sat us at a nice table close to the bar.  Our waitress, Jacqueline, was very friendly and helpful.

What we had:
Manhattan -  Pikesville Rye, Carpano Sweet Vermouth & Angostura Bitters $10 

Bix Ricky - Belvedere Vodka, Fresh Strawberry Puree, Club Soda & Limelight - $11 - it was a bit sweet for my taste

Tuna Tartare with Fresh Hummus, Mint and Preserved Lemon
on Cumin Lavosh Crackers- 4/$12.95 - good
 
Housemade Mozzarella wrapped in La Quercia Prosciutto
with Fiordolio Olive Oil- 4/$8.95 - lollipop style w/ bamboo stick  drizzled w/ olive oil and cracked pepper - very tasty

Nice location, tucked away from all the hustle and bustle.  Can be an interesting place to people watch.  

Will return in the right attire and enjoy a full meal.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Great environment of a prohibition styled hangout.  Grand piano in the middle of the ground floor.  Classical decor and 1930s pillars throughout the building.  The bar gets jampacked after about 7pm.

Took the girlfriend here for her birthday dinner - can't go wrong with the variety this place offers.  The service is great - coat check at the front, a very knowledgeable staff, and bartenders that just come across like they can make some solid old fashioned's in their sleep.

Now for the food...this is American done right.
We had the potato pillows - delicious fried potato treat topped with caviar.
Steak Tartare - the waiter comes to your table with the Brandt Steak meat, and all the toppings surrounding its perimeter, then proceeds to mix it all in front of you as he explains what each ingredients does the dish.  This was the best tartare I have ever had.

My girlfriend had the duck breast, which was very tasty but from reading her emotions - I think she would've rather had the steak.  

I ordered the Porkshire pork chops.  I had no idea what a differentiated a Porkshire pork chop from your premium pork chops, but after my first bite I will associate Porkshire with godlike.  I have never had such a tender pork chop, each bite stuffed with the juices it was marinated and cooked in.  Instead of the butter beans I substituted in cream spinach - no regrets there.

Great food, great service, and parking is relatively easy if you look around the area - no need for the valet unless you enjoy the whole snazzy idea of pulling up in an alleyway and letting a valet take over from there.
author: Christopher L.

description: I have dined at Bix several times a year since the late 90's. The food, service and ambience are consistently superb.  The 1st time that I went to Bix, I was pretty sure that my host was taking me down a dark alley to gain some negotiating leverage with me on the deal we were working on!  The a$$ kicking didn't occur but I was introduced to what is now one of my favorite dining establishments in San Francisco.  The dark alley doorway is just part of the charm.  Much has been said about Bix and I agree with almost all of it.  The wine list is fantastic and the ambience is upscale 30's dinner club.  Lobster spaghetti, french cut pork chop and kobe steak are my favorite 3 entrees, althought I have never heard anyone complain about anything served at Bix.  This is truly a can't go wrong choice for entertaining clients or a night out on the town.
author: Lance W.

description:
Classy, art deco place that probably caters to the white cigar crowd. Fortunately in our party we had a white guy which prevented from the rest of us Asians from getting lynched at the end of the night. 

Food and service was solid, but here is the problem... for the price point that this place charges, it was not on par with the complexity of food or high end service that one can find at similarly priced places such as Prospect, Wayfare Tavern, or even Cupola. Had the black truffle cheesburger with truffle fries.It was gooood...but at 27 bucks..i kept thinking to myself, "the LeGrande burger at Wayfare is better..and only 19 bucks...."

Wife had this fish thing with some red sauce at the bottom that she mentioned looked and tasted like ketchup. Now, if that was a 14 dollar dish, I would be cool..but at 23 dollars? Sacrilege!


Another person had the chicken hash and it was fine, but it literally looked like hash and eggs,which you can get at any decent brunch place for about 13 bucks, and this fu*ker was 23 bucks!

Solid food, but overpriced. If you got the money to pay for this place, you deserve to go to better rated places.
author: Jerry C.

description: I ate dinner prior to coming to this establishment, so this rating is not based on the Resturant and it's entirety. The oyster deserve 5 stars, as well as the service.  The deserts were ok and the Jazz was good too! Pricing is very reasonable for the environment and decor alone. I will return to try more things there, when I'm not on a full stomach.
author: Genesis B.

description:
Reminiscent of the golden age of SF, when dark alleys were filled with speakeasies and jazz bars. 
Bix is located in Jackson Square in a dark alley (Gold Street) and once you step in, it's DARK DARK DARK. You need at least 10 mins for your eyes to adjust. 

Jazzy ambience (even when the jazz ensemble isn't playing) and great food. 
The crowd is older, business though, coz of the prices. 

My fave thing there is the Lobster spaghetti, which i always tend to overeat (ie i get the bigger portion instead of limiting myself to the smaller one. yikes). 
The apps there are fabulous, esp the Crab rolls. 
Banana Foster ice cream is the only way to wrap up the meal.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
My husband and I dined here after a yelp search and were led to believe that this place is vegetarian friendly. Trusting the tip, we made a reservation without checking the menu first.
Despite being only small plates available on the menu, the waitstaff was accommodating and offered options that weren't on the menu, as well as allowed substitutions on the appetizers.

The dessert was delicious.
author: Lauren A.

description: We stumbled upon this place while walking through the city side streets. What a great find. Clean, friendly and efficient service. The food was fabulous. Everyone in our group (6 people)enjoyed their meal.
author: Shane J.

description:
My purpose for visiting BIX recently was to try the renowned $28 black truffle burger, which had been suggested to me by another Yelping burger fan. Best in SF? No. But very good? Of course! My only complaint was that the rye bread wasn't a good fit for a burger, and I love rye bread.

The "Perfect" Manhattan was quite good too, though Dickel Rye isn't my favorite. 

Pro Move 1: You might need to be patient if you take a vehicle into Gold Street (Alley). If you take a taxi or bus, the walk will be less than a block. The valet is nice though.

BIX was the site of my first SF dinner back in 2001, when my parents lived out in Pleasanton and I still lived in Ohio. Our dinner there helped plant a seed in my head to move out here (eventually). We drove in during a storm; you can imagine how my East Bay parents reacted to navigating the one-ways, including Gold St., in the pouring rain, before GPS directions...and then waiting behind other cars in that alley. So, yeah, it was good to get inside finally.

My dad and I thought it would be very cool to own to a huge bar like this. The mural above it is great...almost as great as the array of alcohol lined up below. The crowd at the bar is inevitably lively. 

Pro Move 2: Go to BIX for the happy hour, at least, if tables are booked for dinner. 

Great ambiance, knowledgeable and pleasant service. What's not to like? The prices shocked my midwestern perspective at the time; how could so many people live here on prices like these? Well obviously they couldn't, because Bix is relatively expensive for SF.
author: Mike H.

description: I went here for my senior prom dinner around two years ago. The food was fairly decent and the ambiance was really nice. I just uploaded some pictures, even though the pictures aren't recent, I doubt the menu would have changed much.
author: Denise L.

description: Started the evening at the Bar, where Ben was very cordial and had great suggestions for drinks. Loved the Bix Sidecar, and enjoyed hearing about other drinks from the Bix deink mwnu.  But dinner was Alabsolutely hands down one of the best dinners we have had.  We decided on the pre fixe menu and it was out of this world.  Started with an appetizer special of soft shell crab.  For dinner we had caesar salad and then my husband had the sole while I had the wagnu beef, so tender it melted in your mouth.  Servers Alex and   Alanzo did a fabulous job, never an empty glass or empty plate that was not removed quickly.  Dessert was equally as wonderful,  i had the cheese course while my husband chose the cookies with whiskey cream.  It was great, I will definitely recommend and be back.
author: Terasa R.

description: Great service. STEAK was amazing!!!! Awesome atmosphere :)
author: Susi L.

description: In town with my husband while he was lecturing at Stanford, we both love trying out restaurants in all the cities we visit. I was looking forward to trying Bix, as I love Piano music, however, the hostess who  took my call to make a reservation was a very unpleasant surprise. She was so rude and condescending that we completely were turned off and went to a different very lovely restaurant.
author: Aviana V.

description: Wow!   Amazing. Live music. Great food. Great drinks. The manhattans were awesome. The gruner AMAZING. They only have one. Enjoy every delicious bit. Food. I can go without sex for a little while. The lobster pasta so good. Gruner Vetliner I already said was like heaven the manhattans SO good. I can't imagine what else to say.
author: Paul G.

description: Business dinner here. Nice atmosphere. Expansive feeling to the interior space. Good drinks. Pretty good food. Service was a bit off. Server interrupted conversation abruptly on several occasions.
author: Philip S.

description: Mr. D and I have been eating at BIX for several years and usually for special occasions -a B-day for two or a dinner with SF friends. We think of it as a special treat when in SF. The place is unique, art deco sleek with a atmosphere of discreet and affordable luxury, and that thrilling hint of Thin Man speakeasy glory. I said it is affordable luxury, but it is not cheap. The food is OK, but it is not great. The service is quite good, but it is not perfect. We don't really go there to drink (because we don't drink- except Champagne, which is always charmingly expensive) but we go there for the ambiance. The piano and lounge singer add up to the noise level -if I may be so rude to the musicians- but they also add up to the fun and elegant vibe. So, golly gosh,we dress up when going to BIX to honor the classy feel of the place, though sadly a lot of patrons don't bother. But see, BIX -to me- is a special experience, darling....
author: Ashley D.

description:
Found this place on yelp, since I'm still relatively new to the city.  Trusted many of the reviewers and their recommendations for drinks, appetizers, entrée and dessert and I couldn't have been more pleased.

The service was absolutely perfect, the atmosphere was fun and the gentle live music was a great addition.

It happen to be my birthday too and the staff did a great job of making it feel special without putting on a huge song and dance.

.....my new favorite place?
author: Gary M.

description:
The service, food, and ambiance is excellent. The restaurant is in a great location in Jackson square. The whole experience of Bix is unique. 

After my second visit, I'm definitely adding this place high on the list for visiting friends/family, client dinners, and date nights. 

Lobster spaghetti and the pork chop have been my two mains, and they are impressive to say the least. Excited to come back and try more.
author: Matt R.

description: Awesome atmosphere, excellent food.  Quiet, because it's hard to find.
author: Matt W.

description:
I used to love this place. I really, really did. 
You broke my heart Bix. You broke it in two.

Recently we had an awful, terrible, tragic, experience. It was so bad that I will not be back. I can no longer recommend Bix.

Off with your head.
author: Nathanerin L.

description: Fun place with a buzz and very good food. Highly recommend for the service, food and ambience, which is unique in SF.
author: Russell N.

description: The food was ok, the drinks were yummy and the three stars is solely for the building itself, which was gorgeous. We went for lunch and my husband's burger was great, but my son's and my pasta was just so-so. The food isn't inexpensive so if you're going to spring for a nice meal, reserve a special place with a better menu.
author: Angela W.

description:
Jazz hands.

Bix is a place I've been wanting to try for a long, long time because I'm a big fan of jazz.  We came here tonight and was seated right away.  Bix is located on a hidden street close to Bubble Lounge.  Upon entering, it is very dim and you get the feeling you're in a mansion of a 20's or 30's party, very Gatsby-esque, very beautiful.  There is a downstairs and an upstairs, we were seated at one of the tables close to the pianist downstairs.  Bix is a very romantic restaurant, so if you want to spark some love this is definitely a place to bring that special someone.

We ordered the potato pillows with creme fraiche and caviar.  Wow!  What a great dish to start with.  Small pieces of perfectly fried potato complemented with just the right amount of creme fraiche and caviar.  I could have had another 10 of those.  I had the trout salad and my fiancee had the steak tartare.  Both were very good.  For entrees she had the deliciously made lobster pasta.  Pieces of lobster with a sauce that tastes bisque like, I highly recommend getting this.  If you're not a heavy eater, the half portion should be good enough.  I ordered the truffle burger which I was a bit disappointed with.  Not enough truffle flavor and the fries were too crunchy.  I do want to add that the mojito that my fiancee had was terrific.

Why am I giving it four stars and not five?  I felt the pace of the food came a bit too quickly.  We were in and out in an hour with three courses.  For a place where you want to sit and enjoy a romantic dinner with wonderful music, it was definitely rushed.  I think an hour and half would have been better.  Second we were only listen to the pianist and didn't get to enjoy a jazz trio or quartet because they don't start till 8:30pm which was a bummer.  

I will definitely come back but I hope our dinner can last longer next time.
author: Pierre L.

description:
My husband and I came here for lunch thanks to the Foodspotting app on my iPhone.  

The Tuna Tartare had a nice texture but could have had just a bit more flavor.  I had the Bix Burger.  It was juicy and cooked the way I requested but it wasn't "wow" - not for $16.  My husband had the Pork Sugo with Pappardelle Pasta - this was really tasty and the pasta was cooked well.  The Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding is divinity in a bowl, though...
author: Rose A.

description:
This place isn't really to visible from the street. It's almost hidden in a small alley. When my friend first took me here, I thought it would be this small divey type bar. Once we were inside though, I was impressed! This place is big and there is an upper balcony area for diners. The whole place is classy and has a 40's look to it. We just stopped here to get a few drinks. The cocktails on the menu are exotic and good. The bartender was nice and friendly. 

The people at this place were sophisticated but there were some people here who were dressed casually like us as well. I think I had the blood orange margarita and that it cost $13.00. I liked the drink and the other cocktail that I had. I can't recall what I had after that. The decor is nice. This would definitely be a good place to go on a romantic date on if money isn't an issue as the items on the menu are on the pricey side. I think that in general, most entrees are around $15.00-$25.00 for lunch and $30.00-$50.00 for dinner. I hope to come back here the next time I'm in SF.
author: Butterfly A.

description: Bix is a bit pricey but the food, service and atmosphere make it well worthwhile, especially for a family celebration (adults and at least teens, only) we had a great time with wonderful food. It was a relaxing evening. The ambiance is fine and fun and the music, while well played, is soft enough to converse over. All in all, the $200 for 2 ( incl tax, tip and 2 drinks each, and shared dessert) was well worth it.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
*4.5 stars*

BIX is an incredible dining experience that takes you back to (what I imagine to be) the days of when Sinatra was king and jazz was the norm. The ambiance oozes class and you feel important to even be allowed inside. Usually, I would brush this off as a pretentious restaurant filled with snobs and douchebags, but BIX somehow maintains a welcoming and warm atmosphere that is difficult to not enjoy.

Our server (Bryan) was absolutely on-point. Attentive, friendly, and informative, Bryan provided exactly what I think good service should be. Water glasses were constantly filled and the food came out at precisely the right moments -- it was great.

Our group of 4 went with family-style dining (ordering all small plates) in lieu of any main dishes, so my experience did not include any of the entrees. Although I didn't get to try the pork chop (as I was encouraged to), it was definitely awesome to taste so many different flavors in bite-size form. 

------------------------------
FOOD:

Dungeness Crab Rolls = Incredibly-fresh shredded crab mixed with a sweet and tangy mayo on a thick roll. It was a great proportion of crab to bread.

Potato Pillows = Yes, these are like tater tots for the filthy rich, but they are delicious. The mixture of the creamy potato, the crisped exterior, and the not-too-overpowering caviar was perfect. It really is difficult to justify the price (almost $4 for a tater tot), but when you're swishing that bite-sized goodness in your mouth, you completely forget that finances are actually important in life.

Mini Croques = Like miniature grilled cheese sandwiches laced with truffle oil and mushrooms. Just rewriting that makes me salivate. 

Bone Marrow = It's definitely not my favorite that I've had in the city, but it really is cooked well. I don't think the toast needed to be so oily and crisped, since the bone marrow should provide all of the oil in each bite, but the parsley and salt were great additions.

Mini Lamb Burgers = They really weren't kidding when they say "mini", because these are seriously one-biters. The lamb wasn't too gamy, which is good, but I didn't find too much flavor in these. Luckily, I had some saved up bone marrow and parsley, which I carefully added in there to give it the perfect oomph that it needed.

Chilled Foie Gras = I love all forms of foie gras, so regardless if it's seared, moussed, or (in this case) chilled in a pate-form, I'm going to love it. The foie gras here definitely didn't have as strong of that distinct foie gras flavor that I love, but it definitely hit the spot nonetheless.

Mozzarella w/ Prosciutto = Perfect mozz flavor. The combination was very good.

Truffle Fries = Excellent fries, crisped perfectly.

Brussels Sprouts = These were way too oily and salty. If they had cut down on the oil and salt, they would've been much better, because the sprouts actually had an excellent texture.

Bananas Foster = Incredible. One of the best desserts I've had in a while.

Grand Total: $163.03 (w/ 2 glasses of wine and tax, but before tip)
------------------------------

BIX definitely holds its own as a true SF staple, with a perfect mix of class and cool. It would actually be a great place to come for drinks -- just to sit at the bar, absorbing the ambiance created by the tuxed-out pianist, the soulful jazz singer, and the classy decor. Though, that is only if the food weren't also this damn good.
author: Roy C.

description: So not only did we love this little place (it took 30 mins to find) but the Server was A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. There were 4 of us in our party, I was the only non-drinker in the group as someone had to drive. Anyway, the server made me a fun NON-ALCOHOLIC drink. Plus helped us pick out some favs on the menu. The truffle deviled eggs were wonderful. They were perfect. I had a medium-rare steak, which actually came out medium-rare then for dessert I originally ordered I want to say the creme Brule' and didn't like so the server had me pick something else, Thankfully I did, the bananas foster trumped my bananas foster! It was the best BF I've ever had. That alone will make me go back, the server is the other reason! Did I mention we came a little before closing, not on purpose. I hate doing this. But it didn't matter to the staff they enjoyed having us there. They were all super friendly and help make the place stay lively. :-)
author: Krissy B.

description: My family spent almost $1,000 at this restaurant. The one star is for the band it was really great. They played jazz and came over and chatted with us on their break. Aside from that it was not a great evening. I ordered the strip steak and my sister ordered the lamb. My steak came out medium well and I ordered medium rare also my broccoli was almost raw but the tops were horribly burnt it was not worth the $48 price tag. My sister had a completely raw piece of potato on her plate and nothing was really seasoned. Our waitress Jessica was kinda rude although she did have a good knowledge of the menu. She asked if we wanted dessert and when we declined she seemed very offended. When our check came the tip was written in on the bottom in pen by her and the total. Our two friends asked for a separate check so she split it and we gave her the 2 cards and which checks to put on which. She came back and had charged the wrong cards so we folded each check around the proper card so she wouldn't get confused again, and she came back the second time with it wrong again. Finally, the third time she did it correctly. She never gave us anything to show that she had reversed the other 2 charges and we called the manager over and he said they are getting a new system so they waiters have to just write the tips and totals on the checks which is pretty lame for that caliber of restaurant. Very disappointing night, but great jazz music.
author: Hope W.

description: 1930s Supper Club ala Speakeasy w/ live jazz. The ally entrance sets the whole tone. The House Mozzarella Skewers, Lobster Spaghetti and Ceviche are terrific.
author: Matt K.

description:
Those details of what makes this city so charming, gradually made themselves transparent to me as our taxi pulled up to BIX. Aside from the neon sign, BIX camouflages wells amongst the brick buildings that line up and down this particular narrow alley in Jackson Square. Look across the restaurant and you can catch a glimpse of the the upper levels of the Transamerica building. Enter the restaurant and witness jacketed bartenders serving gimlets, sidecars, rickeys and all things martini behind the mahogany bar. Are those handles and bar knobs gold? Was this a speakeasy? Live Jazz is playing in the background while locals, tourists  and business people alike are having dinner on both levels of this seemingly 1940's era restaurant/bar. 

We snag seats at the bar and order up some martinis. I order the BIX Rickey and some variety of Gimlet and my S.O. orders a Margarita and a BIX Manhattan. The drinks were delicious and well made. Both of us had dinner, but we couldn't resist the recommended Lobster Spaghetti and decided to split this dish. Generous chunks of lobster, sweet tomatoes, creamy sauce and parsley...this dish is very very good. I'm willing to put money on this dish being the the best pasta dish in the city. 

You won't find this place on Michael Bauer's list and you won't for sure find BIX on SF 7x7's 100 things, which is a good thing. BIX is an SF institution and is one of my favorite places in the city not just to eat at, but even to just walk by. I cannot believe it has taken me so long to get here. I highly recommend BIX if you have not been here.
author: Annie Y.

description:
So cool and pretty. Bix is a good restaurant and it has been for years!
The menu is traditional. the bar is the sort of place that makes you feel all warm and ritzy inside. I usually don't brag about the ingested bits but here's the meal
What I ate:
Chilled Foie Gras with Kumquat Relish: not for everybody but it did me like champ!
Chicory Salad with Grapefruit, Meyer Lemon and Parmesan: My type of wonderful
Maine Lobster! Yeah I dine with stylez. I tasted perfect. I almost got the crab but I passed.
bananas Foster for dessert, more desserts should be on fire.
My cocktail was a simple gin martini

I wore a tie to this bizness and I felt sharp!
author: Alexander R.

description:
If they had a few vegetarian entrée options, I'd give this place 5 stars. They only had one and it was off the menu. This is a unique place with unique food, but I have always said that it takes a really innovative chef to create outstanding and out of the ordinary meat-free dishes than it does a meat dish. This definitely seems like the type of place that's capable of crating unique vegetarian dishes, so it's too bad they don't try. This would be the main place I bring anyone for special occasions if they tried to have entrees for everyone. 
This was the second time I was here, but the first time I had anything beyond dessert and cocktails. I chose this place because it was a special occasion and me and my party have a flair for the 1930's-1950's. I knew this place also had a live piano player most nights. 
We got the corner table that I requested which was awesome! Ordered the appetizer sampler, for which I could only eat the deviled eggs (which I do not like deviled eggs), but this evening was no about me. The waitress was super nice and when she found out I was vegetarian she brought me too adorable shot glass size cups of their house made gazpacho. I had never had gazpacho before as cold soup has always seemed anything but enticing, but I had it and it was outstanding! I'd actually order that next time if they had it in  full sized portion. Their hot sourdough rolls are amazing!
So, the one dish they had I could eat was super basic. Delicious, but not at all creative. Spaghetti, basil, heirloom tomatoes, and garlic. Maybe a couple of other ingredients. I would totally get it again if it weren't so expensive. If it had been a super creative dish I couldn't get anywhere, then $27 would ad made sense. 
The cocktail I got was Ambrosia. I wouldn't get it again. Nothing special. 
The ambiance is why I love the place though. If they ever start consisting offering creative meat-free dishes then this will be my go-to place for sure! But till then, there's no benefit for me to go and have to settle for a common spaghetti dish and almost no appetizers I can eat either. 
This is the perfect place for a meat eaters who had a lot of money though! Definitely the highest bill I have ever seen for just 2 people.
author: Unicorn U.

description:
Upscale hole in the wall. Great burgers. 

Bix has live music and it's in an interesting location because it's in a little alley.
author: Irina R.

description:
I like this place.
Went hear with two of my co-workers for dinner.  It has a busy night and luckily my other co-workers knows people that he got us a last minute reservation.
Parking around the area is hard... thank God of valet.
It's on one of those small streets in the downtown city that it's a bit hard to find.
The place was crowded when we came in.  A jazz singer with a piano player was singing which I enjoyed the most out my experience.
Our server was great, very knowledgeable with their wine list.
I had their lobster pasta main dish and it was delish!
The rest of the items in their menu looked pretty good too.
I honestly do not remember the rest of the food we ate because I was already tipsy after a whole day of drinking.
I'm hoping to go back here with the hubby .
author: Learnee L.

description:
We visited for our anniversary, and after agonizing between this place and that, I decided to give Bix the call to the big leagues.  And they did not disappoint. The signage is understated, and the restaurant, while not hidden, is tucked out of the way down an alley. This must be intentional as it ties into their speak-easy aesthetic. Inside, the decor feels like another era. High ceilings, large oil paintings, live music with piano accompaniment; I half expected Bogey to be sitting at the bar lamenting his rotten luck.

Our server Jacquie was exceptional. She was attentive yet unassuming, always around when we needed something, but never hovering or imposing. Even my martini arrived with a little panache. Everything was executed flawlessly; she might have been an assassin in another life.

We started with the Potato Pillows with Crème Fraîche and American Sturgeon Caviar. These are gentrified tater tots. The potato puree is whipped up into a light puff and served crisp with a lil bit of creme fraiche for tanginess and caviar for saltiness. The flavors were understated, but it was more about the contrast of texture that made this dish memorable.

Next we had the Chilled Foie Gras with Spiced Kumquats. This was the whole reason I chose Bix in the first place, so I was looking forward to it. The foie gras was like butter, smooth and rich, served with a tangy kumquat compote with toast points. Better get this while you can, I don't know what California is gonna do after July 1.

I had Grilled Duck Paillard with Spring Onions, Fingerling Potatoes and Foie Gras Sauce. I like a good duck dish, but compared to everything we ordered, this was just okay. It was still delicious, but didn't surprise us like the other dishes.

Luckily the Maine Lobster Spaghetti "alla Chitarra" with Cherry Tomatoes, Jalapeños and Basil was a knockout. Even if you removed the lobster, the tomatoes and jalapenos totally made the dish pop. And I can only assume they use freshly made pasta, because this had a meta-pasta flavor, like pasta multiplied by itself, exponentially delicious. Of course, this dish does come with lobster, so that just kicks it all up to another level. I don't usually order pasta, but for this I would make an exception.

Even though they offered some more extravagant items (Bananas Foster, Crème Brûlée, etc), we decided to go simple for dessert:  Seascape Strawberries with Whipped Cream and Vanilla Meringue, and fresh chocolate chip cookies. Simple, but fresh and tasty. Both were served with whipped cream that was not overly sweet, so it was a nice compliment to each dessert.

If I was local, I would come here for drinks and apps anytime. But I'm not, so I guess I'll save it for when I'm in town.
author: Christopher M.

description: Horrible service, mediocre food.  No wonder Bix is no longer considered a top 100 restaurant in the Bay Area by San Francisco food critic Michael Bauer.  Simply not worthy.
author: Teny Q.

description:
Very fun place.  It's hard to find (down an alley) but has a terrific classic, retro ambiance. The drinks are great and reflect the 40s era vibe of the place--sidecars, gimlets and rickeys are featured on the menu.

The wedge salad with Point Reyes Blue Cheese dressing is excellent.  I enjoyed the Chicken Hash a la Bix.

About the only complaint is that the place is expensive, but you know that going it.  The food and experience are worth the price, but plan to spend $50 to $100 per person between drinks and dinner.
author: Augie R.

description: Good food, but kind of pricy. Enjoyed in particular the steak tartare (prepared at the table by waitress) and lobster spaghetti.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Loved the Jazz music... piano player and jazz singer combo.  Pricey? Yes, but completely worth it.

What we had on the table:
French 77 - Prosecco with Gin... yum
Truffle fries - absolutely delicious, and I don't care if Aaron Sanchez hates truffle oil... it works well with fries
Crab Rolls - I'm a sucker for crab rolls/cakes
Duck Liver "Faux Gras" - foie gras is banned in CA, so they are using an alternative.  The ones I've had before were made from non-gavaged duck liver mixed with goose or duck fat.  Most likely the bix chefs make their own.
À la minute Ceviche 
Baby Lettuces with Strawberries, Marcona Almonds and Feta Cheese
Maine Lobster Spaghetti
Brandt Beef Short Ribs
Black Truffle Cheese Burger served open face on Rye with Truffle Fries

Would definitely go again!
author: Derek S.

description: The entire meal including impeccable service, ambiance, piano player, artwork, every detail was a well rehearsed dance! Look forward to our next rendezvous.
author: Miss H.

description: "Horrible experience with the coldest rudest food server I have met in the city. We finally left the BF and I, after being hovered over and TOLD to order dinner as the table was to be turned over at 7:30. I have never been told to "move it along" in all the nice, pricey restaurants I have been to in the city.  I was always a fan of Bix because of the atmosphere and libations.   But no more.  The woman who was assigned to us had all the charm of a dominatrix.  I mean...maybe some of you are in to that, but not this kid.  We drank our drinks, enjoyed telling her that we were "NOT ready for our spanking", had some laughs at her expense, paid the check and went elsewhere...ugh.  Miserable.  Thank goodness I had a buzz....Nix to Bix!
author: Darby W.

description: It's been a long time since I have visited but this place held quite an impression on me. Hidden in alley way, you pull up to the restaurant, a valley guy greets you and takes your car. You walk into this elegant & classy joint, the lights are dim and ambiance is charming. I feel I'm walking into the past, how a swanky place would of been like before my generation. Food was impressive, loved the lamb. Drinks are yum. I would return in a heart beat.
author: Azizi A.

description:
BURGER BASED REVIEW OF DROP IN AND DINE

Don't say you read the wrong thing when you read this. I came here in search of one the better burgers in the city, needless to say I didn't find it and left pretty unsatisfied.

THE PLACE is in an alley, make sure you can find it because it may be easy to miss if you don't know these streets. Inside its dimly lit which is annoying, but I guess its the ambiance they want to create. Clientele seems older and higher in the salary pecking order of things. 

THE FOOD the prosciutto/mozarella combo was had, which was good but then again its hard to mess that up. The burger came open with fixings to the side. The meat was not medium rare as was asked, and the flavor was very normal despite everything I had been hearing. the fries were also lauded by some and these again were very regular.

THE PRICE the food was up there in price, again nothing to be shocked about but also nothing that I would write home about.

SO IF YOU LIKE BURGERS THIS AINT YOUR SPOT, I suppose the other food could be good, but then again my review wasn't about that
author: Sebastian C.

description: It's been a while since I weighed in on Bix, but not because I've been avoiding it.  Still one of my primary go-to places in SF for its food, bar, ambiance, and outstanding service. Bradley has my favorite drink ready, Will has the dining room under control.  Stopped by this week and had the deviled eggs (wicked good!), crab toast (a favorite), beet salad (delicious to look at and eat), and oysters. Need I say more? As the evening wore on and the piano player kicked in, the mood just got better and better. And not just due to the Ardbeg, neat.
author: Phil S.

description:
Reinforcing my love for Bix.  A certain boy did very well by doing research before my birthday dinner *blush*.

Started with the elderflower sparkling wine (now off the menu) and a ginger gimlet.  The complimentary mushroom crostini was amazing and crunchy [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=f9lrj9ecTfEfn1K_zjeS8Q].

The number one reason I love Bix is because of their steak tartare [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=ZEzkOS47VRBMszLMmAzaDg].  It's prepared tableside, finished off with two spritzes of courvoisier.  The server wasn't as animated this time around, but the dish was still excellent.

I should have gone through the photos on Yelp before ordering the potato pillows [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=qPl6Eubp0-H3OYpE_aHyeg].  It's like fancy tater tots, complete with the crème fraîche and the caviar.  Portions are small (four per order).  Save your money and order another steak tartare :)

The duck trio [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=2t9gY-sX1EY-2YwxwO6cPQ] comes with mustard braised cabbage, chanterelle mushrooms and huckleberries.  The texture and flavors were just right, and definitely not too overwhelming.

The black cod [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=FKOTUlfrKlkQgwCmCHkX6Q, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=Bapwc-lertvZImPmTd_vhg] was just as delicious.  Juicy, not too dry, and complemented with roasted fall vegetables in a spicy tomato-lobster sauce and arugula.

Let's not forget dessert, which I was forced to take two bites of even though I only ate half my entree.  The BIX red velvet cake with cream cheese frosting and Valrhona chocolate nibs [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/PzPPcGVg5O4UuW5cTopJhA?select=sEO2FWROq1fThMaGN9ppoQ].  So good :)
author: Jenny L.

description:
Delicious food and live jazz...say yes to Bix!

Just to get the bad out of the way...

My party of 9 dined here on a Saturday night.  We were seated on the bottom level.  The table was a tad small for our large party...I like cozy but we were bordering on cramped.  When the jazz band was playing, it got a bit too loud for conversations.  I wonder if the mezzanine level is better?

Enough with the bad...because there was so much good FOOD to warrant the solid 4 star rating! (faves in CAPS)

- DEVILED EGGS WITH TRUFFLES - best deviled eggs I've ever had
- MARROW BONES - 4 large bones with tons of deliciously fatty marrow inside
- LOBSTER SPAGHETTI - large chunks of lobster tossed with al dente spaghetti with tomatoes, jalapenos, and basil in a creamy red sauce
- Berkshire pork chop - huge chop!!  The edges were perfectly caramelized and the meat was tender and juicy but the center was a bit dry and lacking in flavor.
- Potato pillows - a bit disappointing given the Yelp reviews but it's basically just a tator tot with a dollop of creme fraiche and caviar on top
- Lamb burgers - to quote my husband "the smallest sliders in the world."  The lamb was a bit game-y but the cucumber and harissa were delicious

I loved the dining space (despite the slightly cramped table).  I don't know the history behind the building but it reminded me of an old bank.  The ceilings are super tall and there's a mezzanine level around the perimeter.

Cocktails, wine, shared apps, entrees, salads, espressos and dessert cost us about $78 each (including tax and tip).  I was expecting to pay $100+ so the bill was a pleasant surprise.

Definitely adding this to my list of good eats in SF!
author: Carolyn P.

description:
What a great date I had here! Amazing food. We had a ressie for 7:30 and sat upstairs. Started with a cocktail and ordered the crab rolls (wow!), the Lobster pasta (woweeeee) brussels (awesome) and kale (ehh alright) and a bottle of zin (woop woop)

The service was great, nicely paced and my wine glass never went empty! Best first date I've had out in a while. Love the live music- had a little toe tapping under the table =)
author: Ricquel N.

description:
Made reservations through OpenTable for my boyfriend's birthday with "Boyfriend's birthday, please have Sazerac waiting for him" in the notes. They definitely went above and beyond. Not only was there a Sazerac waiting for him at our table but we were given the best table in the house! They also gave him a little birthday card too. 

Atmosphere/Service:
This is a really cool spot. Dimmed lighting, old/classic feel and look to the building, music was nice, very much a service-orientated place

Drinks:
Pretty good. They obliged when my boyfriend got picky about his Sazeracs (type of glass, absinthe, rye, etc). I had the Hemingway and the Pear Margarita. I liked the Hemingway better, Margarita was okay  but I didn't taste the sage that was supposedly in the pear-sage puree.

Bread!
They give you hot dinner rolls and SOFT butter. A+

Food:
Started off with Beef Tartare and Potato Pillows. The pillows are simple but yummy. Tartare was one of the best we have had. They use Sriracha in theirs, not traditional but very good. We had the Wagyu Beef Bavette and Angus Short Rib dish. This was amazing. The steak and short ribs were perfect, the potatoes were delicious, and the creamed spinach was the best I've ever had (not too much cream, very clean spinach). We split that and it was the perfect amount of food for each of us. We were a little full to order dessert but they gave us their house-made Blood Orange Sorbet for my bf's birthday. My boyfriend thought it was too tart but I really liked it, but I love tart so...

Overall, really, really great experience we will absolutely come back.
author: Abigail G.

description:
I really liked this place. Great ambiance, friendly service, and free live jazz.

It's pretty hard to find, especially if you're driving by in a car. Gold St is a small alley and easy to miss, but the parking nearby is generally not too bad.

I came on a Sunday night with a couple friends and we sat at a booth upstairs. The building has really high ceilings and has the feel of an old speakeasy. They have a lot of classic cocktails and I would recommend the sidecar.

Food wise, everything was great, although the portions are a bit modest. One of our friends was running late, so we got drinks first and split the ceviche to start. For dinner, I got the chicken hash and it was really tasty. Just the right size for a light dinner and also to save room for dessert. We split the bananas foster for dessert. mmm...so good.

The live music was nice and started around 7pm. On Sundays, it is solo piano. I actually saw the piano player come in since I was sitting at the bar waiting for my friends. He talked to the bartender a bit, got his usual drink, and then sat at the piano and started playing right away.

Bix would be a great place to stop by for a drink if you work in the area.
author: Kenny J.

description:
