Not to mention, the waitstaff were quite accommodating since my male friends tend to get verbally joyous in speech and laughter.  Good thing they are cute to look at.

I like this place.  It has a certain chic adult feel the moment you walk in, as if Bing Crosby is getting settled by the grand piano and turning around to smile right at you.

Holiday Inn was never a flop.
author: Miika M.

description:
We went Bix for the last night of a recent San Francisco vacation and certainly were not disappointed.

Bix is a traditional restaurant in the style of the 30s and 40s, complete with white-suited waiters and classic cocktails you will not find much anymore in most other restaurants. The decor is traditional, and there is live Jazz music almost every night.

The menu is quite amazing, consisting mostly of classic dishes given a new twist. We started with the steak tartare, which was amazing (high praise from a German since tartare is a national dish there), and it's mixed table-side, giving you an overview of your ingredients and a little bit of a show.

I continued with the duck breast with spring mix, bacon, and spaetzle, and again it was extraordinary. The flavors were fresh, vivid, and the combination of colors was great.

For dessert, the bananas foster was a treat, albeit it does not come a flambe as one gets in New Orleans sometimes. Still, the flavor, especially with the dark rum instead of brandy, was exquisite.

I highly recommend Bix for a fancy dinner in San Francisco or just for drinks. It is also a great place to people watch and meet some of San Fran's business owners, etc. on a night out.
author: Jan T.

description: I can't wait to go to SF again so I can eat here. At the recommendation of a friend, dined here for the last night of vacation. PERFECT way to end a great trip. Live music on Saturday night. Lively bar scene. Great drinks. Our waitress was fantastic - very nice and at a good pace (not rushed but not left wondering where she was).  Really cool decor. Such an interesting location (basically entrance is in a super small side street/alley) but the restaurant itself is really big and set up nicely - seating on balcony level and floor level. crab rolls for appetizer - yum. I had the duck breast - PERFECT. My friend had the Prime Bavette. She loved it. Panacotta and butter scotch cookies for dessert. both deelish. yes, I know, it;s just cookies. but they were warm and yummy with the side of fresh whipped cream.
author: Farzin K.

description: The live music didn't end up playing until the middle of our dinner. But it is a very romantic place as I came here for my anniversary. Wonderful music, delicious food however a bit expensive for the amount of food you receive. Service was also great despite the other reviews I've read.
author: Ericalisa R.

description:
Food is good, but for the price that's paid, service should be a whole lot better.  Even with a reservation, we waited for 20 minutes, and when we questioned the hostess about our table for the 3rd time, she was rude and kept arguing back with no real argument.  
Just saying that at a place where a bill for four people comes at $300, having eaten nothing extraordinary, the service CANNOT be as inconsiderate or neglecting as it is.
author: Gabriel F.

description: Place always looks great, staff is always friendly and helpful, however the food is just ok. Had the pork (loin & belly) the other night.  The loin was actually more like two tiny medallions that was as dry as one can make them.  Actually had a tough time cutting them with my knife.  The belly was the savior of the plate.  It was moist and delicious. The dish was presented with three tiny potatoes, which were tasty, just for the $32 price, you could definitely add more.  I'll go back here for a drink, however not for dinner.
author: Dilly M.

description:
I went to BIX with a few friends while vacationing in SF. We did a tapas style menu order: half dozen oysters, crab cakes, devil eggs, caviar, ceviche, mozzarella with prosciutto, lamb bites, faux gras, black truffle fries and bone marrow.  All the items ordered tasting amazing. Although, the mozzarella and prosciutto was simple as well as the caviar. The caviar was essentially a tater tott with caviar on top.   

The staff was attentive, it's a romantic ambiance.  Definitely recommend the spot.
author: Orlando B.

description:
I'm going to come clean - I'm basing this review on a dining experience many months ago. I don't remember exactly what I ate, but I remember the overall end result.

I work only a block away, so my boss took me and two of my coworkers here for lunch. We each ordered a starter and an entree. I believe I ordered the Salmon Tartare to start and either chicken or a fish for the meal. Both were good, but not terribly memorable, and SO SMALL. I understand that fine dining values quality over quantity, but I don't eat all that much, so when I'm still HUNGRY after an appetizer and an entree, that's just plain stingy! My poor boss paid $14 for me to have 4 tiny bites of salmon tartare. Divide that number by three and we'll talk.

Fortunately, our server decided we were her favorite table of the day (or so she said to make us feel special), so she brought us a dessert on the house. In addition to the two we ordered, I ended up filling up on sugar. Not how I wanted to fill myself, but at least I didn't leave hungry.
author: Talia G.

description: Great downtown establishment.  We had drinks here that were quite good.  A young, professional crowd, which is more upscale than I'm used to (typically venture out in the Mission, which could be the same people after they gotten out of their suits and ties).  Friendly service and a cool ambiance.
author: Kevin M.

description: Hands down,  best restaurant experience of my life! We loved the truffled eggs, crab rolls, lobster spaghetti had the best home made sauce and the chicken entre was amazing. Chocolate bread pudding with ice cream, yum! I was so full. I am going again for sure. Great service!! QUALITY!  Even the bathrooms have nice paper towels, soft and absorb water efficiently!
author: Hiba Z.

description: We came here for a joint birthday dinner back in November. We ordered several appetizers and can't remember anything, but the deviled eggs. It was so good that we ordered more while waiting for our entree. I had the lobster spaghetti and it was very good if you like tomatoes. The fiancé had the duck and it was good also. As for dessert, the best was the banana froster! Just thinking about it makes me want some now.  I would definitely come back to try other dishes.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I'm not very liberal with my 5 star ratings, but this place has earned it. I have always known about Bix since I was a kid. My cousins came upon it when it first opened up in the late 80s and instantly fell in love with it. I was honored when they asked me to join them to celebrate their 23rd wedding anniversary here.

It is definitely hard to find and the only reason why I knew where it was is because I work right next door. There is rarely any parking (as is the case in downtown overall), but valet is easy, quick and courteous. When you walk in, it's almost like you're walking into a Mad Men episode. A certain je ne sais qois envelops you. With the waiters and waitresses all dressed up in white coats, the 1940's style supper club atmosphere, it is as if you're taken back into time. The service is excellent, water is never left empty... AND the staff was even so attentive that they caught the one non-ice water drinker at our table and came back with the appropriate jug of water. If that's not good service, I don't know what is. 

Drinks first... pretty basic highlighted cocktails, but extremely good. The Bellini was very refreshing and their Bix Ricky was like lemonade. The food was beyond awesome. We started with the truffle fries and the prosciutto wrapped mozzarella.  The truffle fries were cooked and seasoned to perfection, not too greasy and their ketchup was surprisingly delicious! The mozzarella in the other starter was home made and very moist. Great flavor. 

For starters we all got something different but tasted each family-style. The Ceviche was the best I've ever had, very smooth and light. The fish seemed to melt in your mouth. We also had the smoked trout salad, the plum salad and the roasted tomato soup. The smoked trout had an amazing flavor to it and the homemade dressing complimented it very nicely. The roasted tomato soup was delicious and even had legitimate grilled cheese croutons in it. Very impressive. 

As if we didn't have enough food in our bellies, dinner came and stayed. Two of us had the beef two ways special for the evening. The spare rib meet was cooked to such perfection that it fell off by just breathing on it. The other folks in our party got the steak and the salmon special. Both enjoyed the food and none of us shared, that's how good it was. The portions are quite generous, so don't think you have to load up on starters to get your food's worth.

Last and definitely not least was the dessert. We all shared the Banana's Foster because we were stuffed, but we probably could have killed two of these bad boys even with full stomachs. According to my cousins, the used to give 3 scoops of ice cream back in the day. Now it's just one, but they pour over the banana, rum, caramel and the flavors are like heaven. This is their signature dessert and believe me there's a reason for that. 

Great place to celebrate a special occasion or to treat your special someone to a nice dinner. Also, they have live jazz. Feel free to grab a drink and chill next to the very stocked bar!
author: Jamie P.

description:
As soon as I walked in and saw 3 hot 30 year old drinking martini's and complaining about their boyfriends I knew that I needed to come back to this bar! Unlucky for me, I was going here to eat and not sit at the bar.

I went here on a Monday night and it was packed.  The bar and decor are really cool. 2 levels of seating and high ceilings.  They had a guy play live piano the entire time and it was really relaxing.  

I'd opt for the starters and appetizers over the entrees here as the entrees are pretty typical of any other nice place in SF.  I had the wagyu beef and short rib and it was pretty awesome for an an entree though

Stay away from the flounder, it was boring.

The ceviche here is served a bit different and more like sashimi style, but very good.  We even got another order of it!

The crab rolls were good, probably because they  aren't good for you!
author: Josh D.

description: My girlfriend and I met here for dinner while I was in town for a conference. The food and atmosphere did not disappoint! We were having such a great time, we shut down the restaurant! We didn't get the hint until our waiter came and took the pepper off our table. Lol! I would defiantly go back again. Check it out!
author: Mysba R.

description:
I had really high expectations of this place from reading the reviews on here.  

General feeling: for a $400 meal between 4 people that included wine, 4 entrées, a few appetizers, a salad, deserts, and coffee, I expected a whole lot more.  For those kind of prices, I'm not expecting a blow job under the table, but I am expecting an orgasmic food experience.  This was not it.  

The good:  I liked the guy playing solo jazz piano.  Great instrumentalist and it was nice to hear in the background.  The decor was nice.  The staff was knowledgable and straight.   

The so-so:  The food.  I'm not saying the food was bad, it just wasn't mind blowing.  I simply have high expectations when I pay that much for food.  I had the Halibut with veggies in a basil-mint broth.  It was so-so.  Fish cooked well, I mean it is Halibut.  You can't mess it up.  Broth and flavor was okay.  I just wasn't mind-F#$ked which is what I want at a nice venue.   Two others at the table had the steak, which was cooked to order properly, but it was only served with 3 onion bulbs and this puree potato stuff that looks like they plopped it onto the plate via a cake decorator squeezer thing.   Not BAD, I'm just saying... I expect much more at these prices.

The bad:  It was hot.  I suppose we could have mentioned something about the temperature, but at this kind of nice place, I didn't think you needed to.   What else?  The waitress was a bit pretentious.  I can't pinpoint exactly what it was about here, but she just didn't have a good positive vibe about her. I don't know.  Maybe I expect people to be nice too much.  I just got the feeling like the folks at our table weren't good enough to be in this place, so service was kind of quick (slow rather - I'm talking in terms of feeling)  and I just didn't like the vibe.  

There are so many incredible places to eat in San Francisco and I look forward to trying so many more.  This is one venue however, that I don't plan on returning to.
author: Ross B.

description:
I'm not even going to touch on the food because it really just speaks for itself. 5 stars definitely.

5 stars for the service! Oh my gosh, the touches I couldn't even get at freakin' Gary Danko's for god sakes. Our server was just gushing charm and knowledge and charisma. 

The place is beautiful, the music is delightful, the ambiance is to die for. I have a feeling this is the kind of place that would never ever sacrifice their food or their staff for money or demand. Kudos to them. Mad mad kudos for them doing what's right all the time. 

I love this place. I wish I could eat here more often. Perhaps I could be the trophy girlfriend of some wealthy affluent business man and we can eat foie gras and drink red wine. I'm just musing dreamy quips but it's fun to dream!
author: Jessica K.

description:
I agree with the earlier Yelper who raved about the hand cut steak tartare.  It is fantastic!!!  They also give you a very generous portion of it with plenty of toast--plenty for two people.

I ordered a martini which was brought in shaker tableside--cute touch!!

The jazz singer was excellent.  We were there on a Tuesday night, so I was surprised the was there.  We really enjoyed the entertainment.

I thought the menu was a little boring.  I stuck with the appetizers.  I had the three lamb sliders which were delish!!

The best part of the meal was dessert.  Fresh made madelines with a fresh plum compote over ice cream...yum.

Please note: this place is very loud!!
author: Donnie Mac M.

description: I have dined at this lovely and excellent establishment only once about 15 years ago. The food was divine; the service 5 star with layered wait staff; the instrumental combo playing was excellent. We even danced.   I want to go again for a truly elegant night. It's pricey but totally worth every dollar.
author: Karen L.

description:
Went to Bix for dinner last night.  Food was good but the rudeness of the waitress was truly appalling.  It was almost comical and fortunately we didn't let her ruin our evening.
  
And after looking at some of the other reviews I see a common theme.  If you are late for a reservation, or your entire party isn't there you are in trouble.

And you pay for it throughout the evening by a bad attitude.  I even got scolded because my backpack was in a "dangerous" location.....near my feet.  I didn't check it in because I had an ipad in it.  Now I could have taken it out  and let her take it but the menu said "no ipads at the table".  This place has many unwritten and written rules!  And the backpack wasn't affecting anyone as we were in a corner table.  It's not like anyone was walking by and could trip.

I watched this particular waitress all night long and didn't see a smile in the 2 hours we were there....for anyone.

In fairness, part of our party was late and we got started later than we wanted to.  But we still had plenty of time to eat before next reservation arrived at 830pm.  In fact we left before 830pm so no harm done.

And if there is a concern on timing there are polite ways to say there is another reservation at this table later in the evening.  We are reasonable people.  We get it.   We don't need a rude, snippy attitude throughout the entire dinner.

Would I go back?  Absolutely not.  There are plenty of places in the city with good food AND excellent service.  For the high price of this, you could do better in many other wonderful restaurants the city has to offer.
author: Dennis O.

description: I went here on a first date and I will never forget it! You look down a random alley way that seems like nothing exists down it, but then you see the BIX name in lights. You walk toward it and find a sunk door. You are greeted by the staff who welcome you and hang your coat! Before even looking at the bar the bartender asks you from across the room, "What will it be?", and motions you over with a spot perfectly waiting for you. A live band of piano and cello play jazzy kind of music that really sets the tone. Once your table is ready you are escorted upstairs to a beautiful table :) The food was AMAZING! I took a chance and tried the special which was trout, and I never eat trout, but the description made it sound heavenly! It was delicious and a night to remember! Thank you BIX! I recommend this to any one and everyone that I meet or see.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
OK. 

I think the price you pay here is more for the ambiance and live jazz band. It is definetly very very romantic and has a upscale feel to it. Especially if you sit on the second- you can look down and see the jazz band and the buzz at the bar. This place is certainly loud when the band comes in to play. 

The food was ok to me. I had the smoked salmon salad for appetizer- the salad was mized with some root that was chopped in thin strands (I forgot which root). It taste fresh and was almost filling. Almost. 

I also had the lobster pasta. This is certainly very rich and very very salty. However, I will say that I love the pasta. It was cooked to perfection and had a great chewiness to it. The heavy seasoning overpowered the lobster and pasta. 

It's nice- but I would come here only for drinks and to listen to some jazz.
author: Anna C.

description: Great service great jazz music Great pork belly. Looks like you are in an Art Deco hall.
author: Chris H.

description:
We wanted to take our newly-engaged friends out for a celebratory dinner and I had found BIX through Zagat's romantic restaurant list.  Overall it was a great night, but I think it may have had more to do with the company than the food. Total stars = 3.5.

STARTERS:
Deviled Eggs with Truffles, Radish and Chives: 
This is the only thing I find myself still thinking about.  Absolutely delicious!! Not too rich, very flavorful, and one of the few deviled eggs around the city that I've seen made without bacon.
Dungeness Crab Rolls in Brioche with Meyer Lemon Aioli: 
This was just okay and nothing to write home about in my opinion.  This starter has a little too much bread and BIX gives everyone a dinner roll so if I were to do this over, I would save room for another dish.
Potato Pillows with Crème Fraîche and American Sturgeon Caviar:
This was pretty good and seems to be a pretty popular starter based on other Yelp reviews.  The caviar was a nice touch, and, while good, not something I would have to get if I go back.
À la minute Ceviche with Chiles, Avocado and Toasted Corn Nuts:
I love ceviche, but unfortunately I was pretty disappointed by this starter.  I am used to having large pieces of fresh fish, but this was served on a plate with slices of avocado and barely any fish (picture included!) If you're considering the ceviche, I would recommend trying something else.

ENTREES:
Wagyu Beef Bavette:
The boys had the wagyu beef which came with creamed spinach and mashed potatoes.  Since I don't eat beef, I didn't try this, but my boyfriend said it was just "okay" and pretty salty (which was a theme of the entire dinner!)  He's someone who loves food and loves his meat, so his lack of enthusiasm tells me a lot.  

Trout with Brussels Sprouts and Onions:
I had the trout and asked that it be made without bacon.  The dish was just okay; I definitely have had better fish.  Even though it was trout, it came out pink and tasted a lot like salmon.  In my opinion, this dish was too salty.

Maine Lobster Spaghetti:
Our other friend had the lobster spaghetti and she seemed to really like it.  We didn't try it, but there didn't seem to be complaints there.  It came out in a big dish with some bright tomatoes

DESSERTS:
Bananas Foster w/ Vanilla Ice Cream:
This was pretty delicious and I would recommend it - the bananas weren't too sweet and the warmth of the bananas foster worked well with the ice cream.

Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding:
Meh - I love bread pudding, but the chocolate was just overkill.  The whole thing tasted like a giant brownie that was too dry and waaay too sweet for my taste.  

AMBIANCE AND SERVICE:
- Definitely a romantic setting with the tall ceilings and dim lighting. I liked that there was valet which was quick and also a coat check upon entering the restaurant.
- They initially placed us upstairs at a table and we saw an open booth and I'm grateful that they allowed us to move.
- However, because we were in a booth, the boys sitting on the outside had to get out to allow us to use the restroom.  When we got up to use the restroom, our waiter came over and made a comment about how we can't just leave without paying.  Maybe it was a joke, but it was definitely tactless.
author: Alvina W.

description:
We went to BIX for our belated Vday dinner. 

Parking was easy around the area. Well, maybe we got lucky. Reservation was 6:30p so free parking. Or you can do valet for $10.

We were greeted by the hostess and i'd kindly asked for a table upstairs and she gave us 2 the "dictator" table. It felt weird at first because you are exposed to the entire place. Felt like Al Pacino or a mafia boss at their respective italian restaurant. We totally loved it. Live band is playing nice yet gentle music and with the crowd below us. The entire atmosphere was perfect. Damn, the place made me feel romantic. haha

Services was TOP notch. We had by far one of the best waiter. He was attentive, caring, charming, and just made us feel welcomed. This is how services should be at all places. I swear if restaurants would pay a lil more attention to their services...it would add so much more stars to their venue.

Food was a delish. Everything we had tonite was excellent.
- Steak Tartare - WOW! this was our favorite. the flavors that hit our pallet was unbelievable.
- Chicory and Asian Pear Salad - there was lots of different flavors in it with the pomegranate and bacon which gave it a distinct flavorful taste.
- Lobster spaghetti - generous portion and right amount of mixture of flavors.
- Truffle burger - i thought the burger was good but the fries was even better
- Dessert was Chocolate pudding - it was multi layered of yumminess. if that's a word. 

It was pricey but with the services and experience we had tonite. It was all worthed it. Definitely a must come back again for the steak tartare!!
author: Ernie P.

description:
Bix to me is just a "duh, of course I love it" restaurant.  Everything about this place is fantastic.  You just can't go wrong.  

I've usually gone with the strategy of spend all my money on drinks and the phenomenal apps, and skip the entrees.  But, this time around, I embraced the entire experience.  

Please don't forgo the cocktails.  The bartenders here just do it right.

Whether you like brussel sprouts or not, you'd be a fool to pass up on the ones here.  SO FREAKING ORGASMICALLY GOOD! 

Lobster spaghetti for me. Black truffle burger & fries for my friend. I'd give more detail except I was swept away into heaven for the time being and can barely remember anything except for my taste bliss.  

The butterscotch brownies were...just ok.  I should've had a liquid dessert instead (ie: bourbon).

GO there, right now...deplete your savings, go without heat for the month, brown bag lunch for the week...do what you need to do...but go...
author: Susan L.

description:
We have been to Bix many times and in the past loved the experience.  We ran into a new experience- you can only have the table for 2 hours.  We were not told that in advance, or we never would have made the reservation.  The waiter was aggressive about getting our order.  We told him we wanted to enjoy our cocktails and relax- he was back with the manger, who was totally rude.  It was reiterated that we could only have the table for two hours - 45 minutes had already passed.

This experience was distressful, to say the least.  And, embarrassing for our guest. No one enjoyed the food at that point.  No dessert, no coffee-we were reminded that we were exceeding our time limit.  For the price point - after all the years we have been loyal customers, there are too many other wonderful restaurants to enjoy.  We won't be back.
author: nina l.

description:
Swanky Bix never gets old.

It's been years since I last visited Bix.  I have fond memories of the bar scene with friends from my single days.  It's also where my husband and I had our first kiss out on the front step waiting for the valet.  These are big memories to live up to and Bix delivered this past weekend.  

Bix has a distinctive air of sophistication reminiscent of a bygone era with the long elegant wood bar, beautiful art, old fashioned booths and low lighting.  It's the place to wear that sexy dress in your closet.  You can't help but order a cocktail or glass of champagne when you arrive to get into the jazzy mood.  In spite of all this or maybe because of it, Bix still has a hip vibe to it.  

Getting to the food...I have never had a bad meal at Bix.  The heirloom tomatoes were ripe from the vine and outstanding with the burrata and basil.  The whole fish was well prepared and expertly deboned.  If you are a lover of truffles, you can bet on the deviled eggs, hamburger and fries.  A perfect trifecta of truffled heaven.  Simple, but very satisfying.
author: Patricia M.

description: Incredible look, feel, ambiance.  Full of everything you want classic SF to be.  Steak Tartare was unbelievable.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Dinner was good, but not great.   I had the $30 cheeseburger (yes, $30) and my wife had the lobster spaghetti for $42.  Both were pretty good - burger and fries both had truffles, which party explains the $30 price tag.   

 We also had the crab roll appetizer - 4 bite sized pieces for $16.   That one definitely wasn't worth the price.

Piano player was a nice touch, but he stopped about halfway through dinner and never came back.
author: Dave C.

description: BIX is one of the best dining experiences I have had, anywhere -- and one that I have enjoyed on multiple occasions from the late 1990s to more recently (2012).   It is hard for most restaurants with such a high reputation to sustain its momentum, but some BIX continues to do so.  The food is great.   The atmosphere is without peer these days.  The service is excellent.  It is a place that never gets old.  Expensive but worth it.
author: Nathaniel P.

description: What a nice restaurant! The roasted corn soup is to die for!! VERY great service as well! :)
author: Britney S.

description:
The Good:
Truffled Bix Burger on Rye was out of this world.
Server was attentive and helpful.
Ambiance was nice.

The Bad:
Sampled a range of starters.  Every last one was mediocre at best.  The steak tartare was bland.  The crab rolls in brioche were filled with a crab meat so drenched in mayo is was lifeless.  No flavor, no texture.  The beet and chevre skewers used the most abysmally flavorless goat cheese.
Cocktails were disappointingly unremarkable.  

The Ugly:
The singer for the live jazz trio wanted to thank all the servers and staff at Bix for making the place great.  Unfortunately she demanded rapt attention from every diner in the restaurant while she meandered through her drawn out speech.  "Excuse Me!  Excuse Me!" she scolded the dining room at least 3 times as diners lost patience and got back to their expensive meals.  To the singer: the sentiment was nice, but your speech took far too long. People are there first for the food and second for the entertainment, not the other way around. Do not scold them for your ineptitude.  If the crowd is losing interest, it is you who are doing something wrong, not the crowd.
author: Eli B.

description: One of the worst meals I've had in a while. The meatballs were cold and tasted like they were from a can. The fried shrimp was chewy and fishy, with no flavor whatsoever. The fried chicken appetizer was the only sub par item. The streak tartar prepared tableside wasn't horrible, but salty and nothing to write home about. The server was almost as rude as the manager. When the manager came by to check how we were doing, we told him we weren't very happy with the quality of the food thus far. I couldn't believe it when I heard his response, "well there are chefs that come from around the world and love our food." Well, that's great, but owning a restaurant myself, I am no stranger to food.. And this was overpriced and NOT good. With all the great restaurants in the city, I honestly would never recommend this place to anyone. From service to food, this was a complete fail.
author: Jaclyn S.

description:
We came here for our anniversary dinner while in San Francisco. It was a bit hard to find parking, but we lucked out and came upon a car leaving a meter right next to the alley Bix is in. The meters were free after 6pm, so make your reservations accordingly and give yourself plenty of time to drive in circles (if you choose to drive downtown). 

Appetizer: Mini Lamb Burgers. This came with exactly four small burgers, a couple of bites each. They were very tasty, but make sure to say how you want them cooked if you don't want to see red meat.

Starter: Roasted Tomato Soup with Gouda Grilled Cheese Croutons. This was great (also a great portion to share). The best part was the croutons- soft and gooey cheese goodness. The soup itself, although good, was not much better than Campbell's...as long as you use milk instead of water!

Dinner: Bix Burger for the wife, and seared Albacore for me. Both of these were really good. Again, make sure you say how you want them cooked unless you enjoy raw food.

Desert: Chocolate and Butterscotch Brownies with whipped cream. These were awesome. 

They knew it was our anniversary and had a congratulatory place-card on the table. We were a bit disappointed that we weren't offered anything complimentary such as a few strawberries but understand that a lot of people probably celebrate there, and it would get costly. 

The atmosphere was really nice: dark and romantic, but it was very noisy from the people at the bar downstairs. The jazz music didn't start until we were getting ready to leave, so I can't say anything for that. The only bad part of the experience is the fact that you can go in dressed up for a nice dinner and be seated next to people in jeans and tee-shirts. The website specifically states " jackets preferred," but people are still hooked on this modern casual crappiness.
author: Kurt C.

description:
We started with their crab cake roll for the table.  It was delicious!!  Then moved on to our baby lettuce salad with fresh strawberries.  The amount of dressing was just right, not overdone nor underdressed.  The flavor was fresh, organic, refreshing!  Then for main entree, I had the braised short ribs with spring vegetables, marble potatoes, bone marrow and toast with mustard.  Everthing was delicious!  The short ribs and the spring vegetables were flavorful.  The short ribs were tender.  The bone marrow portion was a bit generous and rich for me, but it paired well with the mustard toast.  My friend had the lobster spaghatti.  It looked delicious and she confirmed the taste was exquisite as well! 

I was disappointed to find out that they removed the blood orange margarita from their cocktail menu due to it's not the season.  We had Warm Chocolate bread pudding for dessert, great!
author: Gina W.

description:
Took my boyfriend here for his birthday dinner, and was extremely pleased with everything. I specifically chose the place because of its ambiance and live music, and both were great! I love how old-fashioned everything feels. For a girl who feels like she was supposed to have been born in the 40s (at least for the fashion), this is definitely my kind of place. 

We ordered the house-made mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto, the split pea soup, the pork chop (a special), the chicken hash, and creamed spinach. Everything was very tasty, especially the chicken hash which is basically a crab cake made with chicken. For dessert we ordered the strawberries with fresh whipped brown sugar cream, and our server brought out complimentary ice cream with a candle in it for the birthday celebration! Speaking of our server, he was also excellent--very attentive, helpful, and available, but he didn't hover. 

We also ordered the Bix pinot noir (apparently they have a winery), which was decent, but not really worth $56 in my opinion. Still, the meal as a whole was surprisingly reasonable in terms of price. The fact that we got to listen to jazz while we ate just made it an even better deal!
author: Shawn B.

description:
Went in for a late night drink and if the food is half as good as the decor, it should get ten stars.

Limited street parking available. They do have valet service.
author: S M.

description:
This place is extremely overrated. It's located in a dark bum-alley which gives a horrible impression amongst tourists and unfortunately the food doesn't live up the the hype.

The main entree was okay, but the rest of the food sucked. Service was slow and the price of everything is outrageous.
author: Brian E.

description:
"I guess the meal is on her!" says the girlfriend, as we spent Valentine's day on Sunday, the 13th.

Dinner and a show tonight when a waitress spilled red wine on a woman. Luckily, the spill-ee was very nice and funny about it. "This is a $200 shirt!!!.... that I got for $20!" :)

The manager was not amused lol

As for my table, the girlfriend was looking gorgeous, as usual. As for me... I could not say the same. I wore a white collared shirt with my black American Apparel hoodie! To say I was sorely underdressed would be an understatement! The girlfriend told me to take off my hoodie and walk to the kitchen and start serving people cuz I looked just like them haha!

The ambiance of BIX is wonderful. It felt like I was in a modern 1920's film where they go from a black & white shot to a colored view of the interior. Very jazzy, calm, and cool. We sat upstairs where servers would go all the way to the back door and magically end up downstairs again.

Speaking of servers and service, our server was very nice and prompt. Food came out orderly and quickly. I'm glad we didn't have to wait forever for our food, cuz I was starving! The food was good, but I don't think it was worth the price. I'll rate the food first:

Potato Pillows: Cavier on top was delicious. We wondered if they ordered it in bulk by the barrel-full! Couldn't really taste the creme fraiche, it didn't add anything but color to the dish. The potato itself reminded us of McDonald's hashbrowns. $14 for McDonald's hashbrowns... That caviar better have been really expensive to charge that much for it! We enjoyed it, but not "$14 enjoyment." I'll stick to $1.25 McDonald's "Potato Pillows" next time!

Chicken Hash - Chicken-y. Don't know what else to say about it. Two patties with ground up chicken mixed with mashed potato and fried. It was kinda bland. Reminded us of croquettes, but in larger form. A dipping sauce might have done some magic for the dish, but it was pretty bare. I like croquettes and sharing them like tapas, but this dish was not worth $20.

Black Truffle Cheese Burger with Truffle Fries - The burger was cooked exactly the way I ordered it. This was actually my first time just seeing truffle separately in a dish. I've only seen it incorporated within a sauce or seasoning. I tasted it without the burger and, to be very honest and frank, it tasted like a toned-down mushroom. Maybe my tastebuds aren't sensitive enough ;p  I don't think I'll ever spend extra money to get truffle in my dish lol Other than that, the burger was awesome. The truffle didn't add anything to the burger. The grilled onion on top was awesome. The bread was good. If they take out the truffle, can it cost less please? Couldn't taste any truffle on the fries either. Seemed like there was parmesan on it instead... which tasted good though. Overall, I would get this again minus the truffles for a lower price haha Without the truffle, I guess it's just a regular BIX burger? Any time a burger + fries is over $12, it's most likely not worth it.

Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding - The girlfriend LOVED it. She loves bread pudding though. It reminded me of a tame brownie. The whip cream on top looked like an egg shaped ice cream. I wish it was ice cream. But it was meant to not be super sugary and it complimented the rest of the meal, and ended the meal, really well. I'd get this again and thought it was actually worth the price compared to everything else.

Now then, it seems like I was rather displeased with all the dishes that we ate. But, on the contrary, I enjoyed the dishes quite a lot! It's the crazy prices that were not pleasing to me. I enjoyed my entire time there though.

I'm a fan, but I would not come here regularly.
author: Timothy L.

description: We were in SF and a friend had recommended this spot, so we gave it a shot. Wow. We are so happy we came. The ambiance is wonderful. Our waiter, Chris, was great and was very knowledgable on the menu. We split an incredible heirloom tomato and fresh mozzarella salad that they made table side. We then had a corn soup with a habanero sauce that we shared that had just a hint of heat to it but great flavor. Finally, we had the duck and got the side of smashed potatoes fried in duck fat. The potatoes were indescribably awesome. The only reason I give service 4 stars is that we wanted to try the fish too but knew it was too much food. We found out as we were leaving that we could have ordered half of two dishes. Would still go back though!
author: Ethan B.

description: Very average food in a very sexy setting. The ambiance is wonderful but stick to the very small appetizers if you must eat here as the main courses are average at best.
author: Jim K.

description:
Date Friday Night.

Ordered Brandt Prime Bavette and Duck Breast. 
Delicious. Melt in your mouth delicious.

Drinks: Sidecar and La Floridita Daiquiri 

Live Music and great paintings.

I am coming back.
author: Tergel P.

description: We went to Bix for our daughter's 16 year old birthday and had a wonderful time.  We needed a place that was open late - they are open until around midnight; plus it's beautiful, romantic and features live jazz, music that we all enjoy.  The service, food, and drinks were excellent.  The atmosphere was relaxing and mellow. The jazz trio was great; they took our requests and were friendly.  There was a happy birthday card on the table when we got there which pleased our honoree.  The prices were appropriate and worth it since we were all happy.  I would recommend Bix for a nice dinner or just drinks at their beautiful bar while you take in the jazz, and to keep in mind when you need a nice place to go after 10PM when many places are closed.
author: Cindy M.

description: We stumbled upon this wonderful place last year during a holiday trip to SFO. It was open late and the food and libations didn't disappoint. The vibe was wonderful.
author: Cristina O.

description: The service is great, the venue is beautiful, but the food is mediocre and extremely expensive for what you get.
author: Heather R.

description: The place  is very cool inside. Just beautiful. Dark and great atmosphere. The food is ok. The apps were better then the entrees. The waiter was a little pushy. They are kind of snobby on there reservations cause they are busy. But in the end tried to be very accommodating and nice. Should experience this place. Great taste of hidden charms in San Francisco.
author: Jaffe L.

description:
I want my ashes sprinkled at Bix! 

We discovered Bix in the '90s.  Wild horses can't drag my husband to a proper restaurant.   Tadich is ok for lunch, but dinner ?  And an early one at that.

One of Matt's vendors took us to Bix and it was love at first sight.  Actually, second sight -- it's hidden in an spooky ally.  

Bix hasn't really changed in the past 15 years.  Fun, elegant clientele.  Wonderful and sexy lighting.  Great jazzy music, and I don't even like Jazz!

We know most of the waiters and have tried almost everything on the menu, and keep going back.  

My favorite in the City and that's saying something. :)
author: Sherylle W.

description: Great food and atmosphere. The truffle pasta was to die for as were the apps and the dessert left me in a food coma. I have recommend this play to several people since my dinner and all have given stellar reviews. Ps don't forget to have a to die for cocktail before dinner.
author: Axay P.

description:
This is a long overdue review for Bix.  We came in with a reservation and for some reason they were really backed up.  Though we waited at the bar and was given complimentary appetizers and drinks for our trouble, we finally had to leave because we were too hungry to wait any more.  The manager then personally escorted us to a nearby restaurant and made sure we could get in there before leaving us.  He then gave us his card and said to call him anytime we wanted to come back.  

A few months later we decided to take some friends out to dinner and called the manager at Bix.  He promised a table on time.  This time we were seated right away.  We proceeded to order bottles of wine and four entrees, and a couple of deserts.  Much to our surprise, the manager comped the ENTIRE meal, our alcohol included, for our previous trouble.  I have never seen customer service like this in my entire life.  We were dumbfounded.  Needless to say we have been back numerous times since (this time paying) and always love our experience at Bix.  The drink options are great and everything we've eaten there is wonderful.  They have made a customer for life!
author: Kalyani B.

description:
First things first, this review will be about their tuna tartare (not bad), and the famous $30 cheeseburger (OVERRATED). 

I understand the pedigree behind the burger, and it's one of the more bolder, open-faced burgers in the city. However, there just wasn't enough omphf behind the flavors and house sauces (if any). 

It's a great fixture of FiDi with the live music nights and the speakeasy history. But for sure, save yourself the time and skip the burger. You can find MUCH better options in North Beach and at Wayfare Tavern. 

I want to really like this place and ball like an investment banker. Unfortunately, it wasn't a truly memorable dining experience.
author: Abel L.

description:
I rarely ever give 5 stars, but Bix deserves a near-perfect score.   Strongly recommended for a "special occasion" romantic dinner.  The entrance from a non-descript alley lead to a two-story dining room with 1930's or 40's vibe. Well-spaced tables. Live jazz piano and vocalist. Attentive wait staff, but not snooty or pretentious. 

Highlight:  Deviled eggs with truffles. Oysters. Pork loin with chutney. 

Con:  Noise level and room temperature were both too high at times. And so were the prices - which means that we can't afford to eat there as often as we'd like.
author: Drew S.

description:
Although I've been to many, many restaurants all over the bay area, Bix is one of the few that I gravitate back to over and over and over again. The ambiance here is the best in town in my opinion - it's a supper club with a live jazz singer(s)and someone on the piano nightly to serenade you as you dine. They even recently published their own handbook offering advice on food,drinks, music and art that includes the recipes for some of their most popular appetizers. Their bar is VERY popular with the financial district crowd and rightfully so. 

Now about the food - I have tried almost everything and love everything here. If it's your first time at Bix, I recommend the Selection of Hors d'oeuvres for the table. My favorite main courses are the main lobster spaghetti and the kobe bavette steak (two staples on their menu) but you really can't go wrong with any other pick. If it's heirloom tomato season, don't pass up the heirloom tomato cart! Love love love Bix!
author: Viet T.

description: I wanted to have a birthday party for my husband in a amazing, fun and adventurous place.  I found BIX on the web and loved what I saw.  I called and reserved a place a week ahead of our date.   I did not say a word to my husband because I wanted to surprise him. He only knew we would meet in the city around 6pm. I called daily to check on the status of our reservation.The WONDERFUL staff accommodated me and were upbeat all through my anxiousness LOL. On the day of our party, I texted my husband the address and he immediately texted me back exclaiming his sheer joy!!! When my driver pulled up in front of the venue I fell in love with it sight unseen.  When I strolled into the waiting area it was love at first sight. Everything fell perfectly into place and the staff the drinks and the food were 5 star.  I am a vegan and the kitchen made me a delicious vegan platter.  BIX has been my husbands favorite place for over 20 years and it is now my favorite place. WE WILL BE BACK.
author: Rosa Lokey O.

description: Bix is one of my all-time favorite places. The ambiance alone is reason to visit. There is a vibe here that is indescribable. The bar is beautiful and the wine list is great. The food is incredible, never been disappointed and always blown away. I LOVE the artwork. I think that perhaps the paintings help create the ambiance. I know they use to sell a book of all of the artwork. The artist is Mark Stock-amazing.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
Food: 5 stars
Service: -1 star (it really should be -2 or -3, but the food was SO good)

We came here for our anniversary. We had a 7pm reservation on a Saturday night, which didn't start off well as we spent $20 and 45 minutes for a 1.5 mile cab ride there (thanks, Chinese New Year Parade). Once we arrived, the unpleasant hostess seated us, and laid our "Happy Anniversary" card on the table. Our server was equally unpleasant from "Hello"... or lack-there-of (there was no greeting, just "ice water, yeah?"). 

About the food... They brought warm, fresh rolls and butter to the table, which helped soften the taxi-cab and bad greeting blow. We started with the dungeness crab rolls (4 perfectly toasted, buttery, crab-filled mini sandwiches) and the house-made mozzarella and prosciutto (creamy, fresh, salty, everything it should be and more). Hubbs got the truffle burger for his entree - which was pretty close to perfect, and not too overwhelming. I got the red snapper special (after beating it out of the server), which was fresh and tasty, but not as notable as the rest of the meal. 

The snooty manager greeted every other table, but ours. Our server either totally missed the ball, or assumed that we were young, infrequent diners who would automatically tip badly and weren't worth the effort. She never even acknowledged the anniversary card staring her in the face. It's always disappointing when a great culinary experience is lessened due to poor customer service.

ALSO- no live music!?! Wth? We must've gone at the wrong time :( 

Would return for the food.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
So Great! This is the PERFECT place to go a nice dinner with family in town - its old school SF, so my bf Grandma LOVED it.... the bow-tied servers and the basic but delicious food!

Service was perfect - appetizers were 4 on a plate, but they gave of 5 of each one we ordered so each person could enjoy - thank you!

The Salmon tartare was so amazing we ordered 2 - I dont even like salmon and this was melt in your mouth tasty and the dill was perfect. 
The hand made mozzarella with prosciutto app was also very very good. 

Great drinks, nice wine list. 

For dinner we each got something different:
BIX Burger - tasty as always
Truffle Burger - Looked AMAZING, truffles stuffed in the middle of the meat
Trout (the special) - light and tasty with lots of artichoke 
Duck - SO GOOD, would order this again, and it comes with spaetzel and apples
Prawns - pretty good, light and a little boring compared to the others, served with a tasty farro.

Upstairs is quieter than down - keep that in mind if you are with a group you plan to talk with a lot :)
author: Jessica L.

description:
I was disappointed at the start due to the service of the host.  I arrived 10 minutes early for my reservation, checked in and asked where to find the ladies room.  When I returned, the host looked at me like I was from another planet and when I asked to be seated, he told me that I would be seated when my entire party arrived, but that I was welcome to make myself comfortable at the bar.  His response made me feel like I was in an SNL skit, because we were right next to the bar, which was obviously extremely crowded--no seats and very little standing room--and I was carrying a purse, coat, gym bag and shopping bag.  It was obvious that nobody could make themselves comfortable at that bar, much less someone who was carrying all of the stuff I had.  I would have understood the "can't sit until party is complete" thing if the restaurant had been crowded, but it was not--I counted six open tables.  So I just passive-aggressively stood with all of my stuff right next to him at the host stand for about 10 minutes.  When it became apparent that I would be waiting for much longer (my boyfriend called to tell me he was running about 20 minutes late), I asked again if I could sit at the table, and the host conceded, displaying what appeared to be some resentment.  What is up with that?  There was no way I could order and consume a beverage at a bar that crowded, but I could easily order a pre-dinner drink at my table.  His attitude didn't even make sense for the restaurant economically.

Once seated, it was a different story.  Our server was helpful and pleasant, and our food was delicious.  The pork chop was one of the best I've ever had anywhere, and the sides were very good as well.  The brussels sprouts side dish was excellent, rivaling Barbacco's (although a much smaller portion).  The ceviche starter was very good, and the bananas foster was a great finish to the meal.  

The ambiance was lovely, and I really enjoyed the live piano and singing.  I would have given it 5 stars were it not for the host's attitude, which made me feel downright unwelcome and made me consider leaving before the meal began.
author: Catherine H.

description:
What a gem of a restaurant!  Last night we took a group of 9 to Bix and had a lovely experience.  It is located down a cute small street and has a "Speak easy" type of feel.  You see a small lit up sign outside the door identifying the restaurant but when you walk in the door a huge lovely room is revealed.  1930's themed decor and background music (including a 3 piece jazz trio playing throughout the evening).  The restaurant is a converted State Assessor's building so there are large columns, high ceilings, and part of the restaurant is located on a top floor that looks down onto the main restaurant.  It is dimly lit which makes it conducive to a romantic dinner for two or a nice intimate family/friend dinner. 

The menu is lovely.  Not a large menu but more than enough variety to please all at the table with some specialties that were absolutely amazingly delicious.  The only thing to be aware of is that it is a pretty pricey place to take a larger group but definitely worth it.  

As a side note, the bar area was really special looking (takes up one complete side of the restaurant) and looked like a great place to stop by for a drink and an appetizer.  Although a pricey place you can still get a drink and an appetizer for about $20 . They also had lots of old fashioned style drinks with a modern flare that looked fun as well (ie. manhatten, gimlet).
author: Michelle C.

description:
A couple weeks ago we went to Bix for a work dinner and were totally unprepared. Yes, it's in the Financial District but it's only three $$$ on Yelp and San Francisco restaurants tend to be a little more laid back. This smaller, alleyway restaurant however is definitely working hard to keep it's classic feel (think piano and jazz singer in the corner, fluted columns and a whole lot of mahogany). I'll be honest, while most of the restaurant customers were in suits, we were rocking a collection of ripped jeans, fleece jackets and plaid. Great apparel for SF, not for Bix. Thankfully the bar area is right near the entrance and their martinis are quite superb.

However, it was hard to feel uncomfortable for long as the friendly hosts and servers chatted us up. We slipped into a comfy half booth, half table situation and assess the wine list, which is quite lengthy. After ordering a pinot noir we had a go at the starters menu. First must have on the list, potato pillows. How can you go wrong with something called potato pillows? These bite sized morsels were almost like gnocchi but a little more mashed potato-like. Topped with creme fraiche and caviar, they were decadent but strangely homey in a way. If you're going with a second appetizer (or you have no desire to try something called potato pillows which is just silly), go with the steak tartare. It's prepared table-side, so you get to watch them break up the running egg yoke into the steak, along with shallots, capers (a great addition to any tartare!), parsley and mustard. I also tried the pork belly banh mi (a Vietnamese style sandwich), which comes out in little bite-sized sandwiches and was surprisingly good for an American restaurant with no clear ties to anything Vietnamese. The deviled eggs were good (aren't they always?) but I think you can get better ones elsewhere. I can't recall what the oyster selection was that day but they were pretty gritty and I got a piece of shell in my mouth, so I'd pass on those.

After the little banh mi sandwich bites, I was in the mood for pork belly so I went with the pork loin and belly entree. The pork is served atop a warm potato salad with a mustard seed aioli, which gives the dish a punch of flavor. The pork was cooked perfectly. The belly was a good balance of soft and crisp and loin was moist. In retrospect though I wish I had ordered the Bix Club Burger, a black truffle cheeseburger. A couple people at the table ordered it and it looked amazing. I found out afterward's it's on 7x7's "2013 Big Eats" list.  I did manage to snag a couple truffle fries from their places, which were of course delicious.

After that you'd think we'd be ridiculously full, but what sane minded person passes on dessert? Especially when you have the opportunity to say "I'll have one of everything." After trying a bite of everything and it all being amazing, I can still recommend without hesitation the  bananas foster with dark rum and vanilla ice cream. While it didn't have the fancy flambe presentation, it melted into this creamy soup substance that we were literally trying to scrap the bowl for. To summarize, I'd recommend Bix just don't wear jeans. It's listed on Zagat as a top place for a date, so get dressed up and go with someone special.
author: Larisa J.

description: I had SUCH a wonderful time at Bix last night! I got a gift certificate from my office, so my boyfriend and I decided to get all dressed up and have a fancy night out. We got sat immediately and our server was very prompt and knowledgeable. We ordered the deviled eggs (which were INSANE with the truffles on top), the oysters (also amazing), and the bone marrow. It was my first time eating marrow and I really enjoyed it. I got the gin cocktail, and he got the Manhattan. Both drinks were great. For the entree I ordered the duck and it was perfect. The side of brussel sprouts were a bit over-salted, but it was still good. He ordered the fish special (trout) and it was sooo buttery and delicious. For dessert the server recommended this awesome after dinner sweet wine, and we ordered the bread pudding. It was a great pairing. All in all, a wonderful evening. I would love to go back when I have a bunch of money to spend on a nice meal. The ambiance was also really nice. The pianist played Christmas tunes all night, and the music was at the perfect background volume.
author: Regina L.

description:
Gosh, I'm really disappointed with Bix. I had the DAT dinner tonite and well, it wasn't very good. I thought I'd give the hearts of romaine salad another try eventhough Irene S. clearly suggested the eggplant soup in her review. Unfortunately, she was right -- way too much dressing! I hardly tasted any salad. Yuck! Luckily, my main dish, the chicken hash a la bix, was better. But to think that this entree normally costs $19 just amazes me because it really was just ok, nothing special. Finally for dessert I had the chocolate brioche pudding. I tasted more fudge syrup than pudding. Also, I'd call it more like a soft brownie marinated in chocolate fudge. Sigh.

The good news is that our waiter was super friendly! A couple of times he couldn't tell if I wanted to order a cocktail or not so he'd say "Don't be shy - That's what I'm here for!"  Awww! 

Still, when you go to an establishment that charges $20-$30 for entrees you'd expect high quality dishes. This place just doesn't do it for me.
author: Helen Y.

description:
My siblings and I had dinner here last night and it was very interesting. 

We got there and my sis was running a tab bit late so we started at the bar for some cocktails. I had their famous "ginger gimlet" and it was very refreshing. It was so good that my sis-in-law liked it as well (she ordered their mai tai) so being the good person that I am =) - I switched with her. I didn't want to order b/c I knew it was going to be a long night with the drinking. Needless to say, I didn't finish the mai tai.

Then the host came after us and he told us he wanted to seat us already b/c he didn't want to "rush us" b/c there's a reservation at 8 pm and it's strict. Those were some of the words that he dropped to us... impressive. NOT! What a turn off!

We got seated, my sis arrived (thankfully) and on to the night.

We ordered the following:
ME: mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto with olive oil and the Kobe steak with a side of their special mushrooms. The mozzarella was delicious! Really good and just the right amount of goodiness! The Kobe steak was just cooked just right! The mushrooms were a good compliment to the steak. Wonderful. 

Sis: potato pillows with caviar and lamb burger. She liked both dishes and the potato pillows were delicious. 

Bro: deviled eggs with truffle and the lamb chop. He devoured both as well.

Sis-in-law: potato pillows and she got the special of the night (salmon). Liked it as well.

The only reason why it's just 4 stars - their host was a jerk. I don't know what was his problem. He gave us an ultimatum of how long we can stay in our table. Such a turn off! 

BUT our server was amazing...considering we ordered a lot! We had a bottle of champagne and a pinot. Then for dessert, we ordered a chocolate bread pudding and the brownies with drinks as well. 

The waitstaff (with the exception of the host) - were all great. Would probably come back to take the boy next time around.

The jazz playing in the background ... just added a good ambiance for the night.
author: Cath M.

description: If there was lower than a 1 star, the restaurant side would deserve it. The bartenders were great... While we waited for our table. 1 hour, 2 hours.... Why did we wait so long after already being on "the list" and with a specific 10:30 time... Only because the bartenders were cordial, made great drinks and prompt. This place is a bar, the restaurant is obviously run by, or hosted by amateurs at the very best. 1 star again, only because the bartenders' 4 star efforts brought the restaurant up from a double 00. Will happily spend our evenings everywhere else.
author: Chad M.

description:
This is a great, old-style place with art-deco-incluenced deco harkening back to the 30s, and wonderful, traditional-haute American cuisine.  It has a wonderful bar that is the focus of the downstairs, with somce nice table seating downstairs plus great seating upstairs.  My favourite tables are the upstairs ones facing the baclony with a great view of the bar below.

It has excellent steak tartare, a wonderful beet appetizer, excellent bananas foster, and great cocktails done right.  These include a good handle on more traditional cocktails and a good ability to make others to order.  This place, for example, highlighted the Sazerac before it was rediscovered by the popular cocktail crowd and reemerged all over the place.  it's not a good place for kids, but is great for couples.
author: Wulfstan C.

description: Tucked away in an alley, this restaurant is definitely a hot spot. We had a wait of just a few minutes, which we spent hanging around the super crowded bar. No worries, this place has a great energy. We were seated on the bottom floor, nice view of the whole scene, and just far away enough from the live music. Food was great, as well as the service. Extra points for good cocktails. Classy, traditional decor, but not stuffy. High evergy vibe. The live music is what really puts this place above and beyond.
author: Olivia H.

description: Definitely get the braised cocktail meatballs,  the pork belly and the house mozzarella skewers. The only complaint I have is that I had a 8 o'clock reservation, and wasn't seated until 8:40.
author: Ali C.

description:
Atmosphere, amazing food, knowledgeable waiter, wonderful music. This place has it all. Not to mention you feel like you're walking into a secret supper club. Dining in this restaurant makes you wish it was 1930 again...I would have to say my #1 dining experience in San Francisco so far.

Stu was the most knowledgeable amazing waiter. If you don't get him, you should request him. He gives you inside information, history about the restaurant, the area, and Mark Stock whose paintings hang in the restaurant. This guy knows his stuff! And having a great waiter always makes the night memorable.

The music was amazing and the jazzy cats even stuck around and talked to my boyfriend and I after words. 

The deviled eggs were to die for and the prosciutto wrapped mozzarella was so so yummy. I got the steak bavette and short ribs with creamed spinach and potatoes and I enjoyed it to the last bite! Even my boyfriend who constantly rejects my homemade deviled eggs ate half of the plate! Not to mention most of the dishes have truffle...and like stu said, "Don't truffles make everything wonderful?". 

If you live in San Francisco this restaurant is a must and I recommend sitting downstairs so you can fully enjoy the music and clap, because these guys were so appreciative and they deserve it. 

Ooh and I almost forgot, the pear margarita helps round out the entire experience!
author: Heather T.

description:
This is quite the hidden gem within the Financial District. I loved the atmosphere of the restaurant and the fact that the wait staff wears white tuxedo jackets. It just reminded me of New York. The bar is elegant and spacious; I waited there for my friend to arrive. The food is delicious, well prepared and surprisingly well priced. I loved the chicken hash, which is one of their signature dishes. It was rich but not too heavy. Nilma and I also got to sit on the second floor where we got a beautiful view of the entire restaurant.

I recommended this place to my friend Dustin who took his boyfriend there for his birthday. They loved it! I would love to go on a date here.

~A
author: Alex C.

description:
It's always difficult writing the gazillionth review of a highly rated place, because typically you won't have anything valuable to add except a reinforcing 4-5 star rating, or (more likely) expressing disappointment in how over-hyped a restaurant really is. Fortunately, Bix is the former.

What I would like to add is HOLY CRAP, the Tomato Cart is amazing, and the desserts (try the banana foster and chocolate pudding cake) are pretty b-o-m-b as well. It's cool that they prepare the heirloom tomato mozzarella cheese dish table-side, as well as the steak tartare (American food Benihana style? So ofcourse parents loved it). Pass on the oysters, meh. Also, I don't remember the last time I was served tap water that was filtered at a restaurant. No yucky bleach aftertaste!

As for the main dishes, they were solid but nothing life changing. The halibut was served over a bed of overly sweet corn and beans, the kobe beef was prepared well but came out luke warm and didn't taste orgasmic like kobe is supposed to, and the lamb was kinda small but executed well like the kobe. All of which however, were very affordable about $28-36 per dish. They'll get you with the $15 appetizers though.

I'd love to come back on Thursdays for live music, happy hour and some good appetizers n desserts. My recommendation, come in on Sundays when parking is actually EASY in SF and they have flexible dining hours.
author: Jess C.

description:
We came to Bix for dinner to celebrate and welcome some "out of town" (out of the country, actually) guests.  This ended up being the perfect experience - fun, great food, and a really special setting.  We got a booth upstairs overlooking the restaurant and piano below.  The waiters wear white shirts/white jackets coupled with decor and the piano playing - the restaurant has this fun, upper class, 1930's / 1940's vibe.

We tried a few starters
   -salmon tartare on rye toast - quite fresh and tasty, very small bites
   -mini lamb burgers with cucumber - must try
   -marrow bones - how can you ever go wrong, really?
   -House mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto - these were AMAZING

Each starter above came with four bites.
 
I had the day's market fish, which happened to be salmon.  It was cooked perfectly accompanied by jimmy nardello peppers and shelling beans.

There's nothing bad I could say, dress up, come hungry, and ready to go back in time in style.

*Great place for small groups as the booths seemed to all be upstairs with fun balcony seating over the main dining area.
author: Janelle C.

description: The atmosphere was awesome and is a great place to take a date. Service was fantastic and the live music really complimented the mood for the restaurant. Food here was great (Bone Marrow was awesome!). This is a must try in the city!
author: Daniel C.

description: A very solid cocktail selection, try the one with smoked ice and honey combined with whiskey, as well as a nice jazzy atmosphere and a solid selection of appetizers. If you want to go away from the tourists and back to the old-school SF.
author: Fabien-Pierre N.

description:
It transports you back to yesteryears.  A good choice for a romantic dinner.  The atmosphere almost calls for it.  Valet parking is also a plus - especially in FiDi.

The drink selections aren't exactly imaginative, but at least they tried.... Now what should YOU try?  Definitely the potato pillows.

If you like the style of Bix you should also give Jardinière a shot.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Superb food.

Clearly, Bix is an SF favorite. If you haven't been, you should come here! Do it before you move away from San Francisco and regret it. 

Bix is one of those restaurants that picks the very best seasonal food they can find. We had a tomato cart appetizer. That's right, a whole cart of the freshest heirloom tomatoes in the county. I asked the server to have the chef prepare a vegetarian entree and they gave multiple choices - pasta or veggie plate. The pasta was super flavorful and fresh and I really appreciated the effort.

The server was friendly, if a little stuffy - but I guess it's that kind of place. We came for a celebratory lunch, and I feel the choice was a little decadent for that... but overall, very delicious. 

In any case, you won't leave disappointed with your meal.
author: Gretchen S.

description: Let's be clear. The Bix food is great, service really good -- attitude at the door, a little too much. Went there on a Saturday Open Table Reservation, received  so much attitude in adding a friend for a couple of beverages, that it really ruined the mood. And then, after spending some cash, being rushed by the waiter out, soiled all the goodwill he built up during the service. Oh well - perhaps we just caught an off moment, but irritated me enough to do a Yelp review.
author: J R.

description:
Friday night, 6:30 reservation. Had some relatives in town from San Diego who are very cool people and wanted to show them some venerable SF dining (rather than the hippest or the most expensive) and chose Bix.

The bar was crowded as the after work crowd became the dinner crowd. I like the bartenders in the crisp white jackets. I like the hosts who hold your table against all odds as your party arrives at 7:10 because of some mixed signals. I liked the first two minutes of conversation with the drunk matron at the bar gulping down martinis. The last 58 minutes, not so much. But I'm a better man now understanding that it's no cakewalk being a rich white woman in SF nowadays. Nicely dressed crowd except for the guy carrying the See's candy bag wearing the fishing hat, tan shorts, white New Balance shoes with black socks.

The dining room was little loud but I would put it just this side of 'festive'. Pork chop was excellent. Bananas Foster was OK but I wasn't blown away. All in all, food was good. Service was crisp. Again, I like the whole 40-something waiter in the white jacket thing. Wine list was decent. All in all, we got just what we wanted. $260 for 4 excluding one round of drinks at the bar and tip. Maybe a tad pricey for what we got but in this day and age where a $12 martini doesn't even raise an eyebrow, thumbs up.
author: Brian B.

description:
3.5, but definitely closer to a 3. 

I definitely expected a lot more from a place like this - maybe it was because my date and I weren't dressed to their standards? The moment we walked in the two hostess that were standing by the door immediately began to stare us down -- not sure if it was because I was carrying my laptop bag (in my defense, it's not worth getting your car broken into and getting your laptop stolen) or because we were a lot younger than the other customers there, but I've never encountered such fake hospitality like these two women. 

Our waiter was great, very friendly and helpful, but he definitely did not pay as much attention to us as he did to the table next to us. An elderly couple (I assume they are very frequent customers) sat next to us and several waiters + the manager came out to greet them and to make sure their night was going well. I felt like the waiter could have easily just turned around to make sure my table was doing just as okay as the table next to us, regardless of whether or not we were regulars. 

The food was alright at most. I had the lobster pasta something and my date had the rainbow trout. The lobster was good, but the dish itself wasn't memorable. Overall it wasn't spectacular or innovative or amazing. I don't see myself coming back here.
author: A Y.

description:
This place rates itself as fine dining - it is not unfortunately. Visiting this establishment prior to a show at the Punchline around the corner. Opening at 5:30 we entered and the french accented front of the house seem to think straight away we were sitting at the bar. She then went on to say, you want 'Full Service Menu'
- we understood her to think we had to eat more than an entre from this as she explained it on this 'Full Service menu'  - we did not fortunately. It appeared she was just getting in the door as the place opened so I would say that the greeting here was less than hospitable and slightly 'snobby' attitude was annoying, The finger food is probably the best thing on the menu I must say but be prepared to spend a lot  for that. The rest of it , forget it. I tried the BIX house special of the chicken cakes from the entre menu  - extremely poor and utterly tasteless. The cocktails were good , but serviced in extremely small glasses ultimately to maximize restaurant profit.
It may have been slow this night , but the waiter attending our table and a couple's table ,who obviously wanted left alone, was overly intrusive, likely bored because not a lot of folk were in. Another black mark for this place. Recommendation ; eat elsewhere - the owners need to get an idea on 'fine dining' and front of house manners.
author: Fred J.

description:
Melissa D is trying to knock out the 7x7 top 100 eats in SF.  We came to Bix with thoughts of sitting at the bar, grabbing a martini & ordering the tartare.  It turned out that the bar was completely packed, so the hostess offered us a table and mentioned that we could  order drinks if we wished.  Since it was already 8:30PM we thought, we would make the most of our time here and ordered dinner.  I'm sure glad we decided to stay because the duck breast was superb. You will defintely feel like you warped back in time to the 30-40's era of old money.  There's a piano & singer that kept us entertained the entire evening. 

(*) Duck breast cutlet with spaetzle, braised red cabbage, apples & grainy mustard sauce $29.75.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Great fun place to eat. Professional staff, great service. Nice piano player and singer on 1st level. Nice view from mezzanine level.  Good mural and art work on walls. 

We had excellent salmon and truffle cheeseburger after the halibut ceviche and oysters. The Pisco sour cocktails were excellent. The Bananas Foster was great - we would have been happy just to get this dessert. 

Noise level is fairly high - not a place for hushed conversation.
author: Lynto L.

description:
The restaurant is beautiful but I have to say I felt totally out of place. Most patrons were a little older and a little more done up than I'm used to on a Friday afternoon. The famous BIX burger was yummy, but not the best I've had in the city - the heirloom tomatoes definitely upped the ante though. Salad was well-seasoned and highlighted the fresh seasonal ingredients well.

I feel like I need to dress up and come try BIX for dinner sometime before I make the final call.
author: Claire C.

description: Lively restaurant with a great atmosphere.  The restaurant is in a back alley lit by a neon sign and two small seating areas out front.  But inside is a great piano and chello playing, large bar with people chatting, and comfortable seating throughout.  I had the sea bass, that evenings special.  It was superb!  Great find for a special evening out!
author: Marilyn P.

description:
Situated in the little narrow alley that is Gold St semi hidden in the FiDi. Clouds of cigar smoke hover around the entrance.

AMBIANCE: Dim and swank. Has a sort of roaring 20s, opera house-ish vibe if that makes sense. Live jazz during dinner.

SERVICE: Nice and unobtrusive. Our server helpfully ordered enough portions of hors d'oeuvres for all 7 of us.

FOOD: I wasn't really impressed. Portion size is small but I ended up feeling perfectly filled post meal (it was also prob b/c we were eating so late).
- Potato pillows: Yep. Glorified tater tots with a dollop of creme fraiche and a smidge of caviar. 
- Ceviche: the slice of fish was soooo thin. All I could taste was the spice from the jalapeno and the creamy avocado.
- Mini lamb burgers: very Indian inspired taste IMO. Bite sized juicy goodness.
- Steak tartar: ooh so rich. I could only handle a small spoonful. Very good.
- Bone marrow: SO fatty. 4 bones/order.
- Bix chicken hash: Looked like crab cakes, tasted like solid chicken pot pie. Quite good... but also weird.
- Special pork cutlet of the day: Thinly breaded and came with mashed potatoes, peas and sweet corn. I thought this dish was good.

DRINKS:
- Ginger gimlet ($11): my first thought: "what an itty bitty martini glass." Second thought: this tastes medicinal! :(  What is with my run of picking medicinal drinks?!
- Bellini ($10): Very tasty. Basically juice. Dangjo!

OVERALL: I could see how coming here to grab a couple drinks might be nice, but I wouldn't return for dinner. I also wouldn't recommend Bix to friends.
author: Susanna W.

description:
One of the better restaurants I've been to in SF definitely. 

I took my gf here for her birthday and was very happy with their service and the food was good as well. I called in a couple times because I was having some flowers delivered to the restaurant so they would be there before we arrived. They were very kind and accommodating. The restaurant is located down this alley way, but to be honest I like how its inconspicuous. Everything was very clean and there's even live music in the evening. 

The food was delicious!
Steak tartare was perfect, as well as the deviled eggs for the appetizers. Taste buds were then jumping for joy!
The burger was also delicious and while maybe you might not order a burger for a dinner like this, I did and well No Regrets there!

My gf had the pork two ways and the ground pork was good, but the pork chop had a bit of fat on it and looked a lot like a steak. While good, not the greatest at least from what i heard... lol

I'd definitely like to return, but only once my wallet feels more "complete"
author: Ben W.

description:
I was pretty stoked to try BIX out, it was one of those places I'd heard a lot about but had never been to so I figured I'd give it a go. Granted, I got there at 9:30 on a Sunday (they close at 10) so I understand why things may have been a little weird. I hate being the last person at a place, I feel like I'm keeping folks from going home. The server was really friendly and when he made some mistakes was completely open about having made them and apologetic, instead of trying to pretend like they didn't happen, which I appreciated. He also let me pay ninja-style when my companion wasn't looking.

We started out with the marrow bones, foie gras and steak tartare, and they were all good. I especially liked the stone fruit/fig mostarda that sat alongside the foie and the toasted brioche triangles. The tartare was peppery and brightly flavored with not too much caper and of course you can't go wrong with marrow bones. The little gem salad with bleu cheese dressing was uninspired and nothing I couldn't find in a neighborhood deli. We tried the dungeness crab rolls and they were fine, but nothing to write home about. The brioche didn't taste quite buttery enough somehow. We also had some oysters that were nice and fresh if somewhat gritty, and the dutch apple pie, confusingly made with phyllo, and while it wasn't horrible, it wasn't really anything special either.

To be honest I know I'm not the target demographic here. It skews a little older and the food is traditional and safe. For what it is, it's fine. If I were older and liked smooth jazz and geometric clip art from the 80s I would be in heaven there.
