Definitely one of the best burgers I've had - so far...
author: Gene X.

description:
And so the burgefest continues!

Burger # 6 on the list brought us to Bix.  I had heard great things about this restaurant....great food, great atmosphere and greatly expensive.  So I was interested to see what this restaurant brought to a burger.

We walked in 15 minutes late, in part due to the lack of parking around the restaurant (note to future patrons - get there early for parking and for finding the restaurant as it's down a hidden alley) but we were one minute too late; they had given our table away.  Burger #6 was slipping through our fingers....but luckily, the staff were nice enough to give us the next available table...which turned out to be the best table in the house!

There are 2 burgers on the menu, one that is not obvious which is the one that 7x7 reviewed (fyi, it's called the club cheeseburger and it's in small print at the bottom of the menu).  All three of us ordered the burger and a drink which the waiter brought to us with no fuss.  

Now about the burger:

What can I say!  Juicy, delicious, perfectly cooked, perfect bun, great sauces.  Their special sauce was so tasty - cornichon and ketchup roasted together with aioli.   We had started to lose hope in 7x7's list as we'd all found that #10 was one of the best and some of the lower ones weren't that great.  This burger has now replaced #10 as the best burger so far.  It was amazing and even though there were other great choices on the menu, I would seriously order this burger again.  

Now about the restaurant:
World class service (they take your coat...something I love!)
Great atmosphere (piano player and jazz singer)
Great service...what I can say is that I would imagine a high end restaurant waiter being annoyed when everyone orders one of the cheapest things on the menu but you would never know it.  He was a great server and it made me realize that this is what a good restaurant should embody. 

So go check out Bix - whether it's for their burger or their great atmosphere and service.  Sure, it's a bit pricier than many other restaurants, but I'm of the mind that service and great food are often worth the cost....and it certainly is that way with Bix.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Loved the location, decor, and appreciated our server.  

Appetizers all looked great, so my date and I did the 3-Apps, 1 Entree deal with dessert.  Crab mini sandwiches were perfect.  Enjoyed the house made mozzarella also.  Was pretty expensive, but I don't often say that a steak dish is memorable and theirs was.  The mashed potatoes complimented it perfectly and the meat was so good, my Medium Well loving date didn't seem to care that she was eating an almost medium, almost medium rare steak.  Kudos for that.  Loved the meyer lemon specialty cocktail.  Asked the server to throw a red at me that fit a few points, and he nailed it.  Big time.

May return for a special occasion, or for chit chat and appetizers.  Or if someone else is paying.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Wonderful place for a date, romantic and charming.  Food was ok, which seems to be a recurring theme in the reviews.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I'm giving it 3 stars because there was nothing wrong with the place, but nothing exceptional either.

If they were attempting to be retro, then maybe they'd get a fourth star, but I'm afraid it more outdated than anything.

We shared a couple of appetizers and decided to cut out losses and move on the next restaurant. We shared the housemade mozzerella and the Dungeness Crab Rolls. Both were completely mediocre.

Service was friendly and prompt but certainly not choreographed like other fine dining restaurant that the city has developed it's reputation on.

The space is interesting in that it's wide open and large, and beckons thoughts of a 1930s big band club. But sadly, so does the dated upolstry, carpet, paint, and the food.
author: David S.

description:
All I can say is WOW!!!

Took my mom out for a lovely mother daughter dinner =)

Everything we ordered was so delicious! First we started with Steak tartare, after the waitor mixed all the yummy condiments together he spritz congac on the tartare as if it was perfume (cute!) This is a must try! I am a Caviar lover so we had to order the Potato Pillow with creme fraiche and Sturgeon Caviar. The crispy potato with the cool creme fraiche topped with the nutty caviar was out of this world! I can eat this all day long!!! Next came the Bone Marrow. They were big pieces with lots of yummy goodness inside. At last we shared the lobster spaghetti and a side of brussel sprouts. The pasta was al dente, the tart and tangyness of this dish was amazing. I love the extra kick from the jalapenos! The brussel sprouts were sauted with lemon and herbs. Perfect!

Bix is one of the very few restaurant I can say that everything is tasty.
author: Lola H.

description: Bix never fails.  We've been coming here forever - and for good reason.  Celebrated the husband's birthday here last night and Bix was spot on! The hostess was as poised and professional as ever, offering us a choice of tables.  Our server was a delight.   The food: Still.So. Good.  Those pototo pillows with caviar are little puffs of potato from heaven.  Our teenage son had the duck and ate every last morsel.  I had the ribeye and had to restrain myself from licking the plate clean.  Husband had the lobster pasta and loved it - though had hoped for a little more bite on the jalapenos.  The wine list never disappoints.  And the piano and jazz vocals just made the evening that much more special.  Bix remains one of our favorites!
author: Bridget M.

description:
Tucked away down a narrow side street, you'd never guess what awaits within from the outside: Great food, drinks, service and decor.

Their table side prepared beef tartare is outstanding. The combination of flavors and the texture of the beef all work together to make one of my favorite starters. For good measure we also tried the King Salmon tartare and the house made mozzarella wrapped with prosciutto. The salmon was fresh and a great contrast to the beef. The fresh cheese was amazing! Soft and tender with a salty touch from the prosciutto wrapper. I could eat it all night.

For dinner I had to try the Black Truffle Cheeseburger with truffle fries. Served open faced on rye it's hardly traditional but worthy of eating with a fork and knife. Where the top bun would usually reside sits a thick slice of grilled onion. Between the perfectly cooked medium rare patty and the rye bun you'll find decadent black truffle shavings. Truffle oil on the fries? Check. If you like gourmet burgers this one won't disappoint.

After all that I still ended up having some dessert (it was my bday so why not!?). The Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding was an easy choice. Finishing it was not...so rich, chocolatey and filling!
author: Matt T.

description:
BIX is my new all-time favorite restaurant - anywhere... replacing my long standing (but still beloved) former fave, Slanted Door.

If you want to go somewhere with old-school class (think: where would Sinatra eat?), mouth watering food (mmmmm... beeeeeef), an extensive and well curated wine menu, fabulous service (they must have their own  private "BIX" school for wait staff and hostesses. The service is impeccable!) and gorgeous decor (ask for the upstairs corner booth -- you'll feel like one of the Rat Pack. I know I did!) then go to BIX.

Great for important business dinners, first dates when you want to impress and a no-brainer as THE go-to place when you've got family visiting (especially if Dad's picking up the bill).
author: Jaimee C.

description:
It's a very cool place.  Brought my friend here for his birthday and they didn't disappoint.  Hidden in Gold alley in San Francisco, Bix has been an establishment that has been in the business for quite some time.  I remember Bix when I was still parking cars near a local lot.  The good ole days.

We started out with some cocktails.  Very good martinis.  Very professional bartenders.  They did a great job.

To the food.

Appetizers

Steak Tartar................always a classic and always good.  a must when here.  served and prepared table side.
Firecracker shrimp........ok.......kinda reminds me of a fast food concoction.
lamb sliders..................it was juicy, tasty
Deviled Egg with truffle oil.............  tasted like a deviled egg with truffle.  hhaahaha.  as simple as that sounds it actually taste as it is advertised.

Entrees
I had the Chicken bix hash.  A very interesting concept.  Make a chicken dish that resembles a crab cake.  It was good, nothing really exciting to write home about.
My friend had the sturgeon, a little over seasoned but prepared well, nice crisp
My other friend had the kobe beef.  It was good, not the best I have ever had but good. This was probably the best dish that they have on the menu.
The birthday boy had the lamb shank.  A little boring.  uneventful, just bland.  Probably their worst dish of them all.

After rereading what I wrote, this place isn't really that good except for the steak tartar, their drinks, and service.  All the other food was just ok.  This is a place where the ambiance and service gave them an extra star and actually made the food taste a little better.
author: jason g.

description:
We've stepped into this place a few times prior and always surveyed the crowd and decided we'd pass on by.  Not so tonight... Surprise!  Dress Me Up and you actually CAN take me Anywhere.  Crowded, lots of party dresses (holiday season, yes.)  Undersized sapphire up with a twist, that came in an even smaller glass after #2 - maybe they'd think I wouldn't notice? Not so much.  Seriously.
Still, pretty girls in pretty holiday dresses to look at, great apps (their take on crab cakes is nothing short of wondrous, and the ahi tuna, yay!) bartenders - well done on being attentive and heavy handed.
The crowd was lively, most seemed to be there to enjoy the full-on drinks/dinner, the balance just to drink overpriced drinks.
author: Meg W.

description:
Bix was v. highly recommended and lived up to expectations!  I loved the decor, the jazz band and the finely crafted cocktails.  I prefer to dine later in the evening so we pushed back our reservation and found that we had a bit more space at the bar and a prime table on the second level overlooking the diners and band below.

Oh, and the food was tasty too.
author: KL S.

description: Delicious food saved our dinner from the initial impression of the TERRIBLE blonde hostess.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Bix has been my all time favorite San Francisco restaurant for the last 5 years!!  It's the restaurant I recommend to everyone...especially if they are asking for a recommendation on taking family visitors or for a business dinner.  The food has always been outstanding and the ambiance and service has been superb... until tonight!!

Actually, the food and ambiance were wonderful (as always).  However, we had a terrible experience with the service, particularly, the bartender (Bruce, the old guy who has been there for 12 years)?  We ordered dinner at the bar and all was good (at least we thought so), until we started chatting with a nice guy sitting next to us.  After recommending that he order his meat "medium" instead of "medium well", the bartender said something like, "My night was going great until you interupted in the middle of my order and offered lousy advice.".  Whoa...I was shocked.  I was just striking up a conversation with the nice guy next to me, and we were laughing together... but the bartender got really bent out of shape.  I really hope this guy was just having a bad night... because it left such a negative impact, I have no desire to go back....
author: Brittany B.

description:
What do you get if you arrive 15 minutes late for your reservation and your table is given away because you had to park in the rain and run down the alley to the well-hidden restaurant? Sometimes, you get the best seat in the house. That's what happened to Melanie N., Gene X., and myself as we came to BIX to try the #6 burger on the 7x7's list. Despite our tardiness, the host was nice enough to give us the next table which ended up being on the upper level overlooking the bar - great view! Bonus points for that.

Now, BIX is one of those establishments that can be described as classy, old-fashioned, yet elegant. It reminds me of Harris' Restaurant, another place where you can relax and rely on professional, understated service and great food. Neither is cheap, but then again, you get what you pay for in this case.

Our gustatory goal was confounded by the fact that BIX has not one, but two burgers. The one that gets the main billing on the menu is the Truffled Pecorino Cheese Burger served on buttered rye, costing you a pretty $27. The burger we were after is called simply Club Cheese Burger and it's hidden in a small box at the bottom of the page. We each ordered that burger, varying only the cheese, and the waiter didn't bat an eye despite it being pretty much the lowest-priced entree on the menu. We decided to get some drinks too. Mine was a Meyer Lemon Collins, because I never pass the chance to try something new made with Meyer lemons, and it was tasty and refreshing.

The burger arrived on a big plate, along with a bowl of french fries and a trio of ramekins with condiments: ketchup, mayo, and the BIX "special sauce". We asked what it was and the waiter said that they take cornichons and ketchup, smoke it over something, and add beef fat and some aioli. It's delicious and I smeared it all over the burger. The burger itself was just great - perfectly cooked to medium-rare, thick, tender, a bit crumbly, juicy and well complemented by the poppy-seeded bun. I also really enjoyed the very thinly sliced pickles and the ripe tomato slices that came on the side. Fries were decent, but the burger was definitely the star of the show. As much as I enjoyed Namu's burger, the BIX one displaces it from the #1 spot.

Along with drinks, the bill came to about $30 for each of us. Pricey, but definitely worth it for the awesome burger, elegant surroundings (did I mention grand piano and a jazz singer?), and the service. I hope to return to BIX with someone who has an expense account and dig into some other fine offerings.
author: Andrei Z.

description: OMG price crazy, food just ok, atmosphere pretty nice... Reservations??? ok, well we can get you in at 5:30, so we show up at 6 anyway and the place is deserted... 7PM still had tables wtf??? anyway for the money will not not not go back...
author: Kenneth F.

description:
I ate here for lunch recently, and it was a very pleasant experience.  I know many others have encountered poor service at this restaurant, but my experience was definitely much more positive.  We were greeted at the door and shown to our table right away.  The service throughout the meal was attentive but not intrusive.  The decor is also very interesting, with art deco/20s influences, and a beautiful, high ceiling.

I got the burger (not the truffle one, that wasn't on the lunch menu when I went) with gruyere on it.  It was cooked perfectly medium rare as I asked for it, and it came with an assortment of ketchup and sauces for the burger and fries.

For dessert, my group split the semifreddo.  It was very tasty, but not outstanding enough that I remember many details of it now two weeks later.

Overall, I'd say that Bix was very tasty and I enjoyed my experience, but it's not a complete standout in its price range.  A nice option, though.  3.5 stars.
author: David W.

description:
Bix is a longtime favorite of mine.  Perfect for the night when you want to dress a bit sharper and pause during your meal to applaud the live jazz band.

Wonderful atmosphere, great service, and delicious food.  The bartenders make a nice, strong drink as well.  The menu changes appropriately for the seasons.  I recently had the beets appetizer, which was very good.  The desserts are rich but not overdone, although a few are a tad on the small side.  Keep your eyes peeled around Watsonville strawberry season, because Bix does some amazing desserts with them - one of them being a very decadent strawberry shortcake - that you won't want to miss.
author: Lee M.

description:
Had another awesome experience at Bix last night. Took some of the boys here as they wanted a "true San Francisco dining experience". Got A+ service from the staff, had some lovely entertainment from the piano player and jazz singer and all the food was amazing. 

Started with the appetizer sampler of tuna tartare, firecracker shrimp, mozzarella wrapped in proscuitto and the mini truffle cheese croques (the best things EVER). The waiter informed us that the cheese is 65 dollars an ounce and is laced with truffles. Ridiculously good. We also got the steak tartare as that is what Bix is known for...

I got the Ginger Gimlet (have to get the martinis at Bix if you are going)... they bring the shaker out and pour the martini at your table. 

For my entree I got the Lobster Spaghetti which is amazing, I can't seem to stray and get anything different every time I go to Bix.

Dessert was butterscotch brownies (more resembled fudge than brownies) and the brioche bread pudding (more resembled a soufflee than bread pudding). But regardless, they were excellent.

All in all we had an amazing dinner and I'm glad the boys got to experience Bix in all its amazement :)
author: Sarah A.

description:
My husband and i were visiting from San Diego and booked a reservation for our Anniversarry night. First impression when walking in was amazing! Wonderful set up and such a great feel. 
We were sat at our reserved table on the indoor balcony over looking the band and bar and it was perfect. 
We were greeted by a very friendly waitress who was more than helpful through out our meal. We had a couple drinks and then ordered our main course which was TO DIE FOR! we both had the steak and it was incredible, by far the best steak we have ever had! 
The ONLY negative from this experience was the hostess that showed us out. She was very snobby and rude and was paying more attention to the man hitting on her then the guests. Overall the experience was wonderful and we highly recommend this place!
author: Britt m.

description:
Let me start off by saying I was none too impressed when I read the menu on-line.  The entrees seemed very limited and the on the high side.  I will continue by saying that I was completely blown away by end of the evening. 

We ordered an array of appetizers including roasted beets with goat cheese, ceviche, truffled fries, and the truffled cheese croques.  I skipped all but the ceviche which I thought was really good and could only have asked for a larger portion. 

A number of us at the table ordered the Kobe Bavette steak, and wow, I normally shy away from beef, but this stuff literally melted in my mouth.  The wine pairing was excellent with kudos to AJ (waiter) and Krishna. 

From reading reviews I knew that we would be entering the restaurant from an alley.  The little neon sign 'BIX Here' hanging on the wall is the only indication you are in the right alley.  It seems like you might be engaging in something illicit just by ducking into the place.  There is a beautiful bar with a soaring mural and a baby grand piano.  Just as we were leaving the piano player was warming up.  The interior is a little too dark but does lend to a certain romantic ambiance.  Too bad I was there with co-workers.  I think this place would be great if you are celebrating an anniversary or just want an intimate evening with a special person
author: Sandyann G.

description:
This restaurant was unbelievable!  Everyone in our group could not believe how amazing the food and service was at this restaurant.  Our waitress was really sweet and even gave us a complimentary side dish of the creamy spinach for being "her best table"....probably because we were drinking several bottles of wine :) I had the lobster macaroni, which was to die for!  It included a LOT of large chunks of lobster, which was a pleasant surprise as typically restaurants only serve several small pieces but still charge you for having lobster in your meal.  

Overall, this was the best dining experience we had while visiting San Francisco.  I would definitely love to go back next time we're in the area!
author: Noelle S.

description:
We went here for a birthday dinner for my friend. We had reservations at 6 and were promptly seated when we got there. We all started off with cocktails, which were delicious. The four we chose were the Bellini, Perfect Manhattan, Hotel Bolivar and gin and tonic. From there we ordered the sampler appetizer, which consisted of fresh  mozzarella wrapped with prosciutto, steak tartar, mini bun-mi burger and  truffle deviled egg. We all enjoyed those with the tartar being the favorite. 

For dinner we ordered

Dorade: really good, which there was no skin on the fish
Lobster ravioli: Amazing
Pork shoulder/belly: melt in your mouth good
Truffle Burger: can really taste the truffle, so if your not a fan then don't order

Dessert we did a savory and sweet. The sample of cheeses was perfectly paired and the bananas foster was the best I had. Our server was very helpful and we would definitely go back again
author: Erica J.

description:
I came here the day after xmas with my girlfriends and was very happy with our server. She did take quite a bit taking our order, but afterwards she was very content and checked in with us quite a bit.

we had ordered the 

dungeness crab roll- very good, but the rolls were a bit too buttery and quite rich.

steak tartar- very good. should definitely order this or the tuna tartar.

black truffled cheese burger extremely good and made to perfection. Although the open faced and the onions stacked up tall made it a bit hard to eat, but really worth it. So if you choose this as your entree, be prepared to get messy.

maine lobster spaghetti was very good. lobster was very tender and had a generous amount.

american kobe steak was okay. I've had better steak.

My overall meal was a great experience and would definitely choose to come back.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night w/ a group of 6. You will never just run into this restaurant; it is down an alley near Broadway. You have to be lucky enough to know about it! As you enter there is a speakeasy vibe w/ jazz music playing throughout, even the margaritas are served in a martini glass. At 8:30 the speaker jazz music turns off and a live jazz trio begins. The food is a little pricy and the portions are small but everything we had was excellent. Started w/ the Dungeness Crab Rolls in Brioche and a Caesar salad. Dinner, my husband ordered the American Kobe Bavette Steak (Wow... I recommend) and I ordered the Maine Lobster Spaghetti w/ Lobster Cream. Ended with the chocolate bread pudding. 
A classy restaurant, I highly recommend Bix if you have not been here.
author: Ava G.

description:
My supervisor often likes to share his knowledge of iconic San Francisco eateries, and thus, Bix was introduced into my life as a pre-Christmas lunch.  According to the Garfinkle, Bix is a type of saloon slash supper club.  Located in Jackson Square, it is totally innocuous, save for a lone neon sign.  However, once you step in, you are transported to a world of tommy guns and a bar which many magazines have said made, "San Francisco's best cocktails".  After closing up shop at noon, our party of four arrived at Bix for our 11:30 reservation.  We were immediately attended to by a tuxedo'd man who immediately passed us off to the hostess who ushered us upstairs to a wonderfully located corner table.  Upon first glance, Bix was rather impressive in a throwback sort of way.  The bar was elegant and huge, with hundreds of bottles lined against the wall.  There were paintings on the walls and it was very throwback of the 20's, the golden age of crime.  There was a piano at the side.  All Bix needed were a dozen men in trench coats smoking and buxom babes walking around in bunny suits.   The Garfinkle explained to me that Bix only served lunch during the holidays.  He ordered the chicken hash, I ordered the Louisiana flounder, the Admiral had the smoked trout salad and the OT had the pasta with crab.  We also ordered a bunch of appetizers.  

deviled eggs with truffles, radish and chives: 3/5  I love deviled eggs and can literally eat them like chips.  However, these were a little too fancy for my tastes.  I think it was the radish that muted the flavour of the yolk.

salmon tartare on rye with dill and creme fraiche: 5/5  The salmon was so buttery and literally melted in your mouth.  It was delicious and the only thing that sucked was that there were only four small goddam pieces.  

sweet onion and truffled cheese croques: 3.5/5  These were in essence, small gourmet grilled cheese sandwiches.  We got this upon the waitresses's recommendation.  It was good, however, not great.

Louisiana flounder meuniere with white grits, meyer lemon, and tory farm grapes: 3.5/5.  I was stoked about this dish as I haven't had flounder in a while however, left with mixed feelings.  The fish was very tender, however, it was so rich.  I felt that there was just too much butter used.  I was never a big fan of grits, as I never really tasted anything.  However, the heavily buttered fish went real well with the grapes.  It sort of made the entree a candied experience.  It is hard to explain.

Panna cotta/creme brulee: 4/5  I am not a dessert person and because I never had panna cotta, Garfinkle insisted I try it.  It was a good dessert, not too sweet, and went very well with the quince and candied walnuts.  The creme brulee was...well...creme brulee.  Nothing much to note here.  Obviously, the torched top was the best part.  The vanilla beans were also visible.  

We had a great bottle of wine which names escapes me.  I also ordered a Negroni, which is a gin, vermouth, bitters mixture.  In french, it is called l'apertif.  It basically is good to increase your appetite.  While my supervisor liked it, it was bitter and tasted like rubbing alcohol.  It was basically shit used to clean wounds.  I am sure that it could fuel a Zippo.  I gave the Admiral a sip and he had try really hard to not spit it back out.  This is a drink that will grow hair on your chest.  I am not one who likes to sit back and sip drinks.  For me, drinking is just a precursor to a most savory adventure, often done on Thursday nights.  Our meal totaled out to almost $400 with tip, and for that money, I was not blown away by the food.  The ambiance and service was most triumphant tho and for that, I recommend you come here at least once.  We were seated in a prime corner, overlooking everything.  One thing I might add is they polish and shine the shit outta the floors.  I nearly ate shit on the floor leading to the stairs.  If it were not for my strong core and my ninja focus, I would have suffered a mishap of most humiliating proportions.
author: Brian V.

description: Bix is my standard for SF dining experience when I am entertaining corporate guests. If I can only get them to try one place, it has to be Bix!  Steak Tartare is amazing.
author: Marc R.

description:
We followed the brick alley walls with hesitation toward the gently lit neon sign where we were greeted by a beautiful woman and a gentleman in a coat and tie who coaxed us into the doorway. Upon stepping from the alley we found ourselves peering into a dark lit and seductive dining room with candle lights. 

We were met by a server in retro bow tie and white jacket. After an order of fresh house made mozzarella wrapped prosciutto, a manhattan, and a dirty martini we were ready for the sliced Kobe beef fillet with a raw sweet onion and a perfect circle of whipped potatoes. 

Each item was seemingly undisturbed by seasonings and oils and the individual natural flavor from the marbled fatty Kobe blended the sweetness of the onion and creaminess of the potatoes into art on a plate. .
author: John B.

description: The bar = great vibe, upstairs booth = cozy and fun, the food = app sampler was superb, our waiter = expert. Five stars all the way, see you next time Bix.
author: Shawn D.

description:
We hadn't planned on going to Bix this trip but since many restaurants were closed on New Year's Day and Bix was open we figured we would try it out. Bix was recommended by the bar manager at our Hotel although not her first choice she did say it was a nice place with good food. Let me start this experience by say ing I love the location and atmosphere of Bix, very unique like a trip back in time.
We called to get a late reservation late meaning 8-9 pm but were told 10:30 was all they could offer us; we took it. The lady that answered did say we should come in early and they would be able to seat us before 10:30, which to me usually means 30 maybe even 45 minutes before. We were seated at 10:20pm. At least the live music was entertaining and the bar staff was nice, this made our wait bearable. We decided to order some drinks and appetizers while we sat at the bar. I highly recommend the crab rolls. Its comfort food meets fresh seafood that is a delightful taste. 
Once we were seated we figured trying another appetizer seemed worth it! We went for the A la Minute Ceviche and all though jalapenos and habanero chiles sound spicy it was not the cilantro oil gave it a fresh taste. The roasted corn nuts were an interesting taste crumbled over a very fresh dish although I loved the many elements of the dish I have never been a fan of corn nuts, so I could have done without. I do get the textural element it brings which is enjoyable I just don't enjoy the taste of them. My boyfriend thought it was a perfect appetizer; he enjoyed the flavor and texture of the corn nuts.
Now on to dinner... I have to say I expected more our dishes. I ordered the American Kobe Bavette Steak and my boyfriend ordered The Maine Lobster Spaghetti that for this night was substituting lobster with Dungeness crab. Since my boyfriend loves crab he was looking forward to this dish. The pasta is made there and that was not bad very good texture to it, however the rest of the dish was lacking. The cherry tomatoes were very overwhelming and I am pretty sure he never even noticed there was crab in the dish... Where's the crab???
My Kobe steak was very bland. Truly all that needs to be said my dinner was bland!
Now on to the best part of our night the Banana's Foster with Vanilla Ice Cream! Simply DELICIOUS! My boyfriend is not a fan of bananas but the dark rum sauce made him rave about it all night! He recommended it to the couple next to us who also enjoyed it!
I would say Bix is great for appetizers and drink... even dessert but I was not thrilled with my entrée. Our waiter was a very nice guy and that always makes for good experience. The hostess talked too much and another hostess looked at me like I was crazy when I asked if being seated early would be possible. Other than their lack of customer service in the front of the house the rest of our visit had its ups and downs. I would go maybe for lunch. A regular mentioned next time we should try the Steak Tartare let's hope next time we pick better entrees.
author: Cecilia M.

description:
I love Bix!  I love the fact that it's hidden away in an unpretentious alleyway that sends you back to the early part of the last century.  As you enter the large and very tall room, you can't help to feel like you're entering the world of the Great Gatsby.  The bar is absolutely beautiful, as is the black polished piano.

Food wise, this is a good and solid menu, with everything from great martinis and mojitos, a wonderful wine list, Foie Gras, very well prepared, some great meat dishes, and some kickass desserts.

I proposed to my wife here.  That, my friend, is a solid 5 stars!
author: David O.

description:
Bix was my DAT restaurant of choice for lunch this year.  It was a bit tough to find them (where the heck is Gold St?!?!) but once we got there, they seated us right away.  Restaurant had a nice throwback clubby feel.  

We had the squash soup for the appetizer, the Atlantic Char (OMG!  This looks like salmon but tastes better and without the dried out flavor!) and chocolate bread pudding for dessert.

The char was kind of oily.  You can see the oil swimming on the plate but otherwise it was good.

I'm never a bread pudding girl but I have to admit that theirs is pretty good (also very pretty looking too!).

Also ordered a Ginger Limonade (ginger lemonade).  That was yummy!

Service was prompt and quick.  I got out of there after an hour and 15 minutes.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Hidden away on Gold Street in a small alley, I always thought this was a very cool restaurant.  This place was one of the first nice restaurants I checked out when I was in college at Cal way back in the '90s.  It was kind of a landmark for me since it was the first time a college date and I spent $100 on a meal!...But even back when I was in college, I thought it was a Benjamin well spent.

Ambiance is where Bix really shines...This split-level restaurant has a very cool bar area with a grand piano on the main floor.  After a certain time, there is a live pianist plus or minus a live jazzy-type of singer.  I was really impressed when they had this female singer that was beltin' out the Ella Fitzgerald like you couldn't believe.

Food is standard American-fare (fish, pork, steak, lamb)...Nothing really creative or unusual, but quality is very nice.  Dessert is particularly good...I recommend the warm chocolate brioche pudding or the bananas foster.  Cocktails here are plentiful.  Waitstaff is very polite & knowledgeable when recommendations are needed.

Overall, this is an awesome place to take a date or even visiting family/friends...Worth checking out for sure!
author: Justin L.

description:
I haven't eaten here before so I'm basing my review on presence, ambiance, drinks, etc...

When I walked in I thought ' Whoa now ' because this place is in a freaking alley (I'm sure everyones gonna mention that part now, huh?) But I thought it was really cool...haha. 

Only stayed for drinks but the crowd was different, older for sure. Nice music, too!
author: Veronica S.

description:
I'd heard a lot of good things about Bix, and most (if not all) of them held true upon my visit: Great ambiance, great food and good service. 

I visited Bix in mid-December 2007, during the height of the holiday season. The dining room can only be described as gorgeous - lots of gilding and a live pianist made us feel like we were in another era. Despite my low-cut lace top and velvet jacket, I felt underdressed. It was tucked away in a little alley near North Beach. As I walked in, I got the sense that I was a special, in-the-know sort of visitor to a well-hidden gem. Of course, they designed it that way. 

While I liked everything I ate at Bix, I didn't enjoy anything as much as I normally would have. That's mostly because I was feeling really crappy that night, and had virtually no appetite whatsoever. (The next day, I'd be diagnosed with Strep throat, but I didn't know that at the time). 

Nevertheless, I do recall starting the meal off with a scalding-hot creamy soup (butternut squash with crab, I think), which I sucked down with abandon to soothe my painful throat. Kind of expensive ($10, I think?), but delicious and served at a much-appreciated temperature. 

For an entree, I had the popular "lobster spaghetti." I was in the mood that evening for upscale comfort food, sort of a Campbell's chicken noodle soup for the upper class, and the dish delivered in spades: It consisted of perfectly-cooked spaghetti tossed with tomatoes, a little cream and cheese, and small hunks of lobster meat. Considering the dish consisted mostly of spaghetti, tomatoes, and probably less than 1/4 cup of lobster meat, $36 seemed over-priced to me; but still, the few bites I had were enjoyable. 

Since my appetite had nearly left me by midway through the entree, I asked to take the rest home, but then had a little scare when the waiter didn't deliver the quite pricey leftovers back to me. Then I realized that at finer restaurants, they wait until the meal has ended before presenting the "doggie bag"

Anyhow, dessert arrived and although I was starting to feel like death warmed over, I took a few bites. I think it was some sort of chocolate bread pudding topped with barely-sweet whipped cream, which tasted yummy, but not in a particularly special way. 

Would I recommend Bix? Ambiance was great, food was delicious, and while a little overpriced, the clubby, swank ambiance made it a restaurant to remember.
author: Suzie Q.

description:
Bix is the best! I am so glad we had a limo driver to take us there. Being in town for a convention, we would have never found it. From the moment we stepped inside and throughout the meal the service was impeccable. We received a recommendation to Bix from a co-worker who lived in SF previously. She was right  on the money.

Our party of four was seated at what I would consider the best table in the house. In a corner of the second level, kind of a balcony that overlooks the dining room. What an awesome view.

The evening started with a sampling of several appetizers, all equally delicious. We moved on to first courses which were all outstanding.
For dinner we each ordered something different. Every dish was absolutely fantastic.

For dessert we shared a warm chocolate brownie that was to die for. 

I can't say enough about how great Bix is. Give it a try yourself. I hope you love it as much as we did.
author: Roland W.

description: Bix is my most recent favorite find among restaurants in San Francisco. I went here for my birthday dinner with my family and I'm very excited to have a new go-to restaurant for special occasions or just a nice night out. From the unique dim lit supper club type atmosphere to the music to the menu and food, this place deserves all five stars.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Our server was perfectly animated and helpful (we LOVED him) and the vibe was great, but I was just not blown away by the food, especially for the price.
I was mostly disappointed by the "potato pillows" tasting like McDonald's hash browns-- which is annoying because I am willing to spend the money for caviar if I can TASTE it, but I couldn't. 
The only thing that saved the meal was dessert. The cheese plate was awesome and the bananas foster, though slightly salty, hit the sweet spot.
Overall I left full not but not very satisfied.
Four stars for the service, three for the food.
author: Kenzie P.

description:
I have been a Huge fan of this restaurant for years.  But, last night I went with friends and it had unfortunately changed for the worse.  Though it is expensive (overpriced), it has always delivered a superb delicious meal.  Last night we had the Lobster spaghetti, which is pricey, but again has always been a nice sized portion with a pleasing amount of Lobster present.  But, last night, the portion was small and the Lobster was barely present, just 2 tiny slivers!!  I don't recall the price but it is enough that you should get some lobster in the dish :)  They told us they changed the chef but assured us that this classic dish was still the same.  But, IT IS NOT.  Such a shame.
I went to Bix's for that dish and I would not go back for what I was served last night.  Meatball appetizers arrived cold and unappetizing as well.
author: Marc D.

description: Very good food, excellent service and an atmosphere that provides a real treat. The chili chicken starter was very tasty. The lobster bisque was delicious and the lobster spaghetti was delicious. This is a great place to go for a nice mix of a unique atmosphere with good food. There are better places for food but I haven't found a better place for the combination of food, service, music and setting. Go at 8:30 or later on Friday or Saturday for the jazz trio or on other days and times for piano. Suggest if you drive the $10 valet is a real bargain.
author: W M.

description:
Great food - great wine - great atmosphere (piano/singer nice touch)

The vodka martini's here were the best I've ever had!  

Service - meh...everyone except for the bartender was very rude.
author: s k.

description:
When I saw the entrance down a narrow alley, I was immediately intrigued. 


Sweet dinner rolls - piping hot and delicious with butter (my inner fattie wishes they came back to replace rolls)

Potato pillows w/ caviar - nice fried fritter puffs with a mellow caviar (no real essence of ocean).  Nice starter.

Asparagus soup - nice, but nothing incredibly memorable

Truffle burger (open-faced) - an entree that managed to incorporate truffles into literally almost everything; excellent chuck with charcoal flavor, center-stuffed with truffles, melted truffle cheese, and a thick, juicy caramelized onion slice; all on top of a thick bread base with crisp outside and soft center.

Dessert:  highlight of the meal
Bananas Foster - amazing
Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding - excellent, lighter/fluffier alternative to a traditional bread pudding (tip: pair & and eat it with the bananas foster with your party!  The vanilla bean ice cream and warm bananas go so well with the chocolate).

Sevice:  unrushed (not for the impatient)
author: Jon F.

description: Awesome fresh oysters. Had the burger it was amazing perfectly coked
author: Danny c.

description:
It's been years since I've been here but a recent visit confirmed my memory of Bix as a great destination restaurant with amazing dishes and an impressive 1920's supperclub atmosphere.

For appetizers, we had the lamb burgers (amazingly complex and fragrant but a bit on the salty side), the dungeness crab rolls in brioche (each with a generous amount of fresh crab) and the steak tartare w/ shallots and capers (very good).  The burgers and crab rolls normally come in 3 or 4 but since there were 7 of us, they accommodated our orders to provide each of us with a portion.  Nice!  We also had the truffle fries, which had a generous heaping of shaved truffles (which reminded me of parmesan in both taste and smell).

The Star Route Farm baby lettuce salad with strawberries, almonds, feta & honey with sherry vinaigrette was amazing.  Equal parts sweet and tart, it had a nice balance and clean finish.

All the entrees were great, especially the chicken hash (Bix's signature dish, looked like crab cakes, delicious) and the mustard crusted pork chop (surprisingly succulent and juicy).   I didn't get to try but others at my table told me that the Bix bacon club burger and the Alaskan halibut were amazing.  The truffle cheeseburger and the American kobe bavette steak were pretty good as well.

By the time we finished, we were so stuffed we passed on dessert (although I will have to return to try their signature bananas foster and the chocolate brioche bread pudding).

A great place for a special occassion, especially for impressing out-of-town guests with the quality of the food and the interior decor and atmosphere.

When we got the bill, it was surprisingly affordable (relatively).  We didn't order alcohol so it came to around $60/person for all that food.  Great deal!
author: F. P.

description:
Great bar!  Too bad the food didn't measure up.  The menu was short,  overpriced and under-whelming - the food being better to look at than to eat.  Service was good, atmosphere excellent and the crowd worth watching.

The artwork is worth looking at for  and the history of the building (the old Assay Office for the Gold Rush participants lucky enough to actually find some) - hence the address on "Gold Street", which is actually a very narrow alley.  The kitchen is located where the vault used to be.

Go for drinks.  Head elsewhere for dinner.
author: Dave C.

description:
food is a little pricey but then you get what you pay for and i fully understand because

place is beautiful, service is fast and friendly,  food is not bad but the overall vibes of 

the restaurant,  patrons and employees is great....will be back for sure
author: Martin C.

description: We only did cocktails but the manhattan was excellent and used luxardo cherries. Jazz trio was great and it was kind of hidden down an alley which adds to the speakeasy style.
author: Chris B.

description:
Worst experience ever with BIX. 

My wife was planning a birthday dinner for me, and made a reservation for 11 people at BIX (approx a month in advance). Nick,  the manager on duty made the reservation and said we were good to go. 

A few days before the dinner, my wife called to confirm the reservation and they told her there was no record of the reservation. Keep in mind all our guests had been notified dinner would be at BIX. 

To top it all off, they weren't able to accommodate us, and the GM wasn't apologetic about the situation. He called the manager that we originally made the reservation with (Nick), who denied speaking to us. 

Very frustrating, and obviously not the way to run a good business.
author: Wais M.

description:
Not an easy place to find, even the cab drivers have issues if they haven't been here. It's hidden in an alley and has a speakeasy kind of feel. Bix is old school with an innovative menu. We started with the Dungeness Crab Rolls in Brioche with Meyer Lemon Aiol... awesome. They were pricey $16 for the small portion, but worth every dollar. I had the Black Truffle Cheese Burger served open face on Rye with Truffle Fries. Holy shit, that was one great burger. I wondered about the truffles, but then found a stockpile of them halfway through the burger. I couldn't believe I ordered a burger, but when it came I understood why it was on the menu. At $28, it might be the best burger you ever have tried. The truffle fries were perfect. GF had the Seared Local Albacore with Fried Green Tomatoes, Tonnato Sauce and Padron Pepper Relish ($27.50)and she was blown away. It was just awesome all the way around.

Worth a mention, but no reflection on the food, or service is when we left, I asked for a cab. The hostess said, "no cabs tonight, but our 'house driver' will take you back to hotel." House driver, I thought, "shit, wish I would have known, I would have called for a ride to the place instead of calling a taxi." So the "house driver" is bullshit. He is a limo driver with some sort of relationship with the hostess and charges double a cab ride. Live and learn, I guess...
author: John R.

description:
We went to BIX for a birthday party with nine people in tow. I was pleasantly surprised at how easily they accommodated us and how great the service was despite our large group. 

The restaurant itself is located in a little alley off of Montgomery street. The ambiance was exactly what I was looking for: upscale speakeasy, hidden away from the facade of the city. The interior was decorated wonderfully, and my only complaint about the environment would be that it was just a tiny bit too dark for my taste. 

The hostess was very patient, allowing us to have a cocktail at the swanky bar. When seated, the server was very quick to address my requests for champagne for a toast. Everyone had barely a chance to look at the menu before the bubbly was poured. 

After ordering a decent Malbec, I had both the potato pillows and deviled eggs as appetizers. Sorry, Mom, your deviled eggs aren't as good as the eggs at BIX. But to be fair, we never had truffles in the kitchen at home. If you do end up going to BIX, these to small plates are an absolute must! The potato puffs especially delighted me with the mixing textures of puff, creme fraiche, and caviar. 

For the entree, I was dead set on the duck trio before the server strongly recommended the lamb. She was right. God knows I love little quackers, but that little lamb was out of this world! I'm usually not impressed by polenta, but the side the lamb came with was just spectacular. That being said, I will have duck next time to see what I missed.

One word of warning, don't order the red velvet for dessert unless you like an equal ratio of frosting to cake, as well as crunchy coffee/chocolate crap on top.  I didn't take half a star for this only because I don't usually order desserts anyway. 

Love this place. You need to go for a special occasion.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Nice setting...reminds me of the old days.  Tucked away in Gold alley...walking through that alley reminds me of Europe.

Anyways, the atmosphere was great with a pianist working his magic.  The place makes me feel like I am in another country...somewhere in Europe!  

The foie gras was great!  I had the steak and it was good.  I think the food is averaging "good"...I've had better steak...but I think this place is for the ambiance and service.
author: Patrick C.

description: I came here for an anniversary dinner and it was amazing! Very romantic setting, it was loud with the music but could still hear each other perfectly. The food was outstanding. I can't stop thinking about the deviled eggs. The chef was able to prepare an incredible vegetarian pasta dish for me and my husband had the steak tartare and said it was perfection and just like they serve in France. The creme brulee was also one of the best I have ever had. We are definitely coming here again and again.
author: Gen F.

description:
When you walk towards the entrance of BIX, you walk into this alleyway and the combination of the neon blue sign of BIX and the moonlight you feel like you stepped into the 1920s. When you enter the restaurant you feel like you're in a scene of the The Great Gatsby. The architecture is great, there are these huge, marble pillars in the middle of the restaurant. A huge mural is painted over the bar and faces the rest of the restaurant. The restaurant has 2 floors and the 2nd floor is narrow and it overlooks the entire restaurant. There was also a live jazz band, which set the mood for the restaurant.

For a starter me and my boyfriend got the bone marrow served with shallots and I think it was crustini.  It was butter and salty and when you spread it on the crustini, it has a really good crunch. We both had the American Kobe Steak, which was good but I've had better steak. For dessert we had the Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding. Yum! Bread Pudding is one of my favorite desserts and this was one of the best.

One negative was that I made a reservation and we still waited about 20-25 minutes for a table.

I would come back here but mainly for the atmosphere and experience.
author: Therese M.

description: I had no idea what to expect when I ordered BIX Chicken Hash - and I loved every bite.  Noted experience when you're pleasantly surprised by a chicken dish.  Great atmosphere, great menu, great food - glad I made the trip.
author: Bill A.

description: Great food + live jazz = amazing experience.
author: Mehdi A.

description:
Every visit to Bix is a delicious culinary adventure set to a backdrop of old-world speakeasy ambiance.  The service is impeccable, friendly and unobtrusive, while the live music seems to perfectly suit either attentive listening or fade into the background, depending on what your mood is.

Don't miss the potato pillows with caviar, the ceviche, the lobster spaghetti or, really, anything on the menu.
author: Marisa L.

description:
My favourite burger in SF. Great cocktails and service.

We stopped in on a whim, although we'd been wanting to try out this old school restaurant for some time. Upon entering, we felt transported to a bygone era of jazz, wit, smoke, and tuxes that were dinner standards. I could picture Dorothy Parker and the rest of the Algonquin Round Table being daily fixtures under those beautiful ceilings.

Having just popped in out of the rain and deciding to eat a late lunch at 3pm, we opted for eating at the bar. We had read the 7x7 article on best burgers in SF, in which the Bix burger was ranked 6th.

Well, my tastebuds told me something different. The perfectly made medium rare burger I had was not only extraordinarily juicy, but had a delicious smoky, peppery taste that I quite couldn't figure out. Whatever secrets this burger had made its way to the top of my burger list!
author: G Z.

description: This place is great. The atmosphere is like an art-deco 1930's restaurant. I think. Anyway, the food is great and the live piano isn't so loud it's overbearing. We had a corner booth which was great and the valet parking is convenient. $10 but I guess it's the city so that's ok. Unfortunately I gave this place 3 out of 5 instead of 4/5 because of the service. If you are a younger couple don't expect to be treated like the older patrons. I was asking questions about the menu and the waitress just left before I even finished... And to add insult to injury every time I tried to catch her attention or any of the other waiters attention they'd look and simply walk to the kitchen. I had to ask the bread server to go get our waitress so we could get our bill that we had waited 30 mins for.
author: Joey C.

description:
Lobster Spaghetti is one of the best dishes I have had in San Francisco. The portion is quite large and suitable for sharing for a couple.  

The cocktails are great.  I love the ambiance at BIX and the service is excellent.
author: Moe J.

description:
BIX has been around for over 20 years, and there's still no other restaurant like it in San Francisco. Hidden in a small alley, entering BIX is like going back in time. The restaurant is a throwback to the supper clubs of the 1940's and creates a swanky, jazz lounge mood with its dark mahogany walls, plush booths, and tuxedo-dressed waiters.

Steak Tartare - they still serve *THE BEST* steak tartare I've ever eaten. It's meticulously prepared table-side with a medley of shallots, capers, and mustard, and served with slices of black olive toasts. It's meaty but light and satiny, and the flavors are fresh and vibrant.

Seared Scallops with Butter Beans - Mmmm, butter beans. I've never had butter beans before and these were soft and creamy. I actually enjoyed the beans more than the scallops. The scallops were nice, but could have used more of a sear on the outside.

Black Truffle Burger with Truffle Fries - they don't mess around with burgers here. This open-faced burger was huge with a generous layer of truffle shavings. The burger was thick and juicy, but I couldn't really taste the truffles. The truffle flavor was actually more pronounced in the fries, which were delish! I looooooooove truffle fries dusted with parmesan cheese - seriously, one of my favorite things to eat in the world.

Bananas Foster with Dark Rum & Vanilla Ice Cream - I was surprised they didn't prepare this table-side...must be a fire hazard. I wish they had caramelized the bananas more, but the dessert still satisfied my sweet tooth. 

To sum it up, BIX is a classy restaurant serving classic food...an oldie but goodie.  
[TIP: Request one of the booth upstairs - it's much cozier.]
author: Karin V.

description:
A place with true class!  I love that there is live music, the staff doesn't tolerate any nonsense (if you act like an idiot or don't follow the dress code, you are outti!), and the fact that this place is relatively unchanged.  As a single woman, I can drink there alone and have a fantastic time with individuals with manners and true class.  The bartenders and staff are as friendly as they are attentive.

The best nights for music to go in my opinion is Thursdays, Saturdays and Mondays.  The singer on Thursdays has a voice from heaven, the band on Saturdays is absolutely amazing, and the pianist on Mondays will take you to another world.

It is a bit on the expensive side, but if you're looking for a place to just relax and tap your foot to some good music, and perhaps meet some new faces, this is a good spot and well worth the expense... Oh and the food is FANTASTIC!
author: N J.

description:
Hands down, the best restaurant I've been to in SF! 
Looks sketchy from the outside, but  its surprisingly big and lively. Really crowded on a tuesday night..Very speakeasy feel. 
The atmosphere is amazing, especially with the live jazz band playing...
Ordered a couple of appetizers and they were all delisssssssssssssssssh ... mini lamburgers were goood, lovvvved the potato pillows w caviar omg
Their duck was good, bread pudding and sorbet were amazing..

Goooooooo.......now
author: Ami Y.

description: The food here is exceptional, I had the pork chop, it was one of the best that I have ever had. Great wine list. We will be back.
author: Joseph H.

description:
Great find!  Appetizers:  Mozzarella Skewers and Deviled eggs....Excellent

Main:  Chicken Hash....Excellent

Washed down with two Dirty Martinis

Will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu and have another Martini.
author: T S.

description:
Way too many good things to say about Bix.  The decor, atmosphere and food are all stellar, and frankly, the only place where it fell a little short was with the slightly pretentious waiter we had.

With that said, literally everything I had was good.  I'll list them out in order of deliciousness:

1. truffled deviled eggs
2. sweet white corn soup with bacon
3. dungeness crab rolls in brioche
4. lobster spaghetti in lobster cream
5. foie gras
6. truffle fries
7. truffle grilled cheese sandwiches

...and I didn't even get to try the steak tartare.  Yeah, it's really rare you find a restaurant where quite literally everything you eat is good.

But Bix is one of the amazing few.
author: Jeff N.

description: Rustic, yet swanky, live music, cool staff, cool location, this place feels like a throwback to a very different era.  The menu is good, and not to big, which tells me they care about the food the put out.  Solid lineup of wine, and drinks, and the tables are not to stuffy, and cramped like a lot of places in the Bay can be.  Its worth every penny, as its just a unique experience, with very good food.  It manages to do this without being overly douchy like a lot of places in SF can be.
author: Nick F.

description: Everything fish is good here. I love salmon tar tar! Have eaten it up every time. Would still probably hit up Boulevard or something like that when it come to fidi food but hey man deal with it! Again love the tar tar!
author: Tan N.

description:
Love this restaurant. Oysters on a half shell was super fresh. Must try the lobster spaghetti at least once - heavenly. 

Service was impeccable. Cool vibe. 

Don't forget to bring plastic!
author: Shy M.

description:
OMG worth the wait.

The Marrow, Foie Gras, Kobe, Potatoes, Bread Pudding.  The wine!
This place oozes over indulgence.  

Maitre D: And finally, monsieur, a wafer-thin mint. 
Bill: No. 
Maitre D: Oh sir! It's only a tiny little thin one. 
Bill: No. F* off - I'm full... 
Maitre D: Oh sir... it's only wafer thin. 
Bill: Look - I couldn't eat another thing. I'm absolutely stuffed. Bugger off....
author: Bill C.

description:
This is for the bar/happy hour only -- really nice, classy 40's-like atmosphere, but the pretentious vibe is a total turn off. 

We had to ask for the complimentary chex-mix bar snack (which my co-worker says is typically just given to you), and then it was taken away IMMEDIATELY literally 2 seconds after we asked for the check! Grr! I was still snacking excuse you, Mr. Bartender! 

I feel like we were being rushed, and I don't like that feeling at all when I'm trying to unwind after work. ESPECIALLY on a Monday.

What saves this place, I suppose, is the food and ambiance. Yes, the potato pillows were tator tots for the rich: super creamy and delicate with a dollop of creme fraiche and caviar. You get 4 pieces for about $13. Nibble VERY slowly and enjoy.

Also ordered the roasted bone marrow by recommendation of co-worker, which was a first for me. Superbly unique - tender and rich in veal oil, you scoop out the goods and spread it on your toasted baguette and garnish it with the fresh, tangy cilantro caper salad. Very special for about $13.

Ordered my usual dirty martini with extra olives -- very very well made for about $11ish. 

The food and drinks alone make me want to come back for a dinner splurge one day. Tucked away in an alley, this may definitely be the perfect place you want to steal away with for a sexy date or night out.

But gosh darn it, I hope the service is way better when you're seated and dropping the bling bling!
author: Gail N.

description:
This is rated purely on sitting at the bar. 

I loved that this place was in an ally and if I drove that there was valet. 
Inside, the bar was nice. My friend said this would be a good place to see older men, and she was right. I wanted to go here because other reviews mentioned their gin martini. It was delicious. We got prosciutto and mozarella to snack on and it was good. I liked that they gave some snack (gold fish, pretzel mix) at the bar. Service was good. We also got another drink that was good, it was a strawberry puree with vodka, delicious and refreshing. 

Only bad thing about this place was that it was hard getting a cab on a Friday night. The restaurant was happy to call for us but we waited and waited, none came and we found our own.
author: Colleen D.

description: BIX is amazing. My boyfriend and I took a spontaneous trip to San Francisco for my birthday. After BIX was recommended to us to go for a nice dinner, we happily went for the first time. BIX is a little difficult to find because it is in an alley but with the help of GPS we found it OK. My boyfriend and I made a reservation for 6:30pm but we were pleasantly seated at 6pm when we got there early. BIX is a very classy, upscale, and romantic restaraunt. We were dressed very casually so we stuck out like a sore thumb, however we were treated very well throughout the entire night. The food is AMAZING!!!! Every single dish we ordered was given an A+. We ordered the fried chicken and crab rolls for appetizers and for our meal we ordered the Lobster spaghetti and the truffle burger. For dessert we ordered Bananas Foster for dessert. I would HIGHLY recommend this place for a nice dinner. The ambiance is very warm and romantic, lights are dimmed and there is a live pianist to make the amiance more enjoyable. If you are looking for a place to dine out for an anniversary, birthday or New Years, this is the place. It is pricey, but well worth every penny.
author: Brianna B.

description:
Had nice leisurely dinner here recently & was delighted. Would go back.

If John's Grill & Tadich Grill are old-old-school -- then BIX is new-old-school.  Meaning it's a nice formal type dining room, the wait staff are professionals wearing black & white & bow ties.  Room is spacious, high ceilings, old style San Francisco type room. Not too noisy even when full.  

Cocktails shaken table-side, tasted fresh & delicious -- not too sweet. Food:  modernized American classics.  Some high end comfort food (the appetizer of fancy grilled cheese mini sandwiches was delicious).  I had the scallops, Mr M.C. had the pork chop; both were excellent. Service was polished & attentive...things swooshed on and off the table, you didn't have to ask for water refills etc.

Small bar area downstairs -- however all bar seats were taken the whole time we were there (Friday night 6-8 ish) so it's clearly popular.  Good news is that it wasn't packed-six-people-deep popular, like so many bars are....you might have to stand but there'd be space for you to stand comfortably & not get other people's elbows in your drink.  

As others note: the location is down a side alley in Jackson Square area -- not much parking nearby -- so come prepared with a transportation plan (where to park, or taxi, walk etc.).  

Bottom line: great place for a modernized classic American meal experience.  If that makes sense.
author: M. C.

description: Wow. I was really dismayed after reading a few of the reviews. Apparently a lot of people like this place. Perhaps my husband and I were there on an off night, but it was terrible. The hostess was snooty and out waiter was so rude and condescending. We had to send a couple items back because they were so extremely salty, our tongues actually burned. Our waiter was obviously put out having to return the items, he practically rolled his eyes. The rest of the food was nice and was presented well, but absolutely overpriced for what it was. The ambience was loud and crowded feeling. Definitely not the romantic dining environment the website touts. This experience was a real lowlight to our anniversary.
author: Carolina H.

description: This place is like walking through a time warp. Staff in tuxedos, entrance in an alley, live jazz music, and multi-level seating has great view of the band... All make for a very cool experience.
author: Jesse S.

description:
Ok, it was good. Not great. 

The martini I ordered as a pre-dinner drink had way too much vermouth. I know that I wasn't wearing my after-work tie and jacket and had my Killers t-shirt, but really? My date's Sauvignon Blanc from Duckhorn was incredible...more surprisingly, it was from the by-the-glass wine list.

The ceviche with jalapenos and corn nuts (!) was unbelievable. But the "firecracker shrimp" with chipotle cream ended up being popcorn nuggets with some kind of pink dip.

My lobster spaghetti was...so so. There was a recommendation from the chef that it not be enjoyed without the cream sauce that I rejected. I think I might have served the price. Ahem.

Her attitude was surprisingly refreshing for a blind date. I found myself infected by her joie de vivre and we closed the restaurant down four hours later. Sadly, we had nothing in common and said goodbye.
author: Joaquin R.

description:
The only reason I didn't give this a 5 star rating is because the bathrooms weren't maintained and the Manager was incredibly rude to our bartender/server right in front of us (re: a drink dispute).

OMG!  My experience knocked my socks off!  We didn't have a reservation, so we made our way up to the bar.  We sat at the last two seats closest to the kitchen which turned out to be the best seat in the house.  Our Bartender/Server was "Bradley" and he was part of the "knocked my socks off" experience.  He was so attentive and smooth.  Real, friendly, professional.  Make sure you ask for Bradley because a good server makes all the difference! 

The ambiance is bustling and fun, art deco and a bit like you're on a modern Titanic.  We watched a chef prep our appetizers: the beet/chevre salad and the ceviche.  Presentation is amazing.  Outside of the box.  Creative.  Fun.  Not to mention all consumingly delicious.  When eating these two appetizers, we were in total silence as we ate and then we couldn't shut up about how creative and amazing they were.  The ceviche was a bit like sashimi topped with jalepenos, habeneros, and Corn Nuts!  The corn nuts act as the crunch you'd get from tortilla chips traditionally.  The beet skewers looked like dessert when they were being prepared and were beautifully presented.  I will most definitely try to make these for my next party.  

Then comes the best part: THE TRUFFLE BURGER.  OMG!!!  I'm a new convert to the carnivore world.  This is the most seductive, all consuming, satisfying, orgasmic meat ceremony ever!  Prime meat, perfectly cooked, tender, truffle cheese, you can't do or think of anything else while you're experiencing this burger... and  it comes with  truffle fries... oh.... OH.... OOOOHHHHH!!!

Okay, so there it is.  Go to BIX every six weeks or so for the most orgasmic dining experience.  Be sure to sit with Bradley the Bartender.  I promise this experience will awaken all your senses as well as your sex life.  Enjoy :)
author: Kim J.

description:
I've loved Bix for a long time.  The atmosphere, the music, and the bar is of another time, in the best possible sense.  

The food during our last dinner here was a bit off, though.  We were a group of five and all had different dishes that left us underwhelmed.  In particular, the cedar planked sturgeon came out...tough.  So disheartening.  The desserts were either way too much, drowning in  sauce, or not nearly enough.  Only the steak was as tasty as expected.

We'll give it another try.  The Giant's were battling it out for the pennant so perhaps the minds in the kitchen were occupied with other things...  

And if nothing else, there's always a great old fashioned to be had at the bar.
author: Lena J.

description:
If I make it to Bix, it's usually for the Friday lunch.  Bix is a 10 minute walk away from the Financial District, close enough that it doesn't take forever to get there but far enough to be a nice escape from the workday.   

If it's your first time at Bix, get the chicken hash.  You won't be disappointed. The Bix Burger is good too, but the chicken hash is the star of the show.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Shockingly rude bartender whose icy demeanor caused me to take my date elsewhere.  I have been to Bix several times in years past due to its lovely, warm appearance and delicious food.  My experience was weird -- maybe the strangest I've ever had anywhere.  I walked in with my girlfriend, our coats were taken, and we sat down at the bar for pre dinner drinks and appetizers.  Both of us were in a pleasant mood, having had a nice day and looking forward to a romantic dinner.  I chose to take her to Bix.  Things immediately took a negative turn however as we sat at the bar and I greeted the bartender (mid-aged with glasses) with a smile and hello.  To which he responded with a cold stare, and silence.  He stood there staring at me without a word or movement (such as handing me a menu) for a good 15 seconds.  I then repeated myself and said hello again, waiting for an appropriate, welcoming response.   He still said nothing and continued glaring at me.  It was quite unsettling and awkward.  My girlfriend had gone to the restroom and I sat there feeling increasingly angry weirded out by this oddball's bizarre chilliness and it made me wonder if I had somehow wronged him in the past (never seen him before though).  He did not like me for some unknown reason made us feel like vermin.  I honestly began to feel discriminated against. We were dressed nicely but not formally.  I had a windbreaker on instead of a dinner jacket.  My girlfriend has a darker complexion.  I don't know, maybe he had a bad night, or hates tourists (yet, we're local natives of over 40 years); or perhaps I reminded him of someone from his past?  I don't know, but whatever his problem was I felt very uncomfortable.  Unfortunately, he managed to remove my smile and good mood with his coldness.  When he finally spoke he attempted to get me to order a bottle of wine -- at the bar!  I should have grabbed my girlfriend and left but gave him the benefit of the doubt.  I was determined not to let this jerk ruin my date and so when my girlfriend returned we ordered wine and appetizers.  The food and wine were excellent.  Still, the bartender remained cool to us and remained inattentive.  A snob?  But for what, why?  I just ignored the prick and focused on my girlfriend, but remained irritated and angry afterwards because I really wanted to sit down to dinner with her there.  Instead, I told her I didn't like this guy one bit and was very disappointed.  I took her to an Italian place up the street which was festive and much, much warmer than chilly, uncomfortable  Bix, ruined by snobby bartender behind the bar.  

Good food, but not worth the disrespect and discomfort that can tarnish a date.

PS  Called and wrote to manager over a week ago; no reply so I'm posting here.
author: Bill V.

description:
BIX is normally one of my favorites, but I went there for my birthday dinner on Friday and was so disappointed!  We were seated right away upstairs, but once we got upstairs and realized there was no air we asked for a seat downstairs.  We were there at 5:45 with hardly anyone there and were refused.  It then took us 20 min to get even a glass of water, not to mention our cocktails, appetizers, and dinner order taken.

The food itself was great.  We had the firecracker shrimp as an appetizer.  I had the kobe steak & my boyfriend had the lobster spaghetti.  We couldn't even have dessert or finish our drinks because we were so damn hot.  There were people next to us that just got up and left before dinner even started. It wouldn't have been bad, but we felt like the waiter was ignoring us a bit and we just wanted to eat and get out of there.   We did finish our drinks by the bar, but were totally annoyed.  The only saving grace was the awesome bartender who gave us a little more wine since he could tell we were sweating our asses off the last two hours.
author: Kim D.

description:
First class establishment.  I love the location, feels very seedy on a hidden alley way in NB. Yet enter and you feel like you transcend time to another era.  One where people cared how they dressed and service was an art form not a privilege.

I have never eaten hear, but just love to grab a drink from time to time.
author: Solbiato S.

description:
We went to Bix last Wed week with a bunch of out of town friends.  From the moment we walked in thing got off on the wrong foot.  We were supposed to have two tables but because some folks couldn't make it we only needed one table of 6.  The host was a bit grumpy about this despite the fact that the place was full and we still had to wait 20 min to get seated.  

By this time it was about 9:30 and we were starving.  We ordered the steak tar tar and fries to snack on.  It took way too long for the apps to come out and the waitress, although friendly, didn't see very interested in taking our order.  

For the main course I had the burger ($29) and my wife had the scallops.  The burger was throughly average, not worth $30 at all.  The scallops came out under cooked and the steak tar tar was also just about average.  

When I go to a place that is $30 for a burger and the staff is in tux jackets I expect top notch food and service.  Everything about this place was average or blow so they're getting 2 stars.  It might be a fun place to sit at the bar and have an expensive drink but other than that I wouldn't go back.
author: Garrett D.

description:
Maybe I jinxed myself by reading all of the 5 star reviews, but I was disappointed in my experience. Liked the jazzy feel, nice service, and upscale ambiance without feeling pretentious. The food just didn't live up to my expectations and that's where I deducted stars. 

We ordered: 

Potato pillows w/creme fraiche and caviar- creative, but the taste wasn't as bursting as I anticipated. somewhat flat. 
Lamb sliders - juicy, great flavor, on the smaller side 
Bone Marrow - again, taste was flat, bland and not remarkable 
Torchon Foie Gras - it looked and tasted like the pate in a can my aunt mailed to me from Bordeaux, which is good, but not what I'm expecting when I order foie gras at a resto 
Ceviche - decent, but again no burst of flavors 
Chicken Bix hash - interesting, tasty, and done well, if you enjoy hash 
Sturgeon (special of the night) - star of the night. fish was fatty, substantial and very tasty with the slow cooked leeks. 
Steak Bavette - not bad, but not great 
Truffle fries -soggy and limp 
Panna Cotta - okay taste, but nice presentation 
Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding - very yummy, so light it almost tasted like a souffle. 

BIX is okay, good in a way, but not perfection which is what I would expect in a place like this. A person in our party said the food is like this all of time when I tried to chalk it up as an off night. I can see the attraction towards BIX, it's a nice place, but when your bill is over $320, you should say, 'it was totally worth it!' instead of, 'eh, it was okay.'
author: Jennifer H.

description:
it was just ok.  our waiter was a bit pretentious which was offputting.

the potato pillows were pretty amazing, but tiny.  each piece is literally the size of a tator tot, if even.

got the lobster spaghetti which was good.
author: Henry H.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for Valentines dinner with my brother and his girlfriend. As soon as I walked in I love the place. The building is beautiful and an amazing atmosphere. Unfortunately when when my brother and his girlfriend got there the hostess looked at them as if they didn't belong there and asked them what they needed. After telling her they had reservations they were shown the bar. We were seated quickly on the upper level; everything looked even better and more private on the upper level. The food we ordered tasted amazing, not sure if it was worth $250 for 4 people but none the less it was good. There was live music which I really liked but they took more breaks then my lazy coworker so I didn't get to enjoy that much. OverAll an amazing experience and if I could justify spending that much money on food again I would definitely return.
author: Lauren M.

description:
The good: The ambience and decor are quite elegant (although the lighting is so dim that a neighboring diner had to use a flashlight to read the menu).  Our table was ready at the time of the reservation. The live music was nice. The service was good.  The martinis shaken table-side were excellent. 

The bad: The food was not nearly good enough to justify the prices. My wife's duck was under-whelming.  The same was true of my pork shoulder and belly.  My daughter did like the lobster spaghetti, however.  The tastiest part of the meal was the three tiny potatoes accompanying the entree.

The ugly (and incomprehensible!):  I started my entree with a bite of the side greens.  Imagine my surprise when I felt something hard.  When I spit out the food, I FOUND A SHARP SHARD OF GLASS THE SIZE OF MY THUMBNAIL!!  If I had swallowed it, a trip to the hospital would have been in order, at least. Fortunately, the roof of my mouth was only slightly scratched -- no blood. After quietly alerting our server, the manager came, asked if I was ok, thanked me for being so calm, and explained that the glass apparently was a piece of a broken ramekin.  He had no idea how it could have ended up in the greens.  He then told me that my dinner would be on the house.  The table also received a complimentary dessert. Our bill still came out over $200 before tax and tip.  Needless to say, the incident ruined the enjoyment of the dinner for our entire party!  While I didn't ask for any accommodation, it shocked me that the entire bill wasn't taken care of!  If it had been, I would have been satisfied that the restaurant had done everything possible  to make things right, and I might have passed on this review.

Needless to say, I will never go back, and I could never in good conscience recommend this place to anyone else.
author: Stephen J R.

description:
Went for lunch. Love the ambiance and setup, and it was tucked away from the hubbub. 

I went to order:

Me: How is your Chicken Hash à la Bix?
Waiter: Excellent, highly recommend it
Me: Would you say it's different?
Waiter: Well, let me say this, it is a dish people specifically come back for

Me (in my head): Yeah right, a chicken-based dish people "come back for" - cmon now, he is exaggerating

Ordered it. 

HOLY SHNIKES!! This was one of the most interesting and scrumptious chicken dishes I have EVER had. I don't eat beef or pork and am often underwhelmed by a chicken based dish.
