I can still vividly remember this dish and am now craving going back to order it again. The waiter was right. 

Good service and ambiance and reasonable prices for what you get (eg Michelin quality but not that crazy prices) = 4 stars. A dish this memorable on top of that, and made with chicken no less = worthy of being in another class = 5 stars.
author: Ravi A.

description:
I came here with two of my bestest to catch up over a "nice dinner", 'nice' meaning spending a little more than 5 dollars on a meal.
I was expecting an exciting ass meal but I don't think I would come back again.
For an appetizer,  we ordered the steak tartare because that is the thing to order at BIX. It was good but not enough for me to crave it again.
For dinner, I ordered the kobe bavette steak. The pommes puree was really good but I just expected a little more from the kobe bavette steak. It was by no means bad, but it wasn't great either. It was just..meh.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Hand Cut Steak Tartare....every time.

Now that I've gotten that out of the way I feel that Bix has all the makings of a 4 but I always walk away feeling it was about 3 (at the very least).

In fact the qualifications for the 4 star review seem to just pile up: Well executed uber-swanky décor, beautiful bar backdrop, excellent professional bartenders, great cocktails, good engaging host staff, excellent menu (that is to say there is just so much stuff that you actually say "wow, there are too many things that I'd like to try...it looks like I'll have to be back again."), and service is pretty decent. 

I'd like to add location too...something so cool about walking down these old Jackson Sq. brick alleys and happening upon nondescript but awesome places such as Bix.

So why oh why do I feel it deserves three?  To me...it lacks soul.  I liked all the food just fine...everything is executed well there just seems like there is an intangible missing.  Also, while I do love Jazz, I prefer to go see it at a club and not have it play while I'm having dinner with my peeps.

I'm curious to see what will happen when Quince moves in about 100' away.  Bix will have to find some warmth to hold its own...they have everything else in place so I actually am pretty sure they'll do just fine and may even assist Quince in maintaining its stellar reputation.

Oh...Hand Cut Steak Tartare...every time.  Vegetarians...suck it
author: Chris D.

description:
DAMN what a good restaurant. The best food I've had in a very long time.

I took my boyfriend here for his birthday last night, and WOW we were impressed. After a sub-par Valentine's Day experience at Nopa, we were excited to try another place on our list.

My boyfriend started off with the Bix Manhattan, which in both of our opinions, was the PERFECT drink. I like to taste the alcohol in my cocktails ( I love the taste of whiskey) and this drink was impeccably on-point.

We also had the Mozarella rolled in prosciutto as an appetizer, which was amazing. Small, but amazing.

As an entree, I had the truffle burger with the truffle fries which was everything you would expect it to be....delicious. It was perfectly cooked  with perfectly seasoned fries. I loved it

But even more than I loved my burger, I loved my boyfriend's lobster spaghetti. Shit, that spaghetti was good. I had never had lobster before (I'm not a big seafood person), but after reading all of the raving reviews about it, I knew I had to try it.
IT WAS AWESOME! Seriously, one of the best dishes I've had in this city. It was the perfect size, with plenty of little lobster chunks in a wonderful creamy sauce.

Excellent service, excellent wine. And yes it was an expensive meal, but that was to be expected at such a great restaurant.

I cannot wait to go back, this meal was worth every penny.
author: Ashley B.

description: Bix. The allure of the location itself, clandestined in an alley street, sets the tone for a cool experience.   Arrived early on a Friday evening with husband and friend from out of town in tow.   We had two dozen amazing fresh oysters and some drinks at the bar.   The oysters were fresh, clean, delicious, and while pricey, worth it.   We then proceeded to our table upstairs to enjoy our meal.   As a massive generalization, I would say the first courses trump the entrees at Bix.   The mini Banh Mi sliders were off the charts good, and you can't beat the Bix deviled egg.  Speaking of beets, the beets were wonderful with a blue cheese pana cotta and a stunning presentation.   I ordered the salmon, and it was average.  It seemed like an after thought, lacking flavor and presentation.   Other than that, all was good.  Definitely a reliable go to when entertaining friends or clients from out of town.
author: Tiss D.

description:
My review is based on a late night with just appetizers and drinks, which was superb.  We had a bottle of rose champagne (Moët & Chandon, Epernay, Brut, Rosé) that was so yummy I'm drooling just thinking of it.  To eat we had Roasted Beet and Chévre, Tuna Tartare with Fresh Hummus, and Potato Pillows with Crème Fraîche and American Sturgeon Caviar.  I like the play of flavors as well as the creative plating.  I can only imagine how good dinner would be.  

An extra plus is that there is live jazz....good place to have a date.
author: Mai-Tam N.

description:
I haven't had the pleasure to eat dinner here but I will review on their drinks.  I've been a couple times for cocktails with family, friends and on a date.  Their drinks blow other restaurants out of the water.

I will give 5 stars to whatever bar can make a better "Old Fashion" than my mother.  BIX YOU ARE TOP NOTCH!!!
author: Sarah W.

description:
I expected to leave with at least a 4-5* meal but sad to say, 2 is all I can give.  First, the cocktails.  I ordered the Gimlet which was  ~$10, ok that's not too bad for this type of restaurant...except its in a martini glass that was barely bigger than a shotglass.  At least it tasted good.  My friend ordered a Manhattan on the rocks.  It came in a short glass that was about 1/3 full.  hmmm...  Do I want another?  no thanks.

Appetizers were pretty good.  Potato pillows, truffled grilled cheese sandwiches, and marrow bone.  No complaints about those.  Then we got to the main entree.  I ordered the Kobe Bavettes.  Slightly tough and completely under flavored.  The mash potatoes were pretty bad too and tasted almost rubbery.  

I had eaten there once in the past and don't remember it to be that bad. But so many good restaurants in SF that it'll be a while before I try them again.
author: R L.

description: Holy truffle-deviled-eggs. This place is delicious. The inside has a very cool vibe, and the story behind the building is great. Awesome place for a date or a special occasion.
author: Kelli D.

description:
This place is a fun find.  Hidden in an alley, I wouldn't have found it on my own without a recommendation.

Good food, good service, nice atmosphere.  I had the truffle burger, which should be renamed truffle explosion.... I've never seen more truffle in one place.  It was awesome and served with truffle fries.  My wife had the lobster spaghetti and loved it.

I hear this is also a great place to go for just cocktails, but I'd suggest dressing nicely to not feel out of place.
author: Teague A.

description: Great place; I felt like I had stepped right into a scene from the Great Gatsby. The building is on the Ntl. Register of Historic Places; it's intimate but fantastic for people watching. The bar just *looks* stunning; the service was excellent; the food, fantastic. There were some odd-looking combinations on the menu, I'll admit (too much fruit & cherries mixed in), but I liked the salmon entree and the strawberries dessert.
author: Katherine L.

description:
April 29th is my birthday and I have had a few so I look forward to dressing up and going to a nice dinner out with my love. We looked up this place and it was said to be a great one for birthday dinner, romantic and all the right "categories" were checked that made it seem like a great choice.

Reservation was made one month in advance for 8:00 pm dinner at BIX. We arrived 7:55 and noticed the place was packed. The host told us to wait at the bar and start with a cocktail. I started to look around and noticed there were as many people standing in the cramped bar area as at least half of the dinning room size downstairs. Could it be that these people were just having cocktails? No they all were waiting for a table. So I wondered how we could possibly be seated on time? Ok so a popular place we can hang out for a few minutes...so it's now 8:30 and we are still waiting and more people are arriving. 

It was very difficult to not let this ruin our mood. We had taken a cab from across town, already had a drink at the bar and when my boyfriend asked the host why we are not seated, he was told because the people were not leaving their tables. Well I'm sorry for a 4-5 star $$$$ category, one should not have to wait as if we are out for a brunch at Zazie's or casual dinner at Puerto Alegra (two examples of great restaurants that set the expectation correctly). We left, it was such a disaster. They almost ruined my birthday. They did not offer to buy us our drinks or anything. It made me remember another birthday I had, we went to Gary Danko and they had us wait not more than 5 minutes and right away poured us Champagne on the house for making us "wait".

So here is the bottom line, this place was half filled with more people that looked like they had come to dinner on their company and for business and some just for a night out. For your special occasion this is not the place. They did not CARE at all about their impact on our evening and fortunately we live San Francisco where there are plenty of fantastic restaurants and we got a table at Chez Spencer (which was our choice last year) right away, were treated so well. They had live piano playing and it was amazing. No thanks to BIX.
author: Bee N.

description: good caviar and drinks I've been going to Bix since early 2000 every one our nice and friendly.
author: Houman R.

description: My husband and I wanted to try something new and this place was highly recommended.  Loved the atmosphere and the history of the building.  Was very impressed with the wine list.  Not many restaurants offer Silver Oak by the glass.  The food was incredible. I had the deviled eggs and chicken, my husband had the truffled burger.  It was scrumptious!  The jazz music was amazing!  We will definitely be back.
author: Cassy H.

description:
My hunnie took me out last night. I can't wait to go back!

BIX took excellent care of us. In addition to what we ordered (appetizer sampler, Kobe beef, scallops with butter beans and plenty of drinks) we were privy to some of their other dishes like the truffled deviled eggs,  ceviche and their INCREDIBLE yet simple house made mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto (plus some truffled fferench fries with our entrees).

Everything we had was expertly prepared. From the tuna tartare and firecracker shrimp on the appetizer plate to the perfectly grilled beef with pureed potatoes to the huckleberry cake with huckleberry and lemon ice cream we had for dessert-everything was great. The only thing I would mention about the menu is the reliance on truffles in a lot of dishes-a little thing considering that every dish that contained the magic mushrooms were delish!

The drinks are worth mentioning, as well. I had the ginger gimlet made with the kaffir lime Hangar One. The drink is a far cry from the cheap vodka and Rose's Lime Juice cocktails I learned how to pour my parents at a young age. I couldn't get enough. My bf had dirty martinis- simple and well prepared.

The service was also exceptional. It should be expected in a place that costs this much, but it is never guaranteed. Our waiter was friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. 

Thanks BIX. I will be back!
author: Cory R.

description:
Beautiful and classy restaurant; jazz music greets you as you walk through the doors. Couldn't wait to experience all the goodness I've read in the reviews. 

Our server was so cold, snooty and rote, why not just send a robot or a cold fish over to take our order? She just wasn't friendly, didn't crack a smile or explain anything on the menu with passion or interest - completely lackluster.  In fact, i felt as if we were doing her a favor...and I hate that feeling...Maybe she was having a bad day.  

Can't understand all the Yelp hype about the cocktails here...basic and served in teeny, tiny cocktail glasses and extremely pricey - $16 for a not top shelf martini!

As for the food:  unimpressive, unmemorable and extremely pricey. Had the deviled eggs which were simply okay,  truffle fries which were YUM but a very, very scant portion (it was probably the size of half a potato) and uninspired cocktail meatballs (think frozen) which should be taken off the menu.  Pork chops were overdone and  it looked like my husband had a double cut while mine was a single cut chop, served with boring bland white beans. Although we ordered the same thing, our food was plated differently in terms of portion and sides!  Our friends had the pan seared flounder which was just fine, nothing fancy or memorable here, and the lobster spaghetti, which they enjoyed. 

That about sums up my experience and review: bland and uninspired.
author: Allison R.

description: It's been a while since I have been here last and the food is still quite impressive.  I love the crab rolls on the brioche bread!! I couldn't stop eating them and had to take an order home!!!  Even after eating their yummy bread...The duck was cooked a little under for my preference so they had prepared a new order for me and it turned out great!! We had the banana foster but it was very very sweet...i think the rum sauce over took the power of the whole dish!! I think I will try the chocolate brioche next time!!
author: Mee-stique K.

description:
My fiance planned a romantic evening for us and BIX was the choice. We had never been there before but the menu looked great and we had heard good things. 

I arrived early and attempted a drink at the bar. I say attempt because the bar was packed. The bartender finally noticed me and proceeded to give me a dirty look when I asked to see the drink menu. I ordered a dirty martini extra olives. It was not a martini and there were no extra olives, I didn't even get a proper martini glass. 

When my fiance arrived, we were promptly seated by a rather unfortunate table right by the bathroom door. The hostess did not bother to ask if I would like to check my coat or umbrella. 

The service was efficient but cold. We very much felt like we were being rushed through or interrupted at really inconvenient moments. The noise level was very high and it was difficult to carry on a conversation.

The best thing about the place was the appetizers. The deviled eggs were awe inspiring and the bone marrow was heavenly. They were kind enough to wrap up the marrow bones for our dog, who is happily gnawing on one as I type. 

My fiance was very disappointed in the kobe beef and my truffle burger was tasty but not easy to eat. We were so irritated after the meal, we decided to skip dessert. 

I was glad we went, glad for the deviled eggs and bone marrow but we don't ever need to eat there again.
author: Jann J.

description: The food is great. Came by for drinks and ended up having some appetizers. The live jazz creates a great ambiance. Not many places like this in SF. Can't wait to come back for dinner next week.
author: Al C.

description: I liked Bix the food is solid but the dining room has a unique look and feel.  If you are looking for a solid Friday night option to share with friends - look no further.
author: Michael S.

description:
When I stepped into Bix I immediately had the feeling that I should have enlisted  a Sugar Daddy to escort me here. There definitely is an, "Air" about this place. It has a very upscale feel, which is weird seeing how it's located in a random alley in the North Beach area.

The wait staff wear white tuxedo jackets, and most of them are older gentlemen...think Mr. Belvedere the Butler. 

I only had drinks at the bar, but from my vantage point I was able to appreciate the, "Great Gatsby" type vibe and hear some good jazz music. 

I'll stop by for dinner one night once I find that Sugar Daddy.
author: Benita S.

description:
World's Best Martini--yes!
World's Best Mohito--yes!

Nice Jazz scene and a very clandestine location..
author: Jay N.

description:
A proposal of marriage to the chef: 

I sat in the corner booth of the second floor, waiting for the waiter to bring us our food. Twenty minutes later he came out with our orders and placed a rectangular white plate in front of me. On it sat four potato pillows topped with Creme Fraiche and American Sturgeon Caviar. "Oh how cute! It's tater tots" I jokingly said to everyone at my table. I plopped a pillow into my mouth, and the pillow dissolved in my mouth. My taste buds screamed with Ecstasy. How stupid of me to compare your heavenly pillows to Burger King's tater tots? At that very moment I knew, I had fallen in love, "I must marry the chef and keep him/her chained up in my kitchen!" 

I sprinkled at least 3 tablespoons of Parmesan cheese over my Maine Lobster Spaghetti with Lobster Cream sauce. After watching all 14 episodes of 'Kitchen Confidential', I've learned I've committed an ultimate crime and sullied your piece of art that you've created. If you promise to cook only for me, I will never destroy another one of your creations. 

Without getting to racy, all I have to say is me + you + and your Vanilla Bean Panna Cotta....and don't forget the strawberries ;) 


Be mine, cook only for me, don't make me go back to eating 'regular' food
author: Nalipay M.

description:
Tucked down an alley way in the financial district, this restaurant certainly feels like a little gem to come across.  Despite the seemingly grumpy woman at the door, our coats were taken quickly and we were seated moments later. The ambiance of the restaurant definitely feels "old-timey" and romantic with live piano music, art deco-ish details and a beautifully lit bar. Our server was very attentive and pleasant and helped us along with our food choices.

The food- I was nervous after reading previous reviews, but I found their food to be quite tasty. We ordered the meatballs as an appetizer and a Caesar salad to share--both were wonderful.

Next for our entrees, we had the duck breast and the pork chop. Both were very tender and good, and we were both impressed by the "bedding" of kale and butter beans under our respective dishes. We also ordered a side of creamed spinach, which was amazing.

The price- We did sort of go all out with cocktails (which were okay), a bottle of wine and coffee and dessert after the meal-- but still, the place felt a bit on the pricey side. For the average 30-something, this restaurant is definitely a once in a while type of destination.

Truth is- though this place was good- and there was nothing amiss- there wasn't anything that particularly stuck with me after I left. I suspect the ambiance is the biggest draw, but I think you can find similar for cheaper.
author: Jessica H.

description:
A classy joint with live music, good food and great people watching.  

We sauntered in around eight on a Thursday night without a reservation and were seated shortly after we ordered our "waiting at the bar" drinks.   It was probably just luck, but we landed the table right in front of the piano and right between the old money family celebrating their tortured gay art student son's birthday and the couple visiting from SoCal that were finger banging each other all night.  Your experience may vary, but sitting next to the musicians would have been fantastic even without all of the peripheral entertainment.  

The food, as expected, was phenomenal.   If you want recommendations, try the gulf shrimp cocktail which is perfectly cooked and served with amazing spicy dipping sauce; the hearts of romaine with Point Reyes bleu cheese, very rich and perfectly crunchy; the fried pork chop, better than my grandmothers, just don't tell her I said that; or the Kobe beef steak, accurately described by our waitress as the less tender but more flavorful of the two steaks on their menu.  The only thing I ordered that I wouldn't rush to order again was the asparagus side.  It wasn't bad, I just wasn't a fan of the pickle/boiled egg relish that came with it.
author: dan d.

description:
Not children friendly. Even though on the phone they will tell you kids are welcome. They REALLY mean, no kids too young to sit in their chairs. Seriously.... I don't have a problem getting a sitter but in this case I actually thought I was going to get to eat with him so of course I brought him after calling and being told he was welcome. 

Thank goodness Hillstone (previously Houston's on the Embarcadero) had a table short notice and they are always a hit. Plus free corkage.... 

Never got to eat at Bix and won't be back.... Too many other places in the city to try.
author: amy m.

description:
Bix is a pretty sweet spot hidden away in a back alley in the financial district.  I've been there three times now.  The art deco interiors are genuinely awesome.  The bartenders are cool, and in general it's the kind of place where you'd order a gimlet, or a manhattan, or an old-fashioned.  That alone is worth the four stars.

The food is, I don't know what you call it -- Cal-Fusion?  Something like that.  It's pretty good.  Last time I went I got everything that was truffled -- truffled croques monsieur, a truffled cheeseburger (!), and truffle fries.  Mmm.  Truffles.

Seriously, though, it's just a place that's dripping with Mad Men-style coolness, so I'd strongly recommend it.

Oh, about that chocolate bread pudding though: be forewarned that it's more chocolate and less bread pudding.  So if you're expecting something more bread-pudding-y, you'll be disappointed.
author: Marco C.

description: Loved Bix. Wanted to have dinner in the retro SF style , you know, pretend I'm living in the 50s. This is the place to time warp back into the old era of SF before you were born. Martinis, Granite bar, Piano in the background, and some decent food. All with the right ambiance to have a decent conversation and make memories. Will be back again when I'm feeling nostalgic. I highly recommend you do the same.
author: Geronimo K.

description: We went here for our anniversary, and really enjoyed it.  The appetizers--we got the steak tartar, lamb burgers, and mozzarella skewers --were probably our favorite part.  It is not overly romantic, as it is quite loud and all tables are out in the open, but you can't help but feel glamorous walking down the huge stairway in the middle of the restaurant.  The live music was also great, and the fact that Bix is hidden in an alley made us feel like VIPs for finding such a cool place.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I'm revising my previous "iffy" review on the vegetarian options to note that the dish that I had last time was quite good. Since there aren't any vegetarian options on the menu, I was very specific about what I wanted in my pasta this time. I got a tomato and basil pasta with fresh vegetables that was great. If you're vegetarian though, I would recommend not doing the veggie platter which was just steamed greens.
author: Krupa S.

description:
Though I've been here for dinner (which is great), I think its more fun for a classy after-work happy hour place.  The lamb sliders and tuna tartare are way too good to just be called "bar food".  

One of the bartenders (you know who you are) is a pompous prick, but I really won't hold it against the place.  

It's pricey but you get what you pay for.... the only thing I was a little offended by was the $38 price tag on Macallen 18.  Come on guys....
author: Ted T.

description:
Been here a few times.  I think its about time I gave this wonderful establishment a review.  Had dinner here before the Peter Pan show.

Its feels "old school", classy but not snooty, and the clientele is older but it all works like peanut butter and jelly =P

I got hooked on this place when I had their Marrow bones.  I blame Anthony Bourdain for this addiction.  I always get this as my starter.  Correction, its second after my vodka tonic.

The mini lamb burgers were delicious.  I could've had 3 orders of this as an entree!  My friend had the dungeness crab rolls which she seemed to enjoy because she'd only allowed me one bite! WEAK!!

Friend had the Steak Bavette which she didnt seem to enjoy because she kept feeding it to me. LOL! 

I had the lobster spaghetti. Well, half a plate of it because my friend kept picking at the other half which was ok since she does it in the most adorable way possible.  

Service was on point. I dont care how good the food is at any restaurant but if the service sucks, then it ruins the whole experience.  Our server was attentive and very professional.  This will definitely be one of my "go to" spots.  I wish I could say it'll be a one of my "regulars" but I'd be flat broke. =P
author: Sun T.

description: I dined at BIX with family in May winding donw an amazing vacation. To my great surprise BIX served beef tatar as a starter, a dish I did not have since leaving my home country of Germany where it is a traditional Saturday evening treat. It was prepared and served to perfection. I should not forget the other equally perfect courses I had. It was an excellent dinner and well worth the price. The service was friendly and not overbearing and  I would come back any time when spending time in the great city of San Francisco
author: Margot T.

description:
excellent food, excellent service. this place is hidden in an alley way. dim lighting to set the mood. i was on a date with my bff. 

the only thing i did not like was the Potato Pillows with Crème Fraîche and American Sturgeon Caviar-very bland and the caviar did not make a difference. was pretty disappointed.

Dungeness Crab Rolls in Brioche with Meyer Lemon Aioli-AMAZING! the brioche was soft with a bit of a crunch. lots of crab and the aioli was just the perfect touch

Steak Tartare with Shallots, Capers, Parsley and Mustard-pretty big portion. really fresh meat and great amount of seaoning. not dry at all

À la minute Ceviche with Chiles, Avocado and Toasted Corn Nuts-the fish was halibut. so fresh that it just melts in your mouth

Maine Lobster Spaghetti "alla Chitarra" with Cherry Tomatoes, Jalapeños and Basil-they spilt the plate for my friend and i and didn't charge us for it (score) they give alot of lobster, but just a lil too many cherry tomatoes. this dish was light and just so good.

Must come back to try all their other stuff. LOVE LOVE LOVE!
author: Karen H.

description:
When the cab dropped us off and pointed to the alley, my first thought was - cool, a speakeasy!  Getting away from the humdrum of franchised or hotel restaurants around Moscone Center was really a treat and relief.  BIX feels like old San Francisco, with two floors of dining, an extensive bar and live music as the evening drew on.

For appetizers, we ordered the deviled eggs with truffle (to die for!) and salmon tartare.  I would've ordered the bone marrow but it required a 15min wait, and we were too tired to wait.  For mains, a couple of us had the lobster spaghetti ($25 for small portion), pork chops (2 huge chops - seemed like the most value for money), and fish of the day which was halibut.  We were all complimentary of the food.  I had the lobster spaghetti, which had big chunks of lobster and the right amount of pasta cooked al dente.  You will want to specify to the waiter the portion desired as they seem to automatically put you down for the $40 unless otherwise instructed.

The place got noisy when the piano and singer started, by which time we were pretty much done eating.  I would've adjourned to the bar if with friends, but this being a business dinner .. it was a signal for us to leave.  BIX is within walking distance to Union Square with the right walking shoes.  Otherwise, be sure to download the Uber app for easy cab dispatch.
author: Liz T.

description: This review is for the bar. I won't ever be eating at the restaurant after this experience. Rude, gruff bartender, mediocre cocktails (sickly sweet blood orange margarita, uninspired manhattan), lots of inexplicable attitude, a swarm of loud tourists at the bar by 6pm. Never again.
author: Dx D.

description:
Steak tartar, definitely a presentation and it made me really hungry watching them prepare it in front of you

Cheese Croques were yummy and the atmosphere was so nice. The crowd seemed a bit older though (maybe it's because I went on a Sunday night)
author: Eric A.

description: Good food, better ambiance, worse service. Great spot for a casual date - very charming.
author: Jerry T.

description:
Loved the ambiance. We had dinner here on a Thursday night since it was walking distance from our hotel and were delighted to see they had live jazz music.

Walking in you feel like you've taken a step back in time. I was impressed with the appetizers and drinks. The bar here is legit. For starters, we had the bone marrow and potato pillows. You can not go wrong with either. Both melt in your mouth and are rich in flavor. As for the main entree, I had the steak paillard and was left unimpressed. The meat was chewy and was a bit salty for my taste. Our waiter was very attentive but came off a little snooty at times. If you decide to try this place I recommend getting a table on the second floor.
author: t s.

description: I agree with Meagan's review.  The location and setting are nice.  The prices are astronomical!  $28.  for an average burger and  good fries.  $12.  for four (halves) average deviled eggs.  $9. for average creamed spinach.  $10. for a side of fries.  The service was efficient, but did nothing to add to our dining experience.  The service was aloof.
author: Alexandria H.

description: The ambiance is great, the piano bar was a nice touch. The servers were friendly and well trained, and the food was good. Would definitely recommend it to my friends.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
If I'm going to spend $50 (not including alcohol) on my meal, I want it to be a fantastic experience. I just had an OK time at Bix. The food was OK. Tasted fine, but was unoriginal and the portions were small for the price. I got the American Kobe Steak and had 6 small pieces of steak.

The clientele was mostly people in their 50s and 60s, so if you're young and expecting a fun scene...don't go here. There was a live pianist and singer, which was great in an old school kind of way. The servers were very attentive and professional.
author: Grace Y.

description: If you are looking for a romantic, yet bustling restaurant with an atmosphere of a 1940s club you've found it.   The food is excellent and many traditional dishes have added tasty twists.  The grilled cheese appetizer and bananas foster are a must.  Get there early and have a drink at the beautiful hand carved old school dark wood bar and listen to the piano player or jazz musicians that entertain each weekend.
author: Eric T.

description: Showed up on time for 730pm reservations and weren't seated till 755pm. The hostess was polite and the wait wouldn't have been an issue, if the service and food for the rest of night had made up for it. We tried the potato pillows, truffle fries, lobster spaghetti and dorade. The potato pillow was the only palatable dish from our selections. The lobster spaghetti was mediocre and certainly didn't live to its hype, but I guess Le bernadin had me hoping for better. The biggest rouse were the truffle fries, which were an absolute travesty and no one should waste their money on it. Our server was too busy with the bigger parties from the conference in town since they were ordering bottles by the bucket load and even after attempts to flag her down to point out the hair in my bread, we weren't successful. Finally, we flagged down the busboy and asked him to call her attention so we could have the bill.
author: A R.

description:
I love love love LOVE this place, especially for the amazing food and the strong drinks. The last couple times I went here there was a solo pianist, so I have made it a point to come back when they have a bigger jazz ensemble performing.
The lamb is a must taste, along with the crab cake app and the butterschotch brownie bites. But in all honesty, everything is exquisitely made and mouth-wateringly delish!
The fifth star is absent because the price point makes it a once-in-a-blue-moon place for me. Very $$$
author: Caron S.

description:
This is one of those places that makes you feel, "Yeah, I made it." (LOL) 

So a few weeks ago, management from my project decide on a nice team dinner. We take a drive into the heart of downtown San Francisco, go down this small alleyway and stop right in the middle. A valet pops out of nowhere and opens the car door. We're quickly ushered into a classy joint,  full of history. 

We were early enough to grab a few cocktails and I got to admire our elegant surroundings. The mahogany bar spoke of old cigars and C-Suite conspiracies. Golden soft lights illuminated a beautiful 2-story dining room. Although this place was definitely more suited for a romantic supper than a power dinner with colleagues from my firm, it wouldn't stop me from enjoying myself. 

The meal, my God was that a meal! Having done my homework in Yelp and armed with all the past reviews, I shared some recommendations. We started off with a few appetizers. As warned by others, the potato pillows with American sturgeon caviar was like biting into a heavenly cloud. The mini-lamb burgers were cute and delicious. Torchon Of Artisan Foie Gras with spiced quince and toasted brioche is as good as any. The Marrow Bones "St. John" - it was succulent, sweet and my absolute favorite of the bunch! 

For dinner I ordered the Fresh Maine Lobster Spaghetti with rich lobster cream. It was slightly disappointing that were no large, identifiable pieces of lobster. Hey, I'm being honest! Others ordered the American Kobe "Bavette" Steak with pommes puree and the Chicken Hash Ala Bix which folks polished off their plates faster than I could sneak my fork in it! After a few bottles of wine, we were feeling rather toasty. 

When dessert came around, I was very selfish. While other shared bites of their El Rey Chocolate And Butterscotch Brownies or spoonfuls of Warm Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding, I slowly and silently savored my Bananas Foster with dark rum and vanilla ice cream. Sure, they tried to get my attention, but I made sure not to make any eye contact. 

I don't want to forget the first-class service - it was impeccable and they missed nothing!  Full, happy and satiated, we left as it started to drizzle. It was a decadent evening and I hope to return one day soon....
author: Jenny D.

description: I had dinner at Bix last night and....what happened? The lettuce in the salad was wilted, the duck was tasteless and the service was horrible. Granted, the waitress had two tables of 10, but they were right next to each other and she couldn't keep our wine glasses filled. This place used to be one of my favorites. Again, what happened? A change in management? Maybe like many places that do a heavy tourist trade, they have fallen off their game because the tourists are satisfied with mediocrity. Such a shame-crossing it off my list.
author: Karen F.

description: Great place, great service, great meal! The Bone Marrow starters were outstanding, as was the crab rolls, some good cocktails, and flavorful food. would go back again!
author: Ahmad B.

description:
I chose BIx for my family birthday dinner and am so happy that I did! We entered to very attentive service. It had been raining outside and they quickly offered to take our wet jackets and umbrellas. Then, we were shown to a beautiful booth table with a simple card on the table wishing me happy birthday from Bix. The restaurant had perfect lighting and awesome decor.

I enjoyed sipping on the ginger gimlet and we all enjoyed glasses from a bottle of nice red wine (my dad ordered it so I'm not sure which it was...).

Then, we sampled tons of items from the menu. My brother and I both chose to pick out multiple appetizers to make our dinners while my parents and boyfriend ordered full dishes. In my family's usual fashion, we all tried samples of each others dishes.

Starting with my favorite tastes, here's what we had for appetizers and mains:

- Trout salad: amazing! a perfect, generous portion of delicious trout mixed with fresh greens and delicious dressing
- Crab rolls: fresh crab between perfect bread
- Ceviche: fresh halibut, avocado, lime, and spices served in an aesthetically-pleasing design
- Beet & chevre skewers: yellow and crimson beets served between thin layers of chevre cheese; yummy balsamic reduction sauce on the side
- Truffled french fries: garlicly deliciousness that were yummy dipped in the aioli and/or ketchup
- French onion soup: not much cheese on top which was perfect for me because I'm not so into cheese. Very oniony and fresh tasting.
- Mahi mahi special: seared raw mahi mahi over a fresh bean mixture
- Firecracker shrimp: large prawns lightly fried and served with a creamy sauce
- Pork chop: I don't even like pork and this was delicious. The spinach on the side was the best spinach I've ever tasted.
- Kobe beef: I heard it was great but only tried the mashed potatoes...
- Mozarella/prosciutto balls: somewhat bland compared to the other amazing dishes

Then, the grand finale... the dessert! They brought candles a top of our bananas foster and the whole table sang happy birthday. I consider myself a bananas foster critic and this was five times better than the second best I've tried. It was AMAZING! We also had the cute little chocolate and butterscotch brownie sticks. The whipped cream served with them made a great dip but the melted vanilla ice cream/bananas foster mixture was an even yummier dipping option...

I'd love to come back to Bix for great service and dishes served to utter perfection!
author: Meghan P.

description: I give this place 5 stars for the ambiance. Unfortunately, I was not that impressed by the food. My husband and I split the bone marrow, fried chicken, crab rolls and steak tartare. I have never tried bone marrow before but was really excited to try it out, since it has so many rave reviews at Bix. Honestly, I thought it was disgusting. I was just happy that we ordered first and it ended up coming out before everything else, because I needed something to overtake the foul taste in my mouth. In all fairness, I am sure it is relatively good, I just ended up not liking bone marrow, as I thought I would. The rest was truly just "okay". I'd say the best value was the fried chicken. I was actually pleasantly surprised how good it tasted for being one of the cheapest things on the menu. Overall, our bill came to over $100, with a couple cocktails. It was nice to try out, but I likely won't make a return visit when in town.
author: Jaclyn S.

description: Went here for a birthday dinner and loved the dark, swanky interior.  The live music in the background was a very nice touch and the service was professional and attentive.  Food was good, but nothing stood out in particular.
author: Eric F.

description:
Great atmosphere. Makes you feel like you are eating at a restaurant set in the Great Gatsby. Every time I come here I always order a Sidecar, Manhattan or an old fashion because it just feels right.

It's located in a small alley way in between in the Financial district and North Beach. The bar is usually bumpin and populated with business types looking to get a social cocktail.

The food here is excellent. The chicken hash and pork chop are favorites of mine. Service is attentive but it has been flighty at times.

If you love bananas fosters then you need to come here. They have the best fosters this side of New Orleans.
author: Jeff P.

description:
we tried their friday only lunch!

this place offers a different vibe than other restaurants that i have been to. it has 20-30's jazz-in-new-orleans sort of vibe to it. it wasn't necessarily my thing but i could certainly appreciate its originality.

they serve rather classic food. the steak tartar and ceviche were not really stunning but they were enjoyable.

their entress were awesome though. chicken hash and the special pork dish were just some of those you can't stop eating. they were savory, flavorful and just pleasant. 
cherry tomatoes were such nice seasonal addition to the dish.

sadly, we didn't get to try their dessert as we had to hurry up and leave.. but warm chocolate brioche sounded sooo good!
author: Sung C.

description:
Great food, cocktails and atmosphere, but the music was a little too loud.

Crab Rolls - Delicious!
Deviled Eggs - They are sprinkled with shaved truffles and are highly addictive.
Chicken Hash - It's served with a tangy lemon sauce and cherry tomatoes.  Great dish.
Pork Chop - The sauce on this is amazing.  Couldn't get enough of the fingerling potatoes that went really well with the sauce.  Unfortunately the pork chop was off.  A little dry and tough.

Overall great place to dine but they need to soften the music a little.  It's difficult to have a conversation without yelling.
author: Peter S.

description:
AWESOME!

Just go to this spot that is literally in the cuts and order the "Pillows", "A la Minute" & "Bavette"!  Have a couple drinks while you're at it and after your meal, go smoke a cigarette with one of the musicians outside and then call it night.
author: Limzer L.

description:
Bix is an excellent restaurant with amazing dishes. The neon sign "BIX" makes you feel you are going to the best night club in town and once you are in you enjoy the superb atmosphere. Their live jazz makes you feel you are in Manhattan; no wonder San Francisco is such a charming city. We had reservations last Saturday night at 9:30pm and it was fabulous to have dinner listening to live jazz playing until 12:15am. Jonathan was absolutely a wonderful waiter, very attentive of us at all times.

We had the following: Appetizer - Dungeness crab was by no doubts very fresh, straight-out-the-bay and the toasted bread used to make the rolls in brioche with Meyer Lemor Aioli was delightful, the special entrée for the evening - two of them and they were spectacular - Wild Alaskan Sockeye Salmon w/Spaetzle sweet corn, wild mushrooms with Buerre Blanc Sauce and for wine Jonathan recommended 2007 Chablis Jean-Marc Brocard Vielles Vignes that was perfect for the seafood. Dessert - Caramelized Vanilla Semifredo with farmer's market nectarines and candles to celebrate the birthday, and to finalize our dinner we had Martell Cordon Blue steamed to truly enjoy the aroma of the cognac. Outstanding cuisine!
author: Gigi W.

description:
The Husband and I went there last Monday night to celebrate our anniversary. On the reservation we told them that we were celebrating. So on our table they had a lil card for us and the waiter brought us out sorbet with a candle..hah. 
Even though it was a Monday night there was still a decent amount of ppl dining and in the bar. There was also a live musician playing throughout the night, which is something we wish more restaurants would offer. 
Food was overall great. Our favorite was the Bananas Fosters dessert...yum! 

I would mostly recommend this place to couples. 

Tip - After 6pm meter parking in the area should be free. 
We also noticed that the Valet guy that you pay $10 to just parks your car in one of the free metered spots.
author: T K.

description:
This review is for lunch only.

Talk about a super hidden gem!  It's totally secluded and tucked into a hidden alley.  Bix however, is absolutely stunning.  The ambience is perfect and I felt like I stepped into a speakeasy esque environment.  The place is gorgeous!

I came for lunch with a friend and we each got the 2 course prix fixe meal called the "Bix Fixe" for $19.95 with your choice of either a salad or soup and then entree options of either chicken or fish.  

Definitely on the pricier side of things, but the food is pretty fab.  You are paying for the quality of food that you're getting, as well as the experience from the ambience and all.

Definitely worth checking out.
author: Carmen Y.

description: Potato pillows & chicken hash were the dishes that I tried. The chicken hash was FAN.TASTIC. Im curious to see how this is made because I would make it everyday! Had the brownies for dessert and called it a night. Perfect ending to a great night.
author: Joy A.

description: This place is impossible to find. It's located in rape alley. We were late for our reservation, but they still accommodated us. The food was decent and very very pricey. But it's a nice place for food and drinks. We got to sit upstairs which gave us a nice view of the whole place. Try the seafood or steak, it's phenomenal. Lots of variety for dessert too
author: Phan H.

description:
Wow, just wow.  

This is one of the best places for a romantic date, dinner party or even business meeting.  The setting is SO posh, art deco like and jazzy.  The food is certainly worth five stars.  Huge wine selection and amazing service.

The bar, although not a large area, is certainly a great way for singles to mingle in a swanky, fun atmosphere.  Get ready to dress to impress!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
BIX is a classic SF spot that my gf took me to for my 30th b-day dinner.  I like the fact that it's off the beaten path a little, but still accessible for folks who work downtown.  BIX has an old school traditional vibe.  You walk in and see a long bar to your right, with a mural as a backdrop.  Martini glasses are in crushed ice chilling perfectly at the bar.  The drink menu contains classics like the sidecar, sophisticated but not too fruity variations on the martini, manhattans and various wine & champagne options.  I opted for the manhattan and was pleasantly surprised to find the libation to be firm but open and perfectly mixed.  

For dinner we walked up the staircase and sat at a nice table with some privacy.  There were several booths that larger parties shared with plenty of intimacy.  The jazz downstairs transported me to the 20s and made the manhattan more relevant.  

I ordered the pillow potatoes with caviar, the trout salad and the ribeye and topped all of that off with a nice Napa '04 cab.  The food was excellent.  I will definitely come back soon.

This place would be a five for me with the exception of two things:
- It was a little loud.  The acoustics for the room aren't great so the live music plus the chatter made the room a few notches louder than what I would expect for a nice sit down dinner.
- Our waiter was a little sarcastic.  I didn't find his style to suit the class the rest of the place exuded.  He seemed disinterested in my gf and me.  While our food was well timed and we weren't rushed, I still felt that he attitude detracted from the night.
author: John M.

description:
Bix is a great choice for drinks and dinner.  The waitstaff was nice even if a bit stuffy, while the food was very good. I'd definitely go for the truffle fries and the pork chop, though everyone was pleased with their meal.

I only took a star off because they were trying to rush us to get to the next seating.

Overall a pleasing experience
author: ZRap R.

description:
BIX is our go to restaurant in SF when we want to take visitors or newcomers to the Bay Area for atmosphere and good food. Somehow this place has an ambiance that keeps people returning and others snagging a sought after reservation (after waiting weeks). The food is good - very consistent and yes, a bit on the pricey side, but after several visits, I believe a good time at BIX depends on the occasion and the timing of your reservation...possibly the people you dine with, too. If you use Open Table, then it's no surprise the top rated restaurants keep the prime time reservations under their control so often you're stuck with an early time. BIX is a popular stop for the younger set to be seen at the bar, but the place comes alive later in the evening, especially when the jazz ensemble begins their speak easy tunes. 
Not sure how we snagged a four top upstairs because we're nobodies. BIX would be a stop for the SF mayor (or ex-mayor) or similar notable types, but we enjoyed the setting nonetheless. Brian was our server. When he didn't show an attitude on sight of the wine we brought was the tip off that he would treat us right. Wine corkage is $25. Upon Brian's recommendations, we ordered several appetizers, which were all delicious. Who orders fries at an upscale restaurant? I did. They had the perfect balance of garlic, parmesan cheese...yum. I so wanted to order the cheeseburger and another order of the fries, but I succumbed to inner pressure and settled with the sea bass. I believe it had asparagus and small slices of ham. Very different taste...a little salty but a nice balance that was fresh and pleasant. My husband and our guests ordered the fish specials as well. Everyone was completely satisfied and too full for desserts. Again, the food was very good but it was the efficient, genuine, and easy going service that we received from Brian that made the evening memorable for this visit to BIX. This SF restaurant should be on your list. Because of the overall experience you can enjoy, the atmosphere and servers, the extra cash is worth it - even if it's just a one time shot, especially if you're looking to wine and dine someone special. BIX is tucked away. Get directions. Don't let the snooty ladies at the door put you off. BIX is unique. There's no doubt what it is and has always been. BIX never changes and that's a good thing. **Request Brian...he's a nice guy.
author: Kathy H.

description:
Quickly seated on a busy weekend night.  Attentive waiter who turned out to be the sommelier.  Lovely live piano. Perfect ambiance. 

We shared amazing appetizers of beet and goat cheese parfaits that were amazingly simple and delicious (although I have no idea how the kitchen so cleanly prepared and plated typically messy beets layered with creamy goat cheese).  We also shared some shrimp appetizer that I can't quite remember because the tuna tartar was phenomenal.  PHENOMENAL.  I still have dreams.

I don't know wine, but I'm told the list was good and I enjoyed the white from Oregon I drank.  Our meals were perfectly timed and perfectly cooked.  My friend had beef that was tender and delicious.  I had fish that was so perfectly cooked that the chef could have given a seminar on it.  The accompanying vegetables were fresh, slightly crisp, piping hot and seasoned perfectly.

I only had a bit of dessert, but someone knows their stuff.  I'd definitely go back. It's a challenge to find as it's on a little street you wouldn't normally look for a restaurant on, but it's worth the effort.  Obviously.  Cabs were continuously picking up and dropping off customers as we left.
author: Kari S.

description: Went here for an anniversary date with my boyfriend. Food was amazing! Definitely worth every penny.
author: Ashley C.

description: We have not been here in years and decided it was time for a revisit and take some out-of-town friends and enjoy the music.  I've withheld reviewing this place, in large part because I became quite ill after eating my main dish, the Dorade.  Just now beginning to recover.  Deviled eggs and Potato Pillows were quite good.  My companions didn't think much of their pork or beef dishes ~ just ok. We weren't happy dropping over $500 for just ok.  Believe me,  we wanted to love this place.
author: Maria P.

description: This place is way overrated. Way better food in the city for these prices. I can think if over a dozen places that are way better high end restaurants with better talent as far as food goes. Pass!
author: Rouz E.

description: Really enjoyed dinner here.  Live jazz and a cool environment with amazing artwork all around.  Our waiter really knew the history behind Bix and went out of his way to make sure we enjoyed our time.  We started off with the potato pillows topped with caviar and fried green tomatoes with buratta - delicious! For entrees we had the duck breast which was magnificently cooked with an amazing punch of flavor and the wagyu beef.  For a side dish, we had the creamed spinach, which was heaven.  To top it all off, we ended our meal with the bananas fosters dessert - probably the best I've ever had!  Can't wait to come back and enjoy dinner with live music.
author: Julie I.

description:
OMG a new favorite spot in SF. The food here is AMAZING cooked perfectly and the presentation was superb. 

The baked spinach and truffled cheese was to die for - A great way to start off the meal!

I had the Kobe "Bavette" Steak  as my main course it was pure yummy goodness.

I can't wait for another good excuse to return!
author: Summer C.

description:
Bix is one of our all-time favorites.  You'd be hard-pressed to find a better dining experience anywhere.  It's a bit hard to find, but that just adds to the ambiance.

One of the best bars ever.  My favorite signature Bix drink is the Germain-Robin sidecar.  We also have to get the caviar (they have it, but it isn't on the menu).  You can actually get lots of things not on the menu if you ask -- that is part of Bix's phenomenal and genuine eager-to-please and serve-you attitude.

Some of our favorite dishes -- you CANNOT leave Bix without at least one of you trying the banana's foster.  We have it every time we go.  Also try the firecracker shrimp (another of our favs) and the Kobe beef.  Actually, we've never had a dish there we did NOT like (well, we weren't too keen on the marrow bones, but that's a personal choice).  

If you have a special dinner planned, try Bix.  But just one warning - BIx will completely SPOIL you rotten.  No other regular restaurant will ever measure up.

P.S.  All seats are good, except upstairs is a bit more quiet/romantic and you get a view of the whole place.  Downstairs is closest to the music and restrooms...like I said, each are great.
author: Deb F.

description: So close to five stars, it's not even funny. Ever so slightly cramped, they make up for it with a killer atmosphere. The ever changing live music can't be beat. The only other obstacle to five stars is the somewhat limited menu. It would be nice to see a wider variety with additional seasonal items. The food they did have was sublime.
author: Julie S.

description:
Recently ate at Bix..I live in the neighborhood. Always had a good experience, NOT GREAT FOOD, but ambiance very nice.
This last meal was the worst!
Lobster pasta salty and pasta clumped together and overcooked. Steak about 1/8 inch and charred. Salmon dry and overcooked.
Only redeeming item was fried green tomatoes.
Very expensive, left feeling totally robbed!!!
Will not return.
Skip the food..just go for a drink and music.
author: z z.

description: Aesthetically beautiful restaurant. Reminiscent of classic supper clubs of the 40s. The food and service were world class. The $28 burger is a bargain as were the truffle deviled eggs!
author: G P.

description:
This is a beautiful and wonderful place, I came here many many years ago and it's like a moment in time here that never changes. Based around a 40's style bar it oozes style and grace. They make a perfect martini here, and you can listen to the easy jazz music and fly away to another time.

The food is uniformly delicious, everything i've ever tried has been wonderful. I'm always worried that this place will be gone, but after 15 years or so, it's still going strong.

Food - A
Ambience - A+
Service - B
Value - B+
author: Forrest D.

description:
I think the extra half-star has to be from the ambience/atmosphere. People like good music. I find it hard to believe the food is more than four stars.

The sweet onion soup and chicken a la Bix were both quite good, but interesting non-traditional (and tasty) takes on things I was used to.

The panna cotta was a disappointment, while I could see the specks of vanilla bean, I couldn't really taste it. I also wish they had just served it with fresh strawberries rather than strawberries in a syrup; I felt it overwhelmed the panna cotta.

I also noticed that several bigger tables got served an amuse bouche...

I went here for lunch, which typically is often when the head chef is not cooking; but I definitely saw him there, which added to my disappointment.

I can't really afford to go back here for dinner, but I can imagine it'd be a nice place with the live jazz. Gorgeous interior.
author: Mark A.

description: Our bartender had worked there forever and was a stitch. Quite good cocktails. This place is about the grandness of the interior and the burger. Yum. Go grab a cocktail and split a burger with a friend.
author: Rachel H.

description:
the appetizers were definitely yummy and a tease..

the main course here was breathtaking! my boyfriend ordered the lobster pasta, and i ordered the swordfish.. tried a little bit of both, and both were seriously amazing. the seafood was cooked to perfection, and seasoned really well.

and the desert.. orange-chocolate mouse drizzled with dark chocolate, was seriously heaven. i died a bit.

wine was good too. the service was great, and our waiter always made sure our glass was filled.

i would definitely come back here again. the food, ambiance, live music... A++++++.
author: Momo O.

description:
Was brought here for dinner on my birthday last week and this has got to go down in my top 5 list of most romantic dinner experiences...EVER!!!! While I am an East bay girl, "Hella Love Oakland" and everything, Bix encompassed all I love about dining in the city: from the inconspicuous alley entrance, roaring 20's decor theme, sophisticated and beautiful, yet lively crowd to the Lena Horne doppelganger jazz singer.... it was everything I could have wanted, and more!!! 

Our dinner and destination plans were unknown to me until we arrived. Fellas, take written notes on how to court a lady:) He hit the ball completely out of the park! From the moment we stepped out of the car, the service at Bix was superb. I got the impression that all of the Bix staff knew it was my birthday. Instead of feeling annoyed and embarrassed by receiving birthday wishes from them throughout the evening I felt incredibly special. One can't help but to feel sexy and romantic in a place like this, but I'm sure my Marilyn Monroe-esque dress didn't hurt:)

We were seated immediately and service couldn't be more prompt. The timing and progression of our meal was spot-on. We started with the Dungeness crab rolls on brioche which were fabulous and I had my signature cocktail. I moved on to the asparagus soup, which I loved as well. I found it to have tons of flavor, without overdoing it. If you love asparagus, you'll really enjoy this soup. For the main course, I had the grilled Salmon. It was medium-rare and cooked to perfection!!!! My date had the Kobe Bavette steak. I don't do red meat, so I unfortunately can't comment on it. He said it was excellent and I trust his palette completely:) We both had a Pinot Noir that our server suggested and it paired perfectly. For desert I opted for the chocolate brioche bread pudding. It was warm, decadent, and just yummy. I didn't finish it however, and for a sugar fiend that is saying A LOT. My entire meal had been so rich and satisfying that I really only needed a few spoonfuls to satisfy my sugar needs and to be quite honest, that's something I really appreciate in a dining experience! 

We finished the evening enjoying wine and the lovely Jazz Singer. Wonderful experience!!
author: Shaunte J.

description:
Places like this are disappearing fast. I am glad we have BIX in San Francisco a very stylish, sophisticated speakeasy supper club. I was there just a few weeks ago for dinner and I loved the ambiance of the place, the food was delicious, very attentive service and lovely live jazz band playing made it even the wonderful evening event. 

Every evening BIX offers entertainment from live jazz, solo piano to jazz vocals and trios... and never a cover charge. Here is the schedule: 

Sundays and Mondays - Solo Piano 
Tuesdays - Thursdays - Piano and Vocals 
Fridays and Saturdays - Jazz Trio 

You must at least try one of the following when dinning at BIX: 

*À la minute Ceviche with Jalapeño & Habañero Chiles,Avocado, Cilantro Oil and Toasted Corn Nuts 

*Roasted Beet and Chévre Skewers with Basil & Balsamico 

*BIX Bacon Club Burger 

*Seared Local Albacore Tuna with Fried Green Tomatoes,Tonatto Sauce, Toasted Garlic and Spanish Almonds 

Remember ..You must save room for the Bananas Foster with Dark Rum and Vanilla Ice Cream a delicious dessert to say good night to a lovely evening.
author: Ernesto C.

description:
This place has a great ambiance and it's in a tiny alley I never knew existed after living all the years in Chinatown. The exterior is definitely misleading to what lies inside. We were promptly greeted and waited at the bar while the other two in our party found parking. Surprisingly, they didn't take too long. Parking can be a total nightmare in that area. We were seated on the 2nd level, which was nice because we had a good view of the 1st floor dining area and bar.

We ordered steak tartare, prepared tableside, so it was really fresh. The flavors were pretty good. We also ordered the truffle french fries which were the size of a small fries order at McD's. We ordered another one for our party of 4. They were really good. I was disappointed they weren't shoestring, but the truffle oil made up for it. Yum!

As for entrees, mine sucked. I got the chicken something, based upon our server's recommendation. It was basically chicken, but in a crabcake form with sauce. Everyone agreed it tasted like stuffing. However, their Kobe steak was really good and really tender. I don't eat lamb, but my friend liked his. So, 75% of the entrees were hits, just not mine. 

Desserts weren't delectable at all. We ordered the red velvet cake and a chocolate type dessert. They both were only half finished amongst the 4 of us! That's saying something, something bad. Their cappuccino was decent. Service was great (aside from me getting tricked into ordering their "house special") and I wouldn't mind coming back at all, sans "chicken crabcake" dish, though.
author: Freckles H.

description:
Place definitely had a geriatric vibe to it.  Not your bleeding gums and boiled meat Tadich Grill kind of geriatric vibe.....more like your One Bedroom Suite Princess Cruise geriatric vibe.   

Here's the cliffs notes version of the night:

Cool alley!
Cranky waitress!  
Ceviche never appeared.
Lamb burgers, firecracker prawns (which actually scored a negative on the capsicum scale), deviled crab floaters (not sure what they were called), truffle burgers, kobe beef and oysters were all well prepared, but I can't say anything was striking or memorable.  Did I mention the waitress was cranky?

The cuisine here fits the crowd.  If you play it safe and think that it's better to be boring than stand out, welcome to your favorite restaurant in the city.  

Host/Manager dude reminded me of mafioso.  +1 star for safety reasons!  ;)
author: Nobody M.

description:
Wonderful!

You cannot go wrong with Bix.  My girlfriend and I usually go once or twice a year for special occasions because this place can be pricey.  But every time we go it is definitely a great experience. Bix has two levels, it is very spacious.  Everything on the menu is delicious. 

I had never tried Bone Marrow, but the platter they have is delicious. The desserts are also very delicious. The atmosphere also makes it a great place for cocktails.  Wether you are meeting for cocktails or you are looking for great place to dine, you've got to check out Bix.
author: Anastacio R.

description: Food was probably 3 stars.  But our waiter was a pretentious asshole.
author: V G.

description:
Delicious. Yesterday was our 1-month anniversary so we decided to celebrate by going to Bix. I guess silly monthiversaries are still better justifications for having baller dinners on random Tuesdays than the usual "I feel fancy today" thing :D 

Bix has great ambiance. Casual but upscale, Bix is the perfect romantic-but-not-too-romantic restaurant. Definitely request to sit upstairs if you're on a date. It's a lot more intimate and the piano isn't nearly as loud. 

The food is pretty tasty, too. Stand outs: beef tartare and truffle fries. The truffle fries were the best I've ever had! Unfortunately, I can't give Bix all 5 stars because every dish was just slightly more expensive than it's worth. For example, my boyfriend's lobster spaghetti was "amazing" -- but not "$40 amazing". haha.

Also, great service. Our wait staff was incredibly speedy and gave us just the right amount of attention.

Thanks, Bix!
author: Han C.

description:
Everything about BIX is top notch. The service is excellent, and I love that every time I have been there during the past three years I see familiar faces with the staff. You are treated exactly the way you would expect at this classy establishment. 

It has an awesome old-school vibe and I feel like it's the kind of place where great crooners would have a corner table and order the usual. There's a reason some things just don't go out of style and the atmosphere alone is worth the trip... 

Oh, and the food is AWESOME! I tend to lean toward the delicious and classic New York steak, but they have a burger that is a resto staple that is also killer. The appetizers are all wonderful (most recently I had prosciutto-wrapped mozzarella) and the side of grilled asparagus is probably the best I've ever had (I try to make it at home, but it just doesn't quite measure up). And for dessert, you can't really go wrong (the warm chocolate brioche bread pudding definitely gets raves). 

Go. Get a cocktail (or two or three) and eat up.
author: Ben R.

description:
Gosh, I feel TERRIBLE.  

I was eating my fabulous and delicious dinner so ravenously that I didn't notice when one of the skinny bitches at the bar drinking a "hipster-tini" drunkenly fell onto my plate.  She was devoured immediately.  

Hey, green is in season at Prada, I guess.  I thought she was a string bean.
author: Kristina R.

description:
In short: great food, good ambiance, caustic-bordering-on-rude service.

This place is pretty expensive, so my 4-person party decided to focus on appetizers, drinks and salad/soup. Apparently this meant we were less worthy of gracious service. Our waiter was funny-rude, in a way I might have easily shaken off -- but others in my party weren't as forgiving. He seemed much more New York than San Francisco.

The food was delicious, but meagerly portioned. Granted, I should know that the more one spends on food, the less he should expect to get, but this seemed a little extreme.

Now, the good stuff: the deviled eggs, the tuna tartar and the ceviche were exceptional. The drinks were mixed at the table, which was a fun treat. The jazz music, which started around 8:30, was also a nice touch. The upholstery was decidedly 80s to me, which didn't detract necessarily, but wasn't exactly the 'old San Francisco' I'd been promised.
author: Helen L.

description:
The ambiance for this place begins outside!

Walking down Gold Alley, you see small round tables with blue votive candles perched on the side walk on either side of this narrow street.  Lined with historic brick buildings on both sides,  you feel transported back to a French Quarter or Parisian street.

Upon entering this dining room you can't help but feel a nostalgic tug to an era long ago gone.  The decor is pre-depression era,  American Jazz, Deco that is bursting with a cool vibe and energy.  The atmosphere is electric but not deafening.  The hubby enjoyed walking up the "Titanic-esque staircase up to the second floor, which looked down on the main floor and bar.  There are no restrooms here, only lounges.

The staff from beginning to end were on game and very accommodating to our lone vegetarian in a pack of carnivores.

We were here for DAT and Bix definitely put their best foot forward!  We started with Martini's, which we're shaken and poured table-side, followed by a steak tartar also prepared table-side and sprayed with brandy - it was TFDF!

The butternut squash soup was amazing  as was the wonderfully warm, fresh bread.

The menu is truly American and right on!  Their signature Chicken Mash, prepared to look like large crab-cake medallions are amazingly filling.

This place obviously does things to people, the couple behind us all of a sudden broke into a passionate make-out session behind us, no sooner than I though to myself  "GET A ROOM" did they get up from the table and leave.  Only to be back 10 minutes later all flushed.....

WTF?  did they just have a quickie in the "Lounge".....WORK IT OUT!

Anyways it must have been the live Jazz vocalist accompanied by a pianist that brought on bouts of passion in the room or was it the best chocolate bread pudding in the world?

WE are so coming back, and we may even try our hand at our own "Lounge" act!
author: A P.

description:
Went here for lunch with the boss.  It's down this little alley in an area between the financial district and north beach.  Really cute place!  We sat upstairs overlooking the bar and the larger tables below.  The service here is excellent!  We had reservations and so after shedding our coats and handing over our umbrellas (it was raining), we were seated right away.

For an appetizer my boss asked the waiter, "what are the truffle cheese croques, exactly?"  And he replied, with a small grin, "basically, it's mini grilled cheese sandwiches."  Feeling almost childish, we ordered it, at the waiter's recommendation.  Really, really good.  Definitely not your kraft sammies at all!

Okay, I honestly can't remember the name of the meal that I ordered, I'm looking at the menu and I'm thinking it was the Louisiana floudner, but I'm not sure.  It was basically a white fish with a crunchy breading over mashed potatoes with a lemon butter sauce.  So it's very likely the flounder.  Anyways, Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm!  So good, so amazingly good!  The fish melted in my mouth and that sauce was mostly buttery (which I love, despite what it does to my thighs) with just a hint of lemon.  I'm not into tang and I hate it when they overdo the lemon in an attempt to hide the fish.  Bix did not do that.  I never finish my entire plate, but seriously, this was too good to not finish.

For desert I ordered the chocolate and butterscotch brownies.  I can't even tell you how yummy this was.  I was soooo full after my meal, but it sounded too good to pass up.  And it was.  I only ate about half of them, but took the rest home and had a lovely desert for dinner!

When we got the check we asked our waiter if they could call a cab, which arrived as soon as we walked out, how perfect!

Not cheap, but not too expensive and really worth it.  One of my new faves!
author: Melissa A.

description:
I like Bix. It  reminds me of how restaurants were back east in the seventies and eighties. I remember very grand stairways and large semi-circular booths and piano music in the background.
I was very young and very impressionable and in awe.

It has a beautiful big bar where the bartenders really know how to present you with a drink in perfect stemware.

And ladies and gentlemen dressed in their finest. And the jewels came out.
No not those jewels you nut , oh God be quiet Katherine.

It's set in a very different place and time.
Bix is somewhere Marilyn Monroe would have loved.

I've been here a half dozen times. Perfect for business dinners and/  their guests.
And especially for special ocassions such as anniversarys and birthdays.

The food is very good. It's solid. The menu changes daily.
It offers selections from many cultures and does them their way.

Personally, I like having a glass of Champagne at the bar after dinnner . 
To linger and flirt.
 It sets the mood for romance.

bixrestaurant.com
author: Katherine N.

description:
First time at Bix for me. 

My nephew and his wife were in town. We had an EXCELLENT meal. Service was perfect. prompt, no rushing. 

They also have Lagavulin on the menu - my absolute favorite single malt.
author: John D.

description:
It's the little things, I tell ya!

The little things like soda water in one of those seltzer bottles. What are they actually called? I dunno, but they are cool looking and old fashioned and vintage looking so that always scores points with me. 

It's the little things like serving said seltzer water in a cool shaped glass with a lime without even having to ask for one. Little things like that, MAKE a place for me and this place nailed them.

The first time I came here it was for a meat party... oh yeah, you heard that right, a MEAT PARTY, which is different than a meat market, but yes, it was a meat party for a meat magazine. How could I have not gone to that??? 

At this event they were serving meat, go figure, and wine, even better. I was happy as can be. But in addition to stuffing my mouth with animals, I also noticed that the vibe of this place was pretty great. The ceilings are super high (always a bonus), the warm glow of the room was very conducive to a good mellow time (a preferred element for moi) and the bar itself is absolutely gorgeous. Dark woods and lots of bottles, yum-E. 

A few weeks after the meat party, I found myself in the neighborhood craving some wine (again, go figure) and stopped in here once again for a glass of vino and it was just as cool as the first time I went... even though there wasn't mass amounts of meat. And so the point of this story is, this place is cool beans and if you like a chill environment, a really cool bar staff and an open kitchen (love that too!!) then checky check it out.
author: Stephy S.

description:
Love Bix!

Usually come here for special occasions (birthday, anniversary, etc.), because I consider it so special (and not so cheap!).

Great American food, great drinks, awesome staff, amazing atmosphere--I really can't complain about anything!  Though you should know that it can get somewhat loud in this joint.

The atmosphere is old, art deco, dinner jazz club.  Live jazz musicians play at night (not sure if it's everyday or weekends only).  Reservations recommended, but if you come without and there are no tables available, you can also eat at the bar.  There's a really cool mural for you to feast your eyes on behind the bar, too.  There is a downstairs eating area and an upstairs too (I am partial to the upstairs since it allows me to watch all the action below).

I also love the area the restaurant is in.  Located in an alley in the Financial District, from the outside it looks like a hole in the wall restaurant only for VIPs in the know (and you might even miss it, if you're not paying attention).  I love the walk to and from the car to the restaurant: walking by the art galleries in the area, distinctive and elegant brick buildings--can be quite a romantic stroll.

Overall: One of my favorite special occasion restaurants in the city!
author: A C.

description:
Weekday after work, the green-eyed boy says he's starving and not in the mood to cook, "Where can we get eats? Somewhere cheapish." 

Gretchen P., trying to change at the gym without dropping the phone, "I'm starving too. How about Epic or Waterbar? Oh yeah, not cheap. Taylor's Refresher? Take-out burritos? Lingba?" 

(I can hear my grandmother in my head saying, "Oi such problems you kids have! You cannot decide on which fancy restaurant to have dinner at in a city of hundreds of fancy restaurants? When I was your age we were deciding between which can of beans to open for supper!")

Green-eyed boy: "I have an idea! Bix!" 

Gretchen P. "Sold!" 

So that's how we ended up going for a not-even-sort-of cheap but fabulous meal at Bix last night. We were able to get in fairly last minute and to enjoy some Stags Leap and oh-my-god-so-good mozzarella-wrapped with prosciutto starter at the bar. We wondered, "Were those so incredible b/c we are starving, or b/c they are so damn good?" 

Sitting down to dinner, we couldn't order fast enough. The waiter knew just what we needed--foie gras and sauternes was delivered in minutes and he gave us great recommendations for dinner. Let me just say that I would personally massage and sing to the cows or whatever else goes into making Kobe beef so incredible--it was the truest expression of love that I gave a slice to the green-eyed boy. Even my side of creamed spinach (thanks for allowing substitutions, chef!) was exceptional. The pork chop and sunchoke gratin was also popular. 

Not wanting this hedonistic feast to end, I insisted on ordering the cheese plate and dessert wine. (I know, grandma, I don't know how I got to be such a spoiled glutton!) 

Finally sated and smiling, we sailed out of the gorgeous historic space with live jazz and piano music trailing behind us--back to my dented Honda and the realization that I will be living on canned tuna for two weeks now.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
We had the nicest dinner here with friends the other night!
Bix is hidden in a cute alley and when you get in, you know that it's a special occasion. The bar is vibrant and the food is really really good.
We ordered a variety of starters to share and all were very interesting and satisfying. 
By the time our entrees arrived, we were almost full.
None of us had any space for a dessert, can you believe??
author: Alexandra D.

description:
A friend of mine was just walking by this little alley way & came across this gem of a restaurant.  Unfortunately, we were not dressed up, nor did we have reservations, but the host was still very gracious & told us he would let us know if a reservation didn't show up...and we snagged a seat at the bar.  

The vodka/sodas are strong, and the atmosphere in here was almost of the 50's.  I almost expected to see the waitresses dressed as flappers, the waiters had coattails.  The decor was velvetty red & golds. 2 stories with a winding sweeping staircase. 

We chose to just get some appetizers to share: 

Firecracker Shrimp with Chile Aioli $10.50 - O.M.G. O.M.G absolutely mouthwatering deliciousness that just melts in your mouth.  I am seriously salvating right now as I type and think about this orgasmic dish.  The shrimps are large, 4 pieces perfectly breaded with this awesome spice..dipped in the spicy aioli and it's a flavor explosion.  So freakin' good. 

Dungeness "Crab Rolls" in Brioche with Meyer Lemon Aioli $15.75 - these "rolls" look like little finger sandwiches with the crust cut off...and this too was little bites of heaven.  The bread on the rolls were buttery & crispy on the outside, the crab stuffed in the middle was sweet & melts like buttah.  wow

Mini Lamb Burgers with Cucumber, Dill and Harissa 10.95 - this i would have to say was my least favorite,but only because I'm not a huge fan of lamb.  But i have to say, these burgers WERE very juicy, the bun was nice & soft. 

This is definitely a restaurant that we're making reservations at next time to get the whole feel and experience...

Great date place. Fabulous food. Awesome hidden gem.
author: Lulu C.
