description: My work colleagues and I came in for happy hour prepared to drop hundreds of dollars. Well we didn't because the hosts at Bix were the rudest I have ever encountered in the industry. I'm sorry we tried to partake in Bix. Never again.
author: Jen L.

description:
My recent visit to BIX was a parade of horribles.  We had a reservation for 8 pm.  At 8:30, the table was still not ready and the hostess told us that the people dining at the table, that we had reserved, had paid but were not getting up to leave.  In such situations, any good restaurant would politely approach the dead beats and would inform that that they are glad the free loaders enjoyed their dinner and are enjoying the ambiance but that the table is again reserved and needs to be cleared for the next patrons and that they should move to the bar.  At 9:15 (an hour and 15 minutes after our reserved time) our table was finally ready.  The hostess did not offer even an apology let alone a comped drink or dessert for the wait.  

After having waited so long for the table and spending over $100 for drinks at the bar without a comp, I normally would be angry enough that I would not be able to enjoy the rest of the evening no matter how good the food and service.  However, in this case I was determined to have a good diner because I had been wanting to dine at BIX for quite some time.  

The first time the waiter approached he was rude and had forgotten the wine list.  When he returned 15 minutes later and threw the wine list on the table nearly knocking a glass to the floor, he was not any nicer.  My three guests and I ordered a bottle of wine along with appetizers and entrees.  Our orders covered a good variety of the menu and we were all set to taste BIX's highly touted offerings.  

The food was so bad that I am going to offer an overall review rather than item by item so as to avoid having to pen a novel.  Most of the dishes were brought out luke warm or partially cold.  The food was buried in sauce to the point of absurdity.  The quality of the underlying meat was less than that of a school cafeteria.  Sauces should accent , not overpower, the flavor of the foods that they accompany.  However, when you are serving sub-par entries, I guess you have little choice but to slop them in a mountain of sauce and grease.  

Shame on BIX for even serving such poor quality food.  If they can't afford to buy top quality ingredients then they should raise their prices.  I don't mind paying for quality but I do mind when a restaurant touts itself as a high end establishment and then serves food that is of lesser quality than mall food court.  I wasted a perfectly good evening eating this sludge when I could have gone to any of  hundreds of quality San Francisco restaurants.  

Moreover, the wait staff at BIX is obscenely incompetent.  One of 50 or more examples of such was when our waiter arrived prior to a new course being served and dumped a handful of flatware in the center of the table as if he still thought he was still working at an army mess tent.  

In sum, BIX is the type of restaurant that appeals to people who judge the quality of the food and dining experience by the size of their bill.  However, for any real foodie, skip BIX and stick with Gary Denko, Boulevards, Fifth Floor or One Market- places that match quality with price!
author: Devin W.

description: I went with my husband for date night and it was just the perfect mix of music, food, and adult companionship!
author: Nydia B.

description:
Food here is much above average, but doesn't blow my mind.

Hand Cut Steak Tartare: prepared tableside, very fresh. very yummy
Potato Pills with creme fraiche and american cariar: decent, but doesn't engrave a spot in my mind


American Kobe Bavette Steak with Pommes Puree: highly recommended, soft juicy and not over cooked (my pet peeve)

Day Boat Scallops with King Trumpet Mushrooms: Was good, but I've had better

Overall good place, nice decor, can be a bit loud, decent food.
author: David S.

description:
best damn bloody mary ever! EVER!
....i guess the secret ingredient is fresh lemon...whatever...its incredible! 

havent eaten here, but fancy shmance atmosphere ie mahogany bars, dim lighting, formalish doormen,,,,actually me and my boss got rejected for wearing sandals and shorts... come on! i only get to wear that like 7 days out of the year!! boooo!
but the other times i 'got' in it has been a sweet spot for a happy hour (minus the fact that we venture capitalists like to hit the bar around 3 sometimes and this place doesnt open until 5.30)   ;-0
author: Kaylan S.

description:
There seems to be scant little to add to a restaurant that has been reviewed 280 times.  Nevertheless, in my own inimitable style, I present this review.

I was dining with a fellow who owns his own plane.  Owns, in fact, a charter company which has a number of planes.  And he was flying himself down to San Diego after dinner, which meant (1) we were eating early, and (2) he wasn't drinking.  We showed up at about 5:15 (I said we were eating early), which is 15 minutes before the restaurant portion opens, so we bellied up to the bar.  He had a Coke, I had a Crown & Coke, which the bartender served with a VERY liberal pour.

In a town full of bars and restaurants, few establishments seem to pay much attention to their bar glassware.  And frankly, there are a lot of ways to do it right.  You come to my house and your scotch will sit in a tumbler that weights about a pound, with a thick and heavy base with a bubble blown in it.  That's one way to do it right.  Bix chooses another way to do it right, with elegant but not delicate glasses that exude class and sophistication.  Does all of this mean that you, on your next trip, will sit and stare in rapt attention at your glassware?  No, but it does mean this: when a restaurant gets the small details right, you have more confidence that they will get the big stuff right, too.

The maitre 'd very politely collected our coats and my attache case (and didn't hover waiting for a tip when he returned them at the end of the night), and showed us to our table.  I wish Bix had a few more options for people who aren't seafood lovers, but that's a common complaint in upscale SF eateries.  I had the pork chops, with the mini lamb burgers to start.  The lamb burgers were tender and juicy.  Most could have used more cucumber---the one burger which had a generous cucumber topping was fantastic, and subversively Mediterranean in flavor.  Bix made me a Manhattan with a small batch bourbon which I wanted to try, and nailed it.  Not too sweet, not too small, excellently done.

The pork chops were fantastic, and the figs which came with it were an excellent compliment.  The spinach bed was not overcooked, an almost epidemic problem.  The skin-on baby gold potatoes were nice, but a bit uninspired.  I had a glass of malbec (hey, just because my dinner companion wasn't drinking, that doesn't mean I can't), which paired very well.  Malbec is an excellent wine if you're having meat and have been drinking for awhile.  Good malbecs are dark, earthy, and spicy, brooding like a scorned wizard.

The total experience was wonderful: great food, attentive service, and comfortable decor.  And it wasn't as much as you might expect: about $50 a head.

I'll be back.
author: Ben P.

description: My boyfriend & I have been here twice.  Both times we went on a Saturday night.  First time we went for just drinks & the live jazz music.  The music trio was really good and play there every Saturday night....so that is what made us come back the second time.  The second time we went for appetizers, dessert, drinks & of course the jazz music.  We had the Truffle Cheese and Sweet Onion Croques which were AMAZING, the salad special of the day which was okay and had the Vanilla Creme Brulee which was tasty.  But of course the jazz is what keeps us coming back.
author: Natacha M.

description:
Bix is one of the most over-rated, stuffy, arrogant, 'plenty-of 'tude' places in SF. And the food is utterly Bland with a capital B at best.
You're paying triple-mark-up prices for the "experience" and "atmosphere" of a restaurant that jumped the shark many years ago.
And the word is spreading  because recently Bix stopped serving lunch, due to poor crowd turnout.

There's no denying the room is gorgeous, but the complete arrogance by the bartenders, and the "you're doing us a favor" by being here 'tude put forth by the owner and its uptight staff is a huge turn-off.

In the interest of full disclosure, I used to frequent Bix for many times in the late 90's until I had the audacity to complain about the crappy service and average food and the owner told me to leave.

I haven't been back since. Do yourself a favor--skip the trendy show, resist the temtation of being force-fed the grandeur of paying $12 for an average martini and go to any number of restaurants nearby with a lot more sincerity and grace. And a helluva lot cheaper too.
author: Rich L.

description:
What really makes this restaurant is the atmosphere, decor and the amazing service. It truly is a very classy restaurant and very inviting. The food is pretty good, too. But I wouldn't say that it's "out of this world" good. Their truffle fries could use a little improvement but the fish I had there was excellent and it was on top of the corn and tomato concoction that would make anyone's mouth melt. The heirloom tomato caprese was quite good. I'd say the low point of my visit there was the tuna tartare. There was just WAY too many capers for my taste bud.

All in all a great place if you want to hang out with a couple of friends or go on a fun date.
author: Ceana K.

description:
Last time I was up in San Francisco I had the privilege of going to Bix. What a beautiful place! It is a restored 1920's bank turned restaurant/bar and jazz club. The place is all polished marble and fine woods. They feature live jazz while you eat dinner and what a dinner. Fish, pasta, appetizers and were excellent! Service was great too. I can't really say anything bad about this place.

If you don't want to eat dinner it a good bar too, but a bit crowded. Getting a drink is challenging as you play the "look at me game" with the bartender. Martini were potent, order them!

Get reservations before you go, it gets crowded quick. It can be hard to find if your not a local, its hidden in a pedestrian alley.
author: David G.

description:
Wow - wonderful service, yummy specialty drinks (Bix Rickey!) and appetizers were to die for. We didn't even get the entrees :P We got:

Bix Rickey - amazing, fresh strawberry puree!

Dirty Martini Up - standard fare

smoked trout salad with green beans - they were super considerate and split the portion onto two plates for us already. the smoked trout could have been cooked a bit more (the center of the meat was a bit gelatinous) but the smoked flavor was perfect, and the green beans were meticulously cut lengthwise.

truffle french fries - I would come back just for these. The garlic aoli was divine, they know it, I ate the whole portion we were given and I wanted more.

Pacific oysters - fairly standard. Only came with vinegar and lemon wedges, wish it came with horseradish and cocktail sauce like the Ferry building serves them. 

potato pillows - I wish the potato part was a bit more delicate, but the creme fraiche and caviar was deli.

foie gras with figs and toast - the toast had pre-applied butter on it (I don't like butter on toast, I know I'm strange, you don't have to rub it in). The fois gras was perfect. The figs were perfect. Wish I got another serving. Yeah, it was that good, better than Meadowood's preparations by far.

apple tart - not so great, but the salted caramel ice cream I substituted in from another dessert was quite fantastic. Reminded me of the crack sold at Bi-Rite creamery.

Muscat dessert wine - don't know what vintage it was, but we want a candle scent based off of this muscat wine. It was so good, we were sniffing the glass like a glue bottle.
author: dj z.

description:
WOW.

Had high expectations for this place and was able to snag a spot at 6pm the day after Valentines day for 2.
Very nice ambience, tucked away in a cute little alley. Very old school but very romantic and the little old man playing the piano is just over the top cute. Very classy and elegant setting. Noise level not as bad as I thought, sat downstairs and it was great.

We got:
Steak tartare- good, VERY VERY fresh, perfect portion for 2, but it was lacking SOMETHING. The bf and I decided it was lacking more punch, more citrus, lemon or capers or mustard or something. Still very tasty and although I wouldnt order this again the next time, it is very good. Chez papa has a better version of tartar and so does chez maman.

Roasted bone marrow. After having it at mario batali's place in LA we are always craving this appetizer at any fine dining establishment that we go to and I actually called ahead to make sure that they have this before we came.  YUM. 4 good little bones wtih bread, and a nice parsley caper salad. Very rich and very buttery. But the one we had in LA still better!

Ceviche- OH SO GOOD. We decided to get this instead of the lamb burgers at the last minute considering our two starters were so rich already and boy did we make a good choice! 4 slices of hamachi in a lgiht citrusy and pistachio dressing...perfect balance of fresh, cold fish marintated in a great citrus dressing SO GOOD. Perfect after the first 2 dishes we had!

BF and I did a split entree of the lobster spaghetti and it met and EXCEEDED my expectations. So so sos sososo good! Did I say it was really good? I couldnt imagine eating this all by myself as it was SO rich. Its perfectly done spaghetti with chunks of good juicy lobster in a light cream broth with minced onion. It was just the perfect dish and probably the best pasta I've ever had. at $39.95 It better have been! Splitting this with someone is hte best way to go, as you can sample more of the hors d's which are a hit. 

Finished off with the chocolate bread pudding, good way to finish off dinner, but the chocolate crossiant bread pudding at chaya is still #1 in my book. Probably would skip thi snext time. 

1 coke and 1 cappacino later  $130 out the door.
author: Petri Y.

description: My favorite Martini place in town. Always perfect balance. The food is great too. If you're looking for huge portions this is not that kind of place. But for great taste, perfect old style service. Appetizers are particularly good.
author: Niktug I.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city and here's why:

1) Food.  You can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  Best steak tartare on earth and the steak is to die for as well.

2) Ambiance.  It has that old-school San Francisco classy feel to it.  You know, real money, not dot com.  An older crowd so you won't find any that Marina pretension .  Dark wood, low lights, but not too low, live jazz band - pure class.  Great place to bring a date too.

3) Location.  I love that it's in it's own little alley.  Seating outside and all of the cops up on Broadway patrolling means that you take your drink outside and have a smoke.

4) The bar.  The bartender always remembers my favorite drink the moment I see him.  Not exactly and easy drink to remember either: Dorothy Parker.  Plus they have good munchies, a real mix complete with gold fishies.  You can also order the full menu at the bar.

5) Service.  These guys don't miss a beat.  They live up to standards of people who know the difference.  Much more than just obsequious servitude.  Serious attention to detai, i.e. they know which side to serve from and which to clear from.  And they don't know how to say no.

Am I missing anything?  If so, just assume it's top-notch.

http://www.cleanscores.com/2348/Bix
author: Ann W.

description: Absolutely impeccable food.  Every single dish we ordered was great.  We ordered the crab cakes, mozarella wrapped in prociutto, onion pancakes, salmon tartar to start and each bite was full of flavor.  Even their salad is delicious with every bite.  My husband and I will go back a million times.
author: Ivane C.

description:
After seeing over 400 reviews about how wonderful this place is, we were expecting to eat some phenomenal food. The location is a bit odd, it's hidden in a dark alley, which we missed trying to find it. We came on a Sunday night, which wasn't crowded at all. The place is very dimly lit and the seating can be a bit too intimate. Especially the corner tables where we felt like people were watching us eat, quite uncomfortable I might say. 

The food was very disappointing. Definitely not the 4.5 stars that this place gets. We ordered the truffled fries, mini lamb burgers, and the kobe steak. Truffled fries: totally not what I expected. It really tasted like regular fries to me. The mini lamb burgers: not much to say other than we found a hair in one of them. The kobe steak was actually not bad, well seasoned and perfectly cooked. 

The drinks are the best thing out of the whole night. The sidecar and the huckleberry fix are pretty tasty. Service was fine. All in all, our dining experience here was a big let down. Will not come back.
author: Jun W.

description:
It's official.  I've died and gone to heaven with the $27 truffle burger and fries.  OMG.  I had no idea heaven really did exist on earth, and in SF for that matter.  Just went for dinner last night, and everything was tops - we showed up over 90 minutes before our actual reservation, and the host was super cool, squeezing us in after only 30 minutes, despite a very busy night.

The buzz and atmosphere of the dining room was great, art deco and elegant, yet casual enough to have conversation at a normal level; people were dressed anywhere from fancy to jeans, all welcomed.  So yeah, the bill packed a bit of a punch - esp with wine - but the service was attentive and efficient, our server was very knowledgeable and outgoing, and food was delish.
author: Jen H.

description: I should have written this update a long time ago.  I received a call from Bix the day after I wrote a review re: a not so perfect dining experience.  I was very happy to know management takes any concerns seriously and goes out of their way to contact patrons.  It's that kind of response that will make me want to try Bix again at some point.  Thank you Bix.
author: Gail B.

description:
One time, sitting at the bar at Bix, this drunk girl at the bar stuck a pretzel in my ear. And not in a nice way. It was a straight pretzel, and she did it in a mean way.

BUT STILL I give this restaurant four stars. That's how good it is.
author: Tim S.

description: Food is awesome.  The service is awesome.  The venue is awesome.  Their portion is so small and pricy but I guess there are reasons for it.  Very good venue for dates or business meetings.
author: Elizabeth B L.

description:
Potato Pillows = Tater Tots

Only negative about this place.  Service, Food and Booze was fantastic.  Atmosphere is cozy, interesting and not too loud.  Great for celebrating a special occasion.

Highs:  Bread Pudding, Bananas Foster (according to my fiance), Pork Chop and Truffle Burger and Lobster Roll.  Also the amuse was quite tasty.
Mediums:  Halibut and the other half of the Potato Pillows (Caviar, Creme Fraiche), rolls.
Lows(Or I guess the Highs):  Price (A little steep) but worth it.
author: Ken P.

description:
been here a few times for lunch and it's been consistently great, but just went here last night for dinner and it was even better than my lunch experiences ...

lunch is just an edited version of the dinner menu.  so for dinner, off the hors d'oeuvres menu, we had the "crab rolls," the mini lamb burgers and the special of the day: mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto on a plate of olive oil.  the mini lamb burger with cucumber, dill and harissa was so awesome.  each one can be politely eaten in three bites, one big one if you don't care.  i could have probably eaten the whole plate as an entree and been satisfied.  the crab rolls, although tasty, weren't so spectacular.  and the mozzarella, same thing.  i did want to try the potato pillows with creme fraiche and caviar, but didn't want to look like a fat pig.

so as my own first course i went with the butternut squash soup with crab.  such a good choice.  i didn't think butternut could be made better, but crab definitely ups the flavor and texture factor.

for my entree, i went with the fish of the day: seared ahi tuna.  kinda boring but i knew i wouldn't have such a great appetite by that part of the meal.  and as expected, i was already full by then, so i ate it slowly.  tuna was alright, but the vegetables that came with it were  blech.

and dessert ... mmmm ... we shared like four different desserts off the menu, but i only had room for a little bit of one and the one i chose was the chocolate brioche bread pudding ... true salivation.  pure deliciousness

so the next time i go, i'm going to share the potato pillows as a starter, then have my butternut squash soup, and then have the lamb burgers as my main dish and finish with the chocolate bread pudding.  mmmm ... let me make my reservations now =)
author: spiff e.

description:
Recap of our recent dinner at Bix:

From the second my friend and I were seated we felt rushed by our waiter "Jonathan".  We didn't even have time to organize our purses when our waiter asked if we wanted something from the bar.  My response was "we haven't had a chance to think about it."  

When he came back we ordered a bottle of Spottswoode Sauvignon Blanc.  After literally a couple sips each time, he was incessantly at our table to top off our glasses.  One might think this is great service, but from the get-go his demeanor was abrupt and each time he stopped by he interrupted our conversation.  It was honestly bizarre.

As the night went on and we were eating, he tried to take my plate before I was finished.  Finally when were were done eating we were asked if we wanted anything more and we didn't.  We were very ready to leave.  As we waited for our check, we discussed the service and decided to ask for the manager.  My friend told the manager that the server was overly attentive to the point of rude.  I commented to the manager that I wouldn't expect this in fine dining.  His response was that this was more of a "gin house" than fine dining and that they were "trying to turn the table".  He stated that we'd been there for 2-1/2 hours.  We had actually been there for fractionally less than 2 hours.  The couple next to us was seated at the same time.  They did not receive the same type of service and they were still there when we left.  The group next to us left shortly before us and they were seated before us.  Perhaps they had different waiters.

I understand this is a business and businesses need to make money.  That being said, we were rushed from the second we sat down, not just at the end.  Why were we singled out and treated rudely?

In any case, this singularly defined the worst dining experience in my lifetime.  The service was so abrupt and pushy and the response from the manager was insulting and unacceptable.  

I will never go into Bix again, ever.  I'm disgusted.  I work in the S.F. Financial District and there are far better restaurants with management that doesn't support treating their customers rudely.
author: Patricia R.

description: I've never posted, but had to. Food riding on its Zenith of success of days long gone. Excitedly came here for my bday w/hubby 8/2/14, dressed-up deco for this deco restaurant. Had come here numerous times after it opened and in past years, food and service were always top notch. Only good service remains. Two stars: one for the hostess, and one for our waiter Chris. Ordered a bottle of champagne, the "sommelier"? opened the bottle, and soon had champagne spilling onto floor. "Gee, didn't expect that" was all he said, after wasting our precious elixir and using his foot and a rag to wipe it up. I expected him to say, "I'm sorry, let me make that up to you with a glass of our house champagne" or something like that, but no. Appetizers--the Pacific Oysters were amazing. Entrees: Sea Bass. One bite of was enough. Both WAY over cooked, leathery, super salty, and completely inedible--for $32! Sent back immediately. Chris was super nice and professional, apologized and explained the sea bass is brined. What? Why? Really? Replacements came, much better, cooked properly and not THAT salty, but still tasted salt. Dessert: me-chocolate bread pudding, hubby-Bananas Foster. Bread pudding was hard and dry--it's supposed to be bread pudding, not an old brown sponge. We drowned it in the bananas Foster and melted ice cream, which added much needed moisture and made it edible. Ah, so much for the excitement of Bix. Needless to say, we're never coming back, and we're spreading the word. For the prices they charge, there are just too many better choices. Let's leave this place for the tourists, who packed the place in their t-shirts and jeans. Let them eat $$$ dry sea bass and bread pudding. What a disappointment!
author: Audrey C.

description:
I like Bix...no...no...I LOVE Bix! I've never been disappointed each time I've dined there. 

Bix is awesome because it has it all: an amazing menu, great service, a laudable wine list, and a lively atmosphere. When compared to luxury restaurants in the extreme price bracket, (Michael Mina, Gary Danko, Epic Roasthouse, etc.) Bix holds its own. I simply adore the potato puffs and the open-faced cheeseburger. The Kobe steak ain't so bad either! To put it succinctly, Bix is great for a special occasion or a fun night on the town. I've sung its praises to everyone I know, and I recommend that anyone reading this checks it out as well!
author: Rodney P.

description:
My fiance took me here for my birthday and I was impressed for a number of reasons which I shall now list:
1. He called in the reservation because he knew I would peek at our opentable account and ruin the surprise. Unfortunately, he said 8:30 and they booked us at 8, so we arrived at 8:25 and were told we would probably have to wait. The manager came over to see what was going on, and she explained the mix up. The promptly seated us which I thought was amazing since technically our reservation was null.
2. They put a little birthday card on the table for me hidden under the menu.
3. The atmosphere was great and I enjoyed the jazz rendition of "It's only a paper moon" while sipping my champagne.
4. Excellent wine list and the waiter made brilliant and well-paired selection
5. FOOD GOOD! (Gougeres are an excellent started, the romaine salad was fresh and super cold, which i love, Kobe beef and mashed potatos were delic, The pork chops were so amazing, and I highly recommend a side of the creamed spinach. For dessert I suggest their bananas foster and the ginger ice cream.
6. hello...bananas foster!


Because I got a coveted flat-iron for my birthday this place gets an extra star...so many good looking people I was glad to have the hair to match. ( I know this is kinda irrelevant but it's my review dammit and I cannot convey to you my joy about this present!)
author: Nikki M.

description: Old School San Francisco.  Period.  Great service and good -- if fairly traditional -- food.  Waiters bring perfectly made martinis to your table, never ever complain if the meal isn't perfect and you want to send it back, and are always at your service.  Great place to go if you're tired of new-agey concrete-and-exposed-beam, loud, hipsters, and really do not want to eat yet another arugula and blue cheese salad or truffle mac and cheese.
author: Tsan A.

description:
The crowd at Bix is well heeled and the atmosphere is posh. I had the benefit of my gracious and generous uncle taking me here so I can't help you with what prices are like since I never saw the bill (this is a rare occurrence in my life). What I can help you with (hence the point of this rather long winded review) is that the food is fantastic and the drinks are excellent. 

Those that love all things meat and are not faint hearted should try the marrow. The lamb burgers are also excellent. On the alcohol side (we were at the bar the entire time), you can't go wrong. Excellent selection of scotch and by far one of the best Bloody Mary's I have had to date. And yes, I know my Bloody Mary's - I carry with me an ancient Singh Bloody Mary recipe that I will never reveal. Let's just say that the family recipe was challenged by what was on offer. Overall, a great night.
author: Abhi S.

description:
bone marrow order- very generous portions, especially for the price

foie gras pate- not notable

braised short rib special- solid, portion overwhelming esp after marrow

chocolate bread pudding= mmmmmm (and I don't typically like bread pudding)

love the atmosphere
author: Hannah W.

description: Great atmosphere! The food was delicious--highly recommend the smoke salmon salad. We were even given some freebies of wine and a sorbet. Highly recommend.
author: Linda M.

description:
Lunch time.

This place tries to emulate old school charm and well, almost succeeds but not quite.  I originally planned to give this place three stars but bumped it up a notch because the manager is awesome! He was the best part of BIX.  He has a great positive energy to him and a wonderful booming cheerful voice.  :o) I want him to be my friend! They also had these weird electronic art paintings that looked like a chalk board from far away.   Apparently you can only see the art if you are up close.  So we walked up to it to try and see this fabulous $11,000 pieces of art - still to no avail.  We had to bust out a digital camera with a flash in order to expose the picture, so we could understand what it was we were looking at.  A waste of $22,000 if you ask me.  Besides that, the food is average for the type of restaurant this place tries to be.  

I will only be back if the manager will be my friend.  :o)
author: Aim E.

description:
Bix has been a mainstay in Michael Bauer's top 100 list, and I can see why.  It's worth traversing past the homeless adorning the sidewalks of the alley to step into a restaurant reminiscent of the 30's and 40's.  The restaurant was packed for a Monday night, so reservations are highly recommended.  Also, you won't be seated until your entire party arrives.

Food:  4 stars.   The menu contained so many interesting items, but everyone in my party strategically decided to order something different so we could try each other's dishes.  That made for an interesting spectacle.  Everything we had was good to excellent, including the potato pillows (glorified tater tots), mini lamb burgers, steak tartare, halibut ceviche, summer squash soup, chicken hash, kobe bavette steak, pork chop, and cheeseburger (with truffles!).  The menu is a bit misleading, as it doesn't mention that the french fries that come with the cheeseburger are actually the same truffle french fries that can be ordered as a side dish.  Best thing on the menu is the bananas foster.

Service:  5 stars.   Service was impeccable, from the warm hosts to the attentive and professional staff.  I also liked the fact that they had a piano player at some point during the meal.

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  The restaurant clearly exemplifies what a supper club / speakeasy would look like in the 1930's/1940's.  Too bad the crowd was born in that era as well.

Hits:   Bananas foster, chicken hash a la Bix, grilled Hill Ranch pork chop, American Kobe "Bavette" steak, truffled pecorino cheese burger.

Misses:  Misleading menus, customers born during the Great Depression.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Boulevard, Mecca, Michael Mina, Silks
author: Keith C.

description: See other commenter for more info...my 2 cents...get the steak tartar!!
author: Matthew D.

description:
Valet Parking: recommended if you got the $10 to spare but you can find street parking pretty easily around 6pm here.

Atmosphere: very nice with the piano playing in the background on a Monday night.

Appetizers: Potato Pillows were good but super small.  You get four basically tater tots (like others have said here) but topped with caviar.

Marrow bones weren't bad but I don't think I'd order them again.

Meal: I recommend regular 1/2 lb BIX Bacon Club burger but upgrade it to truffle fries for like $2 extra.  The truffle fries were amazing.

We also ordered the asparagus side dish but it wasn't that big a deal.

Dessert: The warm chocolate brioche bread pudding was PHENOMENAL.  Hands down the best dark chocolate bread pudding I've had, it just disintegrated in your mouth as you ate it.

Service: Very very pleasant.  Our waiter looked a bit like Chris Parnell but he was very gracious and didn't act offended by any of our choices or lack of sophistication.  They offered to check our coats but politely declined.  Best of all, my buddy and I chose to split the entree, and they served us each on our own plates, with the burger cut in half and the fries divided already for us!  So awesome.

With the $20 half-bottle of Chianti, our total after tip came out to $109.

Next time I would:
- Get one appetizer
- Split the burger and truffle fries again
- Skip the wine

And dine at this place for under or about $40, and be just as satisfied.  We couldn't even finish the split burger but it was so good.
author: Steve L.

description: Grand interiors will give you the real SF power lunch. Their burger is famous for lunch, but their other dishes are just as nuanced.
author: Steven W.

description:
Bix is like an old friend.  We don't see each other often, maybe once a year, but when we do, we always have a good time.

I love disappearing into the alley and through the doors into the room of the impossibly high ceiling.  I love getting a seat at the bar and having a ginger gimlet while chatting with my neighbor, usually an older gentleman and his partner, or some girls out on the town. I love that people make at least an attempt to dress well here.  

I find the painting of the clown & dancer kissing very provocative.  

I like the view from a corner booth upstairs.  

Steak tartare is delicious here.  I could eat it by the truckload.

Chicken hash is another wonderful staple.  Think of it as crabcakes, but made with chicken.  

There is a chocolate dessert that is like warm pudding with cookie crumbs on top that is decadence defined.  

Service is always excellent, from the bartenders to the wait staff, and this is what really makes the experience special for me, and why I will always return.
author: Liz S.

description: So romantic!! My bf took me here spontaneously one night and the food was absolutely delicious. We had a huge booth all to ourselves, right next to the live jazz band. We ordered a nice bottle of champagne to go along with our kobe steak and Alaskan halibut. For dessert we had a plate of brownies and blondies that were to die for.
author: Jeannette N.

description:
The hidden gem of the Financial District or almost North Beach... You know it must be scrumptious if a restaurant hidden in an alley turns out to be crowded inside. 

It is a romantic setting with balcony seating looking to the restaurant below and elaborate bar. I'd recommend taking a date or a group of people for cocktails. Everyone who works here is accommodating and friendly. 

Elegance at its casual finest.
author: Dee C.

description:
Cool location. Cool design and atmosphere. The food was excellent. I had the fillet (medium), ceaser salad and creme brule. Everything was good, but the steak was memorable. I've eaten steak at a bunch if different places in the city and this one definitely ranks near the top.

So why only 4 stars, you ask? Because, there is always room for improvement and in this case it was the matrede (host) and manger. The wait staff was polite and attentive, but the two knuckle heads running the place were rude and flip about our reservation. We were there for my bachelor party and a friend of mine had gone to great lengths to set-up the reservation for 13 people with a pre-fix menu and everything. 

This isn't the damn DMV, it's well known SF restaurant. You would think that the manger and materde would be more polite to a party that is about to drop $1200. But nope. They had our reservation wrong, so we waited. Then we came back when we were told to wait yet again. All in all, about 45minutes. The materde acted like this was our fault and the manager did nothing to compensate for our inconvenience. But he did shrug his shoulders. 

Go on a weeknight when it's not crowded or when the materde isn't on his period. Despite all that, the food was worth it all.
author: Justin C.

description:
This was my first real meal in San Francisco that didn't take place in a conference room or at the airport, and what an excellent meal. First, the ambiance. Bix is located in an old speakeasy, down an alley, and it gives off an almost clandestine vibe. Inside, the combination of high-vaulted, open space stretched over two floors with dark wood paneling and art deco style, smoky jazz-age lights gave a refined vibe. The service is excellent. Despite being nearly an hour late for our reservation, the restaurant kindly accommodated us. Our server was professional and friendly. Still, the food was by far the highlight of the evening. I had had a big lunch, so I skipped starters. My dining companions gave rave reviews on theirs, the oysters and the Caesar salad. For my main, I had the Wild Flounder with Louisiana Blue Crab and Chard over White Grits. The Louisiana Blue Crab was sweet and tender and blended well with the lemony, earthier taste of the chard. I liked the way the flounder was cooked, I believe lightly pan-fried for a crispy outer and softer, meatier inner. I wasn't as excited for the flavor of the flounder, which had an unexpected aftertaste, but I think that's more of a personal preference. For an upscale restaurant, the portions are generous, if not cheap. I was stuffed. But, when the dessert menu came, we couldn't resist. We ended up sharing an order of the Chocolate Brioche Bread Pudding. It was excellent. Rich chocolatey flavor and gooey--the pudding middle was very decadent and encased by moist cake-like brioche, and the crust had a familiar bread pudding crunch. Make sure you save room for this!
Price: ~$50-70/person (Entrees just under $30)
author: Kate H.

description:
Great restaurant, overall.
 
The atmosphere here is very classy, with servers in white tux tops walking around - - it makes you feel like you're dining in a fancy restaurant back in the 20's (or 30's? 40's? I dunno my eras).  Once I entered, I felt overwhelming regret for not having worn a bright red flapper dress w/ slinky little hat - and smoke out of a long pipe and let loose in the middle of the place.  At various points through the night, there is live jazz music, and altogether, the place just rocks.  Ambience-wise, BIX is awesome - - perfect for a business dinner, or a nice date.  The place is a bit too stuffy for what I would call an "outing w/ friends" - and it's a bit too pricey for something casual.
 
Although this place is primarily a restaurant, I noticed on this evening @ 8 pm, the bar was full of people who were not waiting for tables but simply enjoying their Happy Hour.  It's not quite the spot I would have picked for a Happy Hour, but it was a good crowd - and the drinks were good.  That said, our party of our had arrived early in order to get drinks at the bar while we waited, because we saw through their website that there was a fancy long bar at which to wait.
 
While our reservation was initially for 8:30 pm, the host came by at precisely 8 pm to inquire if we'd like to be seated now.  We took him up on it, and were led by the hostess to a "booth" -  very roomy, the lighting was beautiful - - again, transporting you to a different era.  Our party was for four people - - and it was an intimate, rather romantic setting.  This is the type of restaurant where it'd be fun to get two couples together, get fabulously dressed up and dine out before spending the rest of the evening painting the town red.  The seats themselves were perhaps a bit "denny-esque" but the whole setup just kind of works.  The ceilings are beautiful, and the setup with a whole slew of diners sitting upstairs with another bunch all seated downstairs - - it's absolutely classic and reminiscent of days long gone-by.... days before I even came into existence, but what I envision to be "dining out" back in the early 20th century.
 
The menu is very vast and based on just the hors d'oeuvres and starters - there were some 20 items to choose from.  We opted for the caprese w/ heirloom tomatoes and homemade mozzarella "cart" (which they actually serve to you from a cart), the crispy fried shrimp, crab cakes (which were actually crab filled mini-sandwiches),and tuna tartare served w/ toasted olive bread.  The latter was QUITE delicious, the others were all pretty good, except the fried shrimp was overfried in my opinion and not all that impressive.  There was NOTHING special about the caprese, though.  
 
For our entrees, one of us opted for the halibut, which I didn't try this evening.  The rest of us had the rack of lamb (which was OK), the pork chops (which was perhaps the best of the 3 dishes I tried), and the scallops, which were cooked nicely but I didn't think there was anything special about the dish, in spite of it being the evening's special.  Many of these choices were suggestions made by our server on what is best at BIX.... 
 
Service was mixed.
Our server was a friendly and jovial but often too busy, and too scattered.  What he lacked for in time or attention, he made up for in being polite and fun, though, so it breaks even.
 
The wine list was good.
We picked a Russian River Valley Pinot Noir on this evening (which has been my slight to moderate OBSESSION these days) - - decently priced at $60+, and it tasted wonderful.  Between the four of us, we finished 2 bottles of that, 4 scotch on the rocks, and one dessert Muscat which I did not like at all.  We also ordered a cheese plate (decent, at best), and 2 desserts.  One was a strawberry tart that tasted better than it looked, as it was presented looking like it was a  rock off of some unknown planet out there with a dollop of strawberry ice cream on top.  The other dessert was  the Bananas Foster w/ Rum and Vanilla Ice Cream, which was the hit of the evening as it was as decadent as anything I've ever tried.  Delicious.
 
The total bill was $440, not including the tip. (Including tip, it went over $500.)
While rather pricey for four people, keep in mind there were two bottles of $60+ wine, and quite a bit of food.
 
On the food-front, contrary to what most of  the other reviewers have stated, I found BIX to be just "good".  Compared to some of the other establishments in San Francisco, in spite of who the chef is, what experiences he has, or which amazing restaurants he has been a part of, I found nothing altogether special about the food - and on the whole, I give it 3.5 stars for the food.  Good - just not special.  

Combined w/ the unbeatable ambience - BIX earns 4 stars total nonetheless.  I just can't say it was all about the food.  There's better food out there in SF - - but not with this type of a historical feel.

Photos uploaded.
author: Grace K.

description:
Our table shared about 6 different appetizers.  These were all excellent.  Since everyone else has already described them, I won't.  Then for our main course, I had the prixe fix meal with Asparagus Soup (good but I didn't find it to be all that special of an asparagus soup), Chicken Bix (unique, very well made, and tasty), and the warm chocoloate brioche (again, tasty but I wouldn't say unique).  All good, but no taste bud fireworks, nothing made my eyes light up and go WOW!  My husband had the Bavette Kobe Steak, which was a good cut of meat, but we didn't feel that the preparation really did it justice.

I was with a large group of people that do enjoy their food and everyone was happy with the restaurant pick and food.  So in that sense, it's dependable and it doesn't disappoint.  I wouldn't hesitate to bring clients there.  Wine selection was good, atmosphere was nice, bar was very pleasant.  Liked the jazz band playing there.

I also didn't find that the wait staff was all that special either.  They were good....nice, polite, and very professional, but maybe because it was a busy night, they took awhile to get around to us each time we needed service and had to be reminded multiple times to bring out extras of things (e.g. napkins and bread).

So all-in-all, a good experience, but other than for the appetizers, I'm not going to be rushing back there.
author: Ging Ging F.

description:
Bix is excellent.  Everything from the chic supper-clubby atmosphere to the delicious food and excellent staff is pretty much perfect. Everyone who works here is excellent - from the host, to the bartenders, servers, chef, cooks, bussers, EVERYONE.
The drinks are always perfect (they really do make the best martinis here) and the food is always delicious.  Favorite food items are the Potato Pillows (with caviar and creme fraiche - mmmm), Firecracker shrimp, steak tartare, Chicken hash, and the decadently sweet, rich, and rummy Bananas Foster.
author: Deann F.

description:
Top five favorite places to eat in SF .... yes that's right top FIVE! :) 
The ambiance in here is so where it should be. The lighting is just right .. not too bright .. not too dark. The jazz they play in here really ads to this places kick and goes along wit the food oh so nicely.
They have a great selection of booze .... whether it's whiskey or wine ... you won't be dissappointed. 
I really don't have enough good things to say about this place..... the service .. the food ... the atmosphere.... the hidden location ....they just do it all right here.
author: Jeremy R.

description: The new york steak & lobster pasta--to die for.
author: Irene C.

description:
LOVED IT!!!  Food was outstanding!  My friend and I tried the $35 menu and had a delicious salad, entree and dessert.  The creme brulee was so good, I almost cried.  I like to think of myself as a creme brulee connoisseur :) 
Gold street is a bit tricky to find but I was able to get street parking and walk a block over.  The hosts were most kind, seating us early, and the server was fantastic.  We brought our own bottle of wine and paid the $25 corkage fee so our total check was just over $100.  A GREAT deal for the quality of the food and service.  I am definitely going back-- again and again!
author: Sara W.

description:
yay!.  Went for drinks last night, and was totally impressed.  Bartender was plesant, helpful and the drinks ( a perfect Rob Roy) was wonderful. 

I had a great time, the piano player and jazz singer were soothing, and the atmosphere was perfectly relaxing.  Will hope to be back soon.
author: Best M.

description:
Oh wow, absolutely superb! I haven't eaten this well in a very long time. Everything, from the tuna tartare to the chocolate and butterscotch brownies was to die for! So here's the rundown...

Starters: Tuna Tartare with cocktails at the bar; Beef Tartare at the table
Dinner: Sea Bass w/ Legumes and sauteed Spinach, round two of drinks
Dessert: Chocolate and Butterscotch brownie fingers with whipped cream, round three cocktails

The service was impeccable. The ambiance was sophisticated, intimate and rich in history. The company was excellent. As a lovely extra touch, they even placed a card hand written at the table for my birthday (yes, it was a birthday dinner celebration!). I think this is an excellent venue for cocktails with the girls or a fabulous dinner date with that someone special. Highly, highly recommended!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
We had dinner on Friday night, the service was outstanding and the food was memorable. 

The host was very kind and welcoming, the restaurant manager found the time to welcome us as well on a busy night, which we really appreciated. 

The crab rolls were delicious!
I had the flounder and I would really recommend it - fresh and seasoned to perfection. Everybody at the table loved their main course. 
My favorite dessert was the banana foster - a must try!

Great meal + great service + great cocktails + Jazz music... what else can you ask for?

Thank you to the Bix team for the wonderful evening!
author: Sophie C.

description:
Before stepping through BIX's doors, understand that you will step out desperately wanting to make out with your dining companion.

Even if you're there with someone you despise, a Spirograph, the elderly, or an octopus, the combination of the food, ambiance, and strong cocktails makes you want to get your face savaged. Or maybe that's just me.

Potato pillows with creme fraiche and sturgeon caviar? Please, lean a bit closer. Ceviche with jalapenos and habaneros? You're definitely getting more attractive. Kobe steak with cipollinis? Yes, do put your hand on my leg. Warm chocolate brioche bread pudding? For all that is holy, stick your tongue down my throat. I don't care if the socialites at the next table see.
author: Carla C.

description:
The short skinny: Hidden gem that brings to mind Chicago speakeasy days (not that I am that frackin old to remember!). 

We were there early on a Wednesday night at 6:30 because I was told 7 to 8:30 was booked. After being seated right away our waiter - some dude in a white tux jacket with slicked back hair (they all look the same) - served us without a smile. In fact he was kind of a dick. Still rude or not he served us some very tasty wine, fish and vegetables and an hour and $130 later we were out the door. 

At 7:30 when we left, Bix was still half empty which begs to ask why we couldn't get a table then?? Next time I'll try Friday night and some live jazz....
author: Stuart G.

description: Very, very good lunch there.  Great hidden place and beautiful inside.  Enjoyed the Ginger gimlet, tomato cart appetizer and the chicken hash which looked and felt like crab cakes.  Good and different but the texture was a bit off putting.  Friends had BLT and hamburger and both good!  Would love to go back.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Anyone here remember yelling "OVER-RATED" at the over-rated away team at their home college basketball games...the conviction in your voice that the opposing team had no reason to be ranked so high by the critics.  I couldn't help but feel that way while I was having dinner at BIX.

All the food was below average - tuna tartare on olive toast (tuna was had a fishy after taste), kobe beef (more like okay beef) and the banana bread brioche dessert that looked like a hot fudge sundae from TGIFs - I wish it would have tasted that good.

The waiter was chill and made a below average meal seem pleasant.  The interior of the place is a little un-homey with the high ceilings and open space providing over exposure allowing everyone to see everyone.  We did have a great view of everyone upstairs as well as everyone downstairs at the bar.  One thing about this place...it serves up 5 star cougars - quantity and quality.
author: Mamoon H.

description:
I kept flip-flopping from three stars to four.  I'm torn.  I think that given the opportunity to eat a full meal there and not just an appetizer & drinks, I would probably be more confident in the four I am giving them.

This is where was recommended we go for a 'mellow' dinner in the city.  Ummm, not really, no.  Not that it was a hyper out-of-control restaurant, but mellow is not the word I would have used.

Bix is a very chic restaurant in a small alley off the financial district in SF.  The street it's on is old time cobblestone and the lighting was perfect for a romantic walk down the dimly lit street...to bad I wasn't with my s.o., but a best friend will do just fine!

We walked in and the maitre-de greeted us, asked if we had reservations (oops, didn't know we needed them for a 'mellow' place), we answered no; he said they were full but we could eat a full meal at the bar; so the bar it was!

We bellied up to the bar, which was very neat and very fancy-schmancy & ordered our drinks & an appetizer.  I had a decent margarita on the rocks (no one I've met to date can make them as good as my mum) & Anna had a mandarin & 7.  She was pleased with her drink.

We decided on the provolone wrapped prociutto drizzled in olive oil...it was DELICIOUS!  We opted not to do dinner, we just really were feeling mellow, so we asked for our bill, paid & off we went to explore the city a little more.

I would love to go back and have a proper meal here, preferably with someone who is romancing me, it's a very chic place and if the dinner is half as good as the apps are, everyone would be in for a treat!
author: Emily S.

description: I've never had a full dinner here. I just love the vibe and the bar and the music. Always a great bartender with drink knowledge and savvy, with just the right amount of SF cool attitude thrown in. Bix is my place! And I've heard the food is really something...
author: Banana B.

description:
Like I said in my previous review just a car service away was my 2nd place for drinks.  This was the upscale version of Cheers, as everyone seemed to know the names of the people that I had accompanied.  We were greeted by the excited hostesses and with the right # of bar stools cleared off for our party to sit on.  Every bar tender greeted my party by first name only which made me wonder if the bartenders are that good or that bored or maybe my party that I was with frequented that bar earlier that week and were that memorable?  I began to wonder.

The limited food that I had was AMAZING.  We had the crispy prawns in a chitpotle sauce and the tiniest of tiny lamb hamburgers on a almost brioche like bun.  These things were the size of my pointy finger touching my thumb.  The perfect 2 bite burgers, Whole Foods try to do that!  By the way, Whole Foods does a really nice 2 bite selection from brownies to cupcakes.

Anyways, I fully enjoyed the painting of the ballerina kissing the clown and the soulfull singer next to the piano player.
author: Sharon T.

description:
I came by for a work lunch on Friday and I was surprised to see such a nice place tucked away in an alley. But that's SF for ya. The ambiance was terrific. It conveyed class without the pretentious stuffiness.

My pappardelle pasta with duck was a tad bit on the salty side, but overall not too bad. I found myself wishing there had been just a little bit more duck. I think next time I'll have to go with the burger (gigantic!) or the lunch pre-fixe. I was a bit envious of the little grilled cheese sandwiches that came out with the tomato bisque. 

The service here was fantastic. Bix had a great looking bar and I'm sure I'll be coming back to grab a martini sometime.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Hubby made reservations here on a Saturday night for our first wedding anniversary.  He wouldn't tell me where we were going, but just that we were heading to the city.    It's a good thing he was warmed that it can be a little difficult to find, because we left early  and drove around a bit trying to find it. 
I give this place 5 stars.  It is pricey but for a special occasion, it was worth it. 
 
The interior of Bix is beautiful, and I loved the live music - it made the ambiance just perfect.  It has a cozy, romantic feel to it.  Perfect for a special night.

We started off with wine at the bar while our table was being prepared.  Once seated, we had a ceasar salad, which was very good.  For main course, I had the grilled duck and it was perfection.  So tender and juicy, the flavors were just scrumptioius.  Hubby had the special of the day which was salmon and enjoyed it very much.

The greeters, servers and all the employees were cordial and helped to make our time spent here a great experience.

I really enjoyed our initmate evening here and would recommend it to anyone searching for a romantic spot.
author: Jenni H.

description:
Came here on Friday for lunch and everything was pretty tasty. I had the BEST bacon and corn chowder ever! Also had the steak tartare and the chicken hash.  Our server seem a little off on timing each course .. or was it the kitchen staff?? Either way we had to wait a long time for each course to come out. By the time dessert came out we were ready to get out of there asap. 

Lunch is pretty casual compare to dinner (from what I've been reading). But, they do have a pretty good lunch pre fixe menu. 

3.5 stars for now ..
author: Miki M.

description:
I forgot how much I miss this place!!! I can't believe why I haven't been in years.The place has not lost any of its special feel of exclusivity. A lot smaller than I recall though. 

I have to knock off a star or maybe half of one because they use the smallest martini glass I have ever seen and a couple of there signature cocktails were not that good. Other than that the meal was perfect. They make a perfect martini but avoid the Side Car (too much lemon juice) and the Ginger Gimlet (tasted like nasty Country Time lemonade with booze). The Bix Ricky is very good though. Vodka with fresh strawberry puree and sparkling water. Very refreshing. 

Food and service was as top notch as I remembered it. We had the Potato Pillow Caviar and the hor d' oevres for 2 (Shrimp, Tuna Tartar, and this great Fou Gras Butter & Jelly mini sandwhiches) along with the Bone Marrow appetizer. The tuna was the only thing to pass on.

I am just a meat and potatoes kind of guy so I figured I will get the NY Strip w/Truffle fries, a glass of red wine, and be a happy camper. I am SO GLAD I didn't. On the way back I saw another couple who ordered the lobster spaghetti and it looked amazing. I usually stay away from pasta dishes that involve a cream sauce because they tend to be too rich for me. This dish while rich was not too much so. This pasta was so good I did not even care that it had lobster. And I LOVE LOBSTER!!! Do not miss this. 

I am not a desert guy, but I never turn down a Bananas Foster which too was excellent.

Also try to eat upstairs. It can get pretty crowded/loud at the bar and some people seem to spill over on the busier nights. Its also nice to look down at the whole lower level while your waiting between courses/drinks. This is still a very special place but save your nickels because its as expensive as the place looks. So worth it though...
author: Xavier P.

description: I had an experience at this restaurant which I have NEVER had. And unfortunately not in a good way. My first and only time at Bix was a business dinner experience. We were a large group of about 8 on a Thursday night. As large business dinners go, we took our time ordering course after course and wines and coffee... apparently took too long for their liking b/c near the end of our deserts the manager of this restaurant came over and asked very obviously if she could get anybody a cab and proceeded to mention that they needed the table. Needless to say, we all found this extremely rude and quite embarrassing for the hosts of this business dinner! I personally took the manager aside and let her know we found this extremely inappropriate for a restaurant that boast this caliber of fine dining. She made no apologies and truly believed she was in the right. I dont like leaving negative reviews but I would not return to this restaurant. In general, I found the waiter to be attentive. Not overly friendly but not rude either. The food was OK. Fresh ingredients and good quality. The sweets were delicious.
author: Romina T.

description: Good and worth a try. I think it's a good date spot.  For the money to deliciousness ratio, I'd go elsewhere if you've tried this before.  The decor is awesome though; so four stars!  I expect to run into Gatsby here.
author: Erika C.

description:
This place deserves more than just five stars!  When you walk into this place it seems as if you were time warped back into the World War II era.  If the place was a little bigger, I could almost imagine a live big band and people dancing all around.  Very "Great Gatsby" like. Although the tiny older gentleman playing classic jazz charts on the grand piano adds the touch.

The waiters wear black pants with a classic style white coat.  Another odd coincidence about the waiters, they seem to be all over six feet tall.  I wonder if that was a job requirement.  

Everything from the appetizers to the desserts...all top notch.  If money were not an option, I'd want to try everything on their menu.  My only disappointment...I didn't see any BRUSSEL SPROUTS as a side dish order!  oh well!

You must try this place.  It's classy, cozy, elegant, great service, and above all....THE FOOD IS SUPERB!  Every penny spent at this place is worth it.  Eating at this place is well worth the overtime pay to cover the bill.
author: Justin M.

description:
BIX is like a transporting experience to the 1980's world of finance- In fact, I think I overheard the guys next to me discussing junk bond sales.  If I were on a date here, I would feel glamorous in the way of the character Penelope (Winthorpe's fiance) from "Trading Places" (I now feel inclined to add this to my Netflix Que).

 I love BIX and it proves to be the perfect place to.. say.. take your rich uncle in town from Wisconsin, or say.. your big-balling expensive wine-swigging friend who works in finance on her 30th B-day (even worth it if you have to starve yourself and be a hermit the whole week before to afford it).   

I recommend everything I've tried on the menu, especially the steak tartar (you can go 'head and order it here fearlessly- I promise), The lamb burgers, and the seared tuna steak (which was a special recently).  My friends would argue that you have to order the steak, but I'm trying to head back in the direction of my vegitarian ways so it's not for me. 

 The ambiance, classic cocktails, impeccable service, quality french menu without tricks and the act of cabbing it through a sleek secret alley to get there...make Bix an unforgettable dining experience.
author: Kerrie T.

description:
I've been back 3 more times in about 2 months.  Yes, I'm becoming addicted.  

March 4th, 2009
I took my friend Scott here for his birthday in March.  Unreal experience.  

March 11, 2009
I then had the opportunity to take 2 of my business contacts from Chicago here for a late night dinner.  Fried oysters, tuna tartare, shrimp cocktail, lamb burgers, and steaks!  A bottle of red wine, two kinds of desserts and I've solidified my relationship with these two very well connected men.  

March 31, 2009.
I took a friend, a lovely one at that to Bix for her birthday.  Nick DeLullu placed us upstairs, at what was the best table in the house.  I couldn't ask for anything else.  Thank you Nick!  

The atmosphere, the food, the amazing service, turned the night into an experience.   

Tuna tartare, oysters on the half shell, crispy fried oysters, a bottle of 2005 Candado de Haza, swordfish, and duck.  Heaven.  

If you're coming to dinner with a someone you enjoy talking to, be prepared to get sucked into Bix's comfortable booths, beautiful decor, swanky atmosphere and luscious food.  You'll end up spending 4 hours during dinner.  We did.  My date freaked out when I told her it was 11:30 PM.  We arrived at 7:15.  What can I say, Bix is amazing.
author: Dennis M.

description:
If this ain't a five star joint, I don't know what it is.

5 Signs that you're at a kick ass restaurant called Bix:

1. You gotta dress up if you're going to go.
2. It's got a 'secret' back-alley entrance with a neon sign made to look like it's shorting out
3. Old school dark wood everywhere, with Deco flair--nice long and tall bar
4. Very elegant food and a long, nice wine list
5. Bartenders/servers dressed up in black and white
6. Dance floor and live jazz music
7. Did I mention the secret alleyway entrance?

It is a little pricey, but worth it.
author: Mr. R.

description: Cool old school feeling bar but way overpriced.  Came here with a friend on a 7X7 magazine recommendation.  We sat at the bar and had the gin martini, several gin cocktails, some appetizers and steak tar tar.  It was good but the end bill was close to $200.  So overpriced.  For a similar experience I'd rather just go to Tadich Grill.
author: Juliana X.

description: We went there for a friend's birthday.  This is a semi-upscale kind of restaurant.  I didn't know what to expect, so that was okay for me.  The food not only looks good, but tastes good, too.  I had the Kobe beef which was around $30+.  We had some hors d'oeuvres before dinner.  It was a mix of their special of the day, some veggies and a little of this and a little of that.  Nothing special.  However, what was special was the ambiance.  They had a jazz band there and the atmosphere was very classy, but still a fun time!  The service was so-so.  They actually spilled a glass of water and then when they wiped up everything, they made us hold the plates while they cleaned it.  A little weird, but it looked like the guy was new, so he was a little nervous.  The only downside we had was the parking.  We parked a few blocks away, but I guess in SF, that's not uncommon, so it was no big deal.
author: Jamie J.

description:
BIX - How do I love the? Let me count the ways:

1) Your fabulous bar is charming and swanky - it would make even the most die hard teetotalers big fat drunks.

2) The cocktails that you serve at your fabulous bar are a force to be reckoned with - one Side Car later and I was stumbling over words and walking off balance. What a great bang for your buck!

3) Your home made, fresh mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto was to die for. The cheese melted in my mouth and the prosciutto gave it the perfect salty balance.

4) Lamb burgers were perfection -  a lovely and savory spin off of your typical run-of-the-mill sliders.

5) Your ambiance and lighting make me want to take a significant other to enjoy it with - I was with a good friend and all I could think about was how I wanted to make out. Date night anyone?

6) Service was great - extremely attentive and friendly.

7) Location, location, location! You are in the perfect after work spot in the Financial District. I love that I'm a mere hop skip and a jump away from a great treat after a long day.

Seven ways? Not bad - but I'll have to expand on my list as time goes on and I've had more than a couple visits. This place is definitely worth exploring over and over again!
author: Julia N.

description:
I am going to be totally honest and hope it will pass the test.  I used to work here but it was 12 years ago.  Does that count?  Should I not write a review?  I can't see why it would be such a big deal.  I was invited by my aunt and uncle to have lunch in the city and they wanted to go to BIX so.................

I love BIX.  Great food, Great Atmosphere and pretty good service.

I had the Oxtail and French Onion Soup.  Good nothing amazing but instead of a huge piece of toast and melted cheese they had like 5 mini grilled cheese toast puffs in the city.  I thought it was kind of creative and a fun little spin.

For lunch I had the Chix hash.  It was served with a cream sauce and some sauteed cherry tomatoes.  I liked it.  I will get back to have dinner and give it the real test but.....................go and try it out, make a reservation and expect to spend some money.  You are paying for the atmosphere, service and food.  It's a swanky place at least go in for a drink and see how you feel about it.
author: Ron B.

description:
Came here when I first moved to SF with some new friends for a birthday party.  Not only did the staff get most everything wrong for our party of 10, they were extremely late in bringing everything out.

Most of our meal was comped that night, but it left  bad taste in our mouths, as we still spent over $60 a plate.  

This place is extremely loud as well, and it was impossible to make conversation with anyone that wasn't sitting right next to you.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
Awesome space. Love the small door opening into this huge soaring space. Piano player tinkling the ivories as the bartender whips me up an old fashioned.

Did a beef trifecta - steak tartare, bone marrow and the burger.

The tartare was good but not special.
Bone marrow very tasty - served St. John style - which meant parsley and salt. You don't see this on too many menus and I was a happy camper.
Burger - wonderful - my #3 burger in SF after Farley Bar and Spruce. Meat was very flavorful.

I'll be back!
author: Aaron T.

description:
Best drinks, best food and best service!!! Bix is great for any occasion. 

Beautiful decoration, very inviting atmosphere and tasteful food. 

Bread Pudding is must for dessert
author: Seda M.

description:
I was/am so conflicted about this place and the rating that I have assigned to this review. On the quality scale, this place serves some damn good food. I had the sea bass, which came with sauteed spinach and was absolutely yummy. My husband couldn't stop talking about his kobe beef dish. And I couldn't blame him after taking a bite; the meat was tender and literally melted in your mouth. 

The major downer of this place, and hence the 3 star rating, is the price point. As good as the food was, everybody in our party couldn't help but feel that their meals were priced above market.
author: Sandy Y.

description: Had dinner here on a Saturday evening.  The cocktails, beer & wine selection is excellent.  I was less impressed with the food, we shared the crab "sliders" and then I had the pork.  The pork tasted nice & was well cooked, but really I can grill pork as good as that.
author: Andy B.

description:
It has been a while since I last attended a dinner at BIX (in all honesty it was the only time I have been to the restaurant), but what I recall from the experience is that I left an establishment that truly knows how to provide an amazing overall experience.

My boyfriend and I were spending a weekend up in the city prior to our move here, and had been given a recommendation for BIX for dinner on our trip.  I was a bit weary as our recommendation came from a friend of my boyfriend's, someone who indeed worked for the restaurant itself.  Of course he was going to build it up to be something special....he worked there....but he was NOT lying.
Fortunately we were lucky enough to have his familiarity and expertise guide us through the evening.  Our reserved table was the best of the house - a table on the 2nd floor balcony overlooking the piano bar (jazz lounge singer included) and entire restaurant. Our waiter brought us a tasting menu of sorts, providing littler versions of the most popular dishes.  We were blessed to experience this at this restaurant as it isn't something normally done! 

Not one dish failed to deliver.  It was pure enchantment as each plate practically melted in your mouth.  The most notable being the butternut squash soup with crab, lobster spaghetti with cream sauce (low calorie of course), and banana fosters with peanut butter ice cream dessert. Pure heaven on a plate.

It is no where near a cheap establishment, but for the quality of food, excellence of service, and overall atmosphere and experience, BIX is one place well worth saving up for!  So break open those piggy banks and treat yourself and someone special!
author: Ryan H.

description:
Get your swank on, darling! 

Bix has a wonderfully nostalgic feel to it... vintage, elegant, and jazzy. The food has been excellent the handful of times I've gone... delicious classics updated but not so much so as to be trendy or unrecognizable. 

Tuck a gardenia behind your ear, slip on your cocktail dress and prepare for a top-notch dining experience!
author: Beverage Appreciato R.

description:
I love Bix!

Your first impression of Bix is walking down an alley, to discover this charming restaurant, filled with the noise of laughter and a piano player.

When you walk in, you are greeted by a host, who is usually overwhelmed. No matter what night you go, good economy or bad, Bix is still a happening place in town. 

If your table isn't quite ready, have a drink at the bar, they are excellent and the bar is great. I have had dinner at the bar as well. The bar tenders are all highly entertaining. The drinks may cost, but they are well worth the price tag.

When dining, try to have Jackie as your server. They are all excellent, , but she is so funny, I just love her. I had a guy last time and he was good, he knew when I needed another drink just by my expressions.

For dinner, so at Bix, I always want everything, and I get the same thing. I love the Potato Pillows so much. They have cream and caviar on top and they are a little bit of royalty in my opinion. The steak is delicious too. Whenever I get it, everyone in my party is jealous.

There desserts are great. So I wouldn't just sit down and eat at a banana, but I love the Banana's Foster at Bix, it is amazing. It tastes great and it is prepared table side, which I love! The bread putting is also very tasty. w

I highly suggest Bix, whether it is a pre-diinner drink, a full dinner and drinks, or a post-dinner drink. It truly is a San Francisco place, as it's on an Alley! 

If your service is a little slow, just enjoy your time there, it is a truly special restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Just had a most wonderful dinner last night at BIX.

The food was OUT OF THIS WORLD!!!
The service - there are not enough words in the dictionary to describe the service we received - Stu, you are AMAZING!!!
The atmosphere - with the history behind the building, the decor, the music... WOW
Worth every penny spent for dinner!!!

A don't miss for a special occassion or just to have a great dining experience!!!

A don't miss!!!!!
author: Cricket B.

description:
How could I have missed this restaurant? Last night Lisa G (of Yelp fame) suggested we drop by this place. It was late and both of us were hungry. I admit I was not expecting much. It was past 10, we had no reservations and we pulled into a little alley near Jackson square.

When we walked in, I immediately fell in love with the place. A little live jazz playing downstairs, a wonderful stylish old speakeasy atmosphere and one of the best stocked bars I've seen in a while. What more could you ask for? Well, yes... the food. The food is American (read: touches of everything) and it is fantastic. I loved the mini-lamb burgers and ohmygod (technical term) the potato  pillows with creme fraiche and caviar... ok, I am a guy and I hate to admit this, but yeah, I melted a little after I took a bite.

I didn't try any of the entrees. We stuck with hor d'oeuvres and first courses, but if they were any measure, I can't imagine you'd go wrong with anything here.
author: Jordan M.

description:
* * * * * * * 
Seven stars for you, BIX!!

The cuisine at BIX is truly divine. The boy and I enjoyed some delectable starters which included: truffle fries, tuna tartare on olive toasts, and grilled squash + ricotta napoleon. Delish~*

For our entrees, we ordered the Maine Lobster spaghetti and Chicken Hash a la Bix. Comfort fancy food all the way. Everything we ordered was perfection- nothing too salty nor too bland, arrived piping hot and in great time. Fantastic service + well-managed staff.. parking is a bit difficult considering it is the FiDi. With reservations, we were seated immediately. This was an extremely excellent experience for us- we'll be looking forward to visiting time and again :o)
author: Elaine T.

description:
The romance, the style, the establishment.
The architecture, the woman singing jazz ballads, the formality of the staff.
The sparkling oysters, the sexy paintings, the height of the room.
And oh lord did I covet the glossy black entryway, so San Francisco!

I ordered, count 'em, three side cars. Two would have prolly been enough, but I was celebrating. And I ordered the pork chop to see if it was as good as Nopa's. It was not. But it came close. If I didn't have a certified sweet tooth, I might have thought the accompanying fresh fig 'chutney' was too sweet. However, as I have yet to find a sugar too sweet, I loved it!
All of the food was Really good, perfect in fact, including the steak tartar, warm sourdough rolls, heirloom tomatoes with basil and fresh mozzarella, chicken hash, roasted potatoes, whipped yellow finn potatoes, sauteed greens, and mini ice cream sandwiches, the best of which was banana ice cream on oatmeal cookie. Yes, we were there a while..

We had a very special night, and I'm glad we chose Bix. What a quality joint. It was a Tuesday evening - I assume the weekend is a different vibe. This was calm, classic, and I felt like a grown up. (Yeah, that's big points right there)  Seriously, my next house project is to build a replica of their front doors! Well, if not, I'll just have to visit more often.
author: Vale C.

description:
I had forgotten how much I like this restaurant.

Even though we waited almost two hours, and arguably, a cocktail napkin dipped in mayonnaise would taste good after two hours of starvation (though to be fair, we walked in at 8:45 on a Friday with no reservation and the place was packed and the lucky bastards with tables knew it and basically camped out). 

And even though the chicken hash was not as perfect as I remembered - too much thyme in the sauce?  - it was still chicken hash, which is to say decadent and savory and delish.

And even though there was a definite chlorine aftertaste to my Manhattan - was it the glass? the ice? - it was a well-made drink.

See, Bix just has this old-school sexy swankiness that renders these few flaws almost obsolete.  The bar is swingin' (though ok,  mostly filled with the salt-and-pepper sportcoat set).  They have live jazz (appealing to fortysomethings and us young people alike).  You can canoodle in the upstairs booths (though ok, the lighting is kind of too bright up there and I have vague memories of grandma upholstery).   But most importantly, you can order a definitive steak tartare.

Dare I say that this is the best steak tartare I have ever had.  And that's a big deal - speaking in absolutes scares me, if only because I have a horrible memory and it's conceivable that I've had a better steak tartare somewhere, sometime... but it's this one that stands out as flawless.  Because they know how to season.   And that is an exceedingly rare skill.  Those guys at Perbacco (where, about a month ago, I begrudgingly ingested a pile of pink slop they called veal tartare) need to take a lesson from the tartare masterminds here.  

Well.  After this resplendent mound of cool, perfectly accented meat, I basically couldn't be any happier.  OK, I was pretty happy with my hash.  And BF's burger was sublime.  And it didn't hurt that we washed everything down with a bottle of Caymus.  But the real icing on the proverbial cake was the caramel-oozing bananas foster, a fittingly retro end to our fabulously throwback evening.  It was perfect.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I totally ripped off Bix. Don't get me wrong, not in a bad way, but I was sitting at the bar, watching some yuppie suit stuffer (ok, eye-ing, he was quite cute) nibbling on crostini.
