Not just any crostini, though, these beautifully even toasty pieces with super thin slices of the ripest avocado, marinated sardines, sea salt, green onion and olive oil. I make it all the time now for dinner parties (easy to make veg, vegan or with anchovies, too).

That aside, everything is really good here. Of the three meals I've had, I've yet to be disappointed. 

That said, nothing totally blew me into five stars. Except for those damn crostini.
author: Brer R.

description:
I can't believe in all the years I've eaten here I have never written a review, and being the 196th who's really going to care if I do?

I'll write anyway.

I have always enjoyed this restaurant. It at times can be pretentious, but mostly its just good food with good service, and good atmosphere. 

I enjoy that it is a 'dress' place, that you can be business casual in the daytime for lunch, but that it dresses up at night. There really aren't the 'get dressed up' kind of places here in SF that there are on the east coast, so I enjoy it when a place is not ok if your date wants to wear his best shirt untucked from his baggy jeans.

The food is good. It service is also mostly on the mark. You can definitely say that they were not there when you didn't ant them and there when you did.

All told this place is well thought out, and consistently very good.

The bartenders are very well versed in their craft too!

I like a place that wants you to look your best while in their establishment. Makes you look good and them too. I like a situation where everybody wins.
author: Marz W.

description:
A fine establishment- been for drinks a few times, and finally for dinner recently.

First, of the few bars in the city where bartenders take pride in their craft, one would certainly be one of them. You walk into the place and  crave a Manhattan--this is the kind of place where you want a REAL cocktail. And they're excellent.

The host was real accomodating as our party grew from three, to four then ultimately five. We didn't have to wait to long as I was prepared to order another drink when he tapped me on the shoulder to signal that our table was ready. Alas, a fine booth upstairs-- felt like Sinatra.

Had the steak, which was slightly overdone (explains my four out of five stars). 

Bix makes you wanna kick it old school-- real classy kind of a joint. I should take my next date there.
author: Fidel L.

description:
We ate here just over a week ago and the food was really wonderful. The restaurant has a cool, 1940'ish urban feel which we enjoyed. Keep in mind that this place is LOUD so having a conversation on a busy night during dinner may require talking in a raised voice. However I would not be deterred from eating here simply because of the noise level.
As far as the menu goes they have a wide variety of meat and fish dishes. We started out by having salmon toasts on little rye pieces, then shared a pickled veggie salad with homemade ranch dressing, then had the burger and flounder with grits, and finished off with some sorbets. Everything was really good, including the glass of Malbec that my husband ordered.
We really enjoy innovative, modern flavors and BIX really shines in that regard. I have noticed over the years that the best flavor combos always come in the appetizers and desserts as there is only so much you can do with a main course. The main courses we had were great, no complaints but the appetizers are what REALLY stood out, especially the salad which was divine. If you want a nice dinner in a fun atmosphere do visit BIX.
author: Nadia S.

description:
I dined at BIX on January 11, 2008 and I loved it! The ambiance was romantic and dimly lit which really set the mood, the bar was great and fully stocked, the jazz music also did a lot to set the mood, and the food was excellent.

We sat upstairs which was my only complaint of the whole experience.  Our table was cramped and I really wished we either had been given a (1) larger table or (2) a booth.  I did not let the table get to me and I had a blast stopping only to make a mental note to request a booth next time. I would go back anytime.
author: Jonnathan C.

description: I've been here a few times for their excellent cocktails and decided to go for dinner. The interior decor is very cool. The waiter was extremely knowledgeable about the menu and gave us some solid recommendations. The bahn mi appetizer and the duck were the two best things we ordered that evening, but all the food was top notch. We sat right next to the piano player who took our Vince Guaraldi request graciously. Hey, it was Christmastime. The cocktails are always great and this evening was no exception. It is pricey but you should know that going in. For a fancy night out and a superb meal, BIX is the place.
author: Scott A.

description:
Ok...some friends of mine and I went to Bix for our yearly xmas luncheon shindig..thingamajigger. It was really fun! The ambiance is very warm and inviting. I love the art deco and the lighting. As far as food, i should of taken the advice of my fellow yelpers and ordered the beef.

Anywhoo, i order the Lobster pasta. Not very exciting. It was bland and just plain boring. Don't order it!!! My friends tuna tartare was incredible and so were the truffle fries. Otherwise, its a a fun place to go and I would go there again. This time for some dinner.
author: Denise C.

description: Lively restaurant with live piano. The food was good, especially the Foie Gras.
author: Nidhi N.

description:
what a big disappointment! it's pretty pricey and soooo not worth it! our waitress was really weird. she made really bad jokes and it was very awkward. she also just simply forgot about us in the middle of the service.
the ambiance is good and making the reservation was pretty easy.
the food wasn't impressive but the cocktails were yumm!
this is what we had:
Potato Pillows with Caviar-ok
Mini Lamb Burgers -forgettable
Smoked Trout Salad - very good
Steak Tartare-horrible, very very salty
Chocolate and Butterscotch Brownies-ok
i won't be back.
author: Oyo S.

description:
I love everything about Bix.  I love the beautiful decor, the paintings on the walls (especially the aptly titled "The Butler's In Love").  I love the old school feel of the restaurant.  I love the steak and the burger and the martinis that proceed them.  I love the vibe at the bar when I go in for after work drinks (although it does sometimes get a little crowded).  I love the live jazz (even though it makes it a little difficult to have a conversation sometimes.  I love the formality of the service that always makes me feel like a VIP.  Bix is more than just a restaurant.  It is an experience.  An experience that I love every time I have it.  
Oh, and P.S.:My cousin rented it out for his rehearsal dinner, and it was one of the best rehearsal dinners ever.  Perfect place if you have around 100 people for a private party.
author: Erica G.

description:
I'm sure all of you know one of the best ways to get into a popular restaurant is to go on a weekday night, late. 

So, that's what I did. And it was so worth it. We were seated in the best spot in the house, upper floor, center booth, just for the two of us. Perfect view of the bar and very private because the booths are spaced far apart and no one is across from you.

Live jazz pianist and singer started around 9:30. She had a really nice voice and it blended and drowned out some of the cackling heard from downstairs.

I had a cocktail, the Ginger Gimlet, that I wasn't that impressed with. Next time I'll do wine or something else. 

The food was delish. Oysters from Oregon and butternut squash soup to start. The sourdough rolls were warmed just right, too. 

My entree was my first over $20 burger ($26 to be exact) that was center filled with truffle, so it was different but good. The fluffy rye half bun was good enough to eat by itself. I've had similar fries before but these seemed really good that night--maybe I just appreciated everything that came with the great setting.

My date had the special fish of the day with lentils that he ate every last bite of. He also ate most of the side of greenbeans with almonds that we ordered.

I felt generous that night (actually I was too full), so I shared my ice cream sandwich dessert. Six mini sandwiches, three flavors. My favorite was the classic vanilla ice cream with semi-sweet crispy chocoloate chip cookies.

We left very satisfied and my only complaint would be the timing of the food. We were there for about 2.5 hours--took forever just to get the entrees.
author: Kat H.

description:
Bix, hidden away in an alley you sometimes get lost, in a good way of course. 

Last year Joel and I took our friend Laura out for her B-day and for his job interview. We had Lobster pasta, Lamb, and Kobe beef. 

The food was amazing. Chefs at the CCA even go goo goo ga ga for this stuff haha. 

The chef even brought out a few samples from the cold apps and hot apps, such as potato pillows with creme fraiche and caviar and simple heirloom tomatoes with balsamic dressing. 

This is a must eat, it's pretty expensive but everyone there is nice even the cute bartender ;) hehe
author: Harry K.

description: Great food. Good service, Music for part of our meal. Pretty much what I expected though not wow-ed
author: Sean Q.

description:
I absolutely ADORE this place.  My hon of hons husband and I met some good friends here for dinner on Saturday night, and had the best goddamn time.  It probably doesn't hurt that one of my friends is the head concierge at a very well known, very posh, 5 star hotel in San Francisco, and of course ever single person in the restaurant who waited on us knew it and treated us fabulously.

We were shown to a big plush booth upstairs, showered with drinks, little treats from the kitchen, the most amazing fucking food - crab brioche sandwiches, the freshest of oysters, cute little lamb burgers, amazing chicken hash (yes, I said HASH) and some fabulous wine.  Oh, and the most cunning little rolls that were served piping HOT, which is one of my prerequisites for a 5 star review.  

Of course we were far too full for dessert, but the waiter brought out a selection for us any way....and we ate some.  The bill was pretty high, but who cares - we were having a blast!

I've been to Bix before, and have always been so impressed by the food and service.  When we left Bix on Saturday night, we were all asking ourselves why the heck don't we come her more often?

Oh, and love the little dinner jackets on the waiters.  Nice touch!
author: .Hon H.

description:
I was impressed, that's for sure.  I love the cute alley it's in and I love the ambiance inside.  It has a Spanish feel to it with high ceilings, columns and dark wood.  We started with the house-made mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto,drizzled with olive oil and they were amazing!  I had the crab spaghetti in lobster sauce and my friend had the spare ribs with garlic mashed potatoes.  Everything was perfectly cooked and delicious.  We were both satisfied and completely full but we couldn't resist the bananas foster on the desert menu.  Again, incredible!  The wait staff was friendly and efficient and I can't wait to go back!

Second visit back... I had the steak tartar.  AWESOME.  Truly incredible.  That is, if you can handle raw beef.
author: Lauren M.

description:
I am a big fan of bars and eating at bars.  Screw OpenTable.com and calling for reservations -- I eat when I want where I want (I don't make plans) so when I look for a place to eat I need a bar area (with elbow room), a full dinner menu and a kitchen to serve until at least 12am -- Bix has it.  

Located in an alley where there are no street signs you will find a great restaurant with live jazz (I went on a Friday night).  The food was fun to order since there was a lot of variety.  I would recommend to start with a beef tartare (this was prepared table-side) and the mini lamb burgers are a must try.  Dinner items I sampled were all great: Smoked Trout salad, Truffled Cheese Burger.  I now have a nice safe place to eat away from the 'waiting to start a fight crowd' on Broadway St.

PS.  There is a NY Strip Steak on the 'hidden menu'.  I wanted to try, but it was already sold out by 10pm.  I will go back again!
author: Sherman H.

description:
Had been a few years since I ate at Bix.

Gotta say Bruce Hill has taken it up a notch!  With a table of picky eaters, we took ages to order because we couldn't decide what to get.  Everything has some -thing- or some twist that makes it must...get...now...

I can't do the menu justice trying to describe it, so check it out yourself:
http://www.zagat.com/Verticals/Menu.aspx?VID=8&R=47481&HID=9284#jumpDINNER%20MENU

Among the 10 other things we got, I had the Killer Club Cheeseburger.  Cooked perfectly med-rare thanks to the hot new gizmo -- Bruce's patented Plancha Press.  Frickin delicous.  I could have eaten the poppyseed bun plain by itself too, it's so darn good.

Live piano and speakeasy-esque singer.  Such a great night.  Amazing server.  And the comfiest booth seats ev-er.
author: Melanie C.

description:
We read in the Gate last month that Bix would be open for lunch service during December, so that sounded like a nice treat for ourselves during the holidays....and it was!  We went on Wednesday 12/23 for a late leisurely lunch.
Enjoyed a fancy cocktail shaken tableside: Ginger Gimlet- yum!
Kaffir-Lime vodka, house-made ginger simple syrup & soda. One was enough this early in the day....

Lunch:
Crab & avocado in lettuce cups with a louis-type dressing.
Tasty and not too heavy. Crab could have been cleaned a little more thoroughly - I found a few shell pieces.

House-made pappardelle with lamb sugo. Wonderful! I rarely finish an entree portion, but I couldn't stop eating it!

G/F had the burger & fries....kind of a standard order for such a fancy place, but it was darn awesome. Needed more ketchup. I loved the fries, and kept dunking them in my pasta sauce w/ the lamb......

Sophisticated and fun atmosphere - good combo & a great afternoon!
author: A S.

description:
Took my girlfriend to Bix for her birthday dinner last night. Loved the piano player, loved the ambiance, loved the piano player, loved the location, LOVED the service and we really liked the food. 

We had a really lovely time at dinner. As mentioned the service was great. Very attentive and helpful. We asked the waiter to recommend an entree and he pointed us to the Grilled Rack of Lamb which we both agreed was wonderful. The Pork Chop was good, but not up to the level of the Lamb. 

For openers we had Roasted Butternut Squash Soup with Dungeness Crab and the Smoked Trout Salad. Both were welcome beginners. 

With a restaurant like Bix you know what you should be getting and they delivered on all counts. It's difficult to get me to give 5 stars and they were really close. Had the Pork Chop been more impressive they would have had me. As it is it goes down as an extremely impressive 4 stars. I would go back.
author: keith h.

description: Great food. Very classy place. Live music - jazz. Grilled cheese sandwiches and mini burgers are so awesome! Also beef tartar was amazing and big enough portion as an entree. It is good to make reservations as this place is always booked.
author: elena a.

description:
We had an intimate birthday celebration here. Brought our own cake which Bix was nice enough to accomodate for. They even added some wonderful chocolate mousse garnish on the side. They had a nice birthday card ready at the table when we arrived.

Great ambiance, great cocktails, delicious food and great service. Would highly recommend.
author: Mus P.

description:
I've only been to this place for casual drinks but I've always been very impressed by their entire presentation. The bar is very well stocked with lots of great scotch, whiskey and tequila.

On Saturday night they have a Jazz trio playing classic sambas etc. 

Bonus points for the fast bar service and quick attention from a very cute hostess. 

Great date place for after dinner drinks or a good place to hang out with some friends.
author: Carlos V.

description:
I really am trying not to give high ratings "just because"  but I suppose my friends just know how to pick 'em...

I would have gone 4.5 on this one ONLY because we got there for our 9pm reservation and still waited quite a while to be seated- maybe 30 minutes...

On to the food.

We had 3 apps- tuna tartare, crab on brioche and a tater-tot like thing with creme fraiche and caviar. Yum, yum and yum! Dig especially on that tuna tartare.....!!!

A bunch of my friends ordered steak- kobe and also a "secret" steak that maybe isn't so secret if they're ordering it- it's not on the menu though...

As for what I ate- I ordered the mini lamb burgers for my entree with a side of their spinach. I wasn't starving and we had the apps...so it was just enough food. The mini burgers were awesome- I thought they were too cute for words, and I ate them in far more bites than necessary...a-la Tom Hanks in Big eating the baby corn...too funny...

I also had a roving fork and tasted several bites of my friend's crab and lobster creme pasta which was surprisingly not heavy. I was expecing this bisque-ish sauce and it was a lot cleaner than that. Nice chunks of meat too.

Of course we had dessert too- we tried a few and all were good. Bananas foster, the assorted cookies and ice cream sandwiches (minis- yay!) and a chocolate bread pudding that was more like molen chocolate cake...

Go here. 

Oh, and if it weren't for the heels, we'd have walked- so they got that 1/2 star back in there for proximity...love that. As those of you who read my other reviews will soon learn...
author: Diane S.

description:
I've only been here twice and that's because I'm usually broke. One of my co-workers also pulled bar shifts at Bix so they comped me a couple of appetizers including potato pillows and something else I can't remember that involved caviar and Crme frache.

Anyhoo, you can't go wrong here. It's a classy environment that harkens back to the good old days of San Francisco. It attracts a good crowd and not too many tourists. The service is attentive and friendly but not obnoxiously smothering. They serve up some of the best comfort food around. 

If I really like a girl, I take her to Bix. Is there really a better endorsement than that?
author: lazslo t.

description:
Well, this was touted as one of the best places in SF to eat by some friends. I went there for a friends birthday party and the service was shit, everything was screwed up and he completely forgot my order. Once I got it, it was no good because they cooked it so fast.

That being said! The manager was excellent, he took care of everything for the table. Comped a bunch of our stuff. My mediocre meal was free, drinks were free, and after the waiter continued to suck by spilling ice-cream on somebody; desert ended up free. 

My friends told me that Bix was having an off-night, I somewhat believed them because their recovery was top-notch, they couldn't afford to do that every night.

The atmosphere was very nice, and it was pretty cool because the place itself is in a semi-beat up alley, then you walk in and it's all trendy inside.

Has valet parking as well. Tip them, you stingy ass mothers.
author: Alex ..

description: So fancy and adorable!!! We stumbled upon this place trying to get some food on a random Tuesday night and stumbled upon this romantic, old school, ADORABLE place. I'm a sucker for ambiance and the place was amazing. Live jazz singer, piano player, dim lighting, jazz theme with huge paintings of famous jazz singers. The food is delicious. I had the lobster spaghetti (love that they had small and large options, small was plenty) with a Cesar salad. Another reviewer used the word swanky and I must agree. You know when you were a kid and people on tv would take their dates to fancy proper places? That's what I felt this was but the staff was very nice and sweet (no pretension here). Although some fancy Giants dude was there and our server let us know. My hubby had the open face burger with Brussel sprouts (super good). He thought the burger was okay, I didn't try it. If you want a nice romantic dinner, go here! Love. Pricey but nice change of pace from hipster restaurants. I only wish I was dressed nicer.
author: Hanan H.

description: ate at BIX once, remember nothing after the very strong but really good old fashioned I had at the bar. Dessert was AMAZING and we did get a little tuna tartare treat as an added bonus. Am going back tonight and will make sure to remember more of the meal and report back!
author: Holly C.

description: My husband and I have made Bix our special anniversary dinner spot for the second year in a row. First time was great, but we dined too early and didn't get to stay for the music. This time we got later reservations and were able to dine to a delightful jazz combo. Everything about Bix made this a special night, from the delicious appetizers ( smoked trout and fava beans) to the professional waitstaff. We tried the Bix signature chicken hash and it was divine! The Kobe truffle burger was no slouch either. We had a great time and will be back again next year!
author: April E.

description:
This is a really great place for happy hour.  I love the atmosphere and the fact that it's located in an alley.  Great bar and people are usually dressed nicely, so it's not like going down a sketchy alley.  I've never eaten here, but have always wanted to try it.  Just gotta find a date first....

UPDATE 11/14/2007:

I ate here last January for Dine About Town and thought it was really great.   I'd definitely be back for the food or the drinks.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
San Francisco, baby.  I was taken here once two years ago by my boss along with the rest of the company (of 6).  Really a nice establishment.   Very eclectic and charming.  They have a wide variety of liquor, beer, and wines.  

The service was exceptional and the food, whatever it was, was good.

The ambiance was just right -- not too bright, not too dark, not too loud, but enough chatter to get you chattering.

I'd love to come back here again.  It's located in an alley-way and you would never guess such a nice restaurant resides within the brick walls.
author: Hodie K.

description:
Came here last Saturday night for a friend's birthday dinner and the food was amazing but the service was awful. So torn on what to rate this place, wish I could do 2 different reviews.  Let's start with the positive first...BTW, we were a group of 10 people. 

The food was phenomenal. The croques were to die for and hands down the table's favorite. The halibut ceviche & steak tartare were fantastic as well. For entrees, everyone was really happy with their dishes. I had the truffle burger and it was heavenly (but couldnt finish it)...and so were the truffle fries. Others had the kobe beef and were also very impressed. 

Now on to the damper of the evening. My friend's mom had surprised us with 2 bottles of champagne for the table and the waiter never mentioned it when we sat down. Instead he proceeded to ask for cocktail orders to (in our opinion) rack up the bill.  When my friend, the birthday girl, asked the waiter for the champagne she knew her mother had bought us, he said he was going to save it for dessert. Super weird.  After the first bottle was poured, we each realized the bottle of Veuve-Clicquot was bad. Every single glass was totally flat. No bubble.  When my husband told the waiter, the waiter disagreed and only refilled my husband's glass and one other friend. He did not ask the rest of the table if anyone else was unhappy with their glass of champagne.  After a while, he started working the table, person by person taking more cocktail orders even though we had another bottle of Veuve!  Again, my friend had to ask him to bring the bottle out.  At the end of our meal, the waiter asked for dessert orders and my friend (who thank goodness her mom told her what she was going to send over to our table as a gift) asked the waiter why he would take dessert orders when her mother has also bought a huge cake from the restaurant for our table!!??!!!!   He apologized and brought out the cake. Which by the way was enormous and he never brought the left overs to my friend to take home after dinner. 
Honestly, the service was SUCH a turn off I will not return for a looooong time, if ever.
author: Veronica P.

description:
Been to Bix several times. I wish I lived in the City, I would go once a week. 
Food is incredible and the staff is excellent. Incredible bar with great spirits from all over the world they you have not heard of. 
I'm going back during the Holidays.
author: Scott H.

description:
Loved the live music, the very friendly wait staff, and the bar and its selection. From the moment we walked in, the staff was very pleasant and attentive.  At the end of the evening, they called us a cab and waited outside with us until it came.  After we told the waiter that we are vegetarian, he spoke with the chef, and they put together a delicious main dish for us (fresh corn, chard and fingerling potatoes!! YUMMY!)
  
I have to say that I was so so into the decor, couldn't really figure out why there is a trophy case on the second floor... or why there are two paintings that are so dark, that they can almost be mistaken for chalk boards...
author: Erica S.

description: Fantastic energy and old San Francico location. The live jazz was wonderful. Food tries too hard and I would rate 4 out of 5. Service the same. Still a great place for a special occasion dinner.
author: Maggie D.

description:
The restaurant had great food, the highlight of the evening was...the bread pudding dessert!  It was ridiculously good.  The service was really good, the bus-person and waiter were very nice and put in a good effort.

The appetizers we had were the potato pillows and foie gras...they were good, but next time we would probably pass on the foie gras (Alexander's has a really good cold foie gras we kept comparing it to)

The truffle burger and (w/fries) was of note as well, but it was a tad surprising that is wasn't a 'real' burger since it had no top bun.  

The con of the experience was the noise level in the restaurant, otherwise this restaurant and experience should get 4.5 stars.
author: M L.

description:
Didn't even know this place existed, but I've already made reservations for a business group of folks I need to impress.  Great service, great wine, great food.  Get a table upstairs, it's easier to hear things, and they have great round booths for large groups (we had 7).  

I had steak, oysters, and potato pillows with caviar - all were amazing - but the menu changes daily, so just go and take your chances.  The chef has a pedigree involving just about every big restaurant in town as he went up the ladder, and he knows what he's doing.  Trust.

As an aside, I love that the waiters wear cropped dinner jackets.  It adds a touch of class to the typical enjoyable but casual SF dining atmosphere.
author: John H.

description:
I had high hopes as I've been near Bix many times over the years, but Friday lunch was my first time as an actual Bix customer.  Fortunately for me, I didn't foot the bill, because other than my G.B.L. (and we actually had to request a cocktail menu) and the atmosphere, the service, and food were nothing special. Fortunately, the company more than made up for this -- we still had a great time.  

The low point of the meal was when my friend's fish arrived and the waiter had it about 3 inches from my face in order to set it down on my far side, but hadn't given me any indication that he was there. (and I was looking the other direction.)
author: Matt K.

description:
I used to love this place and gave them five stars.  I got sick on their Chicken Hash last week and haven't recovered since.  

You're taking your chances if you go there.  Stick to the cocktails.
author: M L.

description: Great food and service. Also, great music and atmosphere. Fun! Dress up and dig this place.
author: Chris O.

description:
My friends took me here for a girls night out to celebrate my getting married. We got lost trying to find it but the place looked really cool from the outside, it is in this alley. Good thing there is valet parking for only $10, that was awesome.

We got a table upstairs with a nice view of the bar. The service is extremely slow but I guess that gives you time to enjoy the food and ambiance of the place. 

I ordered the crab rolls and lobster pasta. The crab rolls were on the salty side and the pasta was just ok. What I did enjoy was the deep fried oysters, that was delicious but you only get 4 small pieces!! We also tried the steak tartar and foie gras just to see what the fuss is about... they were just ok too. The only other thing that I did enjoy was the Kobe steak. The desserts did not impress me much, I got the brownie and butterscotch...the brownie was regular and the butterscotch was way too sweet for me. It  might have been better if it came wit ice cream instead of just whipped cream. I did  not like my friend's sorbet (grapefruit and tangerine) they were way too sour. The other thing I did not like was my sprite, ack!!! It tasted nasty, did not taste like sprite at all.

I'll just give it 2 stars for the chic look of the place.
author: Christine P.

description: I've been here for lunch and dinner and I love it every time!!.  It's a great deal when they have the prixe fix menu for dine around town.  It is a destination restaurant and a unique San Francisco experience.  Highly recommend it if you have visitors.
author: Karen C.

description:
Old-school American classics like steak tartare (prepared tableside), marrow bones, an upscale burger, and servers in white jackets, but without feeling outdated. The atmosphere seems especially suited to a nice business dinner or lunch for the FiDi environs; I almost felt out of place for celebrating a birthday there instead of a sweet business deal or job promotion. Everything was good, though not outstanding, except for the butterscotch brownies (elegantly presented in small "fingers") which were highly addictive. Solid, classic American cuisine.

*Full disclosure: the bf is friends with the sous chef, but I'm pretty sure our experience wasn't enhanced in any way because of the connection. Also, we once ran into him shopping for the restaurant at the Ferry Plaza Farmers' Market which seemed pretty cool to me. They really do go for *market* fresh!
author: J C.

description:
the experience was disappointing.  we were 10 minutes late for our 6pm reservation and the matradee gave us shit for it.  wtf. 

the waiter was really nice though.  a little jabberie, but still a pro.  

tuna tartare - the chips used were soggy.  but the tuna was hella good. 
we had some kind of grilled cheese kinda thing... i dont know wha tit was but it was delicious. tasted like grilled cheese. but im too lazy to go look up the name
chicken hash... i dont know. 20 bucks for chicken potpie mixed into patties. i dont know why this is popular. 
fish. dont get it. just dont it was overcooked. 
pork brisket.  i dont like stewed meat. so i cant say anything about this. 
fliet mignon was delicious. its the best part yo.
author: Doug ..

description: Came here for a birthday once and it was awesome. Loved the ambiance and the food. Great decor and date spot. Live jazz band and singer. Loved the little alley location. Very reminiscent of the Speak easy era. An excuse to dress up and close to North Beach hot spots.
author: Ro M.

description:
Strolling down a dark back alley a glowing blue sign reading "BIX" beckons one towards a simple brick facade with little candle lit tables and chairs perched out front.  Stepping through the heavy dark doors, one steps back in time to an era where cold champagne accompanies hot jazz in luxurious digs with delicious food.  My husband and I settled into a cozy booth for his birthday dinner and gazed out upon the lengthy mirror backed bar under a beautiful mural.  Beside us an elderly man played jazz on a grand piano.  The white tuxedoed waiters were attentive, informative and ready to give suggestions on what we must try.  My husband had the ceviche appetizer which may have been my favorite item we tried with its lime sauce, avocado and bit of crunchy nuts atop it.  He followed this with the Kobe steak which he said met all his wildest dreams.  I somehow managed to order an entire meal that I could eat with my hands starting with "truffled cheese croques" which amounts to the tastiest mini grilled cheese sandwiches I have ever had, and that I followed with mini lamb burgers and truffled french fries.  Oh...and somewhere in there I had a ginger gimlet which was a delight, though not as gingery as I had hoped.  Still, all were a delight!  We wrapped up the meal with the banana foster which was both decadent and the perfect blend of hot and cold.  mmmm...good.  It came with a classy birthday card and candles too...and I didn't even remind them of my husbands birthday after including the info on a note with my opentable.com reservation.  
Thank you BIX, for taking us back in time to another world both romantic and filled with the trappings of an era that has passed but is somehow kept alive in this hidden alley in the heart of SF.
author: Lindsay S.

description: 1 star for food, 4 star for ambiance, bar area, good date place.  Overpriced, pretty crappy food.  But, nice vibe, live music, feels like you are back in classy times.  But man, the food was not good.
author: Mark B.

description:
Fantastic ambiance; high ceilings, tall columns, and an upper seating area overlooking the main restaurant.

Jazz band adds to the classy atmosphere.

Food is great; try the lamb sliders.  Interesting drink menu as well, I had the huckleberry fizz.  Nice!
author: Nate H.

description: Although we were sat 20 min late (we were on time), the service was very good. I never had an empty water glass. The food, while expensive, was excellent.
author: Norman F.

description:
I am a fan indeed.

Expensive and quasi elite but in a way that includes you... you somewhat expect that.

Went there to celebrate a birthday... Our waiter and server were polite yet very human. Characters almost like Laurel and Hardy. They surprised the birthday girl with two desserts for free (because they couldn't decide which one she'd like). Every aspect of the meal was delicious; however, the cliched concept of nice restaurants and small portions was apparent. Not overly so, but keep that in mind.

Oh and it is in an ally. That is pretty rad and true to the speak-easy/supper club vibe... wouldn't work otherwise. Go here.
author: JAYCE B.

description:
Nice Ambiance for a Romantic dinner date.  I liked the background music, the high ceilings and even the Alley Way location.  This walk into the Alley to get there really made it a unique and mysterious way of getting to the restaurant.  Like you were on a search and just found a hidden treasure like Gold...  

Oh wait, this Alley IS called Gold Street.  Ahhh, no wonder it has that magical feeling.  One of my associates knew one of the managers here so all we had to do was mention his name and we received VIP service.  Maybe they make everyone feel this way...  We did get a complementary appetizer Foie Gras.  Probably my first time trying it so that was definitely SWEET and something additional to make my visit here memorable.
author: Mark W.

description:
I rarely say that any restaurant gets top honors, but i must say Bix is best!... or at least one of the best.  I am a staunch believer that great food is best when paired with great company and great service.  And the service here was SUPERB.  We got there on time but the tables were a bit backed up.  The maitre D profusely apologized and offered a round of drinks from the bar on the house.  We were in no rush and enjoying our conversation with friends.  Never did complain or even seem annoyed by the wait and still to top it off he brought us a Tuna carpaccio appetizer on the house when we were seated.  
The food was excellent!  The tomato cart was outstandingly fresh, the grilled calamari delicious, and the oysters magnifique!

Our waiter had great knowledge about each dish, and was great when asked for recommendations.  Entrees like the lobster spaghetti, full large chunks of lobster in a creamy sauce, and the pork chops cooked just right were all excellent. 

To top off the night we shared some chocolate brioche bread pudding that was tasty as well.  

Again I can rave enough about the service!  Try Bix for a special dinner or just come for some classic cocktails, you won't be disappointed!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I recently went to Bix for a business dinner with some colleagues. It's a beautiful venue although I can't say I was satisfied with my meal. Great although pricey wine list. I had the steak tartare prepared table side, was pretty good but not worth 10 minute explanation from our waitress on the origin of the beef, egg and crackers. I had the ahi tuna for the main course, decent but not anything extraordinary with 4 pieces of fish. Others had pork shoulder, trout and the salmon. 

The service was pretty bad though. Our waitress/"certified sommelier"  was so snooty with plenty of condescending remarks throughout the meal. Plenty of "you will have the salmon if we have run out of trout", or "you can't possibly know how may day is going to go since it is too early". Anyhow, you get the point. This is SF, not NYC. Chill out, you are serving people food not performing brain surgery.

Since the food was only pretty good and pricey, I don't think I am going to be back and avoid subjecting the missus to repeat experience.
author: Oleg P.

description:
Not sure how this place is so highly rated, as I feel as if I dined at a completely different restaurant. The service was disappointing at best from the moment we arrived. No one at the hostess stand to greet us for several minutes; a server who refused to help bring our cocktails and drinks over to the table when we were seated; an unfriendly waiter who was offensive when I told him of my food allergy and completely inattentive; no one in sight to say goodbye as we left. I can assure you I'll never return.

As for the food...the appetizers were forgettable, but they turned out to be the best part of our meal. My piece of fish was so severely under-cooked I had to stop eating a few bites in. As for dessert, their misinterpretation of what bread pudding entails is just comical. I would avoid the trip and save your money for any of the other $50/entree meals in the city.
author: S.J. B.

description:
"WTF?  Where is Gold Street?"  you might ask.  I would have to answer you with "Well, right by my office--lucky me!"

My director took us to lunch at Bix today--because she rocks like that--and we took a little-known short cut through an old, bricked-up alley called Gold Street.  Must have been named during the Gold Rush when all the scallywags were coming up into SF to raise hell and debauch with loose women.

In any event, the aura is very dramatic and dark; baby grand in the corner and immense oil portraits, one in particular rather disturbing, as it features a clown making out with a flapper...but I digress...

And I must note that they are one of the few places in town who still hand out wooden matches--very choice.

The offer a sweet wine list but I did not feel at liberty to order a glass, as I am a fairly new employee.  One might choose an Arnold Palmer, or a mineral water if one is being treated by one's boss at a noontime luncheon.  

The daily special was the Bix Special, which was a 3-course meal for $24, with 2 different salads, entrees and desserts from which to choose.  

I ordered the HEIRLOOM TOMATO SOUP, with a petite grilled goat cheese sandwich for dipping; CHICKEN HASH, which had one of the loveliest presntations ever--flanked by cherry tomatoes and made into 2 large patties consisting of pulled roasted chicken, corn, goat cheese, and scallions; and for dessert, the CHOCOLATE BREAD PUDDING, which was baked into a 10oz ramekin and seemed to consist solely of chocolate cake and mousse.  

The server pulled a brilliant move, which I have seldom seen.  She offered us coffee BEFORE our dessert arrived.  Smart.  The coffee was above average, as well.

I walked out with a leftover chicken hash pattie, a full belly, a choco-caffeine buzz, and a box of wooden matches.  Who could ask for more?
author: Hannah A.

description:
Came her for my two year anniversary and the whole experience could not have been more perfect!  Service was on point, there was a live pianist who i got to play a song for us, and the food...oh man...the food was fresh, tasty, made to perfection.  We had
Steak Tartar
Potatoe Pillows w/ caviar
oysters on a half shell
Mozzerella and Prociutto
Lobster Spagetti 
Kobe Steak

Amazing!!
author: Steph S.

description: Had dinner at Bix a couple of weeks ago. Started with an excellent martini at the bar. Bix is the kind of place that makes you want to have a martini. We were sat at a cozy booth in the corner, there were 6 of us, and the booth sat all of us very comfortably.  Started with the ceviche appetizer, oysters and some salads. All very good, the ceviche was soo good, we ordered another. I had the lobster pasta, which was delicious, and not too rich. My husband had the special trout, and our friends had the steaks. We were all very happy. The service was good, and the piano perfect in the background. We had a wonderful evening .
author: Elen C.

description:
Kevin and I joined Jerry at the bar, starting with what could arguably be considered the best Sidecar I've ever had. Served in smallish martini glasses, dusted with sugar and made with Germain Robin brandy, it was the perfect apertif to start the evening.

For me, much of the draw of Bix (and a reason I would definitely go back) is its old-world charm. A piano and torch singer providing background ambience and white-coated waiters providing impeccable service only adds to the charm of what would otherwise be considered a flash from the past.

For Jerry's birthday, we ordered a bottle of '95 A.R. Lenoble Grand Cru Brut to accompany half-a-dozen oysters and warm, crunchy gougres. This segued nicely into a round of hors d'oeuvres that we all shared; potato pillows with crme frache and American sturgeon caviar, Kampachi crudo with blood orange, fennel, daikon, and Fiordolio olive oil, and a torchon of foie gras with French brandied cherries. Hard-pressed to pick a favorite of the three with the potato pillows most definitely billowy and light, the crudo fresh and flavorful, and the foie gras silky and elegant.

Jerry and Kevin opted for full entres and I for another, smaller dish served with an '01 Gevry-Chambertin Premiere Cru Lavaux Saint Jacques Esmonin. Jerry chose the fish selection of the day, Diver scallops with favas, fennel, fresh parsley oil, and a variety of other flavors... Kevin ordered the rack of lamb which we are having as a left-over breakfast this morning, served with Lentils du Puy and minted carrots, they were tender enough to be eaten like lollipops -- picked up and bitten freely at will with easy tenderness.

My weekness and third course? Tableside-prepared steak tartare. I love tableside service and watching our lovely waiter, Douglas, deftly hand cut and blend the Creekstone Angus beef with dijon mustard, capers, shallots, and quail egg was truly amazing.

A note on service -- the first bottle of Gevry-Chambertin was not entirely corked but a tad off. I expressed my concern that there was a bit too much barnyard funk and there was nary a fuss on bringing a second bottle. Both Douglas, the waiter, and the sommelier, another Kevin, agreed there was some bottle variation and enjoyed tasting along with us to compare.

For Jerry's birthday, he chose the Meyer lemon pana cotta with huckleberries and a glass of Armagnac. I was concerned that the lemon and huckleberry might be too sweet, but there was more an essence of candied lemon rind with darker, pronounced lemon flavors. Kevin and I shared a cheese plate; he with a 1970 Graham port and I with a '96 Rieussac. I mentioned to Douglas my waffling on wanting a bite of chocolate and our cheese plate had a small dish of Vahlrona sauce and a few chocolate tablets, just to appease my craving. The perfect end to a perfect evening.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
Very Pretentious restaurant but why? My foie gras was average, my Char had zero sauce, and the best of the worst was the chocolate "brioche" that was nothing but a vulgar brownie. It's not because you give items on the menu french names that they gain this tasteful lightness like a french brioche would have... What I ordered was everything but light more like cement to me...
Would not recommend at all, on top of that the restauranrt is super noisy
author: Carpe D.

description:
Tucked away on a tight, cobblestone side street lays Bix, a restaurant that will take you on a delightful, cuinary ride.  The place has that old 1920's speak easy vibe;  the waiters, the decor, it all just brings you back to another time and place.  Sitting in the restaurant, we all commented on how we could be just about "anywhere" at that moment. 

Now to the important stuff: ORDER THE CHICKEN HASH!  It's rich, but it's pretty damn amazing.  The heirloom tomato appetizer is nice as well.  A couple at our table ordered the clam roll - I didnt get a taste (bastards), but it looked so good!
Drink menu is also solid - the Bix Rickey is a refreshing treat, made up of vodka, soda, lime and fresh strawberry juices.  
Dessert: Brioche bread pudding - amen.
author: Heather P.

description: Great vibe, dark lighting, jazz band, great bar, not too crowded, and pretty awesome martini. Would definitely go back and hang out here again. Sat at the bar and ordered the $28 truffle oil burger because we wanted to know what a $28 hamburger tasted like. The burger was pretty good. it was stuffed with black truffle, cheesy, juicy and good size. But it was open faced (a little disappointed) and eating a burger with a knife and fork just doesn't taste as good as holding it with your hands. I don't think it was wirth the $28.
author: Cori B.

description:
I love BIX. I mean, the place looks like it hasn't changed substantially since Herb Cain used to camp out here; it probably won't change when nuclear war hits, and frankly I'm okay with that. They've got a formula. It's worked really well for a couple of decades. Why change brilliance, right?

So when the Russians finally invade, you'll find me at the bar at BIX, knocking back their Bloody Marys (which are truly the best in the city, possibly in the world, with the grand exception of the top secret family recipe), plowing through potato pillows, and scooping up bone marrow with sea salt for all that I'm worth. Oh and the chicken hash. And the steak tartare. When you're storing up to survive nuclear holocaust, you need all the calories you can get, right?
author: Poonam S.

description:
My wife and I went to dinner here for our 4th anniversary back in April.  If you can get a booth up on the balcony I strongly recommend it.  The food and service were quite good.  The ambiance of the place from our vantage point (the middle of the balcony) was fantastic.  We had a commanding view of the huge mural and it was fun to people watch the MBA bar scene down below.  

My wife and I are not usually dessert people, but the waiter really made a good pitch, so we decided to split a bananas foster.  I thought I'd had a bananas foster before, but apparently they were all made by incompetent fools.  This is the bananas foster by which all others will be judged for the rest of my life.  It still holds the record for most delicious thing I've put in my mouth all year.

As far as value goes, this is an elegant place and you will pay accordingly.  However, you will get what you pay for.
author: Matt T.

description: Ended up here for a work dinner (as most do) and while I'd been to the bar before, I'd never dined. I went with the beef medallions for appetizer and the Ahi for main. Both were very good and I'd definitely head back. I never saw the bill but I'm very familiar with the drink prices so put this one on the company to enjoy it that much more.
author: Dave W.

description:
BEST BAR to re-live your old Gordon Gekko, trying to be bull market Wall street.  Old school bartenders with the white jackets are the BEST!  So stick to the classic cocktails, martinis, manhattans, mai tais....But beware of those wanna-be bar hogs who are on their best impression date with their ring hungry companions.  Trying to reach through them to grab your drink at the bar is sometimes rough.

Best thing to do is sit at the bar and eat the potato pillows with Caviar and their bone marrow, all while sipping on Rose Champagne. Tres Chic.

I would give Bix 5 stars if there was actually a good entree to eat on the menu.  The only good thing is the Lobster spaghetti.....
author: Lesley H.

description: this is by far the best place i found with an amazing 3 piece band and cocktails!
author: Kenneth K.

description: The best thing about this place is the atmosphere. Food is good. Not great. Service is good. Not awesome. Bix is located in an awesome spot. No views or anything but thats part of the atmosphere. Its located down an alley which is lit up buy their neon "bix" sign. It looks like you're going into a jazz club in chicago but once you go through the door you can't believe the size of the place. You are expecting a tiny, sweaty, club, but....
author: Chris Y.

description: My husband (boyfriend at the time) took me here for my birthday.  Previously, we hit BIX for a martini and we really wanted to come back for dinner.  This place did not disappoint.  The vibe is sophisticated and retro, the food is unbelievable and the service was great.  You can't go wrong here (unless you don't have disposable income).
author: Alena W.

description:
My friends and I have a bad habit of spending a LOT of money on birthday dinners, and last week at Bix was no exception.  But it was worth it:

As a vegetarian, I often feel like I get the short end of the stick when I go out with my meat-eating friends, as I can usually eat less than half the dishes that are ordered.  But Bix has a number of delicious veggie-friendly appetizers, and the waiter was excited to tell me about their veggie entree plate, which was actually a totally yummy and filling version of one of their fish dishes.  I felt that the food I ate was just as gourmet as the fancy meat everyone else ate.

We drank about three bottles of wine and we all had at least one cocktail.  The drinks were great- try the Gimlet, it's sooo refreshing.  And the dessert was WORTH IT- we shared the bananas foster, the chocloate souffle, and the apple tart (that one wasn't quite as good).  Considering there were 9 of us and we were all stuffed with truly superior food, I don't feel that $120 dollars a person was too bad.

The decor is very elegant, and I actually enjoyed the low-key piano player and lounge singer (sometimes they really annoy me).

The service was great- my group is loud and we love to let everyone know what a great time we're having.  Our waiter was right there with us the whole time, laughing and taking pictures for us, and at the end of the night he told us to let the bartender at Cigar Bar know he'd sent us over- and we all got free shots.  Not a bad set-up.

Summary: The best of SF FiDi without the pretention.
author: Shari T.

description: We went for a formal dinner and it was a wonderful experience. The dishes were great and the service impecable.
author: Luca R.

description: It was a last min Yelp recommendation while vacationing in SF.  Service was amazing, staff went out of their way to accomodate vegan/allergies.  The food was excellent as well, especially the vegan coconut sorbet!
author: Chris B.

description:
I had a good meal here - it was a little out my typical price range for a meal, but I have no regrets on the money spent.

I started off with the chilled hearts of romaine with Point Reyes Blue Cheese dressing - very tasty but I think it was covered in too much dressing.

Although they aren't any vegetarian main courses listed on their menu, they can accommodate by making a dish of the vegetable sides (their veggies are sourced all from local farmers) - mine included creamed spinach, whipped potatoes, broccoli raab and grilled squash and ricotta napoleon - all of which were excellent.

Dessert was the decadent warm chocolate brioche bread pudding.

Service was excellent - very cordial and attentive.
author: Sean G.

description:
I actually went here a few times because of work. I got there a little late one night and I couldn't find a parking spot! (No parking in SF, HOW CRAZY!). Anyways, this kind transient/hobo/smelly fellow found me a spot and I gave him five dollars. He was totally stoked and most likely spent well that night after downing some purple drank we commonly call the 'tussin.


Back to the dinner.... the interior is really nice, like a 40's jazz club complete with old guy on piano. It's a split level place so you can eat on the second floor and feel superior to the peons on the lower level. The place frowns on spitting from the second floor, be advised. The wine selection was great and the food was prepared well. The desserts were also a great surprise. Chocolate bread pudding was a win win.
author: Erik U.

description:
What an awesome experience...  

Took my hunny here for her birthday last night and it was a first time for both of us.  The entrance is tucked away on Gold street and was so unassuming and simple from the outside that once we went in we were shocked at the atmosphere.  Awesome little speakeasy feel to it.  Dimly lit, soft piano playing, a lively mahogany bar and cozy, candle lit tables.  The place was pretty busy, but since most patrons made reservations (I requested a private booth so my date and I could make out, but no such luck!)  there were no lengthy wait times or difficulty getting a drink at the bar.  

The drink selection is great - red, white and sparkling wines available by the glass or bottle, several signature cocktails, (try the ginger gimlet made with Hangar One) and even a great after dinner drink menu.
The food was absolutely amazing.  We started with the Steak Tartare and it was incredible.  She had the duck, I had the filet and they were both freakin heaven in my pie hole.  Our sides were also great - I had some mashed taters and she had some wacky little rice mixed with mushrooms of which I ended up eating the majority.  We finished with a complimentary sorbet for two and a marc after dinner drink.  

The service was even better than the food - if that is even possible.  We were greeted immediately once we entered and offered a table right away, (despite being 45 minutes early for our reservation.)  We opted to wait and start with a drink at the bar while we relaxed a bit and listened to the piano.  Once we were seated, our waiter took the time to explain the menu and answered a few of our questions.  After the meal, unsolicited, he delivered our complimentary dessert for my date, complete with a candle for her burfday.  So I jumped up on the piano and serenaded her with my jazz flute as she definitely deserved...  Our waiter didn't want the surrounding tables to feel left out so he even delivered them complimentary desserts...  Quite a gesture!  We chatted it up with them and they, too, were having just as awesome experience as we were.  

Needless to say, we had an incredible time.  Everything was perfect and made for a memorable experience.  We will definitely go back.  If you haven't been, I would STRONGLY encourage you to go check it out.  You will not be disappointed!
author: Sean O.

description:
it was excellent, stupid expensive, but excellent 

i've said it before, i'll say it again. i love places in alleys. 
the decor was great, we sat up in the balcony (oooh fancy) 
we had our cloth napkins in our laps and sh*t;) 
nice live music, attentive staff. it was my friends b-day dinner and they had a little "happy b-day" card waiting for her on the table 

all the food was amazing. the crab app, the asparagus soup 
MINI LAMB BURGERS!!! yum 
the dirty martinis were strong and perfectly dirty
author: kiki b.

description: One of the best dinners I've had in a while.  I had what was one of the best steaks I've ever had.  Great atmosphere.  Liked the live jazz playing in the background.  Would love to go back again soon.
author: Jeff S.

description:
LOVE this place. An elegant restaurant with an "old-style jazz club" feel to it that, surprisingly, was not stuffy at all. 

4 out of the 5 dishes we ordered were excellent, and that's amazing considering how picky I am. It was only the Alaskan halibut that was a little dry, but the side of corn, bell peppers, and cherry tomatoes surely made up for it. 

For my appetizer, I ordered the heirloom tomatoes with mozzarella cheese - which is a seasonal signature dish of Bix's - and it totally lived up to the hype! Ok, so you get like 3 slices of tomato for $14 but they may be the sweetest, juiciest tomatoes you will ever try. 

Overall, great food, great atmosphere, fairly easy parking, and great service. Even the bread was good!
author: Cee J.

description:
One of my best girlfriends was up here for her birthday, and BIX was suggested to me by my foodie friend, Pete -- with the disclaimer that BIX screamed my name, and... I could not agree more!

BIX reminds me of the old school style of Tadich Grill meets the classy touch of a truly top echelon eating establishment.

They have valet (which is a complete necessity for me if I am going to go up to the city), a coat check (old school), great personnel, a luxurious setting and even better menu.

We had the best seat of the house upstairs center overlooking the whole restaurant.  It was perfect! 

We started with a bottle of their most reasonable champagne  -- which totally rivaled Veuve, and we ordered the steak tartare which is prepared tableside to your liking and is very, very good!

Entree-wise -- while there is a great selection from duck to foie gras to Kobe steak, I actually decided to indulge in the $30 truffled cheeseburger .... which was worth every cent & calorie.  It was seriously the best burger I have ever had!  There were truffles inside the burger, the pecorino cheese was truffled and the fries were drizzled with truffle oil! It was truffle madness!

I would highly recommend coming here for great service and fantastic food.
author: Christina P.

description:
Since I love fine dining it's strange that it's taken me so long to try Bix (Aqua was so disappointing that I stopped listening to the reviews of new food places). The decor was a dream since I love Art Deco! The service splendid and we cheated with the menu and only ordered appetizers but what a feast (foise gras, brioche crabs, ceviche, caviar, etc...)

LOVE IT!
author: N. M.

description:
We have been here a few times (my hubby and I).  We love the decor of the place, the drinks, and food. We have always scored with the service - always great.  

First - the ambiance:  1920s Supper Club.  Its got a great feel to it.  

Second, the drinks: I have never been disappointed by Bix' martini drinks.  We order either lemondrops or kamikazes and I have yet to get a bartender with a light hand on the liquor and a mix that is shaken to perfection. 

 Last: the food. We have dined here twice with the dine about town menu and then once with the regular menu.  They have never disappointed me.  We love the steak tartar to start with and the chicken hash is amazing.  

I highly recommend BIX for a date or when you crave amazing drinks and food in a great setting.
author: Ingrid P.

description:
Bix is good food. Some dishes are great here like their pork chops. Yum... felt like butter in my mouth. Since one reviewer posted a limerick here, I'll post my Ode To Bacon since the way they do their pork is solid:

Bacon, oh, bacon
You wonderful thing!
The tigers and lions
All rise and sing!

The grease that comes
From your rich loins
Are an unequal sum
To millions of coins.

Breakfast, lunch, dinner
Teatime, bartime, late night too!
Every meal is a winner
And more enjoyable with you! 

(full poem at http://bernardmoon.blogspot.com/2003/08/ode-to-bacon-bacon-oh-bacon-you.html)
author: Bernard M.

description:
5 Stars for the fond memories of pre-Prom dinner (a table of a dozen teenagers must have been traumatizing for the restaurant as quiet and upscale as this).  But that was ten years ago.

1 Star for making me throw up after the Dine About Town lunch special.  I have not had food poisoning since childhood and was not expecting it from some fancy pants restaurant like Bix.
author: Candice B.

description:
Bix is a great spot. Classic, old school feeling restaurant with an awesome bar and cocktails. 
Service was great and the ambience was as well. Fridays and Saturdays they have a live Jazz band that rounds out the experience. 
Some have noted that it was a little expensive, and it is. That should be expected when you go here. It's not a hole in the wall joint (although I do love a hole in the wall). This is a nice, upscale restaurant and in my opinion they hit all the points of such (service, decor, ambience, food, drinks etc). 
Started with martini's and manhattan's, both of which were fabulous. The potato pillows were a good, light, starter and rather unique. 
For the entrees, we had the Lobster spaghetti and the Veal chop. 
The lobster spaghetti was good, and there was plenty of lobster, but it was a bit dry for me. I like a little more sauce, or maybe just a bit more olive oil. Nevertheless, it was good. That would be the only 4 star portion of the night. 
The veal chop, on the other hand, needs more than 5 stars. This was amazing. A great piece of meat, cooked perfectly, and topped with some type of lightly creamy sauce. I don't remember what the sauce was, but I'll be back for it. The waiter also recommended a perfect wine to pair with it. It was a bourgogne of some sort. 

One of the better dinners I've had in a while.
author: T M.

description:
WOW

Very impressed with the food for dinner
- Truffle Fries are AMAZING.  Some of the best fries I've ever had.
- Potato Pillows are super soft and light, but the caviar on it is overpowered by the crème fraîche.
- "A la minute" Ceviche is perfect in flavor and love the extra crunch of the toasted corn nuts
- Torchon of Artisan Foie Gras was tasty but maybe could have been closer to room temperature
- Chicken Hash ala Bix, simply amazing and unique.
- Lobster Spaghetti is a really big portion and lots of pieces of lobster in it.
author: Jay Y.

description:
My first time here was awesome!  We got there a little early on a Sunday night.  We sat at the bar and had a few cocktails.  My buddy, Tyler, and I ordered oyster shooters.  Even thought they don't actually have them on the menu the bartender whipped a couple up for us... and the a couple more and so on.  One of the best oyster shooters I have ever had.  Later the bartender brought us a sample of their home made motzerella.  My girlfriend selfishly snatched both hers and my piece so we later ordered it as one of our appetizers.  So on to dinner...

Appetizers:
Homemade Motzerella - So good my girlfriend initially stole mine..grrrr!  The motzerella melted in your mouth while the prosciutto added a nice salty flavor.  

Ceviche - I always like ceviche but the corn nuts were delicious.  it gave the fish some good texture.  Jalepenos added good heat as well.

Fries - Fries are fries....good but meh

Main Course 

Scallops (my girlfriend) - Cooked just right but i don't think this is on the menu anymore.

Lobster Spaghetti (Em and Me)- Very delicious!  I have actually come back to this restaurant 2 additional times to have this dish.  It's a cream sauce but I think what makes exceptional are the cherry tomatoes.

Kobe Beef Em and Me)- Decent but not as good as I hoped.  

I can't remember what Tyler ordered that night but it was over a year ago since we first went...

Dessert

NO ROOM FOR DESSERT!!!!  = (

Some additional marks, food servers were very attentive and conversational.  The artwork on the second floor is really cool but the painting of the clown on the first floor creeps me out but I don't really like clowns either.  

This would usually be a 4 star restaurant because I think they missed on the Kobe beef dish but the great service pushed it to a 5 star.
author: Brent G.

description:
Really impressed. We went here tonight for my birthday.  I work in the restaurant industry so when we were running late I called to let them know. They were so glad we called, the waiter sent a free appetizer(the most expensive one on the menu) to our table. The service was great and our waiter suggested items on the menu. 
I had the pork chops - juicy flavorful and very filling
My boyfriend had the club burger - amazingly juicy and tasteful. Not too salty or bland

I would definately go again. We sat upstairs so we could see below. They brought candles on my red velvet cake(which I hogged cuz it was mouth watering!) and even the manager thanked us when we left! No complaints here
author: Stefanie L.

description: Classy, elegant atmosphere on a quiet back alley-type street off Columbus. Delicious food, excellent service, lively bar... it scores high in everything. One of my favorite SF restaurants.
author: Tyler D.

description:
We love it -3rd time for us now over the last few years and Bix has been consistent through all the visits. Last time was Jan 2010.

I love the back alley (valet makes parking easy) transformation into the interesting interior with the art deco look, cool paintings, busy bar scene, and casual elegant white tuxed staff. Never have had seating issues and the wait staff is knowledgeable, helpful, fun, not snooty, and they don't rush you through a meal - I have never felt like too much time was passing between courses. It is energetic there, sometimes a bit loud, but even with the crowd and the jazz trio all going we could still talk fine.

The food itself is extremely good - not the best in SF but it's my style.

Drinks:
Nice wine list.
The martini is the best I've ever had.

Appetizers tried:
truffled deviled eggs, marrow bones, crab rolls, potato pillows, firecracker shrimp, Pacific oysters, foie gras, and shaved halibut ceviche. The deviled eggs, marrow bones, and oysters were high quality and super delicious.

Main courses:
Tried duck, rack of lamb, lobster spaghetti, and the truffled pecorino cheeseburger. The cheeseburger is incredible.

There are better pure food experiences but this is my favorite overall dining destination in SF. Have fun!
author: Frank D.

description:
I am totally underwhelmed by BIX.  I've experienced both lunch and dinner and I think it's over-priced and over-rated.

The environment does dazzle and make you feel as though you've traveled back in time to a classy 1930s speakeasy.  I adore the elegance and spaciousness of the two level dining room.  Even the restaurant's location on a small alley in Jackson Square's antique row nestled between North Beach, Chinatown and the Financial District adds to the charm and mood of this supper club.

The drink selection here is top notch if you are into the finer alcohols.  And the mahogany bar is magnificent.  But for the expense, the food is just okay.  Salads are over-dressed and my stuffed pork tenderloin was  raw in the center.  Everything else I've had or tasted has been totally passable, but I have never found anything to be truly outstanding.

I'm just glad that all of my BIX dining excursions have been on the company tab, because you won't find me spending my hard earned cash at this fancy-pants super club.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Beautiful restaurant. If you are looking for a romantic atmosphere this is a pretty great pick. The live jazz music did have us talking at full volume but it was worth it. 

The service: We waited a while despite the fact that we had reservations, which was quite annoying while wearing heels. However, once we were seated we had an ever so charming and cute waiter who was really helpful while ordering and attentive during dinner without being annoying. 

The food: Be prepared for pricey. I don't think any entree was under $25, but having had the crab pasta dish and sampling most of the dishes my friends ordered, I can say the food is excellent. However, I would recommend skipping the potato pillow appetizer. It's a glorified tater tot that you pay $12 for.
author: Nihad P.

description:
BIX was not what I was expecting.

Based on the menu, I thought it would be upscale hipster. In reality, it was classic 30's (20's?) decor with a large bar and seating along the perimeter upstairs. I was really blown away by the atmosphere -- when we arrived, we decided to pretend we were there to plan a heist. Not a bank heist either -- a jewel heist because it's a classy joint.

Unfortunately, the food and the service didn't live up to our initial impressions. Our waitress was a cold fish. Not mean or anything, but she just didn't exhibit much personality even when greeting us. And given the prices and the size of the tip she'd receive, that's just not acceptible. It's fine to say "They're both good" when we ask which dessert she'd recommend, but perhaps she could've expanded on that a bit.

The food was good -- very good, actually. I had the chicken hash, which is basically chicken salad with some corn fried up like a crab cake. I was particularly happy because I'm allergic to crab so this was my opportunity to partake in an entree similar to one that I'm forbidden to ever eat.

Everyone liked their entree, but nobody liked their dessert. We actually all got the same thing -- the chocolate bread pudding. The description sounded really great, and after having excellent bread pudding experiences at Home on Market and Palomino, I had high expectations for BIX. But what we got was a mediocre pudding with an odd texture and a massive dollop of whipped cream where ice cream would have been more appropriate. The chocolate was actually very good -- a nice dark cocoa. But the dessert was a major disappointment.

Bad dessert + cranky waitress + high prices = 3 stars. Sorry BIX, I really wanted to like you.
author: Scott K.

description: The atmosphere was grand.  The food was amazing.   We had Crab rolls, American Kobe steak, Chicken mash, and banana icecream.  We enjoyed each of them.  There was no live music until 7:30pm, so I suggest you go later if you like live music.  But if you prefer an intimate quiet time with your date (or family or friends), go when it opens at 5:30pm.  You'll most likely get the best table.
author: Jessica N.

description: Bix was a great find for our group of out-of-towners.  It is completely hidden away and has an old school feel.  The live music was nice and not too loud.  Good food, great service.  I would highly recommend this place for a romantic night or even a group dinner.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Bix is San Francisco.

front of house makes everyone feel like they are rockstars...

brilliant and knock you out martinis.
author: Matt K.

description: Great atmosphere. Took a little while to get a drink menu, but when we got it, it was nice, simple and seasonal. Service at the bar a little gruff to start but finished well. Points off only for the shaken 'sazerac' made with angostura bitters and pikesville rye.
author: Valter F.

description:
Came here with the BF and his mom a few months back. First off- minus one start only because the waiter told us to essentially "hurry up" when we asked for a few more minutes to order our entrees.

Besides the douche bag waiter- the food and ambiance deserve a 5. We started with  the ceviche and truffle oil fries. I ordered the halibut as did mom-to-be. Cooked to perfection, served with corn, panchetta and can't remember because I was melting away on the table. BF ordered the lobster pasta which  he said was good but I can't attest to it since I was too busy with my plate.

For dessert we ordered some chocolatey-bread-pudding-ish thing. Was ok, tasted like warm chocolate cake to me.
author: Raya K.

description:
Damn- this place is goooood. I had some friends visiting from out of town and wanted to take them somewhere nice. Everyone was more than happy with their meals. It was one of those experiences where you take a bite, close your eyes, sit back and just let it sink in. 

My favorite dish was the Tomato Cart - imagine this...6 different seasonal tomatoes, fresh mozzarella made daily in their kitchen, topped with fresh basil, olive oil from Sebastopol, vinegar from a local winery, coarse sea salt, and fresh ground pepper. I just made myself hungry.

The entrees were just as impressive as the tomato appetizer - the steak blew me away - and the service was top notch in every way. 

My one and only complaint about the evening was that the place is so popular, that the crowd tends to overpower the volume of the singer/pianist. Next time I go I will make an effort to get a ground floor table right next to the performance. BTW- their regular vocalist is fantastic too.
author: John C.

description:
Very very fancy and classy place. Loved the general ambiance and setting. Came here for our anniversary and my wife was very pleased with the evening. Loved the Jazz style atmosphere.

Started off with the Ceviche which was very spicy. Never had it with habeneros before and helped give it a little bit more kick that I am used to. 

For the main course, I decided to hit it big a get the Kobe Steak. This had to be one of the top 5 steaks I have ever had in my life. It was super tender and melted in my mouth.

Shared the Bananas Foster for dessert and was the perfect end to a prefect evening.

I would recommended BIX for anyone looking for  special evening. The place really defines class and elegance.
author: Chino B.

description:
Prix fixe menu is where it's at. I'm not sure whether it changes regularly but I think it's the best deal on the menu and allows you to try a little of everything. Only downside is that it's limited to two entrees but they picked two good ones the night I was there (pork tenderloin and a chicken dish). 

I read on Yelp that the creme brulee made someone cry so obviously I had to try it. I personally was not moved to tears but I could see how someone would be. It was that good.
author: Asheley W.

description:
Bix is a great place to catch a drink after work with a friend... as long as your friend is buying!  It's swanky (and often "mature") crowd can be entertaining to rub elbows with. It is typically standing room only, but wait it out and be rewarded with a place at the bar. Their complimentary Chex mix is not without its charm. The bar tenders are quick and attentive and certainly on top of not only refilling your glass but also the Chex mix. Not a place I would go with a group, but its nice to enjoy with a friend or two. If you have a dinner reservation I highly recommend you arrive in time for at least one drink at the bar. 

Their food is fantastic especially the appetizers (you can eat at the bar).

If your older and rich friend asks where you'd like to meet for drinks Bix should be considered!
author: All About Town ..

description:
Bix is my favorite San Francisco restaurant. All the food is very good and the service is excellent. But what really stands out is the atmosphere--it's amazing! The restaurant is dark with high ceilings, it feels very old-time San Francisco. I've always gone there a little early in the evening, but I would recommend a later reservation, the live jazz seems to kick-in around 9PM. I didn't pay much attention to the wine list, but at brief glance it looked very complete.

Of the four main courses I've tried, the two seafood of the day dishes were the best. Of the four desserts I've tried, the bananas foster and chocolate bread pudding were the best.
author: Anton C.

description:
BIX is a little OTT in some places, and a little less attentative in other areas - like drink orders.  If you are sitting on the main floor you will have little chance of hearing your conversation or seeing the menu due to lighting.  For such a high end place, when I saw a busboy drag a sack of laundry across the main floor at 9:30 on a friday night - I really began to wonder.

Chix hash is good, bananas foster was delish, oysters taste like they should, potato pillows is another term for tater tot, I'm embarrassed to say what our bill was.  Go on a weeknight as the staff may be less ADHD.
author: M M.

description:
I came into town to visit my daughter in college and took her and my wife to BIX. What a nice evening. The food was excellent and the service top notch. The only thing to comment to the negative was that the lighting was a little too dark to read the menus without straining. 

I liked the fact that it was a little more formal in ambiance and service because California Casual gets a little stale.
author: Stephen C.

description: If you're in the mood for a traditional dining experience i.e. - older crowd, delicious food, white tablecloth, jazz, and giant bar, this is the place.  Tucked away location gives it an underground feel upon arrival. The black truffle stuffed cheeseburger was decandent and best shared.
author: Jill R.

description:
I've noticed that as my time spent on Yelp increases (( yes, I do spend a LOT of time on here! )), my taste buds have grown more and more expensive... Suddenly, I'm finding myself craving the $$$, far-away locales than the regular places I've been frequenting around my area.

I came across BIX on Yelp and was really interested in trying the marrow bones and other items on their menu. Many of the reviews spoke positively about this long-standing restaurant in a "hidden alley" which greatly intrigued me. So, today was the day that my hubs promised and off we went. For some strange reason, we came across bad luck with traffic leaving our area and again just before exiting.. so we arrived about 15-20 minutes late for our rezzies. Upon entering, they took our coats and were still able to accommodate us with an open table.

At our table, a cute little card said "Happy Anniversary" and within a few moments our server, Doug, was there to start us off with some drinks. We ordered a heineken for the husband (I know) and a BIX Ricky. A few moments later, the complimentary bread came out which satiated our empty stomachs for the time being.

Here's what we ordered:

- TRUFFLED FRENCH FRIES $8.95: These are always good anywhere I order them. They came with two sauces: ketchup and one other sauce I can't pinpoint. I really wish we ordered another one of these. They are to die for!
- STEAK TARTARE $13.95: It was our first time ordering this so it was an interesting experience and taste. The raw steak was prepared tableside and was eaten with toasted bread. I can't say that I liked or disliked this dish.. it requires a more sophisticated palate to be able to discern its quality.. my palate is not at that level just yet. Although it was interesting to try, the flavors in this dish would not warrant my ordering it the next time I am here.
