author: Jennifer T.

description: Went back here for a second time for my stepdad's birthday.  We again had a fabulous experience.  Our table was ready and waiting for us.  We had a great waiter (Stu) who allowed us to take our time through multiple courses and was a great character.  The ceviche has to be one of my all time favorites.  It's a new take on ceviche that I've never seen before and is really great.  I also liked the Steak Tartar a lot.  Oh, and the Bananas Foster dessert was amazing.  I'll definitely be back again in the future!
author: Jen F.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner a few weeks ago.  The location, atmosphere and live jazz definitely make this place worth trying.  But be prepared to spend a bunch, because it's certainly not cheap.  A nice touch was the manager (I think) who came up to my friend shortly after we were seated with a personalized card wishing her a Happy Birthday.  

Unfortunately, the service went downhill after that.  The waiter spilled half our bottle of champagne when opening it and never apologized or offered to do anything to compensate us.  After that first bottle, he opened the remaining three, but just left it on the table, requiring us to pour it ourselves.  There were numerous other incidents that I don't have the time to go into.  The food was excellent (the chicken hash is a must, as is the tuna tartar and bananas foster), but unfortunately the poor service really detracted from the food.  

I understand everyone has their off nights, so I'll probably give it another chance, especially given all the good reviews others have given Bix.
author: Shannon E.

description:
Drinks and snacks are just 'okay' for the price.  Restaurant looks good inside, very film noire, but the overall experience was just "eh."  We sat at the bar, had a few drinks, munched a few appetizers and people watched.  The tuna tar-tar was very good, as were the mashed potatoes, but the fried shrimp had absolutely no flavor whatsoever.  The drinks are served in those teeny-tiny martini glasses, which is a drag at 10-13 bucks a pop.  Service was nothing special.  

The other patrons were entertaining.  One early 40's-ish looking guy came in dressed like a Rat Packer, complete with hat set at a jaunty angle, and tried to make friends with people at the bar.  He was pushing it hard with the ladies.  At one point, after several drinks, he started in on a young lady who was waiting with her parents for a table.  The dude kept touching her and kissing her cheeks while the parents looked on horrified.  We happened to leave the restaurant at the same time he did and watched him slide, alone, into the seat of a huge convertible caddy, circa 1970s.  I had to laugh.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
I love the consistency of Bix. Over the years it has maintained it's five star status with me. Tucked away in a little alley, it's a great place to bring a date. Pull your car up to the valet and you feel like a movie star. The supper club atmosphere and live jazz are awesome. I love how the waiters shake your martini in front of you at your table. Everytime I've gone there they have called me by name and treated me like someone important. I'm not really important but they made me feel special and it makes me want to come back. Oh, did I mention the food? Nothing has ever dissapointed me from the appetizers to the dessert. Even the coffee tasted great.

All in all the experience is wonderful. You have to see for yourself. Bring a date, bring your whole family, or just hang out with your buddies. It's one of my favorite restaurants in the City.

For the record, I spent the most amount of money I've ever spent on a girl there and she wasn't even my girlfriend. That's another story not for Yelp.
author: Hunter G.

description:
Classy. A throwback to the vintage days of posh sophistication.  Spectacular food, great service and beautiful old jazz piano standards to get you in the mood for romance.

Go when you got a rich uncle in town. ;-)
author: Sanaz E.

description:
Wow!  I like that place.  pricey but really solid and good.  Been around a long time too and longevity says something in a town when restaurants come and go so fast!

it was a birthday meal for my sweetie and he had never heard of BIX before.  I used to work for Real Restaurants so I always wanted to try AND I would've gotten a nice discount if I had eaten there a few years before.

The BAR!  Is astounding.  I only drank some nice Tuscan wine but i was drooling over the amber colors from afar and the choices.

Had Crab puffs which were delightful and fresh.
Had the Butternut Squash soup with pumpkin seed oil.  Yum for the oil!
Had Salad with Romaine and Pt. Reyes blue cheese dressing.  So good and tasty!

they gave us potato beggars purses (what I call them)  Tater tots with creme fraiche and caviar (american)  These were a little greasy but it was a freebie.  so I enjoyed it.

For Main courses, ate the Pork chop! Yummmm!  with fingerlings and fig compote.
Chicken Hash was only so so.  I think it is one of their signature dishes but really didn't do much though I would definitely say the creamy sauce (almost like stroganoff sauce) and the beautiful tiny tomatoes made up for the medocre-ness of the chicken hash.  I was so full anyway but that time that I was satiated,

But....  I made some room for the bananas foster.  OMG!  that was so good.  Goodness abounded.  The only thing that could have made that better was  the bottle of Sauterne that they had listed for $450.  But then, I would have had to be carried out on a stretcher.
author: Leslie I.

description:
Had a fabulous time here last weekend for my BF's birthday. It seeemd like old school San Francisco, kinda like a proper supper club with the cool, sexy, sophisticated elegant vibe of a proper jazz club.

They gave us a great table, they'd put a birthday note on the table and gave us a compliementary birthday dessert.

Its the restaurants that really know how to treat their clienete and make everybody feel special that always win.

Food was incredible. Wine fantastic. Bix came highly recommended and its definitely our current number 1 spot in the city.
author: Leah O.

description:
Once again,  my fellow YELPers did not steer me wrong.  Which was better?  The food or the ambience?  The piano player or the back-alley location of this gem?  Ah, heck.. I forgot.  I was drunk.  But what I can tell you is that this is a fine place, with good stiff drinks, a laundry list of incredible appetizers and  a very friendly wait staff.  Romance?  Oh yeah.  My wife couldn't take her eyes off me!  

Just quit farting off and go here, then drop me a line to let me know that I wasn't so drunk that the food actually sucks.  Seriously, the Crab on foccacia, tartare and the  trout salad were all great.  Experience food and drink like it was 40 years ago.  This place is great.
author: Mike M.

description:
Okay, so I am writing a review about a restaurant that has been reviewed well over 350+ times. So, if those other hundreds of other reviews didn't convince you, I hope that mine will! My wife and I are always willing to explore and try new places, and finally, we were so pleased to actually find a restaurant where we enjoyed the atmosphere, food, and every single aspect of the meal.

We started with the appetizers... and couldn't decide on which to try, since many looked so good. So, why deprive ourselves?? We chose the mini lamb burgers, firecracker shrimp, and the potato pillows. Each and every one was AMAZING! Not greasy or overly filling at all. I thought that my wife might actually take me down over the last lamb burger!

Next, I had the clam and corn chowder, and she the ceviche. Both were absolutely delicious. My wife, a true expert in the ways of ceviche, was impressed with the flavor. I loved the soup, but when my wife tried it, again, I thought my life would be in danger... she LOVED it. REAL clams (not clam pieces), and such a robust, non-fishy flavor. A definite must!

For entree's, my wife had the halibut, and I the special of the day, the sturgeon (not sure of spelling). Both were wonderful, not too "fishy", and decent sized portion. I had ordered a side of the truffle fries... DEFINITELY get those- so flavorful!!!

We topped off the meal with the bananas foster - quite decadent! Oh, and by the way, the alcohol beverages were delicious as well. My wife had a Mojito, and I a chocolate Martini... yum yum.

So, as you can see, we went to town! The service was really great. In fact, our waitress was a bit concerned that perhaps we wouldn't be able to eat all that we orderd... boy, did we prove her wrong! The ultimate statement regarding this meal is that my wife did not leave ONE thing behind on her plate... she ate EVERYTHING, which is very rare.

Also, even though it is on the pricier side, with all the food and drink that we ordered, it came to roughly 100 per person. Granter, high end, but we definitely feel that we got what we paid for!

I would have to say that the only negative about Bix is that it is not located on the East Bay! Not to worry - we will be back!
author: Michael W.

description: Food is prepared to perfection and music and waitstaff is of equal quality!
author: Jessie R.

description:
Speakeasy of another era -- and, boy, what a great era that must have been, if Bix is at all representative.
Bit of a wait, even with a reservation, but worth it. Great oysters and live piano music! Intimate ambience, despite being a fairly large restaurant (which you'd never guess as you walk in through the arcane alleyway-door), and a scrumptious menu.
author: G. J.

description: Pretend you are on the set of Mad Men......it had been a while since i last visited  i forgot what a gorgeous room it was.....what a unique destination restaurant.
author: Sandy S.

description: I FINALLY made it over here, and I must say it delivered.  I felt like I walked into a restaurant from the 1940's; jazz playing, polite waiters, art deco design.  It was just romantic enough, but not over the top.  On this occasion, I only had desert and drinks, but the food at the tables around us looked and smelled very good.  Ill reserve the last star for after I eat a meal there.
author: Matt C.

description: This place was very solid. The live jazz was wonderful, and there are no bad tables. The wine list was extensive. If I were to come again, I would order more fish. The way they prepared the fish here was great, and the chef just seemed to know exactly how to work it. My burger with truffled fries was great, but very decadent. I think to really see this place at its best you must try several things, which means going on the lighter side.
author: Katrina K.

description:
I have eaten at many a restaurant with an engaging & attentive staff, or fantastic food, or a great atmosphere. Yet, never have I been to a restaurant that hit the mark with all three.  Bix nailed it!  

The decor and atmosphere is wonderful...felt as if I had stepped back in time ..oh, about 60 years.  Now, it isn't a quiet place (and that is before the music starts) but it is romantic, especially, after the music starts.  The key is to be seated upstairs.  Completely changes the dynamic of the experience.  

Our server (Kristen) was pitch perfect.  She was engaging, fun, and helpful throughout the evening.  She really did a wonderful job guiding us through the menu.  Every recommendation she provided was spot on.  

Now for the food...... 

Our party of three nibbled our way through plenty of dishes over three hours...and even though we were full by the end, we really didn't want to stop eating.  

Starters:  Steak Tartare & Ceviche - The first dishes out...and they completely set the tone for the evening.  I am still talking about the ceviche this morning...it was that flavorful.

First Courses:  Grilled marrow bones, two-way prepared shrimp, fresh provolone & proscuitto, grilled asparagus and fried oysters (see fired comment below), and another dish involving foie gras that was silken and unbelivable. 

Main Courses:  Halibut and butter beans,  Grilled lamb, and the Lobster Spaghetti.  All three were prepared to perfection, with flavors that were exquisite and sublime.  

Desert: Bread pudding:  I would have died very happy at that point! 

By the way, we had some french fries tossed in to sample....um, I cannot, nor will I, ever eat another french fry again (unless it is from Bix).  I have never tasted something deep fried, that didn't taste deep fried. 

All in all,  the single best dining experience I have ever had, in which every plate was distinct from the others.  Not one dish crossed over in flavor or presentation......it was F&^@%(@#) amazing!  

Oh yeah...the ginger gimlets go down way too easy!
author: Larry C.

description:
One of my all-time favorite SF restaurants. I  love that it's down a secluded little alley, so you have to know your way around to find it.  Walking down the alley, you feel like you're walking into a Humphrey Bogart movie, a feeling that continues when you step inside and see the staff in their white dinner jackets.  

There's definitely a 30's supper club feel, with awesome bartenders who make outstanding martinis (best in the city). We go here when we want to celebrate something special.

Service is always attentive, yet not overbearing.  The server seems to magically appear when I want something.

My recommendations:  the caviar topped potato pillows and the "marrow bones" (don't knock 'em til you try em).  Both of these appetizers haunt my dreams.  Also the butternut squash soup was delicious.

I usually have fish, but by then we've gone through a bottle of champagne, so I can't remember what kind I usually have, just that it's white and always good.

I always have the same dessert, but again, the martini and champagne fog prevents me from recalling the name.  I just know it's chocolate, and it's always great.  

We've been here four or five times and we've yet to have a bad experience.
author: Jamie C.

description:
I've had two excellent meals here and one not-so-great meal, so I'm mixed. The two excellent meals definitely made up for the mediocre one, and the service was always good (to me, but then again I was with a friend of the owner).

I do like the layout of the place, and it's tucked away in an alley dowtown, which adds to the ambiance.
author: marie m.

description:
Classic steak house.
Table side carving service, elegant martinis, great service.
Enjoy an animal here.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
For the price, I find this place underwhelming. I went here on someone else's recommendation --- the decor is very swanky for sure, with an intriguing portrait of a typical gentleman about town from the roaring twenties, wood highlights all around on the walls and staircase, and nice lampshades.

However, service was so-so: while our server disappeared after first handing us our menus, and we had to flag down someone to ask to be served, and bread arrived fifteen to twenty minutes after we got there, the waiter that we accosted stayed with us and was very friendly.

The food was reasonable, but I've eaten better for less. We ordered the Kobe, which was ordered medium but arrived more well-done, but was still fairly juicy. The pommes puree it came with was the best part of the meal. The salmon my date ordered was quite plump and delicately flavored, but the taste profile stayed oily and citric, with little hint of any herb or vegetables that it was cooked with.

On the wine front: The special, a Priorat, had a fair amount of depth, with dark fruits and spice, but again, for $13 a glass, a bit much. I asked for something more robust to go with my beef --- the Rodney Strong Zinfandel I got was spicy and big, but not a great recommendation. I like my servers to be a little more knowledgeable about wines, especially when I am paying premium prices.
author: Sameer S.

description:
I agree with e amber a.  This place deserves 4.5!  Beautiful, colorful and full of life this place gives me happy feelings every time I visit!  The food is superb and the service is always top notch!  

But my review comes alittle bias since the partner at my firm knows the owner so every time we come by to dine, we are always taken care of!
author: Alice T.

description:
Bix has graet atmosphere and an uber professional staff.  The Mixologists take pride in the cocktails they prepare and the waiters are knowledgable.  

We started our meal with a delicious round of apps.  The steak tartar was excellent.  This is a tough to find dish in the city of SF so it was a treat.  We enjoyed the crab cake roll and the mini lamb burgers were the bomb. 

The halibut special was a solid choice for the main course.  It was served over roased corn and mushrooms with a nice sweet corn sauce.  The short ribs were dry and the sauce lacked falvor.  Our final entre was the crab pasta with lobster sauce.  This was terrible and you should stay away from it.  Minced crab meat with very little sauce over spaghetti.  It is billed as having a kick.  If this is the case Jackie Chan and Chow Fat would be disapointed!!

All and all is was a so-so experince.  You are better off going for drinks and apps
author: Ben V.

description:
Loved it!  Went here for lunch and enjoyed the Bix fixe menu.  Everything was delicious - from the warm toasty roll to athe beginning to the decadent chocolatey bread pudding at the end.  The service was prompt and attentive and the locale was art decoish, retro - beautiful.  I would give it 5 stars, but really feel I should return for dinner first.  

And return, I will!
author: Gabriela C.

description:
Historic ass restaurant in the gold countin alley of days
gone long ago...
Damn fine food too
jazzy black musicians play, some used to play with true blue jazz legends
I miss those cats! My college days saw me as a valet driving very fast cars for Bix and I got fed enough to know how good the food was there in the 90's.
author: mickey l.

description:
I went to Bix with a good friend a little while back with anticipation of great food and the sounds of soothing jazz.  I did not leave disappointed.  To begin, the restaurant itself transcends time and brings you to a place not often seen in San Francisco.  The atmosphere definitely sets itself apart from other restaurants.  

Despite some reviews that I had read regarding the wait staff, they seemed nothing short of courteous, warm, and helpful as they detailed the menu.

We began the meal with the potato pillows with sturgeon caviar.  These were wonderfully light and delicate.  We also had their well known steak tartare, prepared at the table, which was excellent as well.  For our main courses, we shared the kobe steak and seabass, both prepared well and full of flavor.

All in all it was a great experience and I would definitely recommend it to a friend.  It is a great place to sit back, relax and enjoy some great food and music, all tucked in a little alleyway.
author: Gordon M.

description:
Hands down, the best service I've had at any restaurant in the bay area.  The staff is really knowledgeable about their food, drinks and art.   The place reminded us of a speakeasy.  Pretty swank, indeed.

Went here with a group of friends (affectionately called the "meat crew").  For appetizer, we ordered the mini-lamb burgers, steak tartare, and ahi tartare.  The burgers were fantastic; they came with a slice of cucumber that was a nice balance to the lamb.  The steak tartare was prepared table-side and was quite amusing to watch.  After the waiter finished mixing the ingredients of the dish he misted the dish with cognac...  and then he sprayed the air above the table with it.  Awesome.  The ahi tartare was boring but still a good cut of fish.

Three of the four of us ordered the American style kobe beef with pureed potatoes, while the loaner went for the pork chop.  The beef had fantastic flavor, but the cut was a little chewy.  The outside of the meat was absolutely divine; really rich flavors.  Based solely on this dish, one of the meat crew declared their beef within the top 3 of her list.  I sampled the pork and it was moist and well balanced with the apple chutney.  Very tasty indeed.

Overall, the food was quite good and the chefs did a fantastic job in the realm of creativity and execution.

I would definitely come back here and recommend that you do, too.
author: Mary P.

description:
I have always loved this place.  I must confess, it is usually sitting at the bar having one of their perfect martinis or manhattans but tonight I actually sat down to a full dinner.

The truffle cheese and onion croquettes are just as good at a table as they are at the bar.  The chicken hash which I had for my entree, was  amazing - I have had it before and this is a signature dish that should not be missed.

My wife's steak tartar - prepared in the traditional manner table side - was also amazing.  But the thing that topped off the night was desert. 

The bread pudding brioche was nothing short of spectacular and the bananas foster was also delightful.  

Well now my food coma is kicking in, but it is welcome, and I look forward to my next one induced by the fine folks at Bix.
author: David R.

description:
Elegant atmosphere with live jazz music, white-gloved bend over backwards to please you service and exceptionally fresh, table side prepared food makes Bix a San Francisco dining must. When our waiter forgot my ceviche he more than made up for it by supplying our table with endless desserts (the Banana Foster is so rich and indulgent you won't need to eat dessert for days) and taking everything I'd ordered off the bill. 

FiDi businesses men should frequent Bix on Fridays when they do a business man's lunch with three courses for $23. With off the menu options of  home made pasta, rueben's, cobb salads and MORE you should splurge every few months.
author: Jessica M.

description:
A classy place. My friends and I came here only for drinks. So this is not a true review of the place. The atmosphere was good, but we came late at night, so it was not too lively. Drinks good, but pricey. 
My friend spend $200 plus on dinner and drinks for new year's eve here. So it is not cheap here!
author: Leon C.

description:
We came here for my bf's birthday and it was his first time eating here. I came here a couple of years ago and really enjoyed it, and they definitely did not disappoint. I made our reservations on open table and requested booth seating on the mezzanine since it's much nicer to sit upstairs. They gave us a huge booth that normally seats 4 people and it had a birds eye view of the entire restaurant.  They also added a special touch by having a card saying 'happy birthday'. 
The service was really good and the food was delcious.  We ordered 4 appetizers-the tuna tartare, truffled oil french fries, ceviche and their homemade mozarella with prosciutto. We also had really flavorful entrees-the american kobe beef and the lamb chops!  
this is a wonderful restaurant for special and not so special occasions, all the dish concepts were creative, colorful, fresh and just delicious!
author: Eva L.

description:
This place is one of my all time favorite restaurants in San Francisco, primarily because of the atmosphere and the outstanding service.  The food is great, but nothing that sets it apart from our city's stiff competition.  The reason to go here is that there just aren't restaurants like this anymore.  The quality of service is so outstanding and makes you feel so special, that this is my go to place for special occasions and visiting friends/family.

Definitely a place not to miss.
author: Miranda O.

description:
I am really disappointed I have to change my review.  Went back here over the weekend - after such a positive experience the first time, I was excited to share it with my husband and some friends.  The host greeted us as if we were a burden and gave us a table that was too close to others, despite better tables being available.  Service was slow - our server was either too busy or had more important looking guests to serve.  We waited for water, drink orders, etc.  The scene was also very loud - the bar was crowded and the music was competing to be heard over the people talking.

The food was still good.  Considering the ambiance was more LA than elegant evening out, I felt it was overpriced.  It can also take a while for valet to take/return your car.  Overall, I felt this experience lost its charm considerably.
author: Michelle C.

description: One word: Outdated. The food was okay, but it doesn't quite compete with all the other amazing restaurants around town. It has an old-school vibe; servers in white vests, with clown art on the wall, and a piano man. Not bad, but wouldn't go back.
author: Gina C.

description: I love love love the ambiance of this place as well as the live music.  It's very romantic, but also good for groups. Drinks and food are great too.  A bit pricey, but great quality.  Service is usually good too.  The last couple times it's taken a long time to get our food, which is frustrating, but the waiter gave me a free drink as an apology the last time, which I appreciated.
author: Ava G.

description:
Was here over a year ago. The location and atmosphere are great. Old school jazz lounge. 
The food was okay but it seemed that everything was overwhelming with lemon...from the lemon flavored tonic that came with my tanqueray and tonic to the crab cakes and then to the mains - I had a fish dish. Again, it was just hard to determine the flavors over all of the lemon.
Perhaps the new chef has sorted that out.
The location is hard to find, luckily we had a house car from the hotel take us over. Getting a cab afterwards was hard, not much luck in the alley there...had to go out to main street. Would probably go back but with so many choices maybe not for dinner. Drinks for sure!
author: Edward D.

description:
Exquisite, delectable,  palatable, and distinctive are just a few of the words that jump to mind when thinking back to my fantastic experience at BIX the other night.

I love it's off the beaten path location as it has more of an exclusive feel to it.

It was a bit loud, even though we were sitting upstairs (which was quite romantic) as the piano and lounge singer got louder and louder as time went on. That proved to be a little difficult to have an intimate conversation when you're trying to raise your voice so the person across from you can hear you with out the person at the next table hearing you. The service, minus our actual server, was very accommodating and friendly. 

The food was hands down some of the best food I've had in months....and I eat out quite a bit. We started with the potato pillows with caviar which I was a little disappointed with after all the hype on Yelp. They were good, but the saltiness from the cake itself overpowered the taste of the caviar. Too bad. The smoked trout salad was perfect. Fresh, salty, and deliscious. My bf had the Kobe steak which was succulent, cooked to perfection (medium rare of course) and the shallots were perfectly sauteed. I had the pork roulade, which I'd never had before, and let me just say that I can still taste the juicy goodness on my tongue. The moment my fork touched the meat it practically fell on to my fork as the juices spilled on to my plate. The warm spinach and creamy milky mashed potato's were the perfect companion for this amazing dish. The chocolate brioche bread pudding was like a gooey chocolaty taste of heaven with each bite. Simply divine!

I'm a HUGE fan of BIX and can't wait to go back!
author: Kristy M.

description: Two friends and I were at BIX last night having a wonderful evening. We arrived after the Giants game, had made reservations, and were sitting after dinner catching up.  The food was excellent and the service superb and the setting very unique.  We lost track of time, had no idea folks were waiting and frankly were just oblivious until the General Manager, Blake Tippett arrived at our table (it wasn't until later that we found out who he was). At first we thought he was just inquiring about our evening but then he abruptly told us folks were waiting, we had been sitting long enough and he waited as long as he could before coming over. I jumped up along with my friends, apologized and headed down the stairs.  He immediately called a busboy over to prep our table for other guests. I was embarrassed and we all felt it could have been handled much better. We asked for a business card of the GM and did not realize until we were outside it was a generic business card for the restaurant so back in we went and asked again for the business card of the owner/GM.  We then found out that the gentleman that came to our table was the GM and at this point he handed us his card. We explained how we felt and instead of following the cardinal rule of customer service he blew us off and intimated it was our problem and he had waited as long as he could before coming to our table. My friend tried to suggest a better way of handling a situation like this in the future but he could have cared less which is what truly infuriated me. We also frankly questioned if we were three men how it would have been handled. Perhaps BIX has such a following that angering three well educated female executives doesn't matter. Let's see when the next best restaurant comes along (and we all know it will) how truly excellent customer care becomes the number one priority.
author: Rosanne F.

description: One of the things that I miss about San Francisco is BIX.  A throwback to the past yet not too tacky.  Food is stellar (Love the Chicken Hash). I had the best martini in town there as well.  When I go back to San Francisco, I will be visting BIX this time as it's been a couple of years since I've been in there.
author: Darren B.

description: My absolute favorite place to dine for a special occasion.  Valentine's Day, Anniversary, Birthday... it's "the" quintessential San Francisco restaurant.  Doug Biederbeck and Chef Bruce Hill come together and set one fine tone.  I prefer the booths upstairs or down below on the northside wall so that you can watch the flow of the floor.   The heirloom tomato cart (caprese) is phenomenal.  Reminds me that heirloom season is here and right around the corner.  The foie gras is to die for (well some duck did).  Oh wait, back up... let's start from the beginning.  You must start with a tableside shaken martini, some oysters and a little bit of Tsar Nicoulai (who do I think I am?).  Yumm... my mouth is just watering thinking about Bix.
author: Brooke G.

description: The service was top notch; totally professional and efficient.  Some of the food was outstanding (lobster spaghetti; deviled eggs) some just good (grilled tuna). Nice wine list with some interesting CA and European wines. A little bit of a scene, with tables of investment bankers and older guys with their mistresses, but get a table upstairs and it would be great for a quiet (but not too quiet) dinner for two.  Excellent people-watching and a lively bar with solid cocktails.
author: Mandy M.

description:
Birthdays stress me out. Boyfriend's birthday really stresses me out. I practically went crazy trying to think of something special to plan for his big day. 

After much yelping, I found BIX and promptly booked a reservation for 9pm on a Saturday night.  A few days before the evening, I called to pre-order desert for our night. The person who answered the phone was so astoundingly rude, she left me speechless. I actually considered canceling our reservation because of her demeanor, but the menu looked so good that I decided to risk it. 

I'm glad we did risk it because the night turned out to be lovely. We ordered a bunch of hor'dourves so that we could try more things on the menu. The foi gras and the lamb burgers were the most delicious and memorable. I was slightly disappointed by the minuscule size of potato pillows and I didn't expect them to be deep fried. However everything was very tasty and indulgent (in a good way).

A few more notes:

This place had a lot of ambiance and our waitress was really polite and attentive - she more than made up for her rude colleague. 

The restaurant remembered that it was the bf's birthday and left a card on a table - a nice personal touch. 

The musicians were really good - a great show, yet not so loud that we couldn't carry on our conversation. 

So all in all, we had a great night and if it weren't for the rude person who answered the phone, this would probably be a 5 star experience.
author: A K.

description: Great classic SF restaurant.  Solid food under the helm of Bruce Hill.  Awesome cocktails, great food, live jazz (featuring Mary Stallings on the weekends) all make this festive restaurant a fun destination no matter what occasion you're celebrating.  Pluses are the greatest steak tartare and the potato pillows with caviar.  Don't skip the heirloom tomato cart when they're in season.
author: Angelo S.

description: Just came back from lunch.  We had the burger and crab salad.  Food was fine but service was horrible.  The waitress completely ignored us.  We asked for refill on our ginger lemonade and diet Coke MULTIPLE times.  The waitress passed by us couple times w/o the refills.  We ended up having to ask the bus boy for it.  They ended up charging us for the refills! That the...service like this just ruin your overall experience.
author: TU B.

description: They couldn't do a better job - from variety of food to impeccable service to fantastic ambience, I love it all. Not many places can pull off the class, live jazz music and great food all at once, but BIX does it with grace.
author: Kirsten B.

description:
the place is SO hard to find. we drove past the little alley about 5 times. i ended up calling and just as the host said "hello," i said "i can't find your restaurant!!" but alas we found it.

i dig the interior. very nice old jazz club feel. 

they split your dishes without charge, and that is a marvelous thing! 

it was my boyfriend's bday so we ordered up a storm! 

crab rolls-       four mini buttery and sweet, light but rich sandwiches.  they were so small that the amount of bread used for all four combined probably didn't even equate to one full slice of wonderbread! but they were really really good! 

firecracker shrimp-     the batter they use has a nice strong flavor to it. the aioli is really good. i ended up using it for the truffle fries! but again, just four shrimp.

truffle fries-    just like all the other truffle fries i've tried. no different.

lobster spaghetti-     a lot of lobster flavor in the cream sauce.  don't know if it was $40 good, but i liked it a lot.

bavette steak-     the sauce it came with made the dish good. it wasn't as tender as i'd imagined it to be. and the mashed potatoes were just plain. 

chocolate brioche bread pudding!!!!!!-      SOOOO good. yeah yeah, it's not that "different" from other chocolate bread puddings but i almost want to say it beats the one from Chaya in my book.
author: Regina C.

description:
This is a hidden at the edge of the Financial District. It sits in a narrow alley between Jackson and Pacific and between Montgomery and Pine. It might be technically North Beach, not really important. It's been around since 1988 but it feels older than that in some respects.

Ambiance (3): Old school steakhouse feel that is marred by wall decor that reminds me of the 80s or 90s, heck I could make a reference to the "Saved by the Bell" intro...just go, you will see what I mean. There are swirls all over the walls that I am sure are great echo killers (there is live music at times), but exudes I love the (early) 90s. The waiters/servers wear white jackets and are tres formal, again steakhouse vibe. The booths do feel a little aged and with the lights full on, they can't be very attractive. It does have potential and it wouldn't take much to get it into the art deco terrain. Oh and we had a guy playing the piano as we ate for a bit, which was nice.

Food (4): Before I dive into what I actually ate, I have one question: is halibut the only fish out there? Just consider that next time you go to a restaurant that has the classic deployment of 1 fish, 1 chicken, 1 steak, 1 pork, 1 hamburger, 1 shellfish, 1 veggie entree deployment. Moving on...there were a few appetizers that were pulling at my heartstrings; ceviche, deviled eggs, beet and goat cheese skewers, steak tartare, but there was one that you don't see on many menus (at least not nearly as much as halibut) and that was bone marrow. It was presented in four pieces with a little spoon and accompanied by parsley/shallot/caper/vinaigrette salad, toast, and some coarse salt. Perfection. It was better than the bone marrow I had at Incanto (gasp!) even though the way it is served at Incanto (split lengthwise) made it easier to get every delicious little bit of bone marrow. For the entree, I had a Kobe beef bavette steak, which is fancy talk for a skirt steak like cut. I ordered it rare as god intended Kobe beef to be ordered, but it wasn't as flavorful as I recall my last Kobe dish (aside from those Google burgers) was. Nevertheless, it was tasty and came with a couple of roasted cippolini onions (heart) and an excellent and oh so delicate potato puree. 

The wine list was ok but it had a malbec so it was game on. However, I am surprised this is a second time I see a 2009 malbec on a list and similar to the last one I tried, it lacked some soul. I think I might need to open my 2005 bottle and recalibrate my expectations once and for all.

Service (3): Steakhouse formality, but no real complaints. However, I would venture to say that I have had waiters at steakhouses with a bit more life. Also, I cringed every time the water guy came dangerously close to my glass of wine with that water jug. He could have moved it. Also, when they would clear the table they would sometimes leave random items (butter dish, the odd knife) on the table and we are going full stuffy, let's go full stuffy. You know what I mean?

Value (4): Prices were reasonable. I should start coming here for the $11.75 bone marrow. Of course the truffled fries were a bit pricey, so stick to hitting Frjtz for that craving.

Overall: I liked this place. If they overhauled their interiors, I would like it even better. Regardless of the ambiance, I will have to go back for that bone marrow. Hopefully, they don't rotate that off the menu any time soon.
author: Alvaro H.

description: took my boyfriend here for his 26th Birthday. The food was absolutely amazing.. they however didnt give you enough. Very small portions for a ridicously high price. Be prepared to pay over $200 if you are on a date. Great place with great jazz feeling. It has a lot of historial features in the restaurant. Waiter was awesome, great service.
author: Avneet T.

description:
This truly is as good as it gets....FOR NOW.  I plan on visiting the other fancy schmancy spots in San Francisco just to compare.
We didn't have to wait at all.  We had reservations for 8 and got there at 7:50 and were seated immediately.
It was my manfriend's 27th birthday.  They seated us upstairs, which was really nice and we got a view of the whole restaurant.  There was a card upstairs that said "Happy Birthday from Bix", which I thought was a nice touch.
They had a prix fixe menu, which seemed like a good deal.  Two choices of apps/entrees/desserts for $37.  But alas, we did not choose this option.
We started off with booze (of course)
I got the ginger gimlet and he got the Bix rickey.  The Bix rickey was definitely not as sweet as I thought it was going to be.  It looked and smelled like a girly drink, but it tasted like pure liquor.  Delicious.
The ginger gimlet was TASTY and boozy as hell. I couldn't finish it, so I ended up giving it to the boy because I'm a sissy and didn't want to kill my tastebuds before I ate. 
However, it was delicious.
Delicious!
Food:
I started off the with potato pillows with creme fraiche and the caviar.
Then I had the ceviche with toasted corn nuts, and then I finished off with the American kobe steak bavettes.
DELICIOUS.
The potato pillows were a glorified tator tots for sure.  They were delicious and served on a folded napkin, which was kind of rad.
My ceviche had a really odd taste to them.  It was slices of fish with slices of avocado but on top, it was the corn nuts.  The corn nuts kind of threw off the whole taste.
It was strange, but tasty.  Next time I would definitely pass up the ceviche and get something else.
My steak was DELICIOUS.  The onions, the mashed potatoes, oh my god.  Very tasty.  The jus on top was so goddamn rich and buttery.  So good!
My manfriend ordered the lamb mini burgers, the fried oysters, and the halibut.  
The lamb burgers were delicious but reminded me a LOT of my dad's kabobs.  Hmm.
But oh my god.  His fried oysters with asparagus and prosciutto were SO FUCKING GOOD.  I kept trying to feed him my ceviche so he would be polite enough to offer me some of his food.  No dice.  We both knew that his outrocked my ceviche.
I tried his halibut also.  Very soft and nicely cooked, but I really wasn't too interested in his dish because my steak was damn tasty.
For dessert, he had the malted whopper ice cream (with a candle on top!) and I had the chocolate bread pudding.  Very nice way to finish the meal.
I pretty much waddled back to BART after the meal.
One beef that I do have is that our waiter guy seemed kind of annoyed with us.  Maybe it's because we were considerably younger than the rest of the crowd, but he seemed impatient and kind of like he was humoring us when we placed our order.  And after watching him awhile, we realized that he didn't really schmooze or go out of his way with anyone, so I guess it was just a bad night for him.
All in all, we spent about 2 hours here.  It felt like 15 minutes.  I'm not sure what that means, but I will definitely return to try a plate of the fried oysters just for myself and the chicken hash.

*LONGEST REVIEW EVER*
author: Meh M.

description:
Keywords: classy, expensive, jazzy, dark, romantic, moody, candle-lit. What a great place... been here about three times over the past six years, and every experience was wonderful.

When you call for reservations, get a table on the second floor overlooking the bar.
author: Michael M.

description:
So this place was actually recommended by my boss, and it is sooo worth the dining experience! Its so intimate inside, GREAT wine selection - Okay so  we ordered about 6 bottles i believe,  But from what i do remember, the reds were great! I ordered the oysters as my first dish - lobster linguine as my entree and a reallllllllllllllly good chocolate dessert! it's in the middle of an alley and has cute little bistro chairs outside which completes the ambience of the place - very jazzy, dark, classy and great art work all around! It's pretty expensive so beware now!

Kitty's tip - OYSTERS are FRESH! If you love em - order them HERE!!!!OH and we ordered caviar too - which turned into something like caviar on tater tots from what it seemed..haha but soooooooo delicious!!!! Great for dining in groups (say like 5-6). and we were 5 for that evening.. OH and they valet!! YAY!
author: Kay C.

description:
I have loved Bix for a long time and try to go every time I am "in the battery!"  It is a throw back to SF in the 20-30s in terms of the ambiance, not because people are dressed that way, but the way the building is laid out, the murals, etc.  

Whereas Globe is a great place for lunch/dinner and has a nice bar, Bix is a dinner powerhouse with one of the City's amazing bars.......
author: Michael C.

description:
Turn down Gold Street, and you are transported to San Francisco circa 1930's. There is a cool history to the building - you can ask, I just can't recall it. 

Prompt and knowledgeable waitstaff, but a crowded bar makes it difficult to get any bartender love. 

Mini Lamb Burgers are great, as is the mozzarella and prosciutto appetizer. 
For the entree, I ordered the finest pork chop I have eaten, and also highly suggest the Kobe Bavette steak.
author: Jason N.

description:
I took everyone's advice and went for the appetizers and first course.  We had the potato pillows w/ cavier and crab rolls (dungeoness crab meat in between toasted bread).  Both were excellent.  I wish I had room to try the crab louie and the hand-pulled mozzarella.  We then had the clam, bacon, and corn chowder.  This was also delicious.  We split an entree--the Kobe baverette steak, and it was tender and cooked right.  The first time, our steak was cold, and we sent it back.  It came be hot and wonderful.  They clearly redid it.  We also split the truffle fries, very yummy.

This place is very good, and the service was excellent.  Food came out at a good pace.  We never had to wait too long for our food.  Definitely go for their wonderful appetizers!
author: H Y.

description:
The place couldn't accommodate our party of 20 so we had to split up the party into 3 tables 6. Parking was a bit hard to find but after circling a few time we found one within couple of blocks. 

We got our first course before our appetizer but it still worked. The sinful Crab cakes and buttery Tomato soup went well together. And for the main course everyone at the table shared bites of our zesty truffle open face cheese burger. Lastly, can't go wrong with the lobster spaghetti, it was to die for!
author: Jack L.

description:
It's located in an alley where you would never just stumble upon.  However, once inside it's like you're in some fancy smancy, happening retirement home for the rich - alot of older white folks in suits. 

The service was great, food delish, band was a little too loud, and they don't rush you out.  

Tuna tartar - yummy
Fried oyster - just ok
Lobster spaghetti - very rich and good
author: Annie S.

description: I liked this restaurant but i wasn't blown away. Good food, good service, good martinis, and good ambiance.  I don't know if i would go again given all the wonderful restaurants in SF that I have yet to try, but i wouldn't discourage anyone from going either. I think that it is worth a try.
author: J M.

description:
we have a habit at work (and i think this is quite common) of taking interview candidates awkwardly out to dinner at the end of their interview day.  it's awkward because, in some sense, at this point you've already passed the majority of the judgement on the candidate, either way you want to be pleasantly buzzed, either drowning out their final attempts to redeem themselves, or letting your hair down a bit, wooing them gently, showing them how glamorous finance is, and how fun you are.

back in ny, where we would like to do such a thing, is in a thumping meatpacking or west village restaurant slash club, loud and bustling, swishing with the sequined outerwear of models holding colorful cosmo-like cocktails.  i was sold on selling out myself at kittichai in the thompson hotel many years ago, which back then, was precisely the sort of place one gets car service to, and makes a dinner reservation for no earlier than 1030.

apparently, sexy restaurants is not a thing in sf.  bix lives in the awkward deadzone between fidi and north beach, both in actual location and in spirit.  that is, the business ambiance stifles any potential romance, but it's too intimate for an actual business affair.  dinner was early, 530, on a friday and it was quiet.  too quiet.  we ordered steak tartare to share as a starter, and it took very nearly all my willpower not to wrest every last raw meat cube bleeding from my dining companions' hands.  (they should really make an entree option).  while the steak tartare was amazing, the rest was mediocre, and most importantly disappointingly unrecognizable as classic bistro food.  where was charcuterie and cornichon! where were the whimsical modernifications of steak frites, boeuf bourguignon?  where was the tower of fruits de mer, the moules marinere, the cassoulet in a sizzling cast iron?  nowhere. 

there were oysters, but i wouldn't bother with them. there were so few appealing options on the menu that all four of us wanted to order the same thing (the flounder in some sort of seafood bouillabaisse).  i usually take this as a bad sign.  this sounds snobby, but the plating and portioning was sort of pedestrian-- my lobster pasta was a massive heft of nondescript angel hair, perhaps, in my old age, i've gotten used to a bit of guidance.

alright, anyway, if any of you think of a real sexy restaurant in sf i can take a job interview candidate to, let me know.
author: Stephanie L.

description: My husband and I been here before and remembered the food being very good.  So, I  made the initiative to make reservations for our friend's 40th bday dinner.  We had a party of 10 (with reservations)  but it took 1/2 an hour before we were seated. The hostess was very apologetic which was fine. We totally appreciate her sincerity.  I was very happy we were seated at a round table right by the jazz band.  The food was very good as how i remembered it. The reason why I deducted 3 stars is because the service was horrible! Our waitress took away all our wine glasses before she asked if we were ordering wine for the table. I asked my husband, "Did you not want to order wine? He replied, "Yes, I am going to order wine but didn't get a chance to. But maybe they're switching out our wine glasses??"  Ummm.....OKAY.....We did end up ordering 3 bottles and they brought back the same type of wine glasses. What I really didn't enjoy was when they brought our appetizers they threw everything in the middle of the table.  They didn't move the small table lamp but instead used one of the appetizer plates to scoot the lamp over. SERIOUSLY?? I don't expect them to come out and orchestrate because BIX is not that type of restaurant. I think the biggest turn off was when they didn't bring out a small dessert w/ candle for our friend's bday. I don't know maybe it was our fault for not ordering any desserts because we were stuffed. However, at Olive Garden they still bring out a small vanilla ice cream with a candle even if the table didn't order dessert. Plus the hostess and waitress knew it was a bday dinner. My husband made it very clear we were celebrating a bday. After we paid  the bill one of our friend asked another  waiter to help us take a group photo. We stood up and got into our places and literally waited for good 5 minutes or so and figured he was not going to help us take the photo. LOL!! I think I'll come back if I can't get any reservations to any other restaurants. I"m kidding I'm never coming back!
author: Georgia T.

description:
Only praise! 
Wonderful elegant fantasy-land where fancy and casual mingle in happy harmony. 
The spirits of William Powell and Myrna Loy live on (whoopee!).
Perfect for a quick drink, a romantic dinner, or a wildish party. 
The food is good, the bar is one of the best in town, and the music is exceptional. 
Service: great.
Bartenders: nice.
Great spot to celebrate a special occasion.
author: David F.

description:
Lovely space, but the bartender took a big tip off the check when I didn't communicate that. I was surprised and didn't want to put a bad vibe on the evening so I just let him (around 55 years old, glasses) He was really nice though.

The bill was 45 dollars incl. tax, and I was going to tip 10 dollars, but I had three 20 dollar bills and thus needed change. He brought the change back and I gave no signal at all to keep the whole thing. I was going to keep 5 and give him 10. He said thank you a couple times and dumped all 15 in the tip bucket. I was surprised because he seemed like such a professional.

I've tipped big before, but I clearly say to the waiter/bartender "It's all set." or "I don't need any change." Or lift up my hand to imply I don't need any change. But I didn't do anything like that. I was in the middle of a conversation, so I got kind of forced into tipping 15 dollars on a 45 dollar check.

Was there on Tuesday 12/29/9
author: Tom K.

description: Listening to the first movement of Tchaikovsy's 'Pathetique' reminds me of BIX - lush, romantic and slightly bombastic.  Great location and quick valet service.  Soft lighting and plush interior - I resisted from imitating Norma Desmond on the stairs.  I smiled slightly when the pianist started playing 'The Entertainer'.  Food & service were excellent - I won't bore you to tears with a blow-by-blow account of what I chewed on.  Maitre d' gave charming farewell.  Onto the second movement...
author: Stephan J.

description:
Worth every penny and then some. The bartender is very liberal with the alcohol and just about anything you try will leave you thinking "This is perhaps the best I've ever had."

I don't know whether the music or the oysters turned me on more, but this is about the best show-off date you could plan and it worked for me. *wink*
author: Cory D.

description:
Bix is my favorite restaurant in the city, and it's devastating that I only get to frequent it about every 3 months (if I'm lucky).

Everything on the menu is delicious!  I have never ordered anything that didn't have me refraining from licking my plate.

We took my dad here for Father's Day this past June, and I still remember in vivid details what I ordered.  

Oh, you want to know what that was?  Okay!  I started with a mixed green salad with roasted figs stuffed with cheese.  I then had the sea bass, served on a bed of sweet corn, topped with a fried squash blossom that filled with a creamed corn custard.  For dessert, my mom and I split the poker chip ice cream sandwiches, which were actually more the size of silver dollar pancakes.  DELICIOUS!

Service is always fantastic, the drinks are delectable, and I've said enough about the food.  The atmosphere is elegant, and you feel like you're a part of an exclusive club.  It's definitely pricey, thus my less than desired patronage of this fine restaurant.

The head chef, Bruce Hill, also runs a crazy-good Italian place & pizzeria in Larkspur.  Become a Bruce follower - he never lets you down!
author: brittany z.

description:
I loved this place. From the top down...

Scheduled a dinner with a group of friends and we were all very pleased and impressed.

First, how cool is it that the entrance is down this narrow little alley? Like an old speakeasy.

Second, the decor is really well done. The place is small but looks gorgeous. We were on the second floor looking down and it was so nice to see the hustle and bustle of the staff and diners laughing and talking over a great meal.

Third, the service is impeccable. Each plate comes out promptly and the transitions are seamless. The staff really knows what they're doing and are really knowledgeable about the menu.

Fourth, the food. We ordered the appetizers platter for the table and it was delicious. Mini grilled cheese, crab cakes, tuna tartare and 1 other I can't recall at the moment. Every bit was stellar. The entrees were even better. I orderd the Kobe Beef and I must say every taste was perfect. The meat was artfully cooked, the sides were perfect complements and the presentation was beautiful. I was so satisfied and considering what I had read about the place I thought I was pretty surprised it lived up to the hype.

Fifth, I didn't mention the drinks earlier. Again very well made/mixed. Not your average vodka tonic made by some bimbo at a hip club. A perfect mix.

Lastly, the company I was with made it all the better. A night out with the boys especially to a place like this is a necessity to stay sane.

Overall, a blissful dining experience.
author: R P.

description:
I was somewhat dissapointed with Bix. I guess I expected more, considering all the reviews I'd read in various places and their prices. 
I ordered an old-fashioned at the bar and it was unremarkable. My friend ordered a glass of their house red wine and he wasn't happy either.  For $35 for two drinks, we both expected higher quality. We didn't stay for dinner.
author: Yahoot S.

description: Stay away!  They double book reservations and then make excuses. Not worth the wait or the frustration and embarrassment when you bring guests.
author: Mary O.

description: I took the boyfriend here for the big 3-0. The service was impeccable. There was a birthday card waiting at the table which is a cute gesture and we were seated at the huge center booth at the middle of the balcony. We started w/ ginger gimlets and the waiter suggested an appetizer than would pair well with it (the ceviche). We also had to have the caviar puffs (of course). For entrees the birthday boy got the kobe steak and I had the lobster pasta which was heavenly! I am not a huge red meat eater which can be a little bit limiting at BIX but the pasta was divine. So rich it definitely cannot be finished by one person alone! We opted for a fruit dessert and a glass of Sauternes. It was a fantastic meal that I hope to repeat very soon!
author: Jessica H.

description: Talk about a hole in the wall on an dark alley street with a neon sign being the only way to know something is there. As we entered we were greeted and our coats were taken, we sat down on the lower level smooth jazz in the backround playing the lights dimmed low made thee ambiance very romantic. I just want to rave about the Lobster Spaghetti everything else was good but the Lobster Spaghetti OMG to die for!!!! Service was great would recomend this place to anyone.
author: nadia p.

description:
I've gone to Bix numerous times with groups, on dates and even by myself when I get the craving for the amazing truffle french fries.

The atmosphere at Bix is fabulous during dinner time. The low lighting and decor makes it feel intimate, but the noise and buzz in the room makes it fun. I would describe it as a great place to take a date without overdoing it.

My favorite dishes:
Truffle French Fries
Steak Tartar
Lobster Spaghetti
author: Cathy A.

description: Always great!  The atmosphere is light and fun, love the live piano music.  Drinks are nice and strong.  Lobster pasta is what I get EVERY time!
author: D. S.

description: This review is for the BAR, not the FOOD.  I've been here many times on the weekends to have a nice drink.  The Jazz is awesome, a great place to take a date in north beach where you can actually have a conversation.  Very old school SF joint.  The art is really cool as well.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Came here for a Friday night dinner with a group (10 of us).  Between the 10 of us, we were able to see most of the dishes on the menu.  

I personally got to taste the following:
heirloom tomatoes with house made mozzarella - awesome.  everything about this dish was great.  very simple but delicious 
potato pillows with caviar - good, but kind of overrated.  actually thought the potato was better than the caviar itself 
truffle cheese and onion croques  - pretty tasty, like a grilled cheese sandwich only much better 
marrow bones - good, but have had better and i know they're supposed to be fatty, this was a little too fatty for my taste
smoked trout salad - great.  can't remember what was in it, but i remember it was good.  something about the dressing really good  
pork chop - nice flavors and a decent portion, but would probably have rather had a couple more apps instead 

the service was good considering that our table had a pretty complicated order (several different groups splitting food) and although there were some mix ups, they were fixed in relatively short order.  

aside from the service, my other complaint is that we were sitting right next to the band and it was extremely loud.  i could barely hear the person next to me and i was screaming across the table to others.  

overall though, this place is not cheap but for what you get, its a decent value.  would recommend it!
author: Julie G.

description:
Well, what can I say about Bix...? I had my first date with my wife at Bix... I proposed to my wife at Bix... It's absolutely my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.... And I love the fact that it's totally a "locals" restaurant...

The Food: Amazing, Spectacular, Memorable, 
The Service: Something Every Restaurant Should Measure There's against...
The Atmosphere: Time Warp... I always feel like I step back into the 30's when I'm There... Its simple and yet sophisticated... 

If you want to eat at place that has the best of all three things that make an incredible evening, this is your place... BTW... Get the Kobe Beef... It's absolutely to die for...
author: James D.

description:
If you're looking for a restaurant with a well heeled clientele, then this is your place!  They have live jazz most nights and a ridiculously EXPENSIVE truffle hamburger, served on a brioche bun. Yum!  

Great cocktails, fabulous staff!

Parking is valet, spectacular antique stores nearby in case you're itching for some window shopping.
author: Torun H.

description: At the tail end of our honeymoon we ate at Bix and certainly enjoyed it! The service is excellent, from the bar to the table. Great dirty martini and selection of high end bourbons for my husband. It is dark inside, so a little difficult to read the menus, but overall, a really great dining experience. I had the steak tartare as an app, and it was such a large portion I ended up ordering 1/2 dozen oysters as my meal, although it too, was a small plate. The jazz band fired up around 8, and was receptive to our 2 selections after tipping of course. No singer :( but a good band indeed. We only had one gripe here and it was the large table they seated behind us around 9:00. First of all they had an infant with them. And 2 of the men in the party were wearing jeans and tee-shirts. Ok, ok, maybe the sitter canceled, maybe the in laws got sick, but really, even in that case, who brings a fussy infant and passes him around to the group to calm him the whole meal into a jazz club/restaurant that late at night. And jeans I can handle, some are so trendy these days, but at least put a button down on, or a sportcoat over the tee, SOMETHING to class up a little. And yes, we have 3 children between us and can dress down or up, we are pretty flexible, but this was just way overboard for us for a classy joint like Bix.
author: Anne B.

description: Beautiful decor and great service. Creative plates and all 3 of us were incredibly satisfied with our time here.
author: A D.

description: How many times have we eaten here? Lost track. Piano man playing, drinks shaken at table, summer tomato cart rolling, vibe perfect. Born 'n' raised here and I'm telling you, Bix is a solid call for a fancy night out.
author: Stan B.

description: I enjoyed everything I ate.  The portions were a bit small for the price but nonetheless delightful.  Worth visiting again!
author: Matt B.

description:
Question: "How can you tell when a lawyer is lying?" Answer: "His lips are moving." 
Question: "Why won't sharks attack lawyers?" Answer: "Professional Courtesy." 
Question: "Difference between a lawyer and a herd of buffalo?" Answer: "A lawyer charges more." 
Okay, so this place is crawlin' with young professionals and especially a group of young lawyers I met at the bar. Lawyers are a funny group of professionals and they got jokes.  They filled my mind with endless jokes and tried to convince me to convert my H.R. & Modeling profession into becoming an Attorney.  
What can be better than chillin' at the bar and hanging out with some whacked-out lawyers with never ending funny stories.   The bartender was cool.  The service was sweet.  I like the ambience and atmosphere is poshy. 
After I had a Manhattan and Mai-Tai, and I think someone bought me some sort of rum drink, Satsuna and another Manhattan, I started telling my own H.R. jokes and modeling jokes. 
Stupidest questions asked to HR by CEOs: "How much money do I make?" "Too much!" 
"Why must we control excessive absenteeism?" "We can discuss when I'm back in the office next month." 
The drinks were good.  I suppose the bar area can get pretty busy filled with after work folks.  I've dined here before.  But, it was years ago so I can't review the food yet until I come back here for a dining experience that I can remember, and I would love to come back.  So, I guess you can say you can expect a review update from me when I make my return someday.
author: Marzan W.

description: Great place for a nice dinner!  The big bar is awesome, and the bartenders are very knowledgeable and very good at their craft.  The food here is amazing, and their wine list is quite good as well.  The service staff (everyone included) was on point and made the experience very memorable.  One drawback, but not enough to take stars away, was that the waiter was too diligent in checking in.  We were looking for a long, relaxed dinner, and he kept coming to check to see if we needed anything or try to move us on to the next course.   Definitely going to be coming back here!
author: Francisco Z.

description: I have been to Bix so many time and LOVE everything about it : the atmosphere, the service, the food. What else do we need ???
author: Tiffany P.

description: If you are a TRUE JAZZ LOVER, this is the worst place to go to.  If you plan on having an expensive meal with a terribly loud & drunken clientele - this is the place for you.  The food is good, the service is fine but find another place to actually HEAR jazz.  Even if the music is good, you cannot hear it in the UPSCALE dive.  I will NEVER go to this club again, even if I only plan to eat food.  'Free jazz' is not a good deal here unless you have no taste in music.
author: Donna S.

description: It was so dark in here that I could barely read my menu, and so noisy that I could barely hear the people next to me. Usually these are deal breakers in my book, but you know what? Bix has the best bananas foster I have ever tasted. You would be a fool to leave here without trying it. An utter fool!!
author: Angela X.

description: Great food.  The lobster pasta is amazing and worth the price.
author: Aaron R.

description: the food here is four star, the bar and drinks are five star. This is one of the oldest bars in San Francisco and one of the most well known amongst San Franciscans. It does get packed with financial district professionals so you don't really want to go there under dressed, but they would give you the same service anyhow. The food is as good as you would expect, but you might have had better. I can't site all the stuff i have had there, it has been too long. Cheers. If you wanted to find this place always remember off a little alley called gold street!.
author: Sophie M.

description: I've had 2 wonderful dinner experiences at Bix -- both times, great food and great atmosphere. Most recently, my husband and I had a rather extravagant 4-course anniversary dinner and everything was absolutely delicious. I highly recommend the deviled eggs appetizer and the almond ice cream / plum / homemade chocolate madeleine dessert. A-mazing!
author: Amy N.

description:
My husband and I flew up to San Francisco last minute on business and I had Bix on a short list of restaurants that we wanted to check out. The idea of the jazz supper club off a narrow alley appealed to my sense of fantasy of San Francisco in the '30's. Well, first off, the energy felt flat upon entering the restaurant. No question, the space is beautiful but it was missing that smokey feeling I was looking for. I quickly noticed that there was no jazz being played, just an older gentleman at a piano playing standards, very quietly I might add. 

After we were seated we ordered a couple of Martini's that were brought in the smallest Martini glass I have ever seen...2 sips and you were done. Our waiter was nice enough and made some good suggestions. Then the trouble began. There was a table of 8 smack in the middle of the restaurant that very quickly consumed ALL of the attention of the staff. You could see that they were spending serious money on wine and I presume food as well. The rest of the tables surrounding them seemed to be an afterthought to the staff. 

We ordered two appetizers that we split, both of which took way too long to get. Then the real wait began. While I can't tell you exactly how long it was, we had finished our bottle of wine and had lost our appetite. The waiter finally came over confessing that he had screwed up and hadn't put our order in. He brought us a complimentary Ahi tartare (which was some of the most tasteless Ahi dishes I have ever had) to try and compensate for his error. While we appreciated this gesture, by then we had lost interest and the moment of enjoying the rest of our meal had passed. 

 Overall, the food was o-kay. The Ceviche was outstanding, the Chicken Hash was good, Bavette with puree of potatoes was cooked perfectly but lacked flavor, although the potatoes were divine. All around - - service & food was spotty and inconsistent. I was hoping for more!
author: Kelly K.

description: I came here for lunch with a friend during the week.  It was pretty quiet and we were the only people at the bar.  We had the cerviche and my friend ordered the steak which was fantastic, while I ordered the flounder.  The flounder on fist bite was ok.  Second bite it was salty.  Third bite was like drinking the ocean. It had this funny rubbery crust on it that I couldn't identify, and i could not taste the fish at all with the overpowering salt. Everything else was good, but not great or worth the price.  Service is impeccable but stuffy.  Good for a business lunch with people you dont actually want to do business with.
author: Anne R.

description:
Elizabeth and I decided to hit up BIX for an early dinner after work because my flight wasn't until 8:25p.  If I had known how amazing it was, I would've opted to go when we had more time... but the food was so good and we were in such deep conversation that we lost track of time and I just made it onto my flight! (yes, so unlike me) Anyway, when we first walked in - the entrance is in a little alleyway-like street - it was a little dark and reminded me of an old steakhouse or something.  But classy old where the older gentleman at the bar sipping on a glass of $50 whiskey used to own the largest cotton mill in the country or something like that.  We were sat a cozy corner table and started to have mini issues with having too many delicious sounding options.  We ended up getting a bunch of hor d'oeuvres and split a salad and a meal.  First we started with the Tuna Tartare (with fresh hummus, mint & preserved lemon on cumin lavosh crackers) which came out in 4 beautifully crafted bites.  WOW.  I could've eaten 4 to myself.  You always hear you shouldn't order sushi/raw seafood on Mondays, but it tasted fresh and yummy!  We then ordered the Truffle Cheese & Sweet Onion Croques which were basically like mini grilled cheese triangles w/ the crusts cut.  They came with 4 again & yes I have an affinity for truffles and mushrooms, but these little buttery, warm, cheesy triangles of heaven!!!  (note: all hor d'oeuvres come in 4 except the deviled eggs and potato pillows)  Before the croques came out though, our waiter gave us a little taste of the deviled eggs (with chives, summer beans & truffles) and by far they were the best deviled eggs ever!!  Who would think that you could make them that amazing, but BIX does!  (Thank you to our waiter for that nice special treat!) We then split the Star Route Farm Baby Lettuce Salad (with strawberries, almonds, feta & honey-sherry vinaigrette) and the Fresh Maine Lobster Spaghetti with Lobster Cream.  The waiter did say it was rich, but it wasn't as creamy as I thought it would be.  Sharing it was perfect (especially because we had so much other food!)  We only had wine, but they have some great looking drinks on the menu.  I would definitely recommend it!
http://notomatoesplease.wordpress.com/2010/06/28/dont-forget-to-wear-flowers-in-your-hair/
author: Kim N.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Fran - it hits the mark on everything: food, decor, atmosphere and service.  Perfect date spot, fun place to take parents who are in town, really just head here anytime you want a fancier night out.  Here's the breakdown:

Atmosphere: Perfectly romantic and elegant, without feeling stuffy.  There's live piano/jazz, which I love.  A huge oak bar takes up one wall downstairs - which is a great place to grab a drink and take in the scene while you wait for your table to be ready (have waited probably 5 mins every time I have gone, but nothing outrageous).  The layout is an open plan two-story set-up (the second story is more of a balcony level) and super tall ceilings.  I also love the back-alley location -- really completes the speakeasy feel that they have going.

Food: Consistently amazing.  For apps: the crab rolls are mini crab roll sandwiches (think traditional lobster rolls-style but overflowing with fresh dungeness lumb crabmeat).  yum.  The croques are always a crowd pleaser.  I once went during the peak season for heirloom tomatoes and they offered a sampling plate of the freshest, most tasty versions I've had (and I'm not a tomato fanatic). For main courses: the Chicken Hash is one of their specialties and it's delicious.  Kobe steak's obviously phenom.  They prepare the steak tartare tableside and it's standout.  Really, everything I've had has been fantastic.  One downer on desert was that they aren't allowed to flambe their bananas foster at the table (fire codes are always getting in the way of my good times), which is really why I had ordered it =)

Service: Outstanding!  Our waiter the first time I went was in the top tier of the best I've had.  My mom, who's particularly picky on service, raved.  Our server did not overpour our wine (big pet peeve -- when they try to pour out the entire bottle so that you'll buy another, instead of letting a little bit breathe) he also didn't take plates till everyone was obviously finished, and did not remove drinks that still had sips left (also a pet peeve -- I still want to drink that last sip of great wine!).  They consistently recommend great things off the menu and offer legit wine advice (good value recs, not just pushing you to the most expensive on the list)

So many good things to say!  Take a date and it should definitely inspire a night cap or two.. ; )
author: Scottie G.

description: Bix is one of those great San Francisco restaurants. The ambiance here is just outstanding. Think old school and glamorous, straight out of a film noir. It's the kind of restaurant I used to dream about going to when I was younger. I love old school so this is my kind of place. The decor is great here, leather booths, white tablecloths and the waiters are the really good waiters in ties and who really know what they're doing. And the food is classic American. I got the beef tartare which was sublime, and even better were the classic deviled eggs. We also got the potato puffs with caviar. Mmmmmm. I would highly recommend all three of those. My husband got the lobster pasta which he said was amazing. This is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Cathy T.

description:
My wife and I went to Bix for our third wedding anniversary.  In the spirit of full disclosure, we have two young children (20 and 4 months old) so it was our first "big" night out in a long long time.  So you can imagine our expectations were probably a little high.  So please take that into consideration.  Here are our overall impressions.

Pros:
-First and foremost, the food was excellent.
-Cocktails: I had two Manhattan's, they were exceptional.
-Setting: Great location, valet available.

Cons:
-The tables are so close together it felt like the couple next to us was at our table.  I felt like I could not have a private conversation.
-Waitress had too many tables to attend to.  I ordered coffee it never came, yet it appeared on the bill.  Service was a little slow.

Overall, the quality of the food overcame some of the other drawbacks, though in another three years when my wife and I are ready for a "big" night on the town I don't think we will go back to Bix.
author: Aaron R.

description:
any place that has valet gets an instant star from me.

the space upstairs seems more private and secluded than the noisier downstairs seating.

with no sommelier on hand, the servers were thankfully quite knowledgeable.  do start with a fun retro cocktail or martini.

1. the potato pillows with caviar and creme fraiche was a beautiful blend of a slight crunch, light creamy texture and beads of not too strongly flavored caviar.
2. the ceviche was light and crisp with the corn nuts had a perfect bite of heat from the habanero.
3. be decadent with the roasted bone marrow.  a touch of rock salt goes a long way.
4. the fresh maine lobster with lobster cream was rich and heavy.
5.any thing truffled is top of my list so the truffled pecorino burger was a burst of flavor with each bite.

here is where they lose the star...the dessert was a too firm panna cotta.  guess i should have ordered the bread pudding.  ah well, next time.
author: Anh V.

description:
Since my boss knows I am a prolific Yelper and an Elite one at that, I was given the auspicious duty of selecting the location for the company Xmas dinner. 
This was no easy feat since my fellow coworkers (with the exception of my boss) have slightly less...er...shall we say "developed" tastebuds as mine.  So I needed to find a place that served good food that wasn't overly complex in a nice atmosphere while still serving food that would appeal to more sophisticated palates as well.
Enter BIX and Yelp.
Based solely on reviews I put all my blind faith in the powers of Yelp and booked a 6pm reservation for a Thursday night. It bears mentioning that for a reservation of 10 BIX was the ONLY restaurant I had been able to find amongst the 5 or so that I called that didn't require a credit card to hold the table OR limit the menu to three items as Jardiniere, Absinthe and Zinnia did. For the record, I find that practice ridiculous as the dietary restrictions within our group were many so a three item menu would have dissatisfied one and all. I also feel that 10 people is not difficult for most diners to accomodate without limiting their menu so a fine dining establishment should be able to plan accordingly or allow us to order ahead.  We had a non-chicken eater (don't ask), a heavily pregnant woman (LOTS of restrictions there) and a person with allergies to grapes and olives.  So you do the math if the menu is restricted to three items.  Kudos to BIX for obviously realizing such things.
Everyone seemed to enjoy their meals. We started with a torchon of foie gras that was amazing. It was buttery, smooth and so delicious I could have sworn I was eating the liver from the goose that laid the golden eggs. We followed that goodness with some steak tartar that was okay but wasn't as good as I've had it elsewhere (but I'm pretty picky about my tartar). Rounding it up was the oysters and they were phenomenal. Probably my favorite part (please note that our pregnant diner didn't get to enjoy any of these lol).
We also started with a nice bottle of Burgundy whose name escapes me because I didn't order it but which I know to be pricey because my boss fancies himself something of an oenophile. I ordered the second bottle of wine and it was a $92 bottle of Montepulciano that I and others found quite good as well.
