I made an 8:00 reservation on a recent Friday night.  We were told to sit at the bar until a table opened up.  I thought an 8:00 reservation meant that we would be seated at 8:00.  After 10 minutes, I asked when what was going on, and they said some people were getting up, and it would be just a few minutes.  We did in fact see people getting up, and then we saw others being seated - I guess those were other people who made earlier reservations and were finally getting a table.  After waiting for 25 minutes, I asked again when we would be seated.  Instead of expressing some sympathy, the hostess brushed me off saying I had only been waiting for 15 minutes.  That was not true, and I pulled out my phone and proved to her that it was 8:25 p.m.  She said it was normal to have to wait that long on a busy night.  I told her she should have told me that when I made the reservation, as I would have gone somewhere else.  At that point, I was upset, and frankly, even though we were finally seated at 8:30, and even though the manager brought us a free appetizer for having to wait, it just ruined the evening.  Sorry, Bix, but I won't be back.
author: brett b.

description: This is one of the best bars in the city. The bartenders could and should write a book on how to prepare and present classic cocktails. However, the food is another story. The appetizers and the desserts were top notch and that's where we should have stopped. Every vegetable and potato dish we ordered was pureed. What is with that? Did the cook just get a Cuisinart to play with? I could have eaten my dinner through a straw. I know the crowd in here is a bit old school, but come on...
author: Alexander H.

description: A way classy place to down a pricey Fat Tire, complete with live jazz trio.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Bix is a great spot to get a cocktail after dinner downtown.  It definitely has the 'grown up' vibe going on -- given the knowledgable bartenders, swank jazz and beautiful decor.
author: Heather C.

description: I love the atmosphere, the food was good portion and delicious, desserts were also big. I recommend
author: Bak M.

description: Elegant, wood paneled without feeling clubby and sporting an eternally well heeled crowd, Bix is a great place for a date, or a celebration, and is a perfect excuse to frock up.
author: Stellah D.

description: It had been about 3 years since I last went to Bix, and I question myself as to why I stopped going. I sat upstairs for the first time, and it was much nicer, quieter. More date-ish, with large booths suitable for snuggling and feeding eat other (if thats what you're into). It has such a great retro feel to it, and the back alley location makes you feel like you're all of a sudden in Manhattan back in the 20s-30s.  Everything I ordered was absolutely delish. Their signature steak tartar, although might gross people out to look at, was so fresh and good, and not at all slimy. The mini burgers, not very enticing by the sound of it, was addictive with the blue cheese sauce they spread in it (almost looked like profiteroles), and my halibut was baked perfectly, just juicy enough without being raw. Flakey and flavorful. Great live jazz band too.
author: Marina K.

description:
Pretty bad overall experience. My group of four had 8:30 reservations on a Tuesday night, and we got seated at an itty bitty table suitable for two people. They even had to remove the table decor just to fit two appetizer plates on the table. 

After the appetizers, we waited..................................and waited some more.................




killed the bottle of wine.....................waited some more...........



Finally after an hour our food came! So I've never really had any food sent back, because I feel like its a bit rude, but for the wait and the price, my lamb chop was completely unacceptable. Completely dry and overdone, I'm pretty sure it was sitting in the oven for 30 minutes while they prepped the other dishes. So I did ask for another piece which took another 20 mins or so to come out. Even then, the lamb chop was bland and certainly nothing special. 

The only things saving this from a 1 star review are two dishes:
Potato Pillow: melts in your mouth. absolutely delicious.
Lobster Pasta: I really don't even like seafood/lobster, but I had some of my girlfriends and it was BOMB.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
I had a business partner from France in town and was looking for a veritable San Francisco institution for dinner.  After consulting Yelp, I chose Bix, and it didn't disappoint.  After searching for the restaurant for a bit, we found the alleyway of Gold Street.  
The decor is totally 19th century.  A query of our waiter revealed that Gold Street was actually right off of the old pier and that everything from their block to the Embarcadero  was actually fill.  So, this was the Barbery Coast, and Gold Street was were 49ers came to exchange gold for cash.  It is thought that the building might have been a gold exchange at the time, but their not sure if it's an original building or whether it was rebuilt after the great quake.  
The dinner was awesome.  All appetizers so we could sample a little of everything, we started with the Ceviche, Crab cakes and fried oysters paired with a Central Coast unfiltered Viognier.  The wine was nice, with a great balance of fruit and acidity.  The Ceviche was delicious with a jalapeno mix, the crab cakes amazing, fresh crab, lightly browned, and with a beautiful crispy bread surrounding, then finally the fried oysters with a delicious cream sauce on a gentle wafer.  The next course consisted of lamb sliders, St. Johns Marrow and truffled oil french fries.  All were amazing, the lamb had a taste of Moroccan spice, the marrow simply decadent, and french fries that delighted.  I paired these dishes with a Pinot Noir from the North Coast that was definitely new world, but fine, delicious and perfect for the food at hand. 
We talked and negotiated over our delicious food, but the apex of the dinner was when Fred confided in me that over the past ten years American cuisine has really progressed beyond anyone's potential aspirations.  He confided that he thought that you can actually eat better in America than in France.  Having grown up in France half of my life, I think that this might have been a wine induced exaggeration, but it's really nice to hear that from a true bon vivant.  Cheers.
author: Nicolas T.

description: If you want to have a cocktail in a gorgeous setting, go to Bix.  From the moment you walk down the Gold Street alley-like setting, you'll feel as though you are stepping back in time to a more classy era.  Think 20s.  Every time I go to Bix I am pleased with the drinks, service and hors d'oeuvres.  Ask for Kevin and have him tell you the story about the card that is stuck to the ceiling.  Bix is the place to go for lovely jazz and great classic drinks.
author: Anna S.

description: Classic setting...dark wood, starched white aprons, good portions and stiff drinks.  The steak tartare is the best in SF, and twice I've order from the seasonal menu and been very impressed.  Try to get a booth on the balcony upstairs because it can get a bit loud downstairs.  The wine list is a little thin but this place is known for its drinks.  Definitely an elegant, romantic spot that's great for a nice date, but it's also a good place to grab a martini after work.  A bit pricey but nothing out of the ordinary for this town.
author: Geoff K.

description: I'm down with anything that's old school. Thus, I'm down with Bix. It's been a family birthday destination for ages, but lately I've taken to hanging at the bar even when Cousin Kate isn't celebrating her 22nd. Sure, it's a great date destination. But it's also fun to kick off a night there, grabbing a drink or two at the bar and people watching, occasionally chatting up and sleazy businessman or spotting a celeb. Plus, you can't beat smooth jazz in the background. When I'm dining there, which is usually when someone else is footing the bill, I never, ever pass up the grilled cheese and onion starter. It's perfect bar food without a crappy bar...
author: Beth S.

description: I've been here several times now and have never been disappointed. Whether grabbing some drinks after work before a night out or coming for a full fledged dinner evening, it's a great spot. When coming for drinks, they have a fabulous complimentary Chex mix, you can grab apps at the bar, there's a great selection of liquor and some lovely wines, and there's a good happening scene - lots of people chatting and making friends. For dinner it is a great experience. The live jazz really makes the evening. I'd highly recommend the crab roll (New England style), fresh mozarella and heirloom tomato salad, and the Bananas Foster. The crab pasta is very good but extremely rich. I've tried my hubby's Kobe beef steak and it was delish. Great for out of towners, birthdays, you name it!
author: Sarah R.

description: The most impressive aspect of Bix is the atmosphere:  it's chic.  It doesn't hurt that they have vallet parking either.  There's a huge after work martini crowd, and it's the perfect place, especially if the jazz group is playing.  The one time I ate there I was underwhelmed by the food and aware of the high prices.  The tables on the mezzanine provide a cool view of the bar.  I think that's the best component for me.  A+ for drinks, less for food.
author: Patrick B.

description: Elegant, classic atmosphere... The chocolate bread pudding is to die for!!! I enjoyed my salad and halibut.. but dessert was good, I'll never forget it... it was warm, moist with oozing chocolate in the inside and perfectly crisp on the outside.. was so yummy with vanilla ice cream...
author: Denise L.

description: Fabulous martini's await you after you stroll in from the dark alley, known as Gold Street. The atmosphere at Bix brings you back to a different era...try 1920's. The live music creates a mood like non other. The food is fantastic. This will definitely be a night to remember. Don't forget your reservation! Bix usually books out 2 weeks in advance...but it's worth the wait. Enjoy!
author: Stefanie B.

description: I actually had a really good experience here in January, during "Dine ABout Town". Table was ready for us (group of 6, I think) as soon as we got there. Service was good. Food exceeded expectations. Dessert (I think I had something with bananas and caramel in it, which is always a good thing, if you ask me) was delicious, and it wasn'tn soooo loud that you couldn't carry on a conversation. It was a bit pricey, but I knew that going in, so it was okay.
author: beth l.

description: Bix is a fun experience.  It is throw back to a different era.  The service is consistently good and I love; love, love, love and darkly lit room.  Bix has a wonderful environment and the jazz infused background creates a memorable experience.  The menu is non-changing but consistently good quality; I am all about ingredient and then I am equally challenging on food inspiration.  Chicken Hash a seasoned favourite is on this menu.  I like the wine list; although small; is good.  I always want my wine list big and voluminous; I am surprised that they would have Au Bon Climat as their Pinot Noir; I would expect something unexpected.  I am disappointed that they do not have large format red wine glasses.  Please make it a Bordeaux.  I like Bix and will go back again and again.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Fun place to meet for drinks and the truffled grilled cheese is yummy!
author: shoba d.

description:
everything was delicious! top-notch, old-school san francisco.

FOOD:~steak tartare was very very yummy. mmm i love raw meat & steak tartare makes it socially acceptable to chew some.

~the crisp fried oysters were amaaaaaaaazing! how did they do that? i could've eaten 100, no kidding.

~i had the marrow bones as my entree, & i think they thought i was weird. but i don't care, it was off the hook.

~the lamb was reeeeeally good. reeeeeeally good.

everything we ate here was tops! they really know food here. i love how classic it is.

SERVICE: very nice. classy.

DECOR: beautiful. we sat upstairs, which was gorgeous with the high ceilings. i do think the sconces are a little cheesy & should be changed now that we're in a new century (see michael mina). i wanna see the band next time. i looooove the paintings downstairs.

BATHROOM: nice.

OVERALL: i'm so glad i got to try bix finally! nice, romantic, formal place, top-notch food.
author: miss b.

description: Fresh food, good drinks. Can only review the vegetarian options on the menu. Roasted beets skewers, brussel sprouts, creamed spinach, asparagus soup - all really good.
author: Mona F.

description: Top notch, baby.  Excellent and knowledgeable staff.  Excellent seasonal menu (absolutely do not miss any seasonal tomato salads or the beef tartar) and raw bar selections.  Reasonably priced, considering.  Ambience is pretty unique -- set in a cavernous old speakeasy  with entrance through an obscure alley near the TA building.  They typically have competent to good live jazz.  Check out the large paintings on the lower-level -- very cool, very _Remains of the Day_.  The bar is usually jumping with b&t/finance on weekdays evenings.  It's a great place to slip away in for an evening.  Bubble Bar is just down the street, which is a nice complement on a slow evening.  You absolutely must book early for this place.
author: Brad S.

description: Now i really dined there (today at lunch with Dine About Town 2005 lunch menu) it was EXCELLENT!!! wow i love my seared tuna entree and chocalot bread pudding. Probably the best bread pudding ever. Even though chocalot is a little too rich for me at lunch. Portion is big too (for lunch) I high recommend this restaurant to anyone!
author: Angela H.

description: Great atmosphere and lovely food. Had all appetizers the last time we were there and they were all A+! Great for evening drinks as well with a nice bar area. Cute place in the alley way...
author: Yan M.

description: Classy but not stuffy atmosphere...yummy-for-your-tummy chocolate bread pudding :o)  I love the location...seems like such a random alley!
author: Joyce L.

description: Absolutely nothing exciting about the food, the atmosphere or the wine.  BUT - we did end up sitting next to Gavin when we went, so that itself was worth the outrageous price we paid!
author: Serena Y.

description: Yummy!  Had the pre-fixe lunch menu, and everything was spectacular, from the appetizer, to the entree, to the dessert.  The ahi tuna was very tasty.  I had some kind of fish entree that was also extremely well done.  The chicken hash is to die for.  I personally enjoyed the chocolate brioche pudding although some people seem not to like the texture.  It was a little different than you might expect, but very good.  The creme brulee here is also very rich and yummy.  The restaurant has a very interesting lay out, but it's a very cool set up.  A very nice place to go for a "treat yourself" event.
author: Waynele Y.

description: Although I think my sister got food poisoning here, I still think it's one of the best gems in the city.  Can't beat the atmosphere and the steak tar tar is fantastic.
author: Lane K.

description: So I'm a little torn here. The actual restaurant was ok; I liked the bar and the piano but the upstairs area was not particularly nice. But.... the food was pretty good. Best thing we ordered - the truffled cheeseburger. It was amazingly good. I didn't order it but I wanted to eat the whole thing when it came.
author: shadi m.

description:
I think this is my first 5 star rating. I'm almost tempted to give one star and a bad review just to make it a little easier to get a reservation. 

You'd never expect this place to look so nice inside considering the alley it's in. The food is amazing. Try the ceviche. 

The people in there are really nice and helpful. Not too pricey either.
author: JeF m.

description:
How can this be a 3 star?!!  It's all about the attitude!  The bartender was certainly a bit "put off" to have to offer a drink to new customers at the bar?!!
It's been years - but my last visit was certainly 5 star food, 4 star overall due to noise level busy night...
For the first time ever, decided to defer from accepting a second drink from the guy; actually asked for the other bartender - and received a gracious and understanding nod regarding his co-workers attitude.  (he made it a double for my friend on the house to make ammends) That's class... 
I will go back; however will try the other end of the beautiful bar....
author: Mary M.

description: Went with spouse on Fri 9/23 /2011 - made reservations with " Emily " week before and requested a special table on main level next to the piano as it was a birthday and engagement celebration .. No problem was the response !! ( great ) -- They called on thursday to confirm and I asked them to read the notes in the file .. they did after some confusion and everything was perfect .. ( ok then ) So we show up at 7Pm and were taken upstairs to a booth style table __ hey wait a minute .. not what I requested !! - well who did you speak with was the response ? Emily I said .. ohh - well sorry we dont have a table available downstairs .. no kidding - well ok let me have the empty table in the middle of the upstairs . Oh noooo thats a vip table reserved months ago.. sorry .. This place cant suck enough !!.. snobby - pretenious jerks . food and service less then stellar . go if u must ,, be prepaired to be talked to like your the idiot .. not once did anyone come over to ask .. they knew better !!
author: JOSEPH R.

description: Always a warm place in my heart for Bix-that great bar, the tasty burgers (yes, burgers-they are so worth it!)
author: Beth V.

description: What really stood out in a  recent foray to this classic alleyway spot was the service ... really a notch above even the excellent.  Still, for an evening cocktail it's a bit crowded in the slim bar area if you aren't lucky enough to get a spot at the bar or a perch at the rail.  A nice summer evening though can make the few tables outside really nice.  The alley hardly gets any cars passing through so it almost feels like a patio.  4 stars just because it does live up to it's elegant reputation without being overly pretentious, but definitely not a regular hangout.
author: J P.

description: Fantastic atmosphere that maintains its speak-easy history.  If you go, make sure you go when the Jazz band is playing.  I think they usually start around 9pm.  Overall, the food is very good and I highly recommend the Tomato bar!  You get a number of slices of 5 or so different types of tomatoes served with olive oil, a sprinkle of english sea salt, and home made mozzarella cheese.  Delicious!
author: Brian L.

description: Classic old school restaurant setting. This place is great for a full on dinner, drinks or grabbing a burger with cottage fries.
author: Raymond M.

description: Great energy and classic vibe, decadent atmosphere, great dirty martini and yummy food - but the service is what's the best.  We had a reservation but got caught in horrendous traffic so I called to let them know we'd be an hour late and the hostess told me just to call her when we were almost there and she'd fit us in - on a packed Saturday night, I wasn't sure if she was kidding or if we'd have to wait for hours but she totally squeezed us in after less than five minutes.  That was totally beyond what I would expect from a crowded popular restaurant and shows they actually care about their patrons.
author: Jean C.

description:
My friend and I went here for the Dine About Town special. We were the first one's there, beating the power crowd that was about to make it to dinner. The waiter was really friendly-- I swear he reminded me of the host at supperclub! We both ordered the soup, the char (a fish dish-- in case you didn't know because we didn't) because the waiter suggested that over the chicken dish and my friend got the creme brulee and I got the chocolate bread pudding for dessert. Everything was AMAZING. The soup was yummy, the char had sooo many flavors that I had to eat the whole thing, and the desserts were both yummy! We also ordered the tuna tartar on the side.... which we almost didn't get because the cook "forgot to make it." However, the waiter recognized it before I mentioned it, and brought it to us on the house! I was really impressed by this. I left with an overfull stomach-- because I ate EVERYTHING!

Overall, great experience and I would definitely go again!!!
author: Jess D.

description:
This upper prestige restaurant is tucked away in a alley.  But with it's ambience of the old 30's, it takes you back in time.  The food is expensive, but good.   Unfortunately, the portion is lacking.  When we had soup, it came out in a REALLY big round bowl.  It was basically just a thin layer of soup.  I felt like I was scraping the bottom of the bowl.

The whole dining experience is great though.
author: Gary Y.

description: This is a restaurant you'd feel safe taking someone out for a special dinner. Tasteful decor. Upscale setting. In a very hidden alley in Jackson Square. Good wine options. Menu is a delight. Seperate bar seating area. Occasional jazz musician appearances. Ask for a Jameson Macree cocktail. Its very satisfying and you deserve it on a Friday evening after work :)
author: Food L.

description: With amazing atmosphere, great service, and wonderful food. Bix is easily one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  I had the Dungeness Crab Spaghetti but I would HIGHLY recommend the Kobe Steak; so amazing tender and rich it melts in your mouth.  With a great glass of champagne, you can't go wrong here.
author: Angela D.

description: Disappointing to the extreme. The jazz was bland and the band took breaks between each song. Their cocktails, esp the ginger gimlet, sucked. My crab spaghetti was good but not for the price. My asparagus soup was unremarkable. My main reason for visiting this place was to try their Bananas Foster. Ugh. It was all ice cream with a microscopic sprinkling of banana pieces. The flute of champagne I ordered came out FLAT. It was as if they had an open bottle sitting in the back for hours and I was the unlucky soul who ordered the last glassful. It was incredibly loud. There is nothing remotely classy or elegant about this place; how misleading their website was. The only decent thing about Bix was the service.
author: Faye S.

description: We had a great dinner here with friends.   Their location is tres San Francisco urban and a bit hidden as you enter from an alley (adding to the coolness factor, of course).  They offer valet parking and great jazz music.  You kind of feel like you're in a "member's only" club and somehow snuck in.
author: Jenn K.

description:
For more than seventeen years, Bix has provided San Francisco movers & shakers, travelers "in-the-know," and food lovers from around the world an exceptional place to dine. Or that's what I've been told by several colleagues and friends. Naturally, I was intrigued, so I decided to give Bix a try. 

Atmosphere
Tucked in an alley between several high-end antique stores, Bix is reminiscent of an elegant supper club from the 1930s. Upon entering the restaurant, I stood at the enormous curved mahogany bar until my table was ready. Service was efficient, although the bartender didn't spend too much time telling me about their special cocktails or bar menu, which included firecracker shrimp with chipotle aioli ($11), tuna tartare on olive toasts ($12), seared day boat scallops wrapped in chorizo ($11).  The tuna was excellent: fresh and flakey with just the right amount of subtle fishiness, blending perfectly with the olive toasts. The buttery scallops and plump shrimp also worked well, although the chipotle aioli tasted like it had been prepared with out-of-date mayonnaise. Oh well. After ten minutes, I was taken to my table, which turned out to be a cozy, faux-velvet covered booth on the second floor. 

The interior of Bix is stunning. You'd expect to see Frank Sinatra at the bar ordering a martini, or perhaps Jean Harlow sauntering down the staircase to go "powder her nose." Other nice interior features included fluted columns, starched linens and polished flatware. The wait staff is dressed to impress in white jackets, which added a nice touch to the already elegant ambiance. 


The Food
Chef Bruce Hill's 25-years of experience includes stints at some of California's finest restaurants, including Stars, Aqua, Oritalia and the Waterfront. Of course, you'd expect all of his experience to translate into an incredible meal from start to finish. And for the most part, this was the case, although there were a few misses. The chef's selection of mixed hors d'oeuvres ($9.75 per person) was a surprisingly tasty assortment of tuna tartare, foie gras mousse, cauliflower panna cotta and truffled potato puree' in crispy potato cups. I could have done with a few more potato cups, which were crispy, flavorful, and just about the best thing I've had in my mouth in quite some time. On the other hand, and due to a childhood cauliflower trauma incident, I wasn't thrilled with the cauliflower panna cotta. The chilled summer gazpacho of heirloom tomatoes, melons, and cucumber  ($8.25) was extremely light and refreshing, and really set the stage for the next courses. Other excellent first courses included arugula and nectarine salad with champagne vinaigrette ($9.75) and the romaine salad with Point Reyes blue cheese vinaigrette ($9.25). 

As for entrees, the Florida gulf prawns with potato gnocchi, sweet fennel, tomatoes and bread crumbs  ($26) were outstanding. Big and juicy, the tender flesh of the prawns blended superbly with the tartness of the tomatoes. On the other hand, and what I feel is a poor description that should be clarified on the menu, is the Maine lobster spaghetti with langoustine tails ($28). At first glance, one is led to believe that there are going to be large chunks of lobster included in the dish. Instead, the spaghetti is cooked in a lobster-flavored broth. That's right, no big chunks of lobster, for what is otherwise a lovely pasta dish. Other entrees worth mentioning include grilled rack of lamb with lentils and minted carrots ($32), and Kobe "Bavette" steak with pommes puree, roasted spring onions and natural jus ($29). And then it was time for dessert. As a confessed "chocoholic," I was quite pleased with pastry chef Aaron Toensing's warm chocolate brioche bread pudding ($7.75). Come to think of it, there's really nothing better than anything made with chocolate to end a great meal. Other desserts included bananas foster with dark rum and vanilla ice cream ($7.95), strawberries with brown sugar cream ($7.75), and Bix cookies, jellies and ice cream sandwiches ($7.50).

If you've been looking for a great place for a romantic dinner surrounded by elegant ambiance, Bix just might be the place you've been looking for.
author: David G.

description: Really good food, and discrete helpful service. Can you really ask for more?
author: Alessandra J.

description: My husband and I came here for my birthday dinner a few months ago.  The food was very good.  I had pork - I can't remember the exact preparation but I remember the server recommended it and it exceeded my expectations.  Husband's burger with truffle cheese was also delicious - the only $25+ burger we've ever had, but hey.  Service was good, but by no means great.  Big plus is that the wine list includes A. Rafanelli, which is fantastic, in my opinion, and in any event, can't be purchased anywhere else but the vineyard (appointment only).
author: Jes H.

description: I've been to Bix for apps and drinks, the bar is really fun, but never had the chance to have a full meal. The service is very polished and it's a really lively atmosphere. Our waiter was a little on the loud side (ok he was SHOUTING) but to his defense it wfas loud in the restaurant. I had halibut  with some french chili  butter and asparagus soup with meyer lemon cream. Both were very tasty albeit a bit heavy. I think this is a good restaurant to take your parents if they are visiting, they have live music starting at 9:30.
author: Carson H.

description: One of the most amazing restaurant I've ever been to. Stu was an incredible waiter - he definitely "made our prom night" (to quote a friend). Since we were underage, he suggested this "fancy grape juice" (to quote Stu himself). He also spent time talking about the food - where it came from, etc. It just made everything taste extra good. Halfway through our dinner we had the piano playing, but BIX wasn't as loud as I expected. The best part of the dinner was the dessert - the banana foster .... was INCREDIBLE.
author: Judy L.

description: Make no mistake, this is an excellent restaurant with amazing dishes, great service and classy (I hardly use this word) atmosphere.
author: N. C.

description: I came here for a company event, and I have to say I enjoyed my time here immensely. This place is chic, trendy, and elegant. The staff is extremely friendly and attentive. There hasn't been one thing I tried here that I didn't like. All the appetizers were good, and I was particularly impressed with the lobster pasta - fantastic! Highly recommend this place for company/professional gatherings.
author: Angie K.

description: I came in on Friday night with a group of 4 around 11:30pm and sat behind the glasses chilling in ice and hoped to enjoy a few drinks.  An older gentleman who I later learned was named Brad and had worked there for over 20 years approached us and asked if he could help us.  I turned to ask my wife what she wanted and turned around only to see Brad yelling at the other bartender "why am I serving these idiots".  The other bartender who was carrying multiple bottles of wine simply put them down and asked us what he could do to help us.  I inquired why Brad had gotten so upset with us and if the bar was closing.  The other bartender stated that the bar never closed and apologized for Brad being rude and offered to buy us a round of drinks.  At his point I was so angry with the way we had been treated initally that I wanted nothng more to do with the place.  The other bartender who said his name was Chad convinced us to stay and made us some delicious specialty cocktails.  Even while Chad was making our drinks Brad just stood behind him still yelling about who knows what.  The couple next to us that witnessed all this said they had been treated as poorly by Brad as we had.  All I can say is no matter how long someone works somewhere they have no right to speak to anyone the way Brad spoke to us much less paying customers.  We will return for the ambiance and deliciuos cocktails but if I or anyone in my group see Brad behind the bar we will simply leave and go somewhere else.
author: Mark O.

description:
I've been using Yelp for so long now I thought I should finally contribute myself. 
I found this place on yelp and thought the reviews were for the most part accurate, but I wanted to put in my two cents as well.
 To be clear, the food deserves only 3 stars for the price. We were happy with everything we ordered, but nothing was amazing.  Well actually I did love the sweet corn, tomato and mushroom ragout (side dish), but everything else was good but not memorable. As usual I recommend the appetizers and first courses over the main meal.
The reason for the four stars is the ambiance/style of the place, the live music, and the service.  The jazz trio played standards with just enough of their own style.  Our waiter Frank was helpful and just friendly enough. (I know people complain about stuffiness, but it felt appropriately formal for the price and style of the place.) We could not decide between two desserts and so ordered both. When one of the wrong ones showed up, he had a new one sent out before we could tell him we were fine with whatever showed up (all three were good).
He apologized for the mistake and the sugar rush, and somehow none of the desserts showed up on the bill. 
It was a fun evening, and a place where it felt like every table was the best seat in the house. they made us feel good and then left us alone to enjoy our dinner.
author: Q F.

description: Went here for dinner with my parents.  The food was quite good, although not phenomenal.  I loved the ambiance, and the drinks were stellar.  I had  the Sazerac, and although I was a little disappointed that they used Herbsaint instead of an absinthe, it was delicious.  I'd definitely come back for cocktails and some snacks when the band is playing, although I think I might go elsewhere for dinner.
author: Evan M.

description: I spent a lot of time back in my younger days at BIX when I worked in the FiDi and hadn't been back in a while. Well, we went for dinner a couple of nights ago and it was really amazing. They have been able to maintain the atmosphere along with the menu and super bar scene. Actually, it was one of the best meals i've had in a while. Looking forward to going back when they have the heirloom tomatoes in season!
author: BARI P.

description: Bix has been bookmarked for a while and when I started my 100 top eats mission and saw it was on the list I decided the waiting was over. Made a girl date and we headed over after a happy hour at bubble lounge to try the item of choice - gin martini and their tuna tartar. I'm not really a gin drinker - but if the list says to try the gin martini thats what i order. I AM a tuna lover however so I was happy for the excuse to up my mercury intake. Gin martini was surprisingly good, actually, they may have turned me into the occasional gin (instead of vodka) martini drinker. The tuna tartar was very good, but i order it so often everywhere i go i wasn't sure how i'd rate it alone. Definitely really good - but one of the best things to eat in the city? debatable. And their menu is fabulous, everything sounds good so we were confused on how this pairing made the list. Then - it dawned on us - its the pair. Have a sip of your very strong, bitter martini then a bite of the very mellow, soft but flavorful, almost buttery tartar and vice-versa and Ta-Daaaa - they are the perfect combo to compliment eachother. I really liked the dish. We also had a few sides, bread right outta the oven, broccoli and brussel sprouts. The brussels were the best I've ever tasted, I could have had another full bowl of them. Then we orderd a banana foster to split. Divine. Hot bourbon sauce melting the creamy vanilla with a just right ripened banana - and a side of 2 coffees - heaven. The atmosphere was very classy too. I will bring the hubby back for a real date soon.
author: Audrey V.

description: I'm giving Bix 3 stars because of the food and the ambiance, but would have been 4 or 5 if not for the woman who waited on us. We were there for a 75th birthday party of my friend's mom and the gal who waited on our table was incredibly sour the whole evening. It felt like she just didn't want to be there and she never ever smiled and seemed annoyed when we weren't ready to jump to it on ordering cocktails and ordering food the first time she came by. She seemed truly pissed off that we might want to have our cocktails and then order. This is a fine dining establishment but she took it down to diner level with her attitude. We had fun in spite of her but she definitely put a damper on our enjoyment and I won't go back because of that service. I've been there before but her approach just ruined the place for me. Not worth the money to be treated like we were just a big bother rather than paying customers!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Cocktails are a-ok (nothing to write home about, but good enough to order), appetizers are good, and the ambiance is as good as it gets. A great place to bring a group, and to connect with North Beach's roots.
author: Alex R.

description: Classy jazz bar scene/supper club. Great cocktails. Good food.  Love this place!
author: Martha N.

description: Totaly fun, cool atmosphere in an alley near Jackson square. Screams swingers-meets-speakeasy. Tried the quail, which was maybe not the most superb choice, but the salmon is tasty and the joint is just neat.
author: Lindsey B.

description: The food and drinks were great tasting!  The decor is classic, jazzy, and at the same time romantic.  Customer service was really great too, friendly, and relaxing atmosphere.
author: Carmen M.

description: I'll have to write more when I actually sit and have a meal. My friends and I went for a "night cap" last night! We found a couple of seats at the end of the bar and chatted it up with the bar tenders. I loved the feel of the space. Very open and a lot of energy! I'll certainly be back, hopefully to eat, if not to enjoy a great bar!
author: Lisa K.

description: Let me preface by saying I'm a 3rd gen. Native NYC boy. Now, with that out of the way, (please note the NATIVE NYC thing) Bix reminds me of home. The dark woods, the jazz... It's like an old NYC joint with class... and superb food. This is one of my favourite places on the planet - no exaggeration: the atmosphere, the food and drinks all combine to make it Just Right and worth coming back to - that is of course, provided you've got the $$$$$ to spend!
author: Zed Z.

description:
Love, love, love this place!  Truly a gem with phenomenal food and top-notch service.  And you know, I just love the painting of the clown and ballerina (my sister took a picture of it and it's her wallpaper on her computer).
Bix has that speakeasy kinda feel.  It's hidden in one of the many alleys of the city but once you step inside, you're almost transported out of modern day SF into the old "jazzy" black and white era.  And actually, they have live jazz some nights!
Anyway, we were last there for my birthday in August.  There were 8 of us and we thoroughly (and shamelessly) enjoyed ourselves ordering a bit of everything.  A few of our favorites: caviar potato pillows, firecracker shrimp, american kobe steak, the lamb, crab pasta, and bananas foster.  Oh, and we had several bottles of wine :)
The bill was pricey, over $1200, but the food, service, ambiance, and really just enjoying yourself with good friends made it all worth it.  I highly recommend Bix!
author: Francine S.

description: I love this restaurant.  It's hidden and classy and an overall enjoyable  experience.  This is New York in San Francisco.  It can also be quite romantic. It's sort of like Zuni Cafe stepped up a notch. Go with someone you love.
author: M B.

description: Bix is one San Francisco's great consistent restaurants with a nice bar and very nice atmosphere. The food is always good for many years now; over ten years since I have eaten here over forty times. It's located on very small one way street which you can not park on. It serves late and the wine and cocktail list is very good. Great for a date, business meeting or dining alone at the bar. The crowd is mostly professionals/thirty and over make up the mix of people. It is busy almost every time I have been in either for dinner or late night. If you are a frequent traveler like me you will find this place comfortable to return to all the time.
author: David H.

description:
Back when I used to fly back at reasonable hours, this was usually my first meal on my return to the city.  I would drive directly from the airport in order to get there before the kitchen closed.  I still love this place even though now I only get there a few times a year.

The decor is elegant the live music really makes the old supper club feel.  You are greeted by a host or hostess who takes your coat and shows you to the bar where you always have to wait.  I don't  mind because I love the bar and the bartenders.  They not only mix a stellar martini but they do a great job of making you feel welcome.  The crowd at the bar is alway friendly.  Mostly locals or people from out of town who used to live in the city.  It's not a place you stumble upon walking down the street.  Unless of course, you turn down a lot of alleys in your travels.

I love sitting upstairs when I am with friends.  You can look down at what is happening at the bar and you have a great view of the band.  When I am in for a bite after a trip I sit at the bar and have a martini with a couple of appetizers.  I have never had a bad meal at Bix and I have eaten there a lot.

If they happen to have it, the Caprese salad is the best I've ever had anywhere.  It may or may not be on the menu, but ask.  It is worth the effort of remembering.  The tomatoes are fresh and have flavor I have never experienced and the mozzarella cheese is perfect.  They drizzle the magnificent olive oil on it and I could have a huge portion of it as a meal and be happy.  If they have oysters, that is always a great choice as well.  For the main course I usually have either the lamb or the pork chop, both of which are always prepared well.  The meat tender with just the right amount of seasoning.  Whether its the potatoes or fresh vegetables that accompany the dish, they are both great.  I have had the lobster spaghetti once and really liked it.  I don't usually like cream sauces much but this was light.  I am not much on dessert but I hear the chocolate brioche bread pudding is very good.  The trio of cheese is excellent.

They have a great wine list.  There are several wines that are made in small quantities and because of the restaurants relationships, they are always well stocked.  I have gone there several times with friends who really know wines and they were pleasantly surprised to see wineries they don't normally see on restaurant wine lists.

This is a great place for a romantic date or to entertain clients.
author: David S.

description:
when you walk in to bix for the first time, you have to stop and take in the atmosphere. the long bar with huge mural, the 2 story tall columns, the live music, and vibrance of the whole scene, it really has the best atmosphere in SF. 
the food is always top notch and seasonal. and the bar and wine list are fully stocked. best martinis in SF too. great for a night out with a small group of friends who want to talk a lot and catch up, because you can talk and talk and not bother anyone else because they are doing the same.
author: Rich B.

description: Such a cool spot in the city. Great bar, awesome drinks, a nice swanky place to hang out in. It has such a movie set like quality about it.
author: Gerald U.

description:
A friend (local) took us out for drinks at this place.  Let me tell you, the walk down the alley past a bum to find some town cars waiting in the alley.  There, like a light at the end of the tunnel was this place.  It really is one of the neatest restaurants/bars I have been to in quite a while.  Being buried in an alley gave it this 'speakeasy' secret feeling.  It is a very classy place I would love to go back.  We didn't eat any food but I bet it would have been good.  

Highly recommended.
author: c p.

description: Classic, smart, jazz, deco, art.  The place native San Franciscans go.  The place their parents went.
author: Michael L.

description: Still one of my favorite places in San Francisco!  I love Bix.  A friend and I came for dinner here - the atmosphere is so much fun.  Hadn't been here in years, but it still holds up.  Very much a martini joint, but with great food.  We had the potato pillows with creme fraiche and caviar as an appetizer - so light and delicious.  Then I had the pork shoulder that was served on white polenta with wild mushrooms, and it was extreme comfort food - absolutely wonderful.  My friend had the smoked trout salad with fuji apple and a special soup with pumpkin.  I didn't try the soup (pumpkin is not my thing), but she loved it, and we both couldn't believe how wonderful the smoked trout salad was.  Two disappointments over dinner and this is the only reason why it didn't get 5 stars - (yes, I'm being picky): we ordered Banana's Foster for dessert, and if it were true Banana's Foster they would have either flambeed it tableside (as it should be done) or at a minimum served the sauce piping hot.  It came to our table luke warm.  The other reason this is 4 stars, is that I ordered a sidecar cocktail, and the bartender made a poor version.  But shame on me for not ordering a traditional martini at this place known for its martinis.  So....4 stars instead of 5, but really, I truly love this place and will go back any chance I get.
author: J. S.

description: A bit hard to find, but when you get there, it's worth it. I went for lunch, and had the chicken hash (very tasty). However, the service was average (for the price) and it was not very well lit. I may change my mind if I went back for happy hour!
author: Monica N.

description: Think San Fran. style speakeasy from the Rolling twenties and jazz playing with solid food.
author: miriam b.

description: A great place for a date, even better if someone else is paying.  You can easily have a meal of appetizers and dessert.  The potato pillows come from a tiny bed in heaven, and the truffle cheese croques are out of this world.  The mini lamb burgers were impressive too.
author: Derek G.

description:
After being on my list of "Go-to" restaurants for a couple of years, I finally went to Bix. Before I get into the phenomenal food, there a few other noteworthy things about the place. 1. Great, friendly service from everyone at the restaurant 2. Valet parking on a weeknight!!! The only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5 is the decor. It's not terrible, but could use some improvement. On the other hand, the food is so good - you won't care!

Now on to the food. Bix is one of those restaurants that you can tell each and every dish is made upon order and with great care. We started with ahi tartare on toasts, mini grilled cheese sandwiches made with $62/pound truffle oil cheese and the arugula salad. The sandwiches were phenomenal. I then had the ahi for dinner, my friends the kobe steak and the clam spaghetti. I can't speak for the spaghetti, but the ahi was great and the steak was one of the best steak restaurants I have ever had.

I think Bix is ideal for a Mon-Th after work drink or meal. It's delicious, mellow with a relaxed vibe, but not  want I look for in a Fri/Sat night out.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
What do you get when you mix Bubbie, Clams, Lumberjack and Zev, to celebrate a birthday, at an upstairs table in Bix?  GLUTTONY.  I remember the beginning of the night, I remember the middle sort of, but I can't remember the end at all...except that I was so full I almost barfed.  
Over the course of an evening there were 2 bottles of champagne, 4 bottles of red, 6 apps, 4 main courses, 4 desserts, 3 selections of cheeses and a bottle of dessert wine all consumed.  And a bill just under $900.  Not bad considering we ate the entire GDP of a small nation, but not great considering that the food was just ok.  Nothing about the evening stuck out as a must-have including the food and the ambiance.  However, our particular waiter that evening was spot on: friendly, very knowledgable, and willing to steer us in certain directions without being pushy.  
I still haven't decided whether it's worth another visit...
author: Zev K.

description: I brought my husband here for his b-day dinner last night - had only found it online w/ great reviews -- so I wasn't 100% sure and was hoping it would be nice. It was perfect! The service was awesome - nice, friendly and fast. The atmosphere was amazing - great live music and a good vibe in the place. The food was great and the dessert - to die for - bannanas something...try it. I highly recommend going to this place for a classy, sophisticated dinner.
author: Kimberly R.

description: Amazing atmosphere.  There is a piano in the middle of the dining room which makes it good for happy hour and less appealing on a date due to the noise. My sea bass was over cooked and the dish itself was bland with little flavor, but the crab rolls melted in my mouth.  Next time I will not order fish - I will drink my dinner away.
author: S L.

description: My fiance and I went to Bix to celebrate our engagement!  It was an amazing experience.  I have to first mention the MUSIC--amazing jazz, a little Latin & a little Carribbean sound!  The musicians were great!  Perfect background for a fantastic dinner.  The food is 'TO DIE FOR'!  We had the caprese style salad that they made in front of us--the best I've ever had!! He had one of their classic chicken dishes that he loved, and I ordered their grilled cheese with tomato soup--Wow, so yummy!  We also ordered a bottle of Riesling that was fabulous!  Now this can be our special place to celebrate the day we got engaged!
author: B P.

description: This is my new Fav. restaurant!! Honestly the best food that I have had in years. The ambiance and service was great! Try the lobster spaghetti. mmmm
author: Stephanie D.

description: Just like many of the reviews, great food especially the lobster spaghetti.  Service has moments of greatness, but then gets a bit spotty - maybe they're spread a little thing for a full 5 stars.
author: D S.

description: I was there on Christmas Eve drinking some bubbly at the bar. This place is such a Gem. I ordered the tuna and it was very good. It wasn't pretentious. Can't wait to go back
author: Pink G.

description: This restaurant is an absolute must. The coolest atmosphere of any place I've ever eaten, with a very old school 30s feel to it complete with white-jacketed waiters and a lounge singer and piano. The upper balcony seats are especially cool, the bar and the drinks that issue from it are excellent. Great manhattan. The food does not disappoint either; I had a very tasty chicken hash and a fresh tomato salad from their mobile heirloom tomato cart (seasonal) last time I was there.
author: Lou M.

description: A bartender with class, promptitude, makes the waiting at the bar a true enjoyable discussion opportunity with a friend (might even be worth to be too early to kill time there). The historical gold trading room is agreable. Here again the choice of a table can be strategic. Further away from the entrance, the better. The upper floor might be awkward if dating, adequate if wanting to talk with a friend. What makes Bix unique is this old fashion atmosphere, a place where you see recurrent faces, a blend of a East-coast style restaurant with Californian cooking in the plates.
author: Philippe B.

description: Pretty good food, the service was great, but slow. Very friendly staff and sommelier (A.J.) Minus 1 star because the Sea Bass was slightly overcooked. The steak tartare was fabulous and so was the chocolate bread pudding.  Will definitely return...
author: L K.

description:
simply one of the best places to enjoy a meal in san francisco.  excellent service, decor and food, all served up in an alley that brings you back to the days of the speakeasy....

no, the cab driver is not taking you for a ride, preparing to shanghai you in a dark corner of the city...  that dark alley is where BIX is located.  enter into the cavernous room, check your coat, and have a drink at the bar.  the signature cocktails are imaginative and fun, and the wine list is extensive.  or, have a scotch on the rocks and feel like that speakeasy patron you wish you were.

the beef tar-tare is to die for, prepared table side, it is one of the best dishes i have ever had.  the rest of the appetizers were wonderful, as were the main-courses.  they were classics with a twist.  the stand-bys are here, but there are some new gems thrown in.  try them all, i have, and not one disappointment was found.

this place is wonderful, and with so many choices in SF, it's hard to pick a favorite.  this one is mine.

enjoy!
author: Tony A.

description: Went here for my parents' anniversary.  I love the atmosphere and I like where its located.  I couldn't stop looking around the restaurant.  Cool decor.  My meal was really good and it was fun hanging out at the bar while waiting for our table.  Great dessert.  Has a definite San Francisco vibe to it - very cool.
author: Kerry M.

description: This "Supper Club" has a great atmosphere and a fantastic menu. It makes for a great date place or destination dining for a big night out with friends. Allow several hours for a relaxed and full service dining experience.
author: Michael K.

description: I recently took some clients here for dinner and we all thoroughly enjoyed the experience. What can I say, no matter how full I am, I will always make room for the chocolate brioche bread pudding - warm, gooey heaven with each spoonful. I think I could easily have eaten one on own but then I'd look like a pig in front of my clients. Oh wells. Will not make that mistake next time to "share" the bread pudding. Get your own!!!
author: yvonne l.

description: Very tasty food, and well made drinks, but minus a star for the somwhat understaffed bar, and the crochety bartender who served us.  Nice atmosphere.  Not cheap, but not expensive either.  I'd expect to pay around these prices in SF for this kind of experience (though $10 for a basic cocktail is pushing it a bit).
author: Kevin B.

description: Great service &Great food this is one of if not my favorite restuarnts in San Francisco. Great place for a date.  It was one of the few times that i can say i walked away from a dinning experience with a smile on my face because of the service!
author: Mike T.

description: Lovely food, and great atmosphere, has a nice piano bar on the lower lever, but I recommended sitting upstairs if you can get in!  Order whatever is on special and it is sure to be great! Don't forget to fill your wallet with lots of money...as this one is pretty expensive...(but worth it!)
author: Rita M.

description: Great atmosphere, all tucked away in the corner, makes you feel like it's prohibition again. The food is fantastic. i especially recommend the firecracker shrimp. It is pretty expensive, probably better for a special dinner than just a random thursday night gorge-fest.
author: Manlio L.

description:
BIX is one of my favorite new SF restaurants. 
It's pricey, but so worth it. 

The food is excellent! Our waiter was very friendly and prompt. Even though this restaurant is very popular we did not have to wait long. 

The ambiance is great. The art deco design is very cool but you can't beat jazz with your meal. The overall atmosphere at BIX is really what makes it stand out--a well-heeled clientele makes this perfect for a date or entertaining guests/clients/etc. It's extremely elegant, comfortable, charming--everything you could ask for in a dining experience.

If you haven't checked out BIX yet, you're missing out!
author: Nicole R.

description:
The perfect dining experience. 
When you need to impress, Bix is an ace in the hole.
It's a bit of an expensive night out, but the prices are fair.

Get the Bananas Foster. 
I think it's the best dessert in The City.

I still have the receipt from my first meal here in 1986.
author: Randy S.

description:
The food was absolutely amazing. The drinks were good, the kitchen was accomodating (even though they charged more for a vegetarian vegetable plate than for any of the meat entrees....). The prociutto wrapped mozz and the chicken hash were great, the mini-lamb burgers were out of this world!
Our server left a LOT to be desired. She was for the most part absent, her timing was off, and she messed up on our bill. When I pointed it out, she took the bill (and the cash) and didn't return. When I stopped her she said "did you want change?" and then after about 10 more minutes came back out to ask how much I had given her. She never presented me with a correct bill, so I didn't know the correct total to figure the tip, which worked out fine for me in the end....
The atmosphere is amazing, though. I really enjoyed the music, the appearance of the place, especially on the balcony. The bartender, host, and all the other staff were very pleasant and friendly.
I would most definitely go back and just hope to get a different server, because all the rest seemed great!
author: Aubrey B.

description: Didn't eat - just had drinks, which were great. Haven't been there in years. Looks a little dingy. Needs a facelift. Bathrooms could be cleaner.
author: T F.

description: I love this place! The physical space is gorgeous, the service is top notch at the bar & good at the tables, drinks excellent & food great. It's a classy spot. However, they consistently ruin the beef tartare. I don't get it. A restaurant that does so much right, screwing up such a simple dish. It's not an easy dish to find in SF. It's done very well at Chez Papa & Harris', very well balanced. But at Bix...either way too many shallots, or wwaaaayyyyyy toooooo much salt!!! Take it easy folks. I want to taste the beef. The only reason I can think of is that they underestimate their clientele. For that, I am personally offended. I will eat here again though, and bring friends. Overall, an excellent restaurant, and you can't go wrong on the menu if you just order what you like or what the bartender recommends, (unless it's the beef tartare, and then you should pass).
author: Tonya S.

description: I have been a huge fan of Bix since 1992.  Whenever I want to celebrate this is often my go to place.  I have been here to celebrate getting a job, anniversarys, birthdays etc.  Every time I leave I rave for days about how great this place is.  Tonight was the first time I have been disappointed.  We arrived about 10 minutes prior to our 8:30pm reservation.  We checked in and enjoyed a couple of fantastic cocktails. (best part of the night) We had two of the signature drinks the Cosmo, and the Sidecar.  Both had plenty of alcohol and were very well balanced and tasty.  Soon after we started enjoying our drinks we noticed that we kept getting bumped around and were spilling our drinks.  The place was jammed packed and most people including us were forced to stand near the front door constantly being jostled and molested as people passed through. I also noticed that no one was moving to tables.  At 9:00 pm I inquired as to the status of our table.  I was told it would be soon, and then I went back to endure the cattle call with my wife.  At 9:20 pm we were lead to our table.  We were thankfully lead upstairs because did I mention that everytime the door opened (appx every 30 seconds) 45 degree winter air blows in cutting right to the bone and ruining any chance for a warm meal.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Here are the descriptions of the food I ordered:

-House Made Mozzarella wrapped in La Quercia Prosciutto with Foirdolio 2008 Harvest Olive Oil
-Roasted Lamb Sirloin with a Pumpkin-Sage Sformato, Broccoli Rabe, Chilies and Parsley-Pine Nut Sauce Verde

    Based on the sheer number of red-dotted lines my computer shows me, it should be clear how fancy-pants this place is. Take for example, "Sformato." This unpronouncably-beautiful word doesn't even have its own wikipedia page, and although it is described in a few websites, I am still not even convinced it exists outside of Bix Restaurant. That being said, the fact that it is pumpkin-sage flavored makes me not really care what you call it. It, like just about everything else on the menu, though unpronounceable, was delicious. I give Bix a 5-out-of-5 on taste.

    My lamb, served medium rare, was, the best lamb I have ever eaten in a restaurant. The Cheese and Prosciutto was like eating sorbet on an incredibly hot day, but the opposite. Instead of a cool citrus burst, it was like a warm, sensual caressing of the tongue. (They actually did have blood orange and tangerine sorbet for dessert which wasn't that good, a fact I am happy to overlook because a) I was too full to eat it and b) It was cold outside and it was just a bad decision). I was fortunate enough also to have a bite of my aunt's gourmet cheeseburger. It was as good as any gourmet burger out their so if you are a finicky eater, the burger is a great way to go. It comes with fries which are good, but the side order of truffled fries (french fries topped with pecorino cheese and white truffle oil) were completely, outrageously, yummy. We couldn't decide between ordering these fries and the whipped potatoes; we made no mistake. Chef Bruce Hill definitely knows what he is doing.

    Atmosphere wise, I couldn't really ask for better. They had a live piano player to which my mother commented, "I feel like I am in Nordstrom's." I personally think Bix was much nicer and way more special than a trip to Nordstrom's, but both places know what a nice touch a grand piano adds. They have beautiful paintings on the wall, including a portrait of Bix Beiderbecke, the prominent 1920's jazz musician honored with the naming of the restaurant. The decor calls back to the time of decadent cruising and is complete with funny old group photos with men in tuxedos. They also have cool old maps of San Francisco in the bathroom which I am always a sucker for. More importantly, however, was the urinal. It reached all the way to the floor, which is my favorite urine receptacle, but it also had a bar with a slab at shin level angled in such a way that it blocks any splash back from getting on your shoes. Very thoughtful of them.

    The reason I don't give 5 stars is the pricing. As a 19 year old, I can't really every hope to go back there. If you my age, unless you have the best job ever or a rich uncle that is willing to throw you some Benjamins to take a date out, this is not really the place to go. If you do have either of those things, message me and we can either talk business or pleasure; both would go nicely with their 10+ dollar specialty cocktails.

    All in all, great food, nice place to eat, good for special occasions.

If you found this review helpful, check out my restaurant blog at:

http://www.aaronstrick.com/iWeb/AaronStrick.com/RestauranTouring/RestauranTouring.html
author: Aaron S.

description:
We ate there tonight.  It was a busy Saturday and during the holiday season; perhaps the food and service were affected by these factors.  We had made a reservation more than 2 months ago and requested a quiet table.  

The first sign that things were not going well was when we were escorted upstairs to the table right next to the swinging doors to the service/kitchen area....definitely the worst table in the restaurant.  We asked for a different table and were told that there was one table downstairs, but that it was adjacent to the live music.  Since the music wasn't starting for more than an hour, we changed tables.  

Service was slow and inconsistent throughout the evening.  We had to pour our own $85 bottle of wine and we had to ask for refills on coffee.  The appetizers were the best part of the meal.  We enjoyed the steak tartare as well as the crab rolls.  The main courses were less satisfying.  The sea bass was unmemorable.  My husband enjoyed his pork chop.  The bananas foster was excellent.

We definitely won't rush back. For the price, other restaurants provide a much better combination of food and service.
author: RJ E.

description: My boyfriend and i went to this restaurant last year for our anniversary, and it was absolutely wonderful. The slightly hidden location was a nice touch and the ambiance inside was sophisticated without being stuffy. We definately do not look like your average fancy restaurant goers, but were tll given stellar service. The staff was attentive without being oerbearing, and never missed a beat. And the food.... doesnt get much better. Go for the carpaccio, you wont regret it. Each item we ordered was fresh and cooked perfectly. This place is a bit pricey, but after the experience it was definately worth it. You get what you pay for in this case. A great special occasion restaurant. We will be back.
author: Taler C.

description:
I have always been a big fan of BIX.  Great ambiance, great bar, cool music, good service, and excellent food.

Went a couple weeks ago on a weekday.  We sat upstairs, which is very cool.  The Wagyu Fillet was excellent.  The wine list (we had pinot and zin) excellent.  The Mozzarella wrapped with Prosciutto, the best part of the meal.

Great place for a date or a business dinner.
author: Mason K.

description:
Took some business folk from out of town here (they were from the mid-west). They looked very quizically at the menu, and then each ordered a steak. I think they were thinking, "these California @ssholes..."

Foie is not good, don't bother. Appetizers and wine menu is good, however. It's in an alley on Gold st, so you can pass it easily if not eagle-eyeing the street signs.
author: service p.

description: LOVE the atmosphere of this place. Every time I step in the door I feel as if I have been transported back in time to the 1920's. The cocktails are delicious and made with care, and only with the best ingredients. I suggest all of their gin drinks. The food is superb. My favorites: the lobster pasta and the deviled eggs. Omg, my mouth is watering for it right now....
author: Kaitlyn G.

description: The place seems so tiny from the outside but when you walk in the place it's huge! The atmosphere is very jazzy and swanky. The cocktails are delicious. Waiter brought us complementary tuna tartare which was so fresh and flavorful. Then we ordered the "Crab Rolls in Brioche with Lemon Aioli" which was so bomb I could've eaten like a million of those. We also got a breaded chicken dish which was amazing. Dessert was yummy and chocolately! Allover great experience, can't wait to come back and try more!
author: N. M.

description: Go to the bar and eat!  I've never actually sat for a dinner at Bix but hanging out at the Bar and ordering dinner and drinks from the bar.  If you go more than once a month they will remember you and welcome you with a warm smile and remember you favorite drink.
author: Adriel L.

description: My first time there and I didn't know what to expect.  Walking down the quiet alley gave me a little creepy feeling as if there were bums hiding and waited to attack (it's san francisco you know)..  I liked the tall brick building - it looks different from most places in SF.  The decor inside is classy and old school.  They have full bar and great drinks. Most patrons are pretty old.  My dinner was so delicious but I had way too much Hors D'Oeuvres (Today's selection, salad and seabass ceviche) to finish my entree. But I couldn't resist having dessert though and I wasn't disappointed at all.  The chocolate bread pudding was so good!!  I felt really bad for how much I ate but that meal totally made my night and a good start of my week.  I'm so going back to try different dishes.
author: Pawaree S.

description:
Bix is hands down my favorite restaurant in SF.  It has it all: ambience, strong drinks, mouth watering food - EVERYTHING.  Perfect for a romantic dinner, but also great for a delicious burger at lunch.  

I cannot fathom how this place would get anything but five stars.
author: Corinne R.

description: Bix has been my favorite San Francisco restaurant to bring guests for the past eight years and we have always recommended it as a great place to go. We arrived on time with guests who had not been here before. We were told it would be a few minutes, so we said we weren't in a rush and we would go to the bar for a drink. Just as I was ordering, we were told to  follow the host to our table. As we were led up the stairs, I asked if we could sit downstairs since the restaurant was less than half full. We were told the tables were all reserved. We were brought to the upstairs far corner booth, which is quite isolated and next to the service door. I asked if we could sit at another table. since there were at least five open tables. We were told that all the tables "had been reserved by people who have been coming regularly for 21 years." I said that was a pretty silly explanation. He made us feel inferior but I did not want to cause a scene. Throughout our dinner, several tables remained open both upstairs and downstairs, so someone was lying. I don't know who directed our seating and whether the explanation was just bad creativity, but it really put me in a bad mood. Unfortunately, without the downstairs buzz and other distractions, our attention went directly to our meal. The food was ok, if you like heavy sauces and overpowering flavors. As an example, the entire albacore tuna plate had a strong smoke flavor. When I tasted it, I also detected a ham flavor. Since the person who had the  tuna does not eat ham, we were hoping it was just nasty smoke. After I complained to the manager, our deserts were comped. But that's no big deal on a $350 ticket. The only thing that really saved the evening was our waiter, who did an excellent job and deserves 5 stars. Food- 2 stars. Host-0 stars. No music on Friday night-0 stars. Upstairs back corner booth- Don't sit there.
author: Ru B.

description: Incredible.  Live jazz singer was amazing and the food was spot on.
author: David A.

description: OMG. Seriously, five star rating is not given without thought. I would give this place six stars if I could. This place is absolutely amazing. My husband and I went there to celebrate our 1 year anniversary, and it was pretty much one of the best decisions we made in our 1st year of marriage. The food was phenomenal. We were celebrating so we drank and ate one delicious dish after another. I cannot even remember all the dishes we had because I'm writing this 7 months later... but wow trust me that it'll be worth your while and trust the rest of the Yelpers' entree/dessert suggestions. I love this restaurant's ambiance too. The wall mural behind the bar is stunning, the location makes you feel like a mobster, the lighting is romantic. I love the service, our waitress was awesome. I also love that every waiter/ess knows how to shake up a good martini... watch their skill in action when you are dining and to ensure that you see their skill just order a martini. Oh, I also thought that they had a very good wine selection. Treat yourself and enjoy!!
author: Shannel G.

description: I am convinced they purposely made this restaurant difficult to find. Otherwise it would be so popular you would need to get a reservation a year in advance. Located in a small alleyway between Jackson and Pacific, Bix is a very traditional classy restaurant where you will find business professionals sipping on post work cocktails. Not the usually hipster crowd that fills the more trendy restaurants, this place screams old fashioned classiness. Classy with live jazz piano and a swanky bar. Classy with high ceilings and huge oil paintings. This is the kind of restaurant the rich (and I mean people from Pacific Heights) frequent. The service was impeccable, and the food was melt in your mouth heavenly deliciousness. Even the bread was offscale. Warm and buttery, flaky and light as air. We started with an appetizer of fresh home made mozzerella wrapped in prociutto and drizzled with olive oil. Then came an asparagus soup laced with a meyer lemon cream and chives. Perfect for springtime, as asparagus is very much in season right now. I had a very small salad for dinner, because I wanted to save room for the chocolate brioche bread pudding which I heard was to die for. Good thing I did, this dessert is over the top decadent. Dark chocolate with gooy chocolately bread and more dark chocolate oozing all over the place. The whole delicacy is topped with chantilly and shaved dark chocolate. The most intensely chocolatey dessert I have ever tasted. Congratulations Bix, you've won my approval!
author: Kate A.

description: I wasn't a full-time yelper when I went to Bix and unfortunately I don't remember exactly what I ate. What I do remember is having one of the best freakin' meals I've had in years. My brother-in-law owns a restaurant and has all sorts of connections with chefs, waiters, restaurants owners, etc. all over SF. Because of delightful "connections" my family was comped a ton of appetizers at Bix. The ones that stand out in my mind and that I still talk about when telling people where to eat in San Francisco are the potato puffs with creme fresh and caviar, and the fried and stuffed squash blossoms (I think they were stuffed with cheese and crab or something). These apps where like little pieces of heaven. I don't remember what my main course was, but I tried my dad's chicken hash, which was splendid. The waiters were extremely sweet and helpful. I love, love love Bix. Oh and I really dig that it's located down a side alley, so the restaurant feels like a hidden gem you have to seek out.
author: Sammy S.

description: Sorry to disagree with the reviewers, but Bix is fairly ordinary for food....steak tartare at tableside was unexciting...bland and ordinary. The $36 lamb chops were thin and unimpressively seasoned...a fairly pathetic portion for the price. Desert was good, but it takes more than that to get raves....was I at a different restaurant from you folks?
author: Menlo Man n.

description: i love this restaurant - great service every time (4 or 5 times so far) and i love the lamb entree. great wine selection and prices aren't ridiculous. one of the few places my wife and i both equally love.
author: Paul B.

description: my husband and i just celebrated our two year anniversary and had a fabulous dinner at bix on sunday night.   we started with the crab rolls and the fois gras with cherries.  yum!  then he had the chicken hash which was rich and creamy with grits and orange baby tomatoes.  i had the kobe beef steak with a huge helping of mashed potatoes.  for dessert we split the strawberry (my weakenss) napoleon.  excellent food, excellent service!  highly recommended.
author: Cyn B.

description: Fabulous food, outstanding service, great ambiance, cool (sort of "secret") location.  It is always perfect.
author: Christin A.

description: Bix restaurant is a fabulous place for any occasion but a first date was was my first experience with them.  I  loved the live Jazz music playing while sitting in the cozy, warm dining room.  This place will always remain close to my heart and one of my favs for life!  You have got to try it and it's in SF- bonus!  :)
author: Erin S.

description: What happened to the excellent food and service at Bix?  Had dinner reservations for 9 people at 9PM.  Table was not ready at 9, which wasn't an issue for us.  I had the kobe bavette, which I ordered medium rare, and it arrived at the table pre-sliced and the two end slices were grey being completely overcooked.  I didn't complain, since this was a business dinner, however it was so obvious that it really shouldn't have been allowed to leave the kitchen.  This wasn't the big issue for me, what was egregious was the fact that we were still at our table finishing after dinner drinks when the lights were turned up like it was last call at some cheesy bar.  Granted it was midnight, however we weren't sat until after 9PM.  I made a joking comment to the manager who was there, he didn't seem to care and then the lights were turned up again.  We got the hint, got the check and left.  Not a nice way to end the evening.  Bix is an institution in the city and I love taking people there, however, it'll be a long time before i return :-(
author: Sandra P.

description: The atmosphere is great (big room, very retro SF feel), and I love the bartenders (old school, and old school is good school).  And I like a martini (two at the most) (because three, I'm under the table, and you know the rest).   Add to that the possibility of champagne when I'm not in a martini mood, and a good-ish selection of food, and it's great except . .. it's way too crowded.  And the crowd runs a little to old-ish frat boy on a Friday night (the night a friend of mine seems to want to go) in a way that intrudes.  Let me put it this way.  I'm the sort who likes the Noc Noc.  However enticing an upscale vibe is (and I admit I'm superficial), there are different crowds for different types, and I type more toward elsewhere.  Yet . . . I like Bix on the right night with the right friends with the right drink, so there you are.  Schizoid, c'est moi.  (But that's probably why I love San Francisco so much.  I'm so normal here.)
author: Laurel B.

description: nah..it was ok.  The appetizers were a lot better than our entrees.  The food was ok, although we (5 girls, age 24-27) were certainly not impressed by any means.  We like our waiter, he was very attentive and patient with us while we squabbled amongst us girls trying to decide on the menu.
author: CalBear H.

description: What a classic.  We spent the evening there for a friend's birthday and had a wonderful time.  The atmosphere and class of BIX are unequaled.
author: Cheryl M.

description: The food was actually really good.  The Procuito and cheese appetizers was delicious.  However, I'm an alcoholic and I like my vodka sans vermouth and served very cold in a BIG martini glass.  Bix has those pussy ass 3.5 oz martini glasses.  My young hot date commented that it seemed like a place where rich older men take their young misstresses.  I said that I wasn't that old and asked if we could split the bill...
author: Cody R.

description:
when the pickiest eater in the world is actually stuck debating which fantastic dish to eat...you know it's good.  i think there's something valuable about having some of the same classic menu items all the time, then adding seasonal goodies like the tomato cart (which is delicious).  this way, i always know that i can get the chicken hash and romaine hearts, but i'm also free to try something new that catches my eye.  i will never turn down an invitation to BIX.

note that while it's always open for dinner, BIX is only open for lunch on fridays -- boo hoo  -- but they have a great "bix fixe" lunch menu.  mmmmm.
author: G C.

description: this was probably my favorite DAT experience. less inventive than rubicon, but the food just made me happier somehow. could also have been that the very romantic lighting and soft jazz had bf and me fawning over each other all night. love love loved the creme brulee (this was my dat must - i was having cravings). the riesling has me hooked. all in all, wonderful experience with food that, perhaps less inventive, was incredibly pleasing in every other way (i.e. chocolate in butternut squash soup - great flavor mix).
author: Kiki B.

description: It was definitely a refreshing experience. BIX is located in a little alleyway in between some buildings in the Financial District. It's romantic and classic like a 1920's jazz club. However, the food is too expensive. Watch your spend if you're planning on getting a few drinks. A dinner for two at this place could easily cost upwards to ~$200.
author: Tracy P.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  It is old school SF, and the food is fantastic. Order the POTATOE PILLOWS - mmmmmm.
author: Jessica B.

description: I had the beet skewers, the marrow, and the rack of lamb. One of the best meals I have ever had. Great loud, fun atmosphere.
author: Donovan D.

description: We had dinner at Bix this past Saturday night. The location, decor and lighting is exceptional.
